title: WATERMAN WAY - Working together, group chooses name for new Cambridge street
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
WATERMAN WAY - Working together, group chooses name for new Cambridge street

 August 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 742
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - It's official: Waterman Way will be the name of the new road at Cambridge Harbor.The name choice was not a solo decision. Residents gathered at Cambridge Harbor Tuesday evening to vote on the name of the new road parallel to the water that intersects Aurora Street and Dorchester Avenue.The name-choosing event gave residents the chance to hear the three options and pick their favorite. As they voted on their favorite name, attendees enjoyed a free scoop of ice cream from the Scottish Highland Creamery and even got a chance to try their luck at a raffle for free Cambridge Harbor merchandise.Matt Leonard, executive director of Cambridge Waterfront Development said the new street that is closest to the park will be the perfect street to close off and use for events once it is paved."We can have food trucks, we can have art shows, we can have music festivals," Leonard said. "So this will blend seamlessly into this activated park that we're going to have." On Tuesday evening, community members were given three options for the new name: Sailwinds Plaza, Waterman Way and Harbor Way. Everyone got the opportunity to vote on their favorite name using a QR code or by simply telling BCT Design Group Principal Bob Northfield their choice. BCT Design Group has been helping Cambridge Waterfront Development with the naming process.Votes were tallied during the event so that the winning name could be shared before the event ended.Betsey Harrington, who voted for the winning name, said Waterman Way is "traditional" for Dorchester County.Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer also said he voted for Waterman Way. Pfeffer said it "pays heritage" to the county, whose seal depicts a waterman and a farmer.While neither voted for the winning name, Chesapeake College Cambridge Center Director Lorelly Solano and Chesapeake College Director of Development Amber McGinnis were excited to vote on Tuesday."We are neighbors and active members of the community," Solano said. "So we're excited to support our partners and see the community grow." The three names that community members voted on are all in the theme of maritime heritage.Cambridge Waterfront Development, with the help of BCT Design Group, put out an online survey in June for community members to rank different themes that the street name would be created from.The survey, which closed July 1, gave the community four themes to rank. The three other themes were Rose Hill, roses and light/sources of light.McGinnis said she is happy that the Cambridge Waterfront group has tried to listen to and involve the community in its decision-making process."There are so many times that partners have come in and haven't really considered the community," McGinnis said. "And I do feel like Matt and that group has really tried to integrate community needs and wants, realizing they can't make everyone happy. And so the fact they're even just getting input on the naming of the street, I think it validates that they're happy to have the community engaged." Leonard said Cambridge Waterfront Development is a "community-first organization." "When it comes to things that we can get direct input from the community on, like a name, we think they should be a part of it," he said. "And it just gives them the real buy-in. It gives us real input as to what matters to the community. So as we focus more and more on the actual development of the buildings and the uses, we have a better understanding of what matters to the community." His organization's mission is to develop the harbor in partnership with the community so that it is a benefit to the community. Leonard called the relationship with the community "a continued conversation." "If we continue to put out really good accurate information, timely information, and listen to what the community says," Leonard said, "the people who are commenting will be more and more positive over time and more bought in to the whole thing." McGinnis said that she thinks a lot of people in Dorchester County have a connection to the Cambridge Harbor area."I think to see this property be revitalized with some new and interesting ideas - workforce development, economic development, tourism - bringing in the old and the new identities of the county is really exciting."

Matt Leonard, executive director of Cambridge Waterfront Development speaks to a crowd of people before giving them the opportunity to vote on what to name the new street at Cambridge Harbor Aug. 8.

title: Oxford commissioners introduce charter amendment
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Oxford commissioners introduce charter amendment

 August 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 338
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD - At a town meeting Tuesday, the Commissioners of Oxford introduced a charter amendment that would increase the number of election judges on the town's Election Board.If the drafted resolution is passed, the number of election judges would increase from three to six.At Tuesday's meeting, Oxford Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan said the amendment would address the increased hours of town elections. While elections used to be held from 2 p.m. to 7 p.m., they now begin at 8 a.m. and end at 8 p.m.Commissioners approved this change in election hours at an Aug. 23 meeting in 2022. The election in June of this year to fill previous Commission President Jimmy Jaramillo's seat was the first election where the increased hours were in effect.The drafted resolution would also change the start of term for election judges.Currently terms begin the first Monday in April of the year they are appointed by the commission."So essentially, if you're appointed in September, you're term had already started," Ryan said.The drafted resolution would make it so that election judges begin their term the day they are appointed. These terms would run for two years.A public hearing on the drafted resolution will be held Sept. 12 at 6 p.m. at 101 Market Street in Oxford.At Tuesday's meeting, commissioners also set a date to discuss language changes for the charter amendment that residents approved in a July 18 special election.The amendment, which goes into effect Aug. 17, changes how mid-term commission vacancies are filled. Instead of being appointed by the remaining commissioners, vacancies will be filled via special election.A work session to discuss possible adjustments to the language of this amendment will be held at 5 p.m. before the regular town meeting on Aug. 22.During a special meeting in July, Ryan discussed aspects of the amendment that might need to be changed including the length of the term of the elected commissioner, when candidates need to file a certificate of nomination and the timing from a vacancy announcement to when the election would need to be held.

title: Eastside bypass needed
content:
Eastside bypass needed

 August 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: Letters 
 
 299
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I have been a resident of Talbot County for 50+ years and a resident of Easton for 7 years.It is a great town to live in and has many amenities for a small town in Maryland.I would like to know if there is any planning in process to develop a bypass in Talbot County and specifically on the east side of Easton.While we have Route 322 that is on the west side, that route is a Parkway rather than a bypass.A parkway, as I am sure residents know, is designed with intersections and traffic signals. Easton has six once you enter the parkway heading east.Over the years, traffic has increased dramatically on Route 50 as well as the Easton Parkway.And with the possibility of a third Bay Bridge in the region and a new traffic software package designed to regulate traffic light time on the Eastern Shore in order to minimize delays going East and West on Route 50, I would say we are in for a long summer season.As we all know, heavy traffic delays at Goldsboro, Dover and Dutchman's Lane keep getting longer and longer. Let alone, cross intersection accidents that are becoming a common occurrence.I would suggest that the State Roads Commission as well as Talbot County Roads establish a work study program to develop a bypass in Talbot County. It could be on the east side of Easton that would begin at the Route 404 and Route 50 area, or possibly at the Rabbit Hill exit and return to Route 50 East either at Trappe or Cambridge.While this would be a major project, saving lives and giving Talbot County residents the ability to get where they need to go on a timely basis is utmost to residents.It's all about the residents of Talbot County, not the tourists heading to the Beach.ROBERT J. KREBSEaston

title: LETTER TO THE EDITOR - Fond memories of Easton
content:
LETTER TO THE EDITOR - Fond memories of Easton

 August 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: Letters 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am proud to say I endorse Robert Willey for the Easton Town Council presidency. He has worked tirelessly to preserve all that makes Easton special during his 20 years as mayor, and I have no doubt that passion will translate into the Town Council presidency.Robert is a lifelong resident of the Town of Easton and Talbot County, where he raised his three children with his wife, Betsy. I am lucky enough to be one of his four grandchildren with whom he shared this town throughout our childhoods. Robert took everything that made Easton special and only built upon it, both in the community and the economy.Growing up, I have fond memories of coming to the Waterfowl Festival and Fourth of July fair every year, which Robert was always proud to share. His commitment to the town dates back further than just his time as mayor though, as he has also been a part of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department for over 60 years, the First Baptist Church for over 70 years, and the BPO Elks for almost 60 years.I have no doubt that the pride Robert has in this town will make him the perfect choice for the Easton Town Council president. He is passionate about continuing Easton's long history he worked so hard to build upon of being the successful, beautiful town that it is. Vote for someone who has proven his love for this town and helped it grow and evolve for as long as I can remember - vote for Robert C. Willey for Town Council president.CAROLINE GRAZIANOVienna, Virginia

title: Town Council president candidates state case
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Town Council president candidates state case

 August 31, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 1207
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The four candidates vying to be the Easton Town Council's next president shared their thoughts on growth, development and health care in the town with community members at a town hall forum Tuesday evening.The candidate town hall, held at the Avalon Theatre and hosted jointly by the Talbot Spy and the Avalon Foundation, was moderated by Craig Fuller.Questions to the candidates centered on the role of the town council president, development and the community's health care needs.To former Easton Mayor Bob Willey, his decades of service to Easton, including a six-year stint as council president and experience managing a large workforce and millions of dollars in town budgets, set him apart as a candidate."I think there's a lot of things Easton has going for it, and I'd like to be part of keeping those things moving and getting them a little better, and (adding) a few more bells and whistles," he said.Experience is a key part of the campaign for former Ward 1 Councilman Al Silverstein, who said he'd learned a lot from others in his eight years on the council."It's a 20-month service, that's all we have left on this term, but I think it's 20 months of being able to move Easton in the right direction," he said in his opening statement. "I think we've gone a long way under Mayor Willey in the past, but it's time to move forward with new ideas and new challenges, so I look forward to the opportunity." For Frank Gunsallus, who ran a close race for the Ward 1 seat on the town council in May, his campaign for Town Council president is a way to capitalize on momentum and support from the previous election."I am here to focus on smart growth, attainable housing, better health care and fair representation for all citizens of Easton," he said.To Kevin Bateman, continuing to serve Easton residents in a new way and improving the town are key reasons for running."I'm a person that believes that everyone matters, no matter who you are, where you come from, what your religion is, what your ethnicity is - we all matter, we're human beings first," he said. "And keeping that in mind, that is why I've taken on this adventure: to try to make sure that every person in this town matters." Much of the town hall discussion focused on growth and development, issues that the public has frequently chimed in on in recent months.A Talbot County native, Willey recalled growing up in Easton in the 1940s and 1950s, when the town's population was under 6,000. But while the town's landscape has changed since then, some things have remained the same."I think we tend to soft pedal affordable housing; we think if we go ahead and build 100 houses, we're going to solve the problem - we aren't," he said."That problem's been around for years, it's going to be around for years to come." Willey said the town needs to look at including representation from all of the county's municipalities on the Talbot County Housing Commission, saying that all need to tackle the issue together. Having information on the types of homes available is key, too."Easton is not the one to solve the affordable housing issue; we'll do our part, but we don't do it all, and the others have got to chime in," he said.Also addressing development, Gunsallus spoke about ways to bring more connections to residents living on the east side of U.S. Route 50, where there isn't a place to safely cross."Finding ways to make bike-ability and walkability attainable for people who live across (Route) 50, who want to get downtown and not have to drive their car and worry about parking or traffic, are ways we should be looking to incorporate them into the fabric of our town," he said.Speaking on future development within the town, Bateman said that finding a suitable location for affordable housing for residents is the difficult part."It's a tough challenge to find the location that fits, that has the right space and the right mix," he said. "We want to grow, we want to see responsible, common sense growth, and that's going to take a lot of thought and a lot of planning." To Silverstein, getting broader community input on the town's future comprehensive plan and keeping the town's growth rate at 1% are keys in addressing development."I think we have to plan for some growth, but we have to be smart about it," he said.And as for addressing the critical need for workforce housing, Silverstein said the town needs to buy land and designate it as a planned workforce housing project.The town needs to look at the financial factors impacting future home buyers to develop a strategic plan moving forward, he said.The discussion then pivoted to health care and a shortage of medical professionals in the community.Gunsallus said the need for a new hospital in Easton is "long overdue," but it's only part of the problem. A shortage of primary care physicians and specialists greatly impacts many community members, and long wait times exacerbate the issue.To address the shortage in care, Gunsallus said the town could look into being designated as a health professional shortage area, which would open up state loan repayment programs for physicians to alleviate burdens for doctors trying to repay school debts.Tax incentives, along with state and federal grants and subsidies, are other things the town can look at utilizing to attract new physicians."Those are all things that we should be considering and trying to address in the short term, because those are also problems that a new hospital is not going to solve; that will only bring a new building here," he said, later adding: "There are many people here who should not have to wait that long, and we have more pressing concerns in the short term." Bringing the new hospital to Easton is a top priority for Silverstein in the next 20 months if elected president of the council. To him, community leaders and members need to be making noise about building the new regional medical center."I think we need to be engaged with them, just like the county is engaged with them, on an ongoing basis, on a weekly basis, to ask the question: 'What's going on?'" he said. "We should be up in Annapolis banging on the governor's door and banging on the University of Maryland's door in Baltimore saying, 'This is not acceptable.Our community and our region deserve better service.'" If elected, a top priority for Bateman is completing long-outstanding projects that have been postponed, ranging from the hospital to drainage issues."There's other communities in our town that have been they haven't been neglected, they just haven't had the attention that they should have," he said.In addition to the hospital, another priority for Willey, if elected, is addressing the comprehensive plan update."If that was in place, and we had our zoning rules up to date, if we had our needs for housing up to date, if we had the annexation requests up to date, and what we're going to need for public facilities, we wouldn't have had the fights that we were having over Poplar Hill and Maryland Health Club."

title: Zoning commission splits on YMCA recommendation - Cambridge Y may stay where it is if recommendation adopted
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com

Zoning commission splits on YMCA recommendation - Cambridge Y may stay where it is if recommendation adopted

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: A4 | Section: News 
 
 561
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - The Cambridge Planning and Zoning Commission voted four to three in favor of recommending to the City Council a companion ordinance to a proposed YMCA overlay ordinance Tuesday, Sept.5.The proposed companion ordinance is a zoning text amendment that would add an additional category within the table of permitted uses in the overlay ordinance, which the commission voted to recommend to the City Council Aug. 1."This should ensure that the YMCA is allowed to stay in its current location and operate in all the ways YMCAs on the Eastern Shore might be called to do," City Planner Steve Kaii-Ziegler said at the Sept. 5 meeting.The amendment would "create a definition for a non-commercial community recreational facility in institutionally zoned districts that better describes the current YMCA's use of the facility," Kaii-Ziegler said.Planning and Zoning Commissioners George Brown, A.C. Alrey, Eugene Lauer and Chair Mary Losty voted in favor of making the recommendation.Commissioners Chantay Nelson, Theresa Stafford and Vice Chair William Craig voted against making the recommendation.The original drafted ordinance, which was already introduced to city commissioners for first reading Aug. 14, would put an "institutional overlay district" on the YMCA at 201 Talbot Ave. If passed by City Council, the overlay would limit the institutional uses the parcel could be used for in the event the YMCA were to move. It would remain in effect for five years or until the city's next comprehensive rezoning - whichever comes first.At the Aug. 1 meeting, YMCA of the Chesapeake CEO Robbie Gill asked for a third party to review the language in the drafted ordinance to make sure the YMCA will be able to continue providing all of its programming and services.Kaii-Ziegler said city staff and the city attorney considered "several different approaches" to address the YMCA's concerns. The discussions resulted in this companion ordinance submitted to the Planning and Zoning Commission for review and recommendation, he said."This definition specifies that a non-commercial community recreational facility may have ancillary uses that address the concerns the YMCA has expressed," Kaii-Ziegler said.At the Sept. 5 meeting, Gill said he wanted to thank city staff for working with the YMCA to make sure the nonprofit can continue to serve Dorchester County. He said that the proposed overlay, without the companion ordinance, could jeopardize the YMCA's programming."There needs to be an added use that represents the organization's work that it's doing," he said.Kaii-Ziegler said the city received a letter, dated Aug. 25, from the YMCA that confirms the nonprofit's support for the original proposed overlay with the companion ordinance. He said the YMCA also sent a letter, dated Aug. 13, that states the YMCA won't enter any agreements to "sell or convey" the 201 Talbot Avenue property until the end of 2023.Ward 1 Planning Commissioner William Craig said he took issue with the wording of the companion text amendment."This needs more work as far as I'm concerned," Craig said. "I don't think this wording is accurate." Craig said he didn't agree with the description of uses for the overlay companion ordinance."I think we need to get an accurate description of what the local YMCA does and then we'll deal with where it goes in the table," he said.No residents spoke for public comment before the commission voted on the amendment.

title: Repulsive, glossy mailer
content:
Repulsive, glossy mailer

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A7 | Section: Letters 
 
 294
 Words 

 Read News Document

 My name is Tom Duncan, and I have had the pleasure of serving Talbot County for more than 50 years - as a Talbot County Council member for 19 years, as Talbot County sheriff for nine years, and as Maryland State Police commander in Talbot County for 20 years.I share this information with you in hopes that you appreciate my commitment to our county. In the past, I have always declined the request to write supporting letters for any candidate.I have always held the premise that it was important to let the voters decide for the candidate of their choice on their own.I shall also share with you that I do not live in the Town of Easton and therefore cannot vote in Easton elections.We have a great community that has been well managed for years. This fact is evident when we consider the reason why so many people want to live in Easton and Talbot County. The answer is: "It's our quality of life." However, this week a repulsive, expensive, glossy mailer was received by many citizens condemning Bob Willey. I have worked with Bob for many years, and you can believe me that he has always had the Town of Easton as a top priority. The person who sent that mailer is unknown to me as well as to many others with whom I have spoken. Evidently, this individual does not know Bob Willey.There is no place in our wonderful community for this type of negative campaigning.I have had citizens call me to say they were outraged about this horrible mailer, and quite frankly they admitted that they were originally not going to vote, but this has changed their minds. I can only hope our community rises above this negativity and does the right thing.THOMAS G. DUNCANEaston

title: It's official: Gunsallus wins - "I'm quite elated and honored that the citizenry believes in me,' he says
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
It's official: Gunsallus wins - "I'm quite elated and honored that the citizenry believes in me,' he says

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 307
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - After absentee ballot canvassing Wednesday afternoon, the news was official: Frank Gunsallus was elected as president of the Easton Town Council.The town's Board of Canvassers counted 141 absentee votes and certified Gunsallus as the winner of the contested election just after 4:30 p.m.Wednesday.At 35, Gunsallus will be the youngest council president in Easton's history.Over 2,000 ballots were cast, rendering Tuesday as the biggest turnout for a special election.Gunsallus finished strong, won 875 votes in total. Former Easton Mayor Robert Willey earned an additional 50 votes from absentee ballots, bringing his total count to 746 votes.Former Ward 1 Councilman Al Silverstein received 393 votes, and Kevin Bateman received 36 votes.After the results were made official, Gunsallus said it felt "surreal." "I'm quite elated and honored that the citizenry believes in me," he said."I'm very gracious for their support." Gunsallus said his first priorities upon taking office include ensuring first responders' needs are addressed, addressing the town's housing shortage, making sure that all are represented fairly and addressing health care.He extended thanks to Willey, Bateman and Silverstein for their campaigns and for "making it an interesting race." The council president-elect took a moment to address some negative campaigning, specifically referencing false social media accusations that he was involved with the Proud Boys."If you read what I wrote (in a Tweet), it was an insult and was intended as such," he said, referring to the post."Thank you to those individuals for putting it out on Facebook and motivating people to come vote - it had the opposite effect of what you intended." Gunsallus will be sworn in as Town Council president at the council's next meeting on Monday, Sept. 18 at 5:30 p.m. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Frank Gunsallus, 35, was elected president of the Easton Town Council on Tuesday, Sept. 12.

Candidates file in Federalsburg town election

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 9 | Section: News

 FEDERALSBURG - Voters in Federalsburg have a full slate of candidates to choose from in the town's upcoming election on Tuesday, Sept. 26.The mayoral seat and all four council seats - two council members for each newly created district - are up for election this year under the town's recently passed election plan.Incumbent Federalsburg Mayor Kimberly Abner is running for reelection to the mayoral seat. Jeffrey A. Stevenson, Jr. is challenging Abner for the seat.In District 1, which has a 64% Black population, three candidates are running for two seats on the council: Darlene Hammond, Brandy James and Scott Phillips, an incumbent council member.Only two candidates are running for the two council seats in District 2: incumbent Debra Sewell and H. Torbert "Toby" Williamson.The new election plan, passed in June, changed the town's former at-large, staggered term election system to a two-district system that ensures more representation of Federalsburg's Black residents.The change was spurred by a federal lawsuit filed earlier this year, which contended that the former election system discriminated against Black voters by keeping them from being able to elect their chosen representatives.Under the new plan, the council members elected to Districts 1 and 2 who receive the highest number of votes will be elected to five-year terms. Council members receiving the second-highest number of votes in their respective districts will be elected to three-year terms.The next person elected as mayor will serve a five-year term.Terms for the two council members elected to threeyear terms will expire on the first Tuesday of November 2026, followed by an election for two council members, one from each district.The new council members elected in 2026 will be elected to four-year terms.Elections for council members from each district will occur every two years after.Polls will be open from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Tuesday, Sept. 26. Voting will take place at Town Hall, located at 118 N. Main Street.Residents will be able to vote for a mayor and two candidates from their district.

title: Cambridge OKs revised curfew for youth in city - New ordinance applies to juveniles under 16
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge OKs revised curfew for youth in city - New ordinance applies to juveniles under 16

 September 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 621
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Nearly three months after Cambridge's temporary juvenile curfew ended, the city council has passed a new curfew ordinance.The curfew will last 12 months, beginning Oct. 1.It will end Sept. 30, 2024, unless it is extended or approved as part of the city code.The curfew will make it so that juveniles under 16 cannot be in a public place within the city between the hours of 10 p.m. and 5 a.m. on Sundays through Thursdays and 11 p.m. through 5 a.m. on Fridays and Saturdays. There are exceptions to this, however, including when the juvenile is with a parent or when the juvenile is on the way home from work or a school activity.The curfew passed in a four to one vote Monday evening. All city commissioners voted in favor of reinstating the curfew except for Ward 3 Commissioner Jameson Harrington.This vote comes more than a month after Mayor Stephen Rideout vetoed another version of a curfew that commissioners had passed at an Aug. 14 meeting.The failed ordinance used the same language as the temporary curfew that was in place from February through June.The newly passed ordinance, which was drafted based on proposed amendments from Rideout, passed with a number of amendments.Rideout's drafted ordinance included the addition of definitions and alterations to language on enforcement procedures and penalties. It eliminated language that allowed parents to be fined for a child's actions.It also implemented the Children in Need of Supervision process in the event the family refuses to participate in services requested by the Local Care Team, a collaborative group of local agencies serving families. In this process, the Department of Juvenile Services would have the authority to refer the youth to appropriate services, employ a precourt supervision agreement where the youth and family agree to certain conditions like participating in services, or file a petition with the juvenile court.In September, Ward 4 Commissioner Sputty Cephas proposed amendments to Rideout's drafted curfew ordinance.Cephas' version adds a penalties section which penalizes parents if their child is given a curfew violation following an initial written warning. The penalty would be $50 for a first offense and $100 for a second offense. Three or more violations of the ordinance would be forwarded to the Dorchester County State's Attorney's Office for review and could result in "additional crime charges against the parent."During the council meeting Monday, the mayor and commissioners went through Cephas' amendments line by line and voted on each one before voting on the entire amended curfew ordinance. In this process, the council voted to include Cephas' addition of a penalties section to the ordinance, including fining families for juvenile offenses. Harrington and Ward 1 Commissioner Laurel Atkiss voted against amending the ordinance to include fines. However, the amendment still passed.The council voted to include wording so that, unless the child has previously violated the ordinance, the Cambridge police chief cannot proceed with further action.After this amendment passed, Rideout clarified with the police chief, "The fact that a child is uncooperative cannot give you any advance to do anything more about that particular case if it's a first-time offense."Before any action was taken on the ordinance, three residents spoke about the curfew.Jose J. Rodriguez said that a curfew needs to be in place."Responsibility starts with us, not with them," Rodriguez said about Cambridge's youth.At the end of the meeting, Atkiss thanked everyone for coming together to compromise and pass a curfew."I also want to be sure to remind everyone that the curfew is not the solution," she said. "It's just a tool in our toolbox. We still need to address our children and our education and our housing."

title: Caroline Commission shares top requests with Mid-Shore delegation
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Commission shares top requests with Mid-Shore delegation

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 23 | Section: News 
 
 1104
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Caroline County Commission met Tuesday, Oct. 3, with five of the seven-member legislative team for state districts 36 and 37 to advance its annual "bill requests and discussion items" ahead of the 446th Maryland General Assembly Jan. 10 to April 8, 2024.The short list of priorities they asked legislators to support were:■ Providing supplemental funds for emergency medical transports.,■ Licensing for barbershops and beauty shops to allow one-site sales and consumption of alcoholic beverages under restricted circumstances.■ Allowing liquor-tasting and sampling in the county in addition to wine and beer tasting.■ Continuing local funding of legislative bond initiatives.■ Devising a better method of assessing electric vehicle use instead of imposing a mileage tax.The three-member commission met with the legislators for about an hour in the Health and Public Services Building in Denton.The meeting agenda was reversed, with commissioners' unanimously approving the consent agenda shortly after the 9 a.m. start time while they waited for Del. Jeff Ghrist, R-36-Caroline, to arrive. The annual presentation of the consolidated transportation program occurred at about 10:30 a.m.Besides Ghrist, attending the annual delegation meeting were state Sen. Johnny Mautz, R-37; Del. Jay Jacobs, R-36-Kent; Del. Steve Arentz, R-36-QA; and Del. Chris Adams, R-37B. Sen. Steve Hershey, R-Upper Shore, and Del. Tom Hutchinson, R-37B, were absent.Commission Vice President Larry Porter led the discussion by describing the county's critical need for help in funding emergency medical transportation.The Emergency Service Transporter Supplemental Payment Program addresses the difference between the cost per emergency transport versus the Medicaid reimbursement rate. Providers receive a supplemental payment to make up the difference, but it's not enough to cover the actual cost.Porter pointed out that "Caroline County is a long county. It's about a two-hour turnaround time for us to pick up a patient, transport them, get them into the emergency room in Easton or Dover or Seaford, and turn around and come back."Because the "program reimburses at a higher rate, we're able to keep our revenue coming in, so that we can buy the new ambulances, new equipment," Porter said.EMS Division Chief K.J. Marvel explained that Caroline County reimbursement for ambulance transportation per Medicaid patient is increasing from a $100 to $150. She said she was worried about the lack of clarity in the expiration date of the grant program, which was originally set to expire in 2025.ESPP is a federal program sponsored through the Maryland Department of Health, Marvel said. "It's actually been very beneficial for us because we have a lot of Medicaid transports with our population here," she said.Private insurance companies and Medicare pay the rate established by the Maryland health care system."It's very important to us," Commission President Travis Breeding said. "We do not have an emergency room in the county."Medicaid does not pay for transportation to urgent care or Choptank Community Health, nor for transportation back home from an emergency room, so county EMS ambulances and drivers must transport patients to hospitals and, often, back home.Marvel and Deputy County Administrator Daniel Fox told the delegation the county is not looking for an increase in funding, but a continuation of the program.The financial benefit was $723,000 last year, Marvel said. Fox said losing those funds would be "devastating.""That's what? Two, three ambulances," Breeding said.He said the commission wanted to make sure "that our federal representation understands how important it is, and then also make sure that the state continues to have the regulatory and the grant writing structure in place to pass that funding through."The commissioners put forward requests to make three changes in the county liquor code, as recommended by the Caroline County Liquor Board. Assistant Director of Codes Crystal Dadds explained the requests.The board recommends allowing hair salons and barbershop to provide one 5-ounce glass of wine or 12-ounce beer per customer during a hair appointment, if the business were approved for an annual license fee of $100.Two other changes in the liquor code were proposed. Currently, beer and wine tastings and samplings are allowed in the county, but not the tasting and sampling of spirits. The number of two-ounce drinks per day for sampling would increase from six to nine to accommodate the typical number of three-sample flights.The commissioners requested support from the delegation for the Rural Maryland Council for fiscal year 2025. The state council, supported by the MidShore Regional Council, is requesting $9 million for rural development and projects. The funding request remains unchanged from fiscal year 2023.Though not included in the published bill requests, the commissioners voiced their concern about a proposed state mileage tax that would "disproportionately hurt rural residents because we travel more, and residents who travel in other states," Ghrist said.He said the state is "trying to figure out how to capture a use tax for EVs, but that's not the answer." Rather, "the better answer would be a titling tax when somebody purchases an electric vehicle.""Well, I think each day we find unintended consequences of this green energy agenda," Porter said. "Whether it's danger to our firefighters and first responders or the reduction in Highway User Funds, I think it went from $4 million to $400,000. This is just another unintended consequence of this ridiculous mess."A discussion about rural transportation needs, infrastructure needs and costs, and differences between urban and suburban versus rural mobility ensued."Something to keep in mind is, no matter what they do with EVs, as far as how we address that issue, they're still heavily subsidized," Arentz said. "The poor are the ones who are really going to get hammered by this. And we are not wealthy counties."Adams said the talk of a new tax prompted a blip on his wristwatch heart monitor. A politician who would even try to propose a new tax "with a recession coming on and inflation going through the roof" would have to put forth a convincing argument, he suggested."You can expect every person sitting at the table who represents Caroline County to push back and push back hard when it comes to raising taxes," Adams said."We need to be mindful of the economy on Main Street, not just on Wall Street," Mautz said.

title: Oxford keeping investment policy
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Oxford keeping investment policy

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 645
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD - A decision to keep a decades-old financial investment policy, which the town didn't know about until recently, in place was met with applause at a Commissioners of Oxford meeting Tuesday.Commission President Tom Costigan said that while the existing policy might not be perfect, it's what the town can work with for the time being."I think there's consensus from a lot of people in the room and a lot of people at this table that our existing policy is a good one. We should keep it and we should follow it," he said, which was followed with claps from residents in attendance.The policy features three sections that are unique to Oxford.One section states that each commissioner and the clerk treasurer must disclose "any substantial personal investment or management role in any financial institution which conducts business in Talbot County." Another section states that no more than half of the town's investment should be in a stable financial institution.Lewis said that other municipalities didn't necessarily state this the same way.The last section states that the length of maturity on an investment should not exceed one year.At the previous town meeting Sept. 26, Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said that Oxford has had a financial investment policy since the 1990s, which the current town officials and commissioners had not been made aware of.Lewis said that after learning about the policy, she created an updated version.She gave commissioners copies of the original policy as well a policy with her updates at the Sept. 26 meeting.After Costigan said the town should keep the existing financial policy at the Tuesday meeting, Commissioner Susan Delean-Botkin asked if they would consider looking at the small updates that Talbot County had made to its financial policy."Would we consider looking at that and seeing (if) there (is) anything we need to address?" she asked.Costigan said the commissioners could look at "anything," but said that right now, the plan is to stick with what is already in place.Commissioner Katrina Greer said she was thrilled to keep the existing policy in place.During the meeting, commissioners briefly discussed whether to create a Budget and Finance Committee.During the last meeting, Greer had asked to discuss a resolution to create the committee, which she drafted.Commissioners agreed to discuss it at the meeting Tuesday.However, because Greer wanted to go through the language, Costigan suggested the commissioners hold a workshop next week to discuss the resolution.Greer said she would be happy with that, as long as the meeting was in the evening, rather than in the afternoon, so that more residents can attend.Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan said she envisions that commissioners would discuss what they anticipate the committee would do at the workshop so that she can draft something to be put on the agenda for the next regular town meeting.Delean-Botkin said the first question the commissioners have to decide is whether the committee is necessary."Having gone through 40 phone calls of other entities on the Shore, Rockville, Frederick Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Talbot County, Easton, Trappe, Salisbury, Cambridge, Denton, all the school boards - none of them have a citizens budget advisory committee," Delean-Botkin said. "When I asked the aldermen, councilmen, committee members and board members why not, it is because it is the duty of the sworn officials to manage the budget and finances is in every entity's charter." In response, Greer said Annapolis does have a Finance Committee.Costigan said the commissioners should first decide what the committee would be."Let's first define what it is and then we'll decide whether we need it or not," he said. "And we can vote on whether we want it or not." The commissioners workshop will be held Thursday, Oct. 19, at 5 p.m. in the Commissioners of Oxford meeting room.

 CAMBRIDGE - During a council meeting recently, the Dorchester County Council was given an update by Maryland Department of Transportation officials on different projects and programs affecting the county.The council heard from Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld as well as representatives from the Maryland State Highway Administration, Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration, Maryland Transportation Authority, Maryland Transit Administration, Maryland Aviation Administration and Maryland Port Administration.Matt Baker, state highway deputy administrator for project development, talked about a traffic signal project affecting U.S. Route 50 and Maryland Route 750 that will enhance safety for pedestrians and bicyclists. The $208,000 project includes the implementation of countdown pedestrian signals.Baker also mentioned the new sidewalk on Bayly road, which runs between Maces Lane and Governors Avenue, that will make the road safer for pedestrians and bicyclists.Currently, the State Highway Association is doing an intersection study at Maryland Route 343 and Maces Lane to see what safety enhancements it might need to employ at that intersection, according to a press release from MDOT.Bob Munroe, Maryland Port Administration deputy executive director of administration and environment, talked about the Mid-Chesapeake Bay Ecosystem Restoration project. The project, in partnership with the U.S.Army Corps of Engineers and located in Dorchester County, will create shoreline protection for the county by using dredged material from shipping channels to rebuild James and Barren islands."On a macro-level, this project will give the state much needed Chesapeake Bay sediment replacement capacity for the next 30 years," Munroe said during the meeting. "Locally, we believe that the MidBay island restoration will help reduce storm-related shoreline erosion for up to 30% on the upper Hoopers Island area and the areas north of Fishing Creek." Munroe added that he believes the project will also increase overall property values in the county by more than $1 million.This is in part due to a reduced rate of energy and improved water quality.Barren Island construction has already begun and James Island construction is set to begin in 2025, Munroe said.These projects are a part of MDOT's six-year draft Consolidated Transportation Program, a $21.2 billion investment plan for the state's transportation system. According to the press release, the plan will be finalized and submitted in January for consideration of the General Assembly. MDOT is meeting with all of Maryland's counties and Baltimore City to discuss the plan.According to the press release from MDOT, allocations for Dorchester County in the draft Consolidated Transportation Program also include $919,000 to support local transit operations provided by Delmarva Community Transit, $123,000 to help Delmarva Community Services install a propane station for propanepowered vehicles and $337,000 to help fund HVAC improvements at the Cambridge-Dorchester Regional Airport terminal.During the meeting, the County Council presented a list of priorities it hopes MDOT can address, including traffic improvements, pedestrian and safety improvements around the county.These include:▪ Traffic and geometric improvements at the Maryland Route 392 and Route 14 intersection.▪ A pipe replacement on Maryland Route 336.▪ Pedestrian improvements on Maryland Route 392 through Hurlock.▪ Railroad crossing improvements at Indiantown Road and Maryland Route 331.▪ Turn lane improvements to Maryland Route 16 at Mount Holly Road.▪ Pavement marking updates in Cambridge.▪ Painting the jersey walls on Malkus Bridge.▪ A full-function intersection on westbound U.S.50 at Chateau Road.▪ Rumble strips on Mount Holly Road.▪ Visibility improvements on the drawbridge in Cambridge.The city of Cambridge and town of East New Market also submitted a list to the county to be presented to MDOT. Their lists include changes to the intersection at Maces Lane and Washington Street in Cambridge and assistance with speeding in East New Market, among other items.After hearing the presentations from MDOT officials, council members shared their comments with the officials.Council member Ricky Travers talked about the change in road width on Maryland Route 335.He said the road width changes by about 2 or 3 feet on either side."I really think the state needs to take a strong look at that," he said.Council President Lenny Pfeffer and Vice President Mike Detmer thanked the State Highway Administration District Engineer Mark Crampton."I wanted to thank you so much for answering emails and questions and concerns of the council in general and our citizens when they talk," Pfeffer said. "Mark has been phenomenal in customer service [and] getting back to us with answers, whether it's something we like to hear or something we don't." Detmer said the work Crampton and his team have done means a lot to him and to the residents of Dorchester County."From the little to the big, your local team here has been very exemplary in helping us," he said to the MDOT officials.

title: Easton Town Council vote on cannabis moratorium delayed - Tabled measure leads to heated discussion among council members
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton Town Council vote on cannabis moratorium delayed - Tabled measure leads to heated discussion among council members

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A move by Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus to continue a hearing on a proposed cannabis moratorium drew strong reactions from other council members.A tense back-and-forth exchange between Gunsallus and Ward 3 Councilman David Montgomery toward the end of Monday's council meeting stemmed from the council president's executive decision to delay a vote on the moratorium for an additional three weeks.The nine-month moratorium on cannabis businesses, introduced this summer, was originally slated for a public hearing and vote at the council's Sept.18 meeting. The matter had been tabled until Monday so all five council members could be present to vote.The moratorium, if passed, would place a pause on applications, approval, construction, expansion, processing or issuance of building permits for a business that grows, processes or sells cannabis within the Easton town limits.The moratorium would also allow the town to consider and adopt a revised zoning ordinance.Easton's existing zoning ordinance already contains definitions and permitted zoning districts for medical cannabis dispensaries and growing and processing facilities, but does not include language on standards for recreational facilities.Montgomery strongly objected to Gunsallus' continuance, saying the council president did not have the authority to do so. Gunsallus affirmed that he did."Sir, you will contain yourself please," Gunsallus said, speaking over Montgomery, who started to make a comment.Gunsallus reaffirmed he had the power to continue discussion on the moratorium until the next meeting, explaining that he wanted to wait until the town's planning commission made an additional recommendation later in the week.However, in August, the commission unanimously gave a favorable recommendation to approve the ordinance.Montgomery called for a vote on the continuance, questioning Gunsallus' authority."The fact that four of us could reveal that we want to vote now means nothing to you, that you will override the wishes of the council because you are sitting there as the town council president," he said.Town Attorney Sharon Van Emburgh chimed in, saying the council can override the president's action. But in the past, the council has typically given members additional time to vote as a courtesy.Montgomery pointed out that the council had already given an additional month for consideration.Gunsallus reemphasized the upcoming planning commission meeting would provide more clarifying information."Excuse me, what information will that be?" Montgomery said."(The planning commission's) recommendations, as I've stated, so please contain yourself - you've already spoken more than permissible," Gunsallus said.Montgomery motioned to overrule Gunsallus and vote on the ordinance as presented.Ward 2 Councilman Don Abbatiello interjected, saying while he understood Montgomery and "definitely" disagreed with how the decision had been handled, he agreed that granting additional time to decide was in line with past council actions.Mayor Megan Cook, a former council president herself, interrupted the quarreling, calling for the councilmen to settle down."I agree that we are a group of five where you all are independent and you all have various opinions - absolutely.We must respect ourselves - the fighting, we need to" she said, trailing off and moving her arms to motion to calm down."Please." Ward 4 Councilman Rev.Elmer Davis Jr. initially seconded the motion, rescinding his vote just minutes later to agree with Abbatiello's stance on the council's precedent. He voiced worry with how the situation was handled."We have never had such a dialogue that we had tonight regarding issues and concerns," he said. "That dialogue - I'm quite concerned about things that have been said, I've never seen this on this council in all my days." The council will again table voting on the ordinance until its Monday, Nov. 6, meeting.Uncertainty still remains on the moratorium. During Monday's meeting, council members and town residents raised questions on the moratorium's duration, specifics on licensing for both recreational and medical facilities and zoning laws for both types of establishments.The Easton Planning Commission will discuss zoning requirements for adult-use cannabis dispensaries at its Thursday, Oct. 19, meeting.

title: Residents a no show to listening session - Cambridge City Council to vote on ward realignment
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Residents a no show to listening session - Cambridge City Council to vote on ward realignment

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: A5 | Section: News 
 
 721
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Only city staff and committee members showed up to a Cambridge Ward Realignment Listening Session on Thursday, Oct. 12.The city's residents, who the informal meeting was intended for, were not present at the City Council Chambers that evening.Neither the Ward Realignment Committee members nor city staff were surprised by this, though."The people who aren't affected looked at the map, said 'That ain't me. Ok,"'Ward Realignment Committee member Lou Hyman hypothesized.The ward changes, which the committee proposes Cambridge City Council vote to make, would affect less than 3% ofCambridge's population.According to a news release from the city, the committee is proposing:⯀Moving the area bounded by Locust Street, Oakley Street, Park Lane and Willis Street from Ward 1 to Ward 3.⯀Moving the area bounded by Robbins Street, Maces Lane, Bradley Avenue and High Street from Ward 2 to Ward 4.⯀Moving the area bounded byVirginia Avenue, Peachblossom Avenue, Washington Street, Front Street, Brohawn Avenue and Perimore Street from Ward 3 to Ward 5.■ Moving the area bounded by Washington Street, Peachblossom Avenue, Boundary Avenue and Front Street from Ward 4 to Ward 5.These changes would make it so that each ward has a population size within the lawful plus or minus 5% range of the city's mean population.Wards must be within this range for elections.According to city council documents, there are currently more residents in Ward 1 than the range allows and fewer residents in Ward 5 than the range allows.At the end of the listening session, the committee voted unanimously to move forward with its proposal as is."Well, we did not hear anything in the listening session that would make me think we should change (our proposal)," Committee Member Tal-ibah Chikwendu said, referencing the absence of residents and causing those at the meeting to laugh."So I can't see a reason to make any additional changes."Following the committee's vote to move forward, the city will draft a resolution to be put on the City Council's next meeting agenda for a first reading. In November, the City Council will hold a formal public hearing for the the resolution.Ifthe City Council passes the resolution, the city will communicate the changes to the Board of Elections, who will then notify the residents affected.The majority ofthe meeting, however, was spent talking about how to achieve more engagement from residents on different city issues.Chikwendu said residents who would be affected by the proposed changes might have showed up to the listening session ifthey had been notified of the potential impact via mail."We could have gotten people here ifwe had been specific in the targets," she said.Chikwendu also said having more diverse wards could facilitate increased community engagement with the city, overall."It would have impacted a whole lot more people, but we could have actually created more diverse wards and still maintained the balance that we needed to to not be in violation," she said.Because the committee didn't have more time, it opted for the "next best thing," Chikwendu said, adding that there is nothing wrong with its proposal."But ifwe're talking about trying to get more and more people invested to show up for things like that and to do things that we talk about need to be done, we need to, first of all, give people reasons to start to talk to people who aren't like them," she said.Having grown up in Cambridge, Chikwendu acknowledged that there are other obstacles to increasing community engagement."In general, people who live here don't like people who came here later to tell us what to do," she said. "If they're people who aren't (lifelong) Cambridge residents saying it, it's going to be hard to get people to listen."Committee Vice Chair Greg Meekins said education is fundamental in growing engagement."We're not building up another set ofleaders," he said about Cambridge. "That's critical."Meekins also said marketing is important."We've got a large segment of the population in poverty," he said. "And ifwe are going to be intentional about reaching them, we've got to create the material that's going to hit them square in the face in a very positive way."

 EASTON - The Town of Easton's 2020 bond projects are "rocking and rolling," according to Easton Mayor Megan Cook.As of Monday evening's council meeting, the town had spent $6,493,165 of the $7 million allocated for park and municipal building improvements within the town, Cook said.A majority of the funding - about $6.75 million - was allocated for parks, with the remaining $250,000 going toward town buildings.The town's engineering department is working with the finance department to process remaining invoices that are coming in, but Cook said she was confident the town would spend the last $500,000 by Friday, Oct. 20."We are going to hit the mark, we're going to land the plane and we're going to get over the bar," she said, drawing laughs from town officials.The funding, originally granted in 2020, needs to be spent by the end of the month.Projects include improvements to the Rails to Trails system, upgrades to existing parks, sidewalk additions and more.One popular project is North Easton Park's new skate park and pump track, where work is moving along well. The pump track is complete, Cook said.While workers were smoothing concrete earlier this week, two young scooter drivers were whipping around the curves that had already been finished."This park is really nice," said Ryder Cario, an Easton High School freshman who came to be one of the first participants at this park. "It is a lot better than what we had before." Fellow EHS freshman Emmett Rogan joined Cario at the park. The helmeted duo made their scooters move like surfboards on a wave. After each lap, they took a break, panting and smiling.The workers seemed happy that these kids were using their creation, adding to the complex's existing playgrounds and athletic fields, though workers said they were on tight deadlines and quick expectations to install everything.But for now, this windfall is a win for scooter and skateboard lovers alike.Work on other projects is also progressing steadily.Cook shared brief updates on the status of other projects, including the Brewer's Lane dog park and parking lot, the Hunter's Mill playground, field lights installation at North Easton Park and parks storage buildings.

title: Lt. governor energizes Democrats at dinner
author: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com
content:
Lt. governor energizes Democrats at dinner

 October 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 468
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE - In the main hallway of the Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center and Museum in Centreville, Maryland's Lt. Governor Aruna Miller greeted leaders of the Queen Anne's County Democratic Party for a short meet and greet before speaking to the awaiting audience of supporters."We have our work cut out for us," said Frank Alduino, member of the Democratic Central Committee in Queen Anne's County, when asked how support for the Democrats was faring.The Queen Anne's County Democratic Central Committee held what will now be their annual Unity Dinner, at the center on Saturday evening, Oct. 14, providing Democrats across the county and state the opportunity to meet.Jordan Himes, political director for the Maryland Democratic Party, attended the event to "make sure we get as unified as we can as Democrats." In his introduction of Miller, Himes, whose grandmother is from the Eastern Shore and attended school in the Kennard Center, site of the former Kennard High School, said he was brought up knowing that you can never have the absence of hope."I encourage everyone here to use your voice," Himes said."One voice can change one person, a person can change the county, the county can change the state, the state can change the country, and the country can change the world." In 2022, Maryland saw the most diverse ticket that's ever won in the history of Maryland. Miller thanked the audience for their support of the Moore/Miller ticket, which won by the most votes in Maryland's history, and they were the only two people of color who ever won the office together in the United States.Miller told the audience they didn't vote for the Moore/Miller ticket to be the status quo."You all wanted us to move boldly, decisively, and deliberately for all Marylanders," the lieutenant governor said. "You elected us to leave no one left behind." Miller assured the crowd they had heard the voices of rural voters who told them that the only time they saw elected officials was during a campaign year. Because of this, Miller says, Gov.Moore has decided to coordinate a tour bus of his entire cabinet to travel to every Maryland county and listen to the concerns of voters.Touting the success of the legislative session, Miller said the administration worked on raising the minimum wage, increasing services to Maryland veterans, providing high school seniors with a yearlong, post-grad service option, increasing broadband services in rural areas and ensuring training for abortion care providers."Things don't just happen, they are made to happen," Miller said. "We are fighting for equity and freedom. Let's all heal the world and make it a better place."

JeffLankford, business and marketing coordinator ofEaston Airport, said the last tenant to go will be the Talbot County Sheriff's office this coming summer."Ifyou go down Glebe road to Mistletoe, that is where the old Avon Dixon Building is," said Lankford. There will also be some grading that has to be done. There is an incredible amount ofdirt that is going to have to be brought. Ifyou look from the TCBC it really looks like a bowl from that vantage point to the airport."According to the Easton Airport website, 90% of the funding will come from Federal Aviation Administration grants. The Maryland Aviation Administration will contribute five of the remaining 10%, and the Easton Airport has to cover the final five %, which is around $2.6 million dollars.Lankford said that in 30 years of running the airport, they are confident they can cover their share. title: Juvenile services department to move detained girls, again
author: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service
content:
Juvenile services department to move detained girls, again

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 1363
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Maryland's Department ofJuvenile Services will relocate girls awaiting court hearings or long-term placement this month from a single unit of the Cheltenham Youth Detention Center, a facility that previously housed only boys, to a center the agency says will house all girls in the agency's residential care.The move is designed to correct problems highlighted in a series of reports by the Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit in the state Office of the Attorney General.The reports revealed that four moves of detained girls and one move ofgirls in long-term placement over seven months in 2022 disrupted school, led to longer and more frequent periods of confinement and isolation, delayed medical services and exposed girls to sexual harassment.But it's unclear whether the change to an all-girl facility will impact the inequities experienced by girls in Maryland's youth detention system."They just treat these girls like chattel, moving them constantly from one place to another without thinking of how it will impact them," a staffer told a JJMU investigator in early 2023."They are just replicating the streets here, it's like survival every day," said a mental health therapist to an investigator during the same period. While all DJS long-term placement facilities are meant to offer treatment, the therapist told the investigator that the facility was too "short-handed" to do so.A 19-year-old at the facility, the Victor Cullen Center in rural northern Frederick County, said to an investigator, "There is nothing treatment-oriented about this program."DJS has housed detained girls from most of the state at Cheltenham and all girls in long-term committed placement at Cullen since October 2022. The department said that after girls at Cheltenham are moved to the Western Maryland Children's Center in Hagerstown later this month, girls committed by the courts to DJS care will join them "at a later date."Boys currently detained at WMCC will be moved to DJS residential facilities closest to their home communities, the department said. The department also indicated that WMCC staff are receiving training in "gender-responsive programming and trauma-informed care."Girls and young women comprise a small portion ofyouth confined in DJS detention and treatment centers. For fiscal year 2022, DJS reported average daily populations of 10 girls in detention and 12 in court-ordered committed placement. The number of girls sent to detention from juvenile court in the course of a given year is much higher, though it has decreased each year since 2018, from 437 to 91 in 2022.The department's repeated moves of detained and committed girls in 2022 followed over a decade of debate and activism about how DJS should serve girls in its custody.In March 2022, DJS closed the Thomas J.S. Waxter Children's Center in Laurel and moved detained girls to the Alfred D. Noyes Children's Center in Rockville, which the department had refurbished to serve as a girls' facility. The monitoring unit had been calling for Waxter's closure since 2007, stating that it was "virtually impossible to improve the physical plant sufficiently to make it suitable for a secure detention program." A 2010 bill in the House of Delegates that would have closed Waxter died in committee.The Juvenile Services secretary at the time, Donald DeVore, told CNS he couldn't close Waxter because it would mean placing girls in a facility with boys."If I close Waxter, the other facilities I have are for boys. Where do I put the girls? I would hate to stuff them in two wings (in a facility) where I have boys," DeVore told CNS in 2010.Just one month after the move to Noyes, the girls were moved again, this time into a 12-cell unit at Cheltenham after an air handler unit caught fire. The girls returned to Noyes in late May but were moved back to Cheltenham in October, this time to address a staffing shortage that had reached a crisis level. Cheltenham staff had been working back-to-back double shifts to reach the level of coverage required by departmental policy.Girls at Cheltenham awaiting court-ordered secure placement were sent to Cullen, the center in Frederick County.Keeping girls and boys separated at Cheltenham created new problems:■Delayed medical care:Girls at Cheltenham did not have access to the facility infirmary because boys are housed there. A girl experiencing withdrawal symptoms in early 2023 was transported from Cheltenham to WMCC in Hagerstown, almost 100 miles away, because her condition required monitoring.■Disrupted school:Persistent staff shortages at Cheltenham led to shortened or canceled school days. A special education teacher who had taught at Noyes quit in late 2022 after several years of service, partly due to her increased commute to Cheltenham with no definite end date, according to JJMU.■Increased isolation and confinement:During a COVID-19 outbreak in late 2022, a lack of space to quarantine girls meant that girls who tested positive isolated in their cells for 23 hours a day for five to seven days, according to the monitoring unit. After seven days isolating in her cell, one girl "destroyed her room." Staff asked another youth to comfort the girl from the hallway.■Heightened conflict between girls:Staff separated girls into groups that took turns in a dayroom and small TV room, as well as going to school, to manage tensions. One girl told a JJMU investigator that all the noise made her feel anxious. She said, "It's so crazy here. It's so hard to concentrate in school because it is so loud, and loud noises are my trigger." A pregnant girl who was assaulted twice indicated, "Me and my child feel threatened."■ Exposed girls to sexual harassment:Two girls reported in early 2023 that a boy made repeated lewd comments and gestures when they were all in school. The boy moved his hand over his crotch and told the girls to perform a sexual favor and referred to the girls pleasuring themselves with tampons.In its report on the first quarter of 2023, JJMU wrote, "Relegating detained girls and young women to a single unit in a secure detention facility set up to serve boys and young men indicates a lack of appropriate planning and dedication of resources and arguably demonstrates a casual disregard for the well-being of girls in DJS custody."At Cullen, shortages and lack of continuity of staff interfered in girls' mental health care, according to JJMU's report for the second quarter of2023. The report described how one girl who experienced suicidal ideation was "ejected" from the program at Cullen and sent to a secure detention center for a month to "stabilize her."The girl had told staff that she thought no one loved her and that she had nowhere to go after Cullen.DJS, Moroney and other advocates of girls in the youth legal system agree that a new facility for girls is not the way to provide genuine treatment.DJS acknowledged in its response to JJMU's first quarter 2023 report - the first of the new administration - that girls' needs were not being met at Cheltenham or Cullen, but said that the number of girls in its residential facilities - 13 in secure detention and 4 in commitment on June 1,2023 - was too small "to invest a large amount of resources into correctional facilities dedicated to girls." "The answer is not simply to provide dedicated space and gender specific treatment, although those things are important," DJS wrote in its response. "It is the institutional model itself that is failing these young women."In the Maryland House Judiciary Committee meeting in September, DJS Secretary Vincent Schiraldi voiced the aim of expanding Maryland's range of services for youth, which he told lawmakers has deteriorated over the past eight years.But justice reform advocates differ on whether the department is equipped to divert girls to community-based services and treatment.Schiraldi told lawmakers that DJS has adequate resources to develop Maryland's community-based offerings.But JJMU indicated in its first quarter 2023 report that there is "a shortage and lack of variety and specialization" in Maryland's community-based programming for girls.Moroney said that although relocating incarcerated girls to their own facility is a positive step, corrections-oriented facilities are not suitable spaces for young people to receive treatment."We would prefer that the girls not be incarcerated in the first place," Moroney said. "But I guess if courts and the police cause kids to go to a jail-like situation, then having their own place is a better situation than being shoehorned into a boys' place."
