title: 'It felt like we were abandoned' - Management working to address problems at Altair Apartments as residents seek housing elsewhere
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
'It felt like we were abandoned' - Management working to address problems at Altair Apartments as residents seek housing elsewhere

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - In August, everything came to a head at Altair Apartments.Trash piled high outside the apartments on Greenwood Avenue for an entire week. Broken water heaters and air conditioners couldn't be fixed. Even the internet stopped working.Resident Rodaisia Brummell said she felt disgusted."It felt like we were abandoned," Brummell said. "Like they didn't really care about us." The reason for these conditions: its new California-based management company, FPI Management, hadn't been paying all of the bills since taking over the property in April.Property Manager Judkya Murray said that overtime, vendors stopped showing up, causing trash to build up and plumbing to remain broken.She said the problem was all caused by one person at FPI Management, who has since been let go. That one person wasn't paying the bills to keep everything at Altair running. FPI Management could not be reached for comment."I was literally sitting here pulling my hair out because we had no internet," Murray said. "We had no phones. I couldn't call anybody.I couldn't email anybody." At the time, Murray was the assistant property manager acting as the property manager. The previous property manager had left for another opportunity, Murray said.The week the garbage trucks didn't show, Murray remembers the garbage being so plentiful that the building's maintenance worker had to take garbage cans from inside the building to fill with the overflowing trash outside."We were trying to do everything we could possibly do to keep the trash contained somewhere," she said. "It was just too much trash." The building's staff was quitting left and right."Nobody really wanted to leave but it's like, the conditions - you have no choice but to leave," Murray said.Even Murray quit.However, in about three weeks, she was back."The senior director of FPI (Management), she actually reached out to me one day," Murray said. "She was like, 'Can you please come have lunch with me.'" At the lunch, Murray explained why she quit and said the senior director told her they were already working to let go of and replace the the person within the company that hadn't been paying the bills for months.With that conversation, Murray agreed to come back in early October, this time as the official property manager.Having a boss who pays the bills has made Murray's job easier since coming back, she said. But she still has a significant list of to-dos and goals, especially because so many people quit a few months ago.In mid-October, Murray said she has hired a new assistant and interviewed a potential new maintenance worker."And if we hire him, we'll just need one other maintenance guy and we'll be fully staffed," she said. "Once we're fully staffed, everything flows perfectly." Murray also has some big picture goals in the works to increase occupancy and create new community programming.She is working to increase the property's occupancy rate by filling the vacant apartments. Of Altair's 144 total units, Murray said 20 are vacant. She hopes to bring the occupancy rate from 86% to 94% by the end of the year.While the waitlist of applicants is "a mile long," Murray said maintenance has to get the apartments fixed up and ready before new residents can move in.PROBLEMS PROMPT RESIDENTS TO LOOK ELSEWHEREWhile Murray is taking applications to fill apartment vacancies, Millie Lewis and her husband Willie are filling out applications for other apartments in Cambridge. After more than 40 years of living in the Altair Apartments, the Lewises are tired of dealing with the problems.Recently, they dealt with the outcome of a recent water leak, which affected their kitchen, living room and bathroom. In all three rooms, water spilled out from the ceiling. In the kitchen and bathroom, water filled in the ceiling lights.The edges of the carpeting against one wall in the living room has turned from beige to rusted brown.For years, even before the leak, the carpeting in Lewis' bedroom has been coming undone from the floor.Lewis covers these spaces - where pockets of air separate the carpeting and the floor - with small area rugs. She said Altair won't fix this issue, even though she has complained about it.Although the ceilings were patched up by maintenance following the leak, it took weeks and a citation from the city for the mold, which grew from one of those patched up spots in the bathroom, to be removed.Lewis has COPD and asthma, which made her even more concerned about being in a home where there is mold in the bathroom that she and her husband use everyday."I pay my rent every month," she said. "Before I'm supposed to pay it.Why can't the head people do their job? Why can't they pay? Why can't they take care of what's got to be taken care of at these apartments hereft" Lewis isn't the only resident looking to live elsewhere.Tieonna Wisher, who has lived at Altair for three years, said she has already filled out an application for another apartment.She has concerns about how long it takes for management to respond to problems.Wisher has a hole in her wall that she said management hasn't done anything about for months."They keep saying they're going to come in here," she said.Wisher remembers one day when she unplugged a cord from a socket in her home and it sparked and caused half of the lights to go out in her apartment."They told me to call the emergency number," she said. "Call it and nobody answers. Go to the office.Like, nobody wants to do nothing." Brummell, who has lived at Altair for over a year, said she has also started submitting housing applications.In the time that she's lived here, Brummell has experienced a months-long leak in her bathroom and a leaking dishwasher. She said that when her dishwasher was leaking, all maintenance did was drop off a shop vac. She has yet to receive a working dishwasher.It took about three months before Brummell could get someone to fix the leak in her bathroom. She said that gnats are still flying around the apartment because of it.A mother of two young kids, Brummell has noticed her children keep getting sick. She fears it is from the building. The one time she saw mold in her home, a previous property manager told her to spray it with bleach."That's all she told me to do," Brummell said.THE CITY's INVOLVEMENTTo get problems solved, Brummell said she has started reaching out to the City of Cambridge. She said this has been effective because code enforcement can fine Altair for property violations."A couple weeks ago (workers hired by management) came in and painted and fixed my stuff that was supposed to be fixed," she said. "Only because I called the City of Cambridge.Because, if I didn't call them, it wouldn't have been that." Cambridge Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson said a goal of the city is to solve quality of life issues."That's not always going to be possible from the outside of homes," he said."We need to get people to the point where (residents) trust us and they are contacting us and they're aware of their tenants rights and they're ability to call us about issues they're having with their rental homes and their apartments." Hesson said they have been able to do this at Altair and are "still very present." Since August, Hesson said communication with upper management has been satisfactory. He said they shared an action plan with multiple items they plan to address. As of Nov. 3, Hesson said he was still waiting to see if they are following that plan.Hesson clarified that communication with Altair's on-site management "has always been pretty good." Murray said she is making sure that she stays in communication with the city."I know their biggest thing is nobody was communicating anything back to them," she said about the city. "They just need to know if somebody's on top of (a problem)." With all of the issues at Altair, Brummell said residents are paying rent and not getting the services they should be getting as tenants."Everything's being prolonged," she said. "But ya'll want things from us. You want rent money from us.You want us to go in the house at a certain time. But we're not getting the things that we properly need." 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Judkya Murray, Altair Apartments property manager, was so frustrated with surmounting issues that she quit. Now she is back and trying to get the tenants resources.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Rodaisia Brummell is looking for another place to live with her husband and two kids. "It felt like we was abandoned," Brummell said about Altair Apartments management. "Like they didn't really care about us."
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Millie and Willie Lewis have lived in the Altair Apartments for 40 years. Recently they had mold coming out of a vent in their bathroom.

title: St. Michaels commissioners take action at Wednesday meeting
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels commissioners take action at Wednesday meeting

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 237
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - The Commissioners of St. Michaels took action on three new items at its meeting on Wednesday.▪ The Commissioners voted unanimously to enter into an agreement between Mid Shore Mediation and the St. Michaels Police Department. SMPD Chief Jeffrey Oswald said the Maryland Police and Correctional Training Commissions recommend the adoption of a police mediation program.▪ The Commissioners agreed to put out a request for proposal for interior and exterior painting of the Environmental Concern building on Boundary Lane. Town Administrator Rob Straebel said proposals are due Nov. 28. He said the RFP will be advertised in the local newspaper and on the town's website.▪ The Commissioners voted unanimously to amend an ordinance to increase the number of Parks and Recreation Advisory Board members from five to seven. Marise Galgano, who is on the board, said they could use "some more hands to get dirty." She said that the board has been working well with Public Works and thinks having more minds would be helpful.▪ The Commissioners did not vote on whether to approve design fees for jail and bathroom improvements at the Police Department. Timothy Crosby of Crosby and Associates shared his design proposal with the commissioners.Commissioner Tad DuPont raised his concerns with the cost of the design, saying that it seemed too high a price. He said he would like to get other estimates on the project before moving forward.

 CAMBRIDGE - Commissioners heard two presentations at a Cambridge City Council meeting on Monday evening.The first was from a Baltimore-based nonprofit, Lead4Life, about a possible partnership with the city. The second was about the need for a day shelter in Cambridge.Jennifer Gauthier, founder and executive director of Lead4Life, spoke about the services which the nonprofit offers and inquired about partnering with the city."Allow us to hire people who can go into the community," Gauthier said. "Allow us to have that peer-to-peer model to be able to spend some of the resources that we have on these two initiatives in your community." Founded in 2008, Lead-4Life aims to lower the number of youth entering the juvenile justice system.According to its website, the nonprofit offers 10 different programs, including alternative placement programming, mentoring and individual and family therapy.At the Council meeting, Gauthier talked about two pilot programs, a gun diversion program and a returning citizens program, which it wants to offer in Cambridge.Gauthier said Lead4Life has the funding to provide these services in Cambridge and "all the way down to the Lower Shore." "We just want to hear any concerns that you have or any opportunity for us that you want to be able to partner (with us)," she said."We're not asking you for money." After Gauthier spoke, Commissioner Sputty Cephas said that he thinks it would be great to partner with Lead4Life and try to expand the program in Cambridge."From everything that I've heard so far, we need you here," he said. "Any way that we can continue to funnel this information and get the word out there about all that you guys are doing, I would love to." Valerie Nwakudo Davis, with Delmarva Community Services, spoke to the Council next about the need for a day shelter in Cambridge."This presentation is not for any agency," she said."It really is on behalf of our homeless population in this city, in this county." Davis said that there is a growing population of homeless people and talked about the importance of having a shelter for people to go to, particularly the aging homeless population."We cannot afford, as a community, to have people sitting on benches when it's 22 degrees outside, or when it's 92 degrees outside," she said.Davis said that although The Salvation Army provides shelter at night, those people in need of service don't have somewhere to go in the day. She said this problem is most apparent on the weekends."Sunday is the most miserable time of the week when you're homeless," she said, adding that places like the library and One Mission Cambridge are closed then.Delmarva Community Services hosted a meeting last week, Davis said. The Overflow Cafe, One Mission Cambridge and The Salvation Army were at the meeting."We talked about what was here already and what we need," she said.To get a day shelter in Cambridge, Davis said support from the local government is needed. She also said support from churches is needed."Because that could be an awesome volunteer segment of this," she said.After Davis spoke, Mayor Stephen Rideout said he had spoken with Davis about this a few weeks ago."I thought it was very important," he said. "It was something that we have not really paid attention to enough. So we're having an ongoing series of meetings with the churches and citizens and agencies to see what we might be able to do here to address this particular issue."

title: Easton considering changes to zoning, subdivisions
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton considering changes to zoning, subdivisions

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 760
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Easton Town Council is considering amendments and updates to two chapters of the town code concerning zoning and subdivisions.The two ordinances, which separately amend several aspects of the town's zoning code and update its existing subdivision code, were up for public hearings at the council's Monday, Nov. 6, meeting, where a number of town residents opposed some changes.Ordinance 803, which concerns changes to zoning code, drew a number of questions and prompted the council to continue its public hearing to the first meeting in January.The public hearing on Ordinance 804, which would update the town's subdivision code, will be continued at the council's Monday, Nov. 20, meeting.ORDINANCE 803: ZONINGThe town approved and adopted a comprehensive revision of its zoning code in December 2021, but after evaluation and monitoring of the code, the planning commission determined that certain amendments were appropriate to better guide and regulate development activities, according to the text of the ordinance.In response to the evaluation, the planning commission proposed 12 amendments to the zoning code, which were recommended for adoption in March. If passed, Ordinance 803 would enact the amendments.At the Nov. 6 meeting, Town Planner Lynn Thomas characterized a majority of the amendments as "housekeeping." But she noted two more important aspects: changing the ways in which middle housing types are created and changing five of those subtypes from a special exception use to a permitted use in three Easton districts: R-7A, R-10A and central business.Lynn Mielke, a Talbot County Council member who spoke at the meeting only as a resident of the Easton Club neighborhood, raised concerns about the "inadequate" amount of time residents had to read through the 250-page agenda packet and research before attending the meeting to make a comment.Mielke also objected to a revision of the language detailing how quickly planned unit developments must begin construction after final approval and language extending the expiration dates of those projects.The proposed revision extends the length of time owners or developers have to begin construction on a project from two years to three years after final approval. If no action is taken within three years, the site's zoning will revert to its previous classification.Mielke pointed to the proposed Maryland Health Club project within the Easton Club neighborhood as an example, asserting that residents have been "living in limbo and uncertainty" about the development's status.Easton Club resident Pamela Reynolds voiced concern with several housing types currently classified as special exception uses being permitted by right in the R-10A district - a residential area."I find most of them charming names, but they can have a considerable impact on the density (of the) development," she said.Reynolds also questioned if the recently approved and scaled-back neighboring Poplar Hill development could increase its density under the amendment and if the Maryland Health Club's PUD application would be impacted.Speaking on behalf of the East-End Neighborhood Association, president Joseph Minarick expressed worries about trash removal the number of additional cars on the streets if middle housing structures were added in the neighborhood, The association recommended and requested that no change be made to the special exception requirements for all middle housing structures in the three districts in question.Kelly Pezor, who serves on the town's historic district commission, said she and other commissioners were concerned about preserving the area's historic nature and keeping new developments within guidelines.In an Oct. 30 letter to the town council and mayor, the planning commission expressed support for limiting special exceptions to address the town's need for more affordable and diverse housing types. Commissioners also supported revising the expiration of PUD approvals to three years.Council members also raised concerns and questions about the complexity of the proposed amendments.The public record will remain open until the council's first meeting in January.ORDINANCE 804: SUBDIVISIONSSpeaking on revisions to subdivisions within the town code, Thomas said there were not a "tremendous" number of proposed changes.To Thomas, the most significant changes include the elimination of a street hierarchy system, which was dictated by average daily trips; adding new nonresidential street types and standards for commercial and industrial roads; revised standards for residential street types, including street widths; and requiring that at least 50% of park space in a subdivision must be provided in the form of one centrally located neighborhood park.No public comments were shared at the Nov. 6 meeting, though council members voiced positive feedback for the revisions.The two ordinances and details of the proposed changes to the town code can be found on the Town of Easton's website under pending zoning legislation.

title: No recommendations made on Boundary Lane Waterfront Park master plan - Town discusses potential dog park
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
No recommendations made on Boundary Lane Waterfront Park master plan - Town discusses potential dog park

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 648
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - Following a joint meeting Tuesday between the St. Michaels Planning Commission and the town's parks and recreation advisory board, no recommendations were made by either board on options for the proposed Boundary Lane Waterfront Park master plan.Though both boards declined to make formal recommendations on the master plan options to the town commissioners, the meeting furthered the discussion process on possibilities for the waterfront park project ahead of the commissioners' consideration of the options in January.Recommendations by the boards are not required for the commissioners to consider the master plan, but would be helpful in the process, according to Town Administrator Rob Straebel.Conversations on the master plan for the park have been ongoing for several months after the town purchased the 7.6-acre property on Boundary Lane adjacent to San Domingo Creek for $2.9 million earlier this year.The property, formerly owned by nonprofit Environmental Concern, includes an administrative building and several acres previously used for a nursery operation.About 4.6 acres of the property are within town limits and are designated as an intensely developed area within the critical area, but nearly three acres remain under the county's land zoning designation of resource conservation area.Several areas of concern outlined in the master plan's previous public outreach meetings and in public survey comments were clarified at Tuesday's meeting, including sea level rise, stormwater and a potential name for the park.According to Town Planner Steve Ball, the park's master plan does consider sea level rise and includes a berm to protect buildings from that impact in the future.In terms of stormwater, Ball said there wasn't much of a concern with the property currently, but the master plan does recommend removing much of the site's existing impervious surface.Expansion of the wetland area and maintaining the current living shoreline to filter stormwater will also be beneficial.However, a particularly significant point of contention with the park that remains to be considered is whether or not to include a dog park within the proposed waterfront park.In February, the town commissioners passed a resolution supporting a dog park location within the town, though no location was specified.The town's intent for the park is primarily open space, which opens up opportunities to receive state grant funding to offset the purchase price. However, the inclusion of a dog park within the property's future amenities would be inconsistent with the funding, Ball said.Other locations within the town have been identified as possibilities for a dog park, including a roughly twoacre piece of land adjacent to Bradley Park that's currently owned by the State Highway Administration.Scott Scarfone, an associate principal at Mahan Rykiel Associates, who's worked on the design for the Boundary Lane park project, said the project is trying to accommodate a variety of different park users.Ultimately, two park master plan options will be considered by the commissioners.Both options will include connectivity to the existing nature trail, loop trails, expanded wetlands, the living shoreline, a fishing pier, a pollinator meadow, reforestation, a viewing mound and a comfort station. One option will not include a dog park and will instead have an expanded pollinator meadow.Comments from residents at Tuesday's meeting primarily centered on the appropriateness of a dog park within the Boundary Lane property, though vehicular access to the park via Boundary Lane and West Chew Avenue and water quality concerns also came up.Several members of the planning commission said they were uncomfortable with making recommendations on the master plan due to a lack of information and research on the dog park, though there was acknowledgement of the town's preference for a passive park.The town commissioners will consider both options and the number of comments submitted by residents at the Wednesday, Jan. 10, meeting.

title: Highway Administration hears from public on Route 404
author: Maggie Trovato; trovato@chespub.com
content:
Highway Administration hears from public on Route 404

 December 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; trovato@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration gave Caroline County residents the opportunity to share their thoughts on state Route 404 between Harmony Road and Greenwood Road at a public open house held at Denton Elementary School on Wednesday.SHA Project Manager Carmeletta Harris said the purpose of the open house is to get feedback from the public on what they would like to see regarding Route 404."We are not presenting any concepts tonight," Harris said. "We want them to tell us what else is out here that we haven't seen yet." At the open house, poster boards lined the school cafeteria to show SHA's findings from its Planning and Environmental Linkages Study.The purpose of the study is to assess transportation needs.Information was broken down into seven sections: Study overview, PEL process, environmental overview, transportation needs, mapping, Title VI and safety.At the mapping station, residents could place post-it notes with their concerns on a map of Route 404.According to the information displayed at the event, the top five dislikes, gathered from stakeholder interviews so far, are congestion, uncontrolled intersections, danger from high speeds and trucks, accidents and that there is not a dual lane all the way through.Harris said SHA wants to listen to residents before presenting any concepts. Currently, SHA plans to develop preliminary improvement concepts this winter and present those concepts for feedback in the spring. It also plans to finalize its study recommendations and identify any potential stand-alone projects in the spring.Harris said the project is not funded for anything outside of the study."Not construction and things of that nature," she said. "That could come down the line But right now, we're tasked to do this study and develop some concepts." Bruce Pepper, who lives on Mitchell Road, said he's most interested in seeing the concepts that the SHA comes up with.One of Pepper's main concerns is traffic. He said that he has noticed Legion Road getting beach traffic."They run 60 miles an hour down that road," he said. "It's hilly, winding.And they think they're getting ahead, but they're not. But the GPS tells them it's a shortcut." Pepper's neighbors, Alyssa and Jamie Taylor, said they have concerns with safety and the accidents."We have only been here for about two and a half years," Alyssa Taylor said. "And we have walked up to, I would say, at least three - I can think of four or five accidents that we hear happen." The Taylors are especially interested to find out if Route 404 will be expanding."I would love to know if 404 is going to be in my front yard," Alyssa Taylor said.If that does happen, the Taylors would consider moving. They said it would affect property values and be a safety concern."Even though my front door right now is probably 160 feet from the centerline - If they do dual-lane, I don't want tractor trailers, cars, motorcycles, whatever, going 80 miles an hour now 60 feet from my door, 80 feet from my door," Jamie Taylor said.Alyssa Taylor said she was happy that SHA wanted to hear from residents and said that they had written down "everything that we're saying." John Booze said everyone from SHA was receptive and willing to listen."Tough forum too because everybody has their own issue," he said."I don't envy them. But they gave everybody a good listen and I think it'll be positive going forward." Booze said traffic volume and getting across Route 404 are some of his major concerns."Getting across the road," he said. "Whether it's somebody coming from a home. Whether it's somebody coming from business The folks that have frontage right on 404 I really am concerned about." Like Pepper, Booze has noticed more drivers taking roads that connect to MD 404."Because of Waze and GPS and Google Maps, people are starting to go farther out on the back roads to get where they want to go," he said.Booze said those drivers are driving fast and its causing the traffic problems to spread outside of Route 404."So you need to take that into consideration as well," he said. "That was one of the things that I wanted to make sure I shared with them when I came."

title: Residents weigh in on potential improvements to Matthewstown Road
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com

Residents weigh in on potential improvements to Matthewstown Road

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News

 EASTON - Easton residents voiced desires to see improved pedestrian and bicycle access, left turn lanes and traffic volume mitigation on Matthewstown Road during a transportation open house Tuesday evening.Facilitated by the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration, the open house served as an opportunity for residents to ask questions about the agency's working study of a 1.6-mile stretch of the busy two-lane road.A SHA team first began considering environmental, community and economic goals in terms of improvements along Matthewstown Road this past spring as part of a Planning and Environmental Linkages Study.According to survey data collected by SHA, residents primarily like the road's traffic lights and convenience.However, concerns were raised about extensive traffic congestion, timing issues with the traffic light at Elliot Road, speeding, excess development and a lack of sidewalks.Those concerns were echoed at Tuesday's open house, where residents were able to view an aerial map of the portion of the road being studied and place sticky notes on areas of concern.Notes included adding left turn lanes at the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Black Dog Alley and the road's intersection with Dyott Court, changing speed limits and coordination of signals to lessen traffic.Residents also highlighted the number of dense housing developments along the road, some of which have yet to be built, like Gannon Range.To Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey, who lives near Matthewstown Road, the lack of pedestrian and bicycle access along the road could stand to be improved.Efforts have been made to improve pedestrian access on the west side of Easton, particularly west of Route 50, but dense development on both sides of the highway necessitate taking steps to handle the additional volume.Adding sidewalks - and dedicated center turn lanes to avoid cars traveling around others on the shoulders - would be great, he said.But above all, Lowrey hopes the community will be engaged with the process of improving the busy road.Hunters Mill resident John Franczak raised concerns about the significant traffic on Matthewstown Road, noting long wait times for lights to change.Franczak said he would be willing to look at the possibility of a traffic circle somewhere along the road stretch in question to slow speeding traffic down, though he also voiced a request to lower the speed limit from 50 mph to 35 mph between the Hunters Mill neighborhood and Route 50.The SHA study is set to finish by spring 2024. The agency is still accepting survey comments, which can be accessed via the SHA project page.

title: Commissioners Mull Moratorium On Poultry Byproduct Storage
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com
content:
Commissioners Mull Moratorium On Poultry Byproduct Storage

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 914
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Following a sometimes spirited discussion of a controversial poultry byproduct treatment system, the three Caroline County Commissioners went into closed session Tuesday, Dec. 12, with the county's attorney to refine language for a temporary moratorium.Crystal Dadds, director of the Caroline County Department of Planning and Codes opened the discussion that focused on a "possible moratorium on the onsite storage of dissolved air flotation, otherwise known as DAF."
Dadds said the department and the commissioners had heard concerns from citizens about the recent construction of a concrete storage pit used to store DAF, or raw food waste.
"And there's some concern that the county does not have any specific regulations to address agricultural storage tanks," she said. At issue is the waste products being trucked into the county from poultry processing plants located elsewhere.
Concerned citizens, an agricultural expert and a trade association spokesman weighed in during the nearly hourlong discussion.
Grayson Middleton, government affairs manager with the Delmarva Chicken Association, argued that DAF is "an agricultural product because it's coming from a product that's being manufactured agriculturally on the Shore, and it's being applied to the Shore in an agricultural manner."
"If there's no place to store this, it makes it extremely hard for application," Middleton said.
However, Commissioner Frank Bartz claimed there was a distinction between a farmer being paid to store a product or being the end user of it.
Commission Vice President Larry Porter was more blunt. "We're not going to become a storage ground in this county for things brought in here from somewhere else and then everybody else is going to have to sit around and deal with it," he said.
The DAF pit is located on River Road outside Ridgely.
Neighbors reported the stench and flies emanating from the open-pit DAF were unlike manure since the DAF contains poultry processing byproducts.
"The smell smacks you in the face," said John Hammer, a farmer and poultry producer who lives about a quarter-mile from the DAF facility.
Sue Ellen and Mike Woodward live on Marblehead Road, and their property borders the land on which the facility sits.
Mike Woodward said the smell is so sickening, he can't work at his sawmill outside, and the flies are "just outrageous. I mean, they just cling right to our house."
Commission President Travis Breeding cited another concern. Hauling the materials in 18-wheelers and tanker trucks "is increasing the weight in traffic and potential damage to roads that, frankly, we struggle to keep up with now," he said.
Bartz placed the responsibility for storing byproducts on the poultry plants.
"It's up to them to expand their holding facilities and processing facilities where they are, instead of sending it to wherever they can just find a room and just to stick it temporarily," he said.
Caroline County Extension agent Jim Lewis said DAF is part of the nutrient management program and regulated by the Maryland Department of Agriculture, but "they very rarely issue fines" for violations.
The Maryland Department of the Environment deals with biosolids and can "pull their permits, they can fine them, shut them down," Lewis said.
However, at this point DAF is not considered a biosolid, but rather a "soil amendment" which should be worked into the soil within a day, Lewis said.
"If you do incorporation, then you're exposing soil to the surface rather than leaving a cover crop with no till," he said. DAF is untreated, Lewis said. "It's a decomposing meat, fat, blood product that potentially, I would think, would carry foodborne diseases.
The residents who commented said the DAF pit in their vicinity is not the only one in the county. The commissioners and planning department have heard of other storage facilities.
Porter asked Middleton if Caroline County had any poultry processing plants.
Middleton said no and added that the county has chicken houses.
"I'm fully aware that we have chicken houses," Porter said. "Are the chicken houses bringing material to these pits directly?" "This is the kind of thing that irritates me to no end," Porter said. "We're not going to subject our citizens to this."
County Attorney Stewart Barroll told the citizens who complained about the DAF pit, "What you've described to us is clearly a nuisance and not protected by the Right to Farm law." He asked if they had sought legal counsel. They answered that they couldn't afford an attorney and were afraid of retaliation.
"I don't know if I can handle that fight, let alone the expense of going through a long, drawn-out process of me trying to prove what the stink is like in the air, or how many flies are around my window or what's in my ditch," Sue Ellen Woodward said. "I don't have the resources or the emotional part to fight that. That's why I come to you."
"I think we're going to attempt to address the issue for you and try to come up with reasonable expectations and guidelines for the storage and application of this product," Breeding said.
The commissioners went into closed session with Barroll to determine the language to place in a resolution to declare a temporary moratorium.
They plan to introduce a resolution at their Dec. 20 meeting.

title: Helmer Sworn In As Chief Deputy
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com
content:
Helmer Sworn In As Chief Deputy

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 408
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Capt. Rodney "R.J." Helmer was sworn in as chief deputy of the Caroline County Sheriff 's Office Friday, Dec. 8.Clerk of Court Terry Lord administered the oath of office at 1 p.m. at the Caroline County Circuit Court.
A reception followed at the Sheriff 's Office on Double Hills Road in Denton.
"R.J. has been with me through thick and thin at the sheriff 's office," Sheriff Donnie Baker said. "He is true blue, and I really appreciate that, So it wasn't really a hard choice for me."
About 40 people attended the ceremony, including Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter, Commissioner Frank Bartz, retired Sheriff Randy Bounds, Judge Heather Price, Register of Wills Jim Phelps, Deputy County Administrator Dan Fox, members of Helmer's family, deputies and county staff. Attendees greeted Helmer's promotion with a standing ovation.
"I thank Sheriff Baker for the opportunity, and I wouldn't have this opportunity if it weren't for Sheriff Bounds," Helmer said.
"It's a pleasure to work with each and every one of you, and I look forward to doing everything to the best of my ability."
Helmer, 38, began his career in law enforcement in July 2008 with the Cambridge Police Department and joined the Sheriff's Office as a deputy first class on August 19, 2013. He and his family live in Hurlock where Helmer served as chief of the Hurlock Volunteer Fire Company until Dec. 18.
"R.J. is an outstanding police officer, a wonderful human being and one of the hardest working people that I've ever had the pleasure of working with," Bounds said.
"It was an honor to hire him, and I've never regretted that one second. He's knowledgable, energetic, and most supremely of all, he cares about those with whom he interacts."
"You will never, ever have to worry about his dedication and loyalty," Bounds said.
"He will serve the citizens of Caroline County well."
"He is an absolutely hardworking individual and a very capable individual to be my chief deputy and to lead this agency to the next level," Baker said.
Helmer formerly was the lieutenant of the criminal investigation division. Baker appointed Lt. George Paugh, former chief of the Greensboro Police Department, to that position Nov. 1.
Former Caroline County Chief Deputy Sheriff Maj.
James Henning retired in September after more than 26 years of service to the Sheriff's Office.

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: B6 | Section: News 
 
 441

 New Court Appointed Special Advocates for CASA of the Mid-Shore were sworn in by Clerk of the Court Amy Craig at a ceremony in Dorchester County Circuit Court on December 6.CASA staff and board members were present as the new advocates took an oath promising to advocate for the best interest of children who are under court protection because of maltreatment.
Court Appointed Special Advocates are officers of the court and, as such, are provide assessments and recommendations to judges regarding the best interest of the children to whom they are appointed.
Presiding over the swearing-in ceremony in Dorchester County Circuit Court were the Honorable William H. Jones and the Honorable Mary O'Donnell.
The judge and magistrate thanked the new CASA volunteers for their time and talents on behalf of children and commended the organization for the important information contained in their insightful reports to the court.
"Our program strives to ensure that all children under court protection due to maltreatment receive needed services and a safe, permanent home. We could not accomplish our work without the dedication and commitment of our amazing staff and volunteers.
They work passionately to help improve the lives of maltreated children to assist them in growing to their full potential and giving them hope," said Robin Davenport, executive director of the CASA of the Mid-Shore.
CASA of the Mid-Shore is a private nonprofit created to advocate for every child who is under the protection of the circuit court because of abuse, neglect or abandonment.
CASAs attempt to identify specific needs of each child for the court, advocate for service provision to meet those needs and assist in seeking a permanent resolution for each child's life as quickly and safely as possible.
Most importantly, the CASAs get to know the child and frequently become one of the most consistent adults in the child's life.
CASA of the Mid-Shore is currently accepting applications from adults from Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's and Kent Counties who are interested in becoming CASA volunteers. An organization valuing diversity and equity, CASA seeks volunteers from all walks of life, varied experiences, backgrounds and professions, and who are at least 21 years of age. After completing the application and screening process, prospective volunteers participate in pre-service training before being sworn in as officers of the court.
To learn more about becoming a Court Appointed Special Advocate visit casamidshore.org

 EASTON - After Kody Cario cut the red ribbon at the entrance to the town's new skate park and pump track on Thursday afternoon, skaters, bikers and BMX riders made their way to the track and onto the ramps for the official inaugural ride at North Easton Park.Cario, Easton's Engineering Department project manager, went to Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh with the idea to create the skate park and pump station. Van Emburgh said that although he was a little bit skeptical of the idea at first, the project turned out great.
"Projects like this make working for the Town of Easton so rewarding," he said before the ribbon was cut. "We felt the excitement from the community and can't wait to cut the ribbon and officially open the skate park and pump track." Easton Mayor Megan Cook thanked the town's Engineering, Parks and Recreation and Public Works departments.
"They took the creative vision and really built it," she said about Public Works.
Town Manager Don Richardson said this project was one of multiple funded by a $7 million bond from 2020 to improve Parks and Recreation facilities. He said that before the new skate park and pump track, there were one or two small skate ramps at North Easton Park that weren't being used at a high rate.
"But certainly this has been a major investment and a major project for the Town of Easton," he said.
"I hope that you all enjoy it and do it safely and often." Jacob Bowie said that he comes to North Easton Park to skateboard all the time. This new skate park is "exactly what we needed," he said.
"It's got a little bit of everything for everybody," he said. "It's just perfect." Bowie said he plans to come out to the park to skate once a week "maybe every day once it's summertime." Van Emburgh called the schedule to complete this project "extremely aggressive" but said that the town worked hard to make it happen. Spohn Ranch, the general contractor for the project, worked with Easton Public Works to prepare the site before construction.
Public Works constructed the drainage in the middle of the pump track, put in the concrete between the pump track and skate park, put in benches and picnic tables, did some of the landscaping, re-striped the parking areas and installed signage.
Richardson said that these Parks and Recreation facilities projects are something that residents will be able to see throughout the town.
"Things like dog parks and woodland parks and other improvements to many of our parks and recreation facilities are coming soon," he said. "So please keep your eyes and ears attuned to those things happening here."

title: St. Michaels Commissioners choose Boundary Lane park master plan
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
St. Michaels Commissioners choose Boundary Lane park master plan

 January 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 711
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — With time ticking to submit a grant application to the state, the Commissioners of St. Michaels concluded a nearly three-hour meeting Wednesday with a vote to move forward with a master plan for a new park on Boundary Lane.The master plan for the park that town staff recommend be named San Domingo Creek Park — as the 7.6-acre property is adjacent to the creek — includes nature trails, expanded wetlands, a living shoreline, a fishing pier, a comfort station and a pollinator meadow.
The property was purchased by the town in September for $2.9 million. Formerly owned by nonprofit Environmental Concern, the property has an existing administrative building, which the town plans to use for a new town office.
At the meeting, Town Planner Steve Ball told commissioners that the town intends to submit a grant application to the state for Program Open Space funds in order to offset the cost of the park.
With the grant application due Feb. 10, he said the commissioners would need to decide if any changes need to be made to the master plan at the Jan. 11 meeting so the plan can be brought back for final adoption at the Jan. 24 meeting and then submitted to the state.
After Ball spoke, Scott Scarfone, an associate principal at Mahan Rykiel Associates, gave a presentation on two master plan options.
Following the presentation, commissioners discussed aspects of both plans and whether certain parts should be included. They considered the possibilities of including a dog park and a viewing mound as well as different parking options.
Commissioner Tad DuPont said the town has spent a large chunk of its savings to purchase the land and that the town should maximize the amount of open space in the plan to get as much grant money as possible.
"It's my feeling that the town has this one shot to maximize as much open space, unencumbered as possible, to be able to be able to get the most money we can from Program Open Space to cover our costs," he said, causing residents at the meeting to applaud.
Program Open Space is a state program under the Department of Natural Resources that administers funding for open and recreational space in local communities.
DuPont said he didn't think the dog park was appropriate on the land and didn't like the viewing mound — a 10-foot hill with an ADA-accessible path that visitors could walk up to get a view of the creek from above.
The inclusion of a dog park has been a point of contention when it comes to proposed plans for the park.
In February, town commissioners passed a resolution supporting a dog park location within the town, though no location was specified.
At a joint meeting in December between the St. Michaels Planning Commission and the town's Parks and Recreation Advisory Board, Ball said the inclusion of a dog park would not be consistent with the open space funding program.
DuPont also voiced his concerns with the plans for a parking lot off Boundary Lane. He said that 12 parking spaces outside the town office building would be enough — eight spots for employees, two spots for visitors and two handicap spots.
During public comment, resident Langley Shook said if there is no dog park on the property, there is no need for more parking. He said adding more parking could affect how much funding the town gets from the state.
"All the parking would do would be to draw people who would have to drive at a distance," he said. "Which I think you generally don't want."
Shook made a suggestion to not include the additional parking lot to the plan, and if there is a need for more parking down the line, it can be added to the park later on.
Commission President David Breimhurst said not everyone who uses the park is going to be able-bodied.
"We'll have senior citizens and others who are not going to enjoy (the walk to get to the park)," he said. "They're going to want to be able to park, maybe walk to one of the pavilions and sit and enjoy the view."
Ultimately, the commissioners voted to not include the dog park or viewing mound in the master plan.
The master plan they voted on does include the parking lot off Boundary Lane.

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 EASTON — Residents woke up to two inches of snow Tuesday morning in Easton.With the snow came a snow day for Talbot County Public Schools students. Weather conditions caused the school system to close for the entire day.
Dorchester County Public Schools also closed for the day due to icy road conditions. Caroline County Public Schools closed for students, but offices opened at 10 a.m. for its 12-month employees.
Easton's Superintendent of Public Works Mike Dickerson said Easton Public Works used 46.92 tons of salt to keep the town's roadways safe. He said the department applied salt to the town's main roads — roads like Washington Street that get you into town — three times.
After receiving a notification from the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, Easton Public Works began salting roads at 4 p.m. Monday. Dickerson said the last of the department's five trucks finished salting for the third time at 4:44 a.m. on Tuesday.
"We had five trucks out," he said. "And each one of them has an assigned route."
According to the National Weather Service, winter weather advisories for Queen Anne's, Talbot and Caroline counties were issued early Tuesday morning and in effect until 1 p.m. on Tuesday.
The advisories were for mixed precipitation with additional snow of up to an inch and ice accumulation of around one 10th of an inch. The advisories stated that morning commutes could be affected due to slippery road conditions.
Dorchester County received a winter weather advisory from the National Weather Service for freezing rain and additional ice accumulation. The advisory was in effect until 11 a.m. Tuesday morning.
As of noon on Tuesday, according to the National Weather Service, snow and freezing rain were likely in Easton before 1 p.m. with a chance of rain and snow between 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. and a chance of more snow after 2 p.m. Little or no snow accumulation is expected. title: Tense discussion precedes Easton Town Council approval for Pride festival
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Tense discussion precedes Easton Town Council approval for Pride festival

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 1010
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A request to approve a public assembly permit for the Delmarva Pride Center's annual Pride festival, though approved in a 3-2 vote, elicited strong concerns from some Easton Town Council members.Though the Delmarva Pride Festival is heading into its third year in Easton, one council member's uneasiness with the contents of the festival stirred up a multi-pronged discussion on Town Council precedents and the council's responsibilities and scope in reviewing events meant to benefit the community good.
This year's Delmarva Pride Festival is set for Saturday, June 15, from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. It's planned as a celebration of the Delmarva LGBTQ+ community and its allies during Pride Month.
The previous two Pride festivals held in Easton featured a variety of food trucks, live music, local vendors and performances. Residents and pets alike donned rainbow clothing and accessories as they celebrated in the heart of downtown Easton.
Festival organizers expect about 2,000 people to attend the 2024 festival.
COUNCIL CONTENTIONS
After the introduction of the festival's public assembly permit at Tuesday's town council meeting, Ward 3 Council Member David Montgomery raised a flag about the festival's activities in previous years.
He cited a video he'd seen that reportedly showed "overtly sexualized performances and behavior" and voiced concern about harm to children exposed to those displays.
"For these reasons, I don't believe this event as it was constituted in the past serves the common good of our town," Montgomery said.
The Ward 3 council member said he wanted to see what could be done to find a "more appropriate" location and about festival organizers' efforts to prevent similar behavior, adding that the displays were "not ones that many people want to see in this town."
Montgomery suggested postponing Delmarva Pride Center's application to a later meeting for a more thorough discussion.
Town Council President Frank Gunsallus said the council should extend the privilege of waiting to Montgomery, citing the council's precedent of tabling discussions based on members seeking more information or a deeper understanding prior to voting.
Ward 4 council member the Rev. Elmer Davis Jr. disagreed, calling it "quite unfair" to change the Pride festival's location or timing.
"I respect my colleagues, but I don't respect their opinion on this issue and this concern," he said. "I think the date and time is here and available to us, and I think we should vote on it."
Davis honed in on Montgomery's mention of young children in the context of the event, pointing out that parents had brought them to the festival.
"We are not in a position to be parental guidance for anyone; that's the parents' responsibility. We don't have oversight," he said, eliciting some claps from residents in the gallery.
Montgomery countered, saying he thought the council did have a responsibility to look at the content of festivals proposed to occur in the town. He re-emphasized his concerns about opening the festival up to minors and potentially harmful content.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook pointed out the festival's success over the last two years and a lack of complaints.
"The only complaint I ever heard was that it was such a lovely event, and it's shared with Juneteenth — he wished it was actually extended into two weekends," she said before Gunsallus began speaking over her.
"We've had an outpouring of people raising concerns in the past week," he said.
"We've also had an outpouring of support on this," Cook said, being echoed by Ward 1 Council Member Maureen Curry.
"You're right, and that's fine," Gunsallus said. "But we also have to serve everyone that has voted and put us in this position as a broader community."
Montgomery's motion to table approving the festival's permit was put to a vote, with Gunsallus seconding it. But before a roll call could be taken, Ward 2 council member Don Abbatiello chimed in.
"While I wholeheartedly disagree with waiting, and I have every intention, when we do vote on this, to vote in favor of allowing the public assembly permit to go through — if there is a member of this council who would like to wait, even if I disagree with it ... then we should wait," he said.
Though Abbatiello supported waiting because of the precedent set by the council before, he emphasized strongly that he would be voting in favor of the assembly permit as soon as possible.
Curry and Davis also emphasized their intentions to support the permit's approval, but they said they would honor Montgomery's request to wait.
VIDEO
A video of a performer from a previous festival was shown at the meeting, though it was not the same video that put Montgomery on edge. That video reportedly involved children coming up to a dancer, watching the dancer's crotch and handing money to them, he said later.
Tina Jones, a co-founder and treasurer of Delmarva Pride Center, approached the podium to try to allay the concerns voiced by some council members, tackling the questions sparked by the video.
"These are dancers, these are performers — if you decided they're something else, that's the decision you're making, but these are professionals," she said. "They are no different than a ballet dancer or somebody in a musical, and I bet you would have no problem letting a child come up with them and present flowers."
No one was "scantily clothed" either, Jones said.
Montgomery said he only asked for assurances that there would be no exhibitions like the ones reportedly in the video he referred to.
"We are not trying to groom anybody, we are not trying to change anybody's mind about who they are or what they want to be," Jones said. "We're just trying to say to folks who feel different, who feel like they don't have a place, that they do have a place, and I would love for that place to be the place where I grew up."
Montgomery later conceded to the council moving to vote, saying he doubted the council would hear anything different.
Curry initiated the motion to approve the assembly permit for the Pride festival, which was supported with resounding "ayes" from Abbatiello and Davis.
Montgomery and Gunsallus voted against approving the permit for the Pride festival, resulting in a 3-2 approval.

title: Long-awaited Easton dog park officially opens
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Long-awaited Easton dog park officially opens

 January 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 467
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Not even sub-freezing temperatures and bits of ice laying on the turf grass Thursday morning could stop over a dozen dogs — and their owners — from celebrating the grand opening of Easton's long-awaited dog park.Dogs of all ages, sizes and breeds were pulling at their leashes with energetic anticipation, waiting for the ceremonial red ribbon to be cut by Easton Mayor Megan Cook.
Thursday's ribbon cutting was a welcome sight for local dog owners and dog lovers, many of whom had waited years for the project to come to fruition.
A voiced interest in a dog park first came seven or eight years ago, said Rick Van Emburgh, the town engineer.
But in 2019, Easton residents David Ferraris and Noah Matten restarted the efforts, working with Rauch Inc., a local engineering firm, to prepare concept plans for a dog park near the downtown area.
And in fall 2020, the town received $7 million in bond funding, a majority of which was required to be allocated to parks.
Almost three years later, in March 2023, the Easton Town Council voted to fully fund the dog park on Brewers Lane and to add a restroom there, Van Emburgh said.
With the legislative work completed, construction of the dog park required a true group effort from the town's public works, parks and recreation, IT, buildings and finance departments.
Willow Construction, Easton Utilities and Chester River Landscaping also lent a hand with a number of other efforts to make the park a reality.
"I believe this is a wonderful example of teamwork," Van Emburgh said. "I believe it's a wonderful example of our community working together to build something beautiful for our town residents and our dogs."
Cook kept her comments brief, acknowledging a number of excitedly yapping dogs waiting to enter the park and play.
"I really want to give an extra shoutout to all the departments," the mayor said. "Pretty much every department in the Town of Easton played a role in getting this park up and running."
Once the ribbon was cut, the dogs were unleashed and off to play.
The new park, open dawn to dusk, includes two separate play areas for the pups based on weight, with a larger area allocated to dogs over 35 pounds.
A turf grass layer on top makes for a comfortable surface for dogs to run, jump and roll around, and underneath, there's an anti-microbial infill material and an irrigation system for cooling the turf.
It was clear that the dogs were excited as they raced in circles and made new friends, and the smiles on owners' faces told a similar story.
Easton resident Scott Cohen, who stopped by the park with his two Australian Shepherd-poodle mixes Scruffy, 4, and Casey, 3, said the dogs had a great time playing Thursday morning.
"I think it's a terrific add to the community," he said.

title: A lifetime of accomplishments in Easton
author: Staff Writer
content:
A lifetime of accomplishments in Easton

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 806
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last weekend, hundreds of friends gathered to wish former Easton Mayor Bob Willey a happy retirement.It was a forced retirement. Willey lost two elections last year, first in the mayoral race in May and then in the race for Town Council president in September.
Those elections ended 32 years in elected office in the town, first as a councilman on the Town Council for six years, followed by six years as Town Council president and then a 20-year run as mayor.
But those electoral losses should not overshadow a lifetime of accomplishments.
His list of accomplishments during those 32 years is long, just as the list of dignitaries gathered to honor him Jan. 13 was long — a proclamation from the Talbot County Council, a proclamation and shadowbox from the Town of Easton, a framed plaque of recognition from Easton Utilities and citations from state Del. Chris Adams and state Sen. Johnny Mautz.
"It's heartening to see Mayor Willey get recognition for all he's done for our town and region," Mayor Megan Cook said. "Knowing him and many of the dignitaries that have come to present, it's easy to see the positive impact and impression he's made to each of them, from the local fire department to the Senate floor."
There were honors recognizing a lifetime of devotion to Easton.
Those walking the Rails to Trails will soon see a plaque on a boulder honoring Willey for his leadership in building the well-used trail system throughout the town. A concept for the monument was shown at the retirement reception.
Easton Volunteer Fire Department dedicated its new fire engine, Engine 63, to Willey, including a plaque affixed to the side of the engine. That honor recognized 60 years of service with the volunteer fire department.
Willey joined the fire department two years after marrying Betsy Lee Thompson from Oxford on Sept. 2, 1961. The couple raised three children in Easton. That family now includes four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.
Willey was employed by Waverly Press for 41 years until retiring in March 2002.
Bob Willey was not one to boast of his accomplishments — and there were many over the years. Typical were his comments at the opening of another branch of the Rails to Trails in April last year.
"Our teams have been consistently making improvements to the beauty of the trail, while also making it more usable and safe," Willey said at the ribbon-cutting. "It will be nice to show off some of that hard work and to share it with the community."
Every day hundreds walk, run and bike along the trails through the city, which were developed under his leadership.
Perhaps it is not the trails that are his greatest accomplishment over those many years in public office. One of his lasting legacies is the unseen strong financial position of the Town of Easton.
That was not the case when Willey first became mayor in 2003.
Easton's economy was in shambles when Willey first became mayor. The town was deeply in debt. Under his fiscally conservative leadership, that dire situation turned around. Easton has not had a tax increase since 2007.
After a lifetime of accomplishments in Easton, Willey was visibly moved by the outpouring of love and support at the Jan. 13 reception.
"It means a lot," he said. "It's more than I ever could've hoped for. I'm really glad to see everyone out here enjoying themselves and having a good time. ... It really was a surprise."
There is more to do. Willey left office with some unfinished business. Others will need to pick up the mantle and complete these projects.
Affordable housing continues to be a difficult problem. In 2007, the then mayor created the Affordable Housing Commission and a low-cost home repair loan program which met with some success.
"We need to achieve more," he said last year.
And there is the new Easton hospital, which moved closer to becoming a reality last week with the state's approval of the certificate of need and the governor including $100 million in his budget proposal to make the plans happen.
Yet when the new hospital is built, the current buildings will be vacant. We like one of Willey's ideas to turn that property into a Veterans Administration facility to serve the many veterans on the Eastern Shore.
It's a great idea. It will be up to the next generation of town leaders to turn that idea — or another idea — into a workable plan.
They would be wise to look to Bob Willey's leadership over the past decades for examples of how to make that happen.
His philosophy was hidden in a comment he made at the ribbon-cutting ceremony for the Rails to Trails segment.
"This is just another step forward," Willey said referring to the added trail. "It's going to get better."
That is a philosophy for success in leading a town — keep taking steps forward and believe that it's going to get better.

title: Legislation seeks to make persimmons the state fruit
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Legislation seeks to make persimmons the state fruit

 January 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sen. Arthur Ellis (D-Charles) introduced a bill on the first day of the General Assembly that would create something that Maryland has never had before — a state fruit.Native to Maryland, persimmons can be found just about everywhere in the state, with the exception of Garrett County due to the mountainous nature of the region.
In May and June, persimmon trees flower, but the fruit isn't ready until the fall, leading to many seasonal recipes and drinks. Persimmons have especially been used for fine wines, jams and baked goods.
The trees are known for their resilience, being able to thrive for years when they are below the canopy of a forest.
Prices for persimmons have gone up significantly in recent years, reaching about $6 per pound, and many have not heard how easy it may be to source their own, according to Ellis.
"I have persimmon trees in my yard," Ellis said. "They grow naturally, and they're beautiful and delicious."
Ellis introduced the legislation to raise awareness for the fruit, as many Marylanders do not realize it is a part of their state and its history.
Indigenous people of the region used the fruit not only for food but medicinally as well. Sore throats and indigestion were common ailments that the use of persimmons attempted to treat.
Throughout the Civil War, persimmon seeds were used as a coffee substitute when trade routes were impacted.
The usefulness of the persimmon tree doesn't end with the fruit. The wood of the tree is extremely strong, and is commonly used within shoes, golf clubs, flooring and musical instruments.
If Senate Bill 74 makes it through both state legislative houses and is signed by the governor, it would become effective Oct. 1.

title: League of Women Voters holds training for election info website
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
League of Women Voters holds training for election info website

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News

 CENTREVILLE — A group of women came together to get trained on how to run a spin-free election information portal called Vote 411. They came with laptops from as far as Frederick and St. Mary's counties to be ready for this year's primary election on May 14.This exacting and meticulous training is what the nonprofit the League of Women Voters is all about. They hold the power to vote as sacred and nonpartisan information about that vote to be integral.
"The goal is to provide training for the people that are going to be doing the voters guide and inputting information in the Vote 411 website," said the president of the Queen Anne's County League of Women Voters, Elizabeth Hammond.
"This is it for in-person training. There will be an online training on Saturday, Jan. 20. I think it is a good idea to do both of them," Hammond said.
She said the organization gets donations to do this work and create the voters guide both online and in print.
"We insert it in the Record Observer and then order about 500 extra copies and distribute them to towns and post offices and various other public places to pick up and get information to make intelligent decisions about what they want to vote for," Hammond said.
She is clear about the big picture of voting rights.
"Voting is one of the freedoms that we absolutely cherish. You want to be able to make a responsible decision and vote for the candidate that you think can do the best job. That is what we try to do with the voter's guide — to give the voters the best information possible in a nonpartisan way," Hammond said.
She said this primary election will be smaller than the general election, which will have a more involved voter's guide.
The state Board of Elections is the ultimate authority for the League of Women Voters.
"It amazing what the state Board does. What the election boards do is amazing, and they really deserve all the support we can give them and their thanks. That's why you watch the candidate listings on the state board, because that is what is going to show up, and then the proof comes when they send out the individual ballots for each county. The hard thing is you have to look through each one of those ballots. It is like 200 pages long," said Jeanne Halpin of the League of Women Voters of Maryland.
She led the training that took place at the Queen Anne's County Public Library in Centreville.
She tried to be less daunting to all the volunteers that showed up across the state.
"This is just a great learning opportunity. Don't get stressed, don't go crazy. The political parties are nominating candidates. They are asking people to run. In both the primary and the general," Halpin said.

title: Second amendment introduced for Lakeside unit resolution
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Second amendment introduced for Lakeside unit resolution

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Environment 
 
 764
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A second amendment to previously introduced legislation relating to the number of equivalent dwelling units in each phase of development at Lakeside at Trappe was introduced Tuesday by two Talbot County Council members.The amendment, requested by council Vice President Pete Lesher and introduced by him and council member Lynn Mielke, would modify the still-pending Resolution 347 to incorporate provisions of separate, but related, Lakeside legislation — Resolution 338 and its amendment — into its language.
The original version of Resolution 347, first introduced last September, would amend the county's comprehensive plan to include the number of equivalent dwelling units for each phase of development at Lakeside, though the numbers for Phases 2 through 6 are estimated.
It also provides the current water and sewer classifications for each phase. A total of 2,874 equivalent dwelling units are planned at Lakeside.
The language to be incorporated from Resolution 338 proposes amending the county's comprehensive water and sewer plan to be consistent with the Maryland Department of the Environment's discharge permit for Lakeside's wastewater treatment plant.
The permit, issued in October 2022, is limited to the project's first phase and allows for an annual average flow of 100,000 gallons per day, or roughly 250 gallons per day per equivalent dwelling unit, only allowing for roughly 400 residential units to be built.
A major permit modification approved by the Maryland Department of the Environment is required for any future expansion of the wastewater treatment plant.
Resolution 338's provisions also would mandate any future expansion of the new plant to require a comprehensive water and sewer plan amendment.
The resolution's amendment, introduced in November, adds language requiring a certification from the Talbot County Planning Commission of the amendment's consistency with the county's comprehensive plan.
At Tuesday's council meeting, Lesher emphasized that none of the language proposed to be added to Resolution 347 via its second amendment is new. It's a different way to help the county's Planning Commission come to a finding of consistency, he said.
Resolution 347, though considered in a multi-hour Planning Commission meeting last October, has yet to receive any final determination of consistency, which is required when amending the county's comprehensive water and sewer plan.
Multiple postponements of discussion on the legislation have lengthened the process, though the amended language of Resolution 338 was found consistent by the Planning Commission in December.
"This simply gives an alternative for the Planning Commission to say, 'Yes, with this language, if you combine it, we can find this consistent,'" Lesher said. "They may find Resolution 347 consistent without this amendment, they may find it consistent both without and with this amendment. If we get those alternatives, we then have that option to act at the council level."
The need for Resolution 347 stems from a request from the Maryland Department of the Environment last spring.
The agency asked the county to submit updated phase information and figures for water and sewer services with corrected classifications for all parcels within Trappe, including Lakeside, in a comprehensive water and sewer plan amendment.
Related legislation, Resolution 348, addresses the incorrect water and sewer classifications of parcels shown in two exhibits to Resolution 281, the original legislation approving a wastewater treatment plant for Lakeside under a draft discharge permit.
"Without that finding of consistency though, this resolution doesn't reach our desk," Lesher added, "and we don't have that way of bringing closure to the outstanding issues from MDE that will allow us to finish that Report of the Review."
Council Member Keasha Haythe questioned the need to add language from Resolution 338 into Resolution 347, saying the addition seemed to be the opposite of what the Maryland Department of the Environment requested.
The Town of Trappe is not on the same page as the county regarding the resolutions, she pointed out. Later, Haythe confirmed that the initial resolutions proposed were in line with what the agency wanted from the county.
The county's Planning Commission and the Public Works Advisory Board are set to discuss the two pending resolutions and amendments in a joint meeting on Wednesday, Feb. 7, at 11 a.m.
A public hearing on all three Lakeside resolutions and amendments will be held at 6:30 p.m. at the Tuesday, Feb. 13, County Council meeting.
Following Tuesday's meeting, council President Chuck Callahan issued a statement on the pending legislation.
"We understand that the resolutions regarding the county's comprehensive water and sewer plan and the Town of Trappe can be difficult to follow. It is a complicated matter with a lengthy history," he said in the statement. "The council looks forward to addressing this matter on Feb. 13, 2024, and resolving the concerns raised by the Maryland Department of the Environment."

title: Federalsurg water lines go dry as pump fails
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Federalsurg water lines go dry as pump fails

 January 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 353
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The Town of Federalsburg remains without running water Monday morning despite efforts to fix a failed well and restore pressure.The problem began Friday night after a power outage at the town's water and sewage plant. The power outage depleted water in the system and left air in the lines.
Mayor Kim Abner said an alert system did not go off Friday night when one of the town's water pumps failed to work. She said currently all three pumps are working and that they are pumping 600,000 gallons to fill the system. She said Department of Emergency Services was distributing water to people.
Abner said Monday morning that she expects the water to be back soon. Abner said an investigation will be undertaken to figure out why this happened so it can be avoided in the future.
She said the town staff and council members have been pitching in to help people get water.
The latest Facebook post reported progress at 9:30 a.m. Monday.
"Staff will be delivering meals. Meals will be at fire department. All three wells are back online and pressure is coming up," the post read. "We are now pumping 500 gallons a minute, but we need to fill the water towers and lines that were empty. It will take time, but we are making progress."
Bottled water for pick up is available at Federalsburg Volunteer Fire Department Company at noon.
Abner is telling people not to turn on their faucets yet to allow pressure to build up in the pipes.
A Facebook statement from the mayor, council and staff said, "Water conditions have not improved like they should have. We have called in a well specialist for assistance. In the meantime, we are working on sourcing drinking water for our residents. Once we have a distribution location, we will let you know. We sincerely apologize for any inconvenience and appreciate your understanding. Staff worked tirelessly yesterday (Sunday) to try to restore services and truly thought time would have allowed the lines to fill and restore pressure."
Abner said some people have been calm and some have been agitated on Facebook, but that solutions are in progress.

San Domingo Park project plans move to Board of Zoning Appeals

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 513
