 ST. MICHAELS — The Town of St. Michaels Planning Commission has found that plans for San Domingo Creek Park are consistent with the town's comprehensive plan.At a meeting Thursday, the Planning Commission voted unanimously on this.
The 7.6 acre property at 201 Boundary Lane was purchased for $2.9 million by the town last year.
The town plans to use the existing building on the property for a new town office. The remainder of the property will be a public park, complete with nature trails, expanded wetlands, a living shoreline, a fishing pier, a comfort station and associated parking.
In late January, the Commissioners of St. Michaels voted to approve a final master plan for the park, as well as a $1.7 million open space grant application to help fund the project.
With the Planning Commission's vote Thursday, the Board of Zoning Appeals will now be able to vote on a request made by the Commissioners of St. Michaels to allow town administration offices and parks and recreation facilities on the property as a special exception.
At the meeting, Town Planner Steve Ball said that in order for this request to go to the Board of Zoning Appeals, the Planning Commission needed to determine that the proposed plans for the property are consistent with the town's comprehensive plan.
Ball gave a brief overview of his findings in reviewing the town's current comprehensive pan.
He said that although there is nothing in the comprehensive plan that specifically addresses the Boundary Lane site — as the project wasn't anticipated when the comprehensive plan was last updated — there were four chapters within the comprehensive plan that he believes prove the project is consistent with the comprehensive plan.
Specifically, Ball pointed to the chapters on municipal growth, environmental resources, climate resistance and parks and recreation.
He said the project is consistent with municipal growth because a part of the property will be annexed into the town.
When it comes to environmental resources in the town, Ball said the park will provide buffers, create stormwater filtration and protect and enhance wetland areas. For climate resistance, he said the park will have a living shoreline to help with sea level rise.
With parks and recreation, Ball said the master plan for the park will give residents the opportunity to enjoy the natural environment. He said the park will enhance the existing town park facilities.
"It also allows for the town's trail system to be expanded for the community," he said.
After Ball presented his findings, Planning Commission Chair Christopher Thomas said he wanted to make it clear that the Planning Commission wasn't voting on the specifics of the master plan, but on whether the project plans, overall, are consistent with the town's comprehensive plan.
"I think that's important to note," he said.
Before making the motion to acknowledge the project plans are consistent with the comprehensive plan, Planning Commission Vice Chair John Novak said he didn't see any contradictions, adding that the project makes economic sense for the town too.
"Using an existing building instead of building an entire new town office for $2 million plus, I think it makes economic sense," he said.

title: A renewed call for openness in government
author: Staff Writer
content:
A renewed call for openness in government

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 765
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Open Meetings Compliance Board this week ruled the state law requiring government bodies to conduct business in public did not apply to a Nov. 13 meeting of the Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.'s Nov. 13 meeting which included all members of the Dorchester County Council and a non-quorum of the Cambridge City Council.The Star Democrat and WHCP, the NPR partner in Cambridge, filed a complaint alleging that the meeting — or most of it — should have been open to the public. The board ruled that the development corporation is not a public body and the meeting was not a "meeting" of the County Council.
"Thus, the Act's requirements did not apply," the ruling stated.
The meeting was convened by the Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. board to discuss issues related to developing the prime acreage along the Choptank River at the entrance to the city. The project envisions public spaces like a promenade and parks, a boutique hotel that has a restaurant and bar, and residential and mixed-use spaces along the river.
The Nov. 13 meeting included all members of the County Council. A quorum of the City Council was present, but one of the members left so those remaining would be in compliance with the state open meeting laws. The council members present had voted that they believed the meeting was in violation of the open meeting law.
CWDI, a nonprofit that was formed by the city of Cambridge, Dorchester County and the state of Maryland, has been tasked with planning and developing space along the Cambridge waterfront, known as Cambridge Harbor. Plans include public spaces like a promenade and parks, a boutique hotel and residential and mixed-use spaces along the Choptank River.
CWDI Executive Director Matt Leonard said that during the meeting, CWDI talked about business deals it is working on.
Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said he was glad to see the decision that was made.
"There was never an intention for the Dorchester County Council to be violating any confidence of trust," he said.
Yet the County Council did violate the public's confidence, and the Open Meetings Compliance Board noted so in its conclusion, saying: "Although the Act did not apply to this discussion, the appearance that business was being conducted secretly did not serve the purpose of the Act 'to increase the faith of the public in government.'"
The ruling added: "Our conclusion in no way condones the action of a quorum of the [Councilmembers] in creating what was, at the least, an appearance of impropriety."
That appearance of impropriety is harmful to a project that is much needed in Cambridge. The successful — and financially sound — development of the 35-acre parcel is critical to the city's future.
Some good things have already followed the filing of the complaint. We have seen more openness from the development corporation. The group has begun publishing monthly letters detailing what the CWDI board is working on with Cambridge Harbor.
"We plan to keep the public informed on our progress and what you can look forward to in the coming months/year," said the Jan. 29 letter, signed by CWDI President Angie Hengst.
There are crucial discussions ahead, especially about how the projects will be funded. Talk has been to use tax increment financing where property taxes on the land is frozen for decades with the increased taxes generated by the project going to pay off loans financing the development of the property.
A rift between the city and the CWDI has developed over recent months, perhaps a reflection of the previous secretive nature of the development corporation. Perhaps it is growing concern in the city about the long-term effects of tax increment financing.
The widening rift and a proposed city ordinance that CWDI opposes prompted current Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. city-appointed board member Shay Lewis-Sisco to attend the Jan. 8 council meeting.
"CWDI is doing things to meet the needs of what the commissioners are asking, as well as working diligently to strengthen the relationship between the city and CWDI," she said. "I do believe, as we've stated in previous meetings outside of the council meeting, that we all have the same heart and the same mind to see, not only CWDI's project come to fruition, but that the community also benefits and it makes sense for the city at large."
We, too, hope the project comes to fruition. Its success depends on more openness by Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. and all of the government agencies it partners with. It would be a mistake for those involved to take the Open Meetings Compliance board ruling as an invitation to be more secretive and less transparent to the public.

 DENTON — Among the agenda items discussed during the Denton Town Council meeting Thursday, Feb. 1, were flood resilience, expanding water and sewer to West Denton and providing town law enforcement officers with enhanced portable radios.Two ordinances were introduced and received unanimous consent to move forward.
Ordinance 751 would amend the code's subdivision code to allow shared access for minor subdivisions and improved right of way, which is not a component of the town, county state or federal road system.
In Ordinance 752, the town council amended the town code with two updated official zoning maps that align with the Comprehensive Plan adopted Dec. 11.
In December, the town council adopted the 2020 Comprehensive Plan, following a process that had been held up during the Covid pandemic.
The council green-lighted the first step in working with the Federal Emergency Management Agency in Philadelphia to receive free technical assistance through a memorandum of understanding.
Town Administrator Wayne Getchell said his "key takeaway ... will be that (FEMA) will come on site and do a needs assessment in our areas that we struggle with flooding in and around the Choptank, and develop an action plan that would be consistent with their grant program."
The second step would be to apply for FEMA money "to make whatever improvements are found to be made," but the 3-year MOU "was required by them to get started," Getchell said.
Crisfield is the only other town on the Eastern Shore who is working on a similar MOU with FEMA, he said.
The council approved the purchase of new portable radios for the Denton Police Department.
Bacorn asked the council to approve the purchase of 16 Motorola portable radios, 13 for officers, two for office staff and one to have on hand as a spare.
The radios will replace the 6-year-old BK Technologies radios "which have been failing regularly and without warning, which causes safety concerns," McNinch said.
Bacorn said the old radios were unreliable, and "as of late, they have been feeling, and they don't give any warning. We've had officers out on traffic stops who couldn't be contacted, on calls where they couldn't be contacted."
Bacorn said up to 75% of the $107,425 pricetag could be covered by grant money from the US Department of Agriculture. Even so, Getchell said ARPA (American Rescue Plan Act) funds were available, enabling the town to commit to ordering them. It will be Bacorn said the "backbone of Caroline County's radio system is a Motorola system. The compatibility is just better, the features are much better. So we're looking to upgrade and, more importantly, increase officers' safety."

title: Voters should decide who represents them in Annapolis
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Voters should decide who represents them in Annapolis

 February 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 654
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the 2024 General Assembly session, discussion is again underway on changing the roles and responsibilities of local Republican central committees and local Democratic central committees.The primary focus of these committees has historically been on recruiting and supporting political candidates.
Under current law, local central committees also have a key role to play whenever a vacancy occurs in the General Assembly resulting from "death, disqualification, resignation, refusal to act, or expulsion of a state senator or delegate, or in the case of a senator's or delegate's removal from the city or county from which he or she was elected."
When that occurs, the local central committee or central committees in the legislative district with the same party affiliation as the departed member are charged with making a recommendation to the governor on a replacement. The recommended individual must have the same party affiliation as the departed member. The governor, in turn, "must, in accordance with specified procedures, appoint a person affiliated with the same political party to serve the remainder of the vacating senator's or delegate's unexpired term."
Such appointments are far more common than one might think.
Of the 188 members currently serving in the General Assembly, almost one fourth were not elected by the voters, but were appointed to fill a vacancy and complete an unexpired term.
Even more vacancy appointments may occur in 2024 if incumbent General Assembly members win bids for other offices and resign from their present office.
Reaching consensus in changes to the current vacancy process has been and is elusive. Presently, there are three proposals under active consideration, each with supporters and opponents.
One proposal would allow central committees to fill vacancies but would require public notice of vacancies and information on a central committee's application and interview process. It would require central committee interviews and votes to be open to the public and central committee members who apply to fill a vacancy to recuse themselves from the recommendation vote.
Another proposal would allow central committees to continue to fill vacancies but subject their recommendations to voter ratification under certain circumstances. Recommendations made in the first two years of an unexpired term would be subject to voter approval in the next presidential election. In the second two years of the unexpired term, the appointed individual would have the option of running in the next state election.
A third proposal would replace the current appointment process with special elections. If the vacancy occurs within the first three years of a term, voters in the district would fill that vacancy through special primary and general elections. If the vacancy occurs within the fourth year, central committees would name an initial replacement who would have to run for election in the next primary election. This proposal requires an amendment to the state constitution which needs a three-fifths vote of approval in the House and the Senate then voter approval in a statewide referendum.
Concerns have been raised about this third proposal based on estimated costs incurred by local and state boards of elections to administer multiple special elections.
The General Assembly is currently discussing a proposed $63.1 billion annual state budget. They also are discussing moving forward on an additional $3.8 billion in new state and local funding for public education over the next 10 years as mandated by the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (the Kirwan Report).
Emily Scarr at the Maryland Public Interest Research Group recently opined that special elections are "the cost of having a democracy. People have [a right] to vote for who represents them. It's a fundamental thing and if we're not spending money to ensure that right, what are we doing?"
I agree.
Now is the time to address the outsized role of political central committees and the governor in the process to fill vacancies in the General Assembly.
The way to do that is a new process that maximizes opportunities to let the voters decide.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant. He lives in Easton.

title: Dorchester County Council introduces rental registration legislation, zoning code amendment
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester County Council introduces rental registration legislation, zoning code amendment

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 614
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Council introduced two housing-related pieces of legislation at its meeting on Feb. 6.The first piece of legislation deals with rental properties. If passed, vacant buildings, short-term rentals and rental units would need to be registered with the county annually.
Short-term rentals are defined as properties that are rented for more than 15 days and less than 30 days.
County Planning and Zoning Director Susan Webb said the intent of creating these three different registrations is life safety and property maintenance. She said that with this registration, the county would be able to contact property managers in case of an emergency.
"Right now we don't have anything," she said. "If there's a vacant property out there, and there's a fire and the person lives out of state or out of the area, we have no way of contacting them."
Webb said the registration would also keep property owners accountable when it comes to property maintenance and following county codes and regulations.
"We don't get a lot of complaints about rental properties, but when we do, they're deplorable," she said.
Webb said although code enforcers aren't firemen and policemen, creating these registries and being proactive can help save lives.
Currently, the county doesn't know how many vacant and rental properties there are in the county, Webb said.
"We need to see how many we do have, and how much time and manpower we have to put into these properties," she said.
Because of this, Webb said the Council might have to revisit this legislation in the future to make it stronger.
The second piece of legislation would amend the zoning chapter of the county code to lessen restrictions on residential accessory structures.
Webb said 75% of the county's Board of Appeals cases in the past two years have been for accessory structures that are greater than what is allowed by county code. She said this has incurred more legal fees for the county and made meetings longer.
"We need to make a difference," she said. "I mean we've had some meetings that have gone later than 10 o'clock at night because the agenda's so big."
Webb said she thinks this amendment would provide relief to both property owners and county staff.
If passed, the amendment would make it so that, for lot size of up to 1.99 acres, a residential accessory structure could not exceed 200% of the building footprint of the principal residential structure.
For a lot size of two acres to 4.99 acres, a residential accessory structure could not exceed 300% of the building footprint of the principal residential structure.
For a lot size of five acres or more, a residential accessory structure could not exceed 500% of the building footprint of the principal residential structure.
According to current county code, for suburban residential, suburban residential-RCA, rural residential and rural residential-RCA zoning districts, the sum total of residential accessory structures on a property cannot exceed the building footprint of the principal residential structure or 1,200 square feet, whichever is greater, without a special exception by the Board of Appeals.
For agricultural conservation, agricultural conservation-RCA, resource conservation, resource conservation-RCA and rural residential-conservation zoning districts, the sum total of residential accessory structures on a property cannot exceed the building footprint of the principal residential structure or 1,600 square feet, whichever is greater, without a special exception by the Board of Appeals.
At the meeting, Council Vice President Mike Detmer verified the amendment would not give anyone permission to use the residential accessory structure for commercial use.
"Absolutely not," Webb said in response. "Every permit that comes into the office, I review and sign off on use to make sure that is compliant with zoning."
Council President Lenny Pfeffer said public hearings will be held for both of these pieces of legislation.

title: Candidates file for May primary election

Candidates file for May primary election

 EASTON — Voters across the state and on the Mid-Shore will have a full slate of candidates to vote for in this year's upcoming elections.Although 2024 will be marked nationally by a presidential election, Maryland residents will be casting their ballots for a U.S. senator and congressional representative. Locally, Mid-Shore residents will be voting for new county Board of Education members.
Maryland's primary election will be held on Tuesday, May 14, from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Early primary voting will run from Thursday, May 2, to Thursday, May 9.

U.S. Senate
The race for the next U.S. senator is a crowded one — 10 Democrats and eight Republicans have filed to run for the seat being vacated by current U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin. Three candidates not affiliated with either party have filed to run.
Several candidates are previous or current elected officials.
Congressional District 1Incumbent Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican, is seeking to maintain his position representing the 1st District. He's not without challengers, though — four others have filed in the hopes of winning the seat.
Blane Miller and Blessing T. Oluwadare, both Democrats from Harford County, filed to run against Harris. Fellow Harford County resident Chris Bruneau Sr. is running in the race as a Republican.
Caroline County resident Michael Scott Lemon, a Republican, is hoping to win the seat.
Talbot County Board of EducationSeven candidates have filed to run in this year's election for the three open seats in District 2, District 5 and District 6 on the Talbot County Board of Education.
In District 2, incumbent Board of Education member and current Vice president Candace Henry is running for reelection to her seat. Residents Connie Loveland and Ann C. O'Connor also filed to run for the seat.
In District 5, current Board of Education member Anna Howie is running for her first full term on the board. Howie was appointed to the District 5 seat last October after former Board President Susan Delean-Botkin vacated the district seat.
Trappe resident Karla Wieland-Cherry is Howie's sole challenger in the District 5 race.
The Board's District 6 seat will be the only one definitely seeing a new face after this year's election — incumbent board member Mary Wheeler did not file to run again.
Easton residents Kerry Gunshenan and Cynthia Marrah Jurrius will face off for the District 6 seat.
Dorchester County Board of EducationEight candidates filed for the three open seats on the Dorchester County Board of Education. Incumbents from each district are running to maintain their seats on the board.
In Councilmanic District 1, current board President Michael Diaz Sr. is running for reelection. Diaz is being challenged by Brandy Dawson Cumberland and Lucas Thorpe.
In Councilmanic District 3, current board Vice President Susan V. Morgan is vying for reelection. Cambridge resident Christine LaMonica is seeking the seat as well.
Chris Wheedleton, the incumbent Councilmanic District 5 board member who was appointed to his seat last year, is running for a full term on the board in this year's election. Candidates Jerome J. Harris and Michael Hartford also are running for the open seat.
Caroline County Board of EducationAlthough the terms of three members of the five-member Caroline County Board of Education are ending this year, only two are up for election by the public: the District 1 and District 2 seats.
A third seat opening up this year will be filled by gubernatorial appointment.
No candidates have filed to run for the District 1 seat.
In District 2, Stefanie D. Johnson is the sole candidate seeking the open seat.

title: Oxford votes on two items at Commissioners meeting
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford votes on two items at Commissioners meeting

 February 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 612
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — At a Commissioners of Oxford meeting Tuesday evening, the Commissioners approved an ordinance that establishes zoning regulations for cannabis businesses as well as an application for FEMA technical assistance.CANNABIS BUSINESSES ZONING ORDINANCE
The Commissioners approved an ordinance on zoning regulations for cannabis businesses that would permit cannabis dispensaries and processing facilities as a special exception in Oxford's general commercial zoning districts (C-2).
The ordinance would also permit growing facilities as a special exception in Oxford's commercial industrial district.
A nine-month cannabis moratorium, which temporarily blocked applications, site plans, permits, construction, processing and approval for businesses looking to manufacture or sell recreational or medicinal cannabis in Oxford, will run its course at the end of month.
Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan said that Oxford must establish reasonable zoning regulations for cannabis businesses and not be more burdensome than the town's regulations on similar businesses.
Under this ordinance, each applicant will have to come to the Board of Appeals to prove the business meets the criteria of a special exception, which includes the most appropriate use of land building and structure, adequate ingress and egress, and adequate utilities.
FEMA ASSISTSNCE
The Commissioners also voted to apply for the FEMA Building Resilient Infrastructure and Communities Direct Technical Assistance application.
This program provides a wide range of non-financial support to communities that may not have the resources to begin climate resilience planning.It will deliver up to 36 months of technical assistance for the town.
Identified hazards for Oxford include erosion, flood, hurricane winds, rising sea levels and storm surge.
PUBLIC COMMENT
Transparency was a theme throughout public comment at the town meeting Tuesday. Residents asked questions about the town's stormwater management and how the town receives and uses grant monies.
At the beginning of public comment, resident Deborah Pulzone read a letter addressed to the Commissioners of Oxford and the town's citizens. In her letter, Pulzone said that for 2021 and 2022, there was only one Maryland Public Information Act filed. In contrast, from Jan. 1, 2023 to Jan. 30 of this year, Pulzone said 30 PIAs were filed.
"It is obvious that these PIAs have become weaponized," she said. "It appears they were made for the sole purpose of keeping our town employees preoccupied with busy paperwork, thereby making it extremely difficult to function in a productive and cost-effective manner."
After Pulzone received an applause from some residents for her comments, resident Jan Greenhawk said that although she has never written a PIA, the people who have filed them have done so for a reason.
"We don't have anything against our employees," she said. "In fact, our employees do a great job. But the problem is, when you don't have transparency, and when decisions are made that no one understands or knows about, then people will ask questions. And if they don't think they can get the answers, then they file PIAs."
Greenhawk said it is the right of town residents to ask questions.
While Greenhawk was speaking, a moment of tension between her and Pulzone caused Commission President Tom Costigan to say, "Please keep it civil."
Like Pulzone, Greenhawk also received an applause from some residents for her comments.
LIVING SHORELINE
During the meeting Tuesday, Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said resident Jennifer Stanley will be installing a living shoreline to prevent erosion across the front of her property. Lewis said Stanley is willing to extend the living shoreline to include the end of First Street, which is owned by the town.
Lewis said Stanley knows the end of First Street is used to take out kayaks and other small boats, and so Stanley would incorporate that into the design.
Stanley is asking the commissioners if they would like her to extend the shoreline, Lewis said. This would not be a cost to the town.

 OXFORD — Cheryl Lewis, Oxford's town manager of more than a decade, will be retiring June 30.Lewis, who has worked for the town since 2012, made the announcement at a Commissioners of Oxford meeting Tuesday.
Before making the announcement, Lewis discussed the town's progress in hiring four open positions in the town, including a planning and zoning coordinator, a clerk-treasurer and a police chief.
"As you can see, I'm kind of working through a transition of replacements," Lewis said.
Over the next several months, Lewis plans to get the town administration positions filled so that she can set up a "somewhat seamless" transition, where people have been hired and trained for their roles before she leaves.
ADMINISTRATIVE POSITIONS
During the meeting, Lewis said the planning and zoning coordinator position has been filled.
In an interview Wednesday, Lewis said Marilyn Williams from the Wicomico County Department of Planning, Zoning and Community Development has been hired for the job.
The position, which was previously held by Maria Brophy, Lewis' daughter, was posted on Dec. 28. Lewis said at the meeting Tuesday that Williams will begin working at the end of February.
The clerk-treasurer is a new position for the Town of Oxford.
At the meeting Tuesday, Lewis said she has recommended to the commissioners that the town try to hire clerk-treasurer by the end of February so that person can begin working by the end of March.
According to the job posting on the town's website, the new hire will be tasked with directing and managing the town's finances under the town manager's direction and implementing policy set by the Commissioners of Oxford. The clerk-treasurer will act as the chief financial officer of the town.
The creation of this position was talked about at a Jan. 11 Commissioners meeting, when Commissioner Katrina Greer said she wanted to discuss the possibility of hiring someone to take on the town's financial duties.
At the Jan. 11 meeting, Greer said this could address a material weakness detailed in the town's audit for the town's lack of internal controls. This has been a finding in town audits going back to 2016.
Once the town has brought in a planning and zoning coordinator and a clerk-treasurer, Lewis said she recommends the town advertise for a new town manager. At the meeting Tuesday, she said the town manager would "replace the remaining bits and pieces" of her job, which would be split up by having three town administration positions, not including an administrative assistant.
"I do believe, in order to seamlessly move forward, that you will need to bring in three people," she said. "You're going to have to disburse the workload. You can't just have a person come and replace me and pick up all three of these pieces."
Lewis said there have not been any discussions yet regarding the salary range for the town manager position, but she said it will be included in the job posting. According to the clerk-treasurer job posting, the estimated salary range for that position is $60,000 to $80,000 per year.
OTHER OPEN POSITIONS
The town is also in need of a new police chief and a new public works member.
Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner stepped down from his position in January for "personal and professional reasons," but is staying with the police department as an officer. The department's Lieutenant Chris Phillips has stepped up as interim chief.
At the meeting Tuesday, Lewis said she planned to post the chief position online Wednesday and hopes the town can hire a new chief by mid-March so that person can begin working in April.
Mike McWilliams, will be leaving the town's Public Works Department. Public Works Wastewater Superintendent Matt Ozman said McWilliams came to work for Oxford from the City of Cambridge and is going back to the City of Cambridge.
Lewis said she hopes to get the job posting up for McWilliams' position in the next week or two.
Toward the end of the meeting, Greer thanked Lewis for the "well thought out" transition plans.
Commissioner Susan Delean-Botkin said she had worked with Lewis for 12 years now.
"I've worked for a lot of people in my 50 years of business," she said. "And I have never met anyone as confident and as caring as you are to this town. Thank you. Thank you for this transition."
After Delean-Botkin spoke, the room erupted in applause.

title: Senate candidate Angela Alsobrooks appeals to Eastern Shore voters
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Senate candidate Angela Alsobrooks appeals to Eastern Shore voters

 539

 CHESTERTOWN — "I'm not so easy to push around. I've been in spaces now and held my own," said Democratic candidate for U.S. Senate in Maryland Angela Alsobrooks.Approaching the May primaries, she is one of several candidates vying to represent Democrats in the race for the state's open senate seat.
"This race is not only important to the state of Maryland, but to the country," Alsobrooks said.
On Sunday, she spoke at a meet-and-greet hosted by the Democratic Club of Kent County held at Minary's Dream Alliance in Chestertown.
Her opponent, Democrat David Trone, who has represented Maryland's 6th Congressional District in the House of Representatives since 2019, spoke at Washington College back in Dec. 7.
As reported by Washington College press, Trone stressed working across the aisle on issues like the opioid epidemic, drug and alcohol addiction, mental health issues, criminal justice reform, structural racism, climate crisis and education.
Alsobrooks, a former two-term state's attorney, expressed passion for some of the same things, growing economic opportunity, investing in education and making sure people are safe.
Like Trone, Alsobrooks encouraged reaching out to Republicans on important issues. She saw that differing perspectives are not something to run from.
Alsobrooks brought up many bipartisan opportunities in the future and some in the past lost over partisan politics.
In healthcare, Republicans worked to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, she said.
On Economic Issues, there are infrastructure bills both can agree on, she said.
In poreign policy, they need people who can exercise a diplomacy-first approach.
"Freedom defines our way of life as Americans. America needs to be a strong leader around the world and protect our allies," she said.
Alsobrooks noted Ukraine as an ally, and the need to support them against Russian President Vladimir Putin. She said Isreal is an ally that needs support as well.
Alsobrooks wants her experience to speak for itself, but she said she is aware her history as a Black woman plays a role. If elected, she said she'll stand in the gap for rights she said are under attack, such as voting rights and LGBTQ rights.
"There's no women representing us. Our delegation is talented but not diverse. Of the eight congressmen and two senators, all are men. It is time to send a woman to Washington so our lived experiences are there. I believe every one of us should look at the State and see ourselves. Every race, gender, background, socioeconomic level, makes us stronger if all of us are represented."
Alsobrooks went on to address former Governor, Republican Larry Hogan, who announced his intentions to run for Senate seat on Feb.9.
Some pundits have speculated if he wins the Republican primary, that would force Democrats to divert resources usually spent in other states.
Hogan, who Minority Leader Mitch McConnell said was the "get of the year," as put by Alsobrooks, would help Republicans gain a majority in the Senate.
Senior Adviser of her campaign David Sloan pointed out that Kent County went blue for former president Barack Obama in 2008.
"On May 14, this county's going green for Angela Alsobrooks," he said.
Alsobrooks said, "I can really make a difference to our state. In a body that needs a difference-maker I can shake loose some of the gridlock in Washington."
Alsobrooks' next stop was in Easton, capping off her Eastern Shore visit.

 STEVENSVILLE — Phase 1 of the deck replacement on the eastbound Bay Bridge is underway with an anticipated completion date in spring 2025.The first section, on the Eastern Shore side of the eastbound span, is almost one mile of the overall 4.35-mile-long bridge. During construction, the project will utilize off-peak lane closures during the day to get work areas ready to ensure successful night work.
The eastbound span will close at night, weather permitting, with two-way traffic in effect on the westbound span. Crews will remove at least one section of the deck and replace it with a new precast section during the same overnight shift.
During construction, the project will utilize existing off-peak lane closures during the day to get work areas ready to ensure successful night work.
Weather permitting, when the eastbound span closes at night, two-way traffic will be on the westbound span. Temporary joint-connection grates will be utilized for this crucial work, allowing for travel lanes to reopen each morning and for a smoother driving transition across work areas.
While the work is significant, the MDTA has designed the project to limit traffic impacts while maximizing safety for contractors and customers during this crucial work.
Cranes are in place and visible while crossing the bridge. Transportation Authority officials urge drivers to be alert and not distracted by construction.
Work is underway to relocate existing electrical power, communication and fiber-optic lines from the roadway barriers to a dedicated utility corridor.
Relocation of the utilities will not only eliminate the need for temporary relocation during construction of the new roadway deck and barriers; the under deck location will be accessed for maintenance activities without working in a temporary roadway closure.
Installation of the new conduits will be staged from the water, with barges and cranes used to lift material and equipment to temporary under-deck platforms located adjacent to the access catwalk. Almost 10 miles of new conduit will be installed as part of this project.
A top priority of the Transportation Authority is protecting the environment. For the eastbound deck replacement project, the MDTA is using environmentally sensitive technologies and construction practices to reduce environmental impacts on plants and wildlife in the vicinity of the Bay Bridge and beyond. As part of the Maryland Artificial Reef Program, the MDTA will recycle deck panels removed during this project.
These deck panels will be deposited at the existing Love Point artificial reef located in an approximately 20-25 feet deep, 50-acre area in the Chesapeake Bay northeast of the Bay Bridge. It is estimated that approximately 145,000 square feet of deck will be deposited.
A Stormwater Management Plan includes a 1.04 acre pocket pond that is proposed to address the stormwater management needs of the deck replacement project. The pocket pond will be constructed in a grassy area bounded by U.S. Route 50 westbound lanes, Revell Highway, and the ramp from Oceanic Drive to westbound Route 50 on the western shore.
The pocket pond will provide treatment of runoff from existing, untreated pavement owned by the MDTA along westbound Route 50 and improve the hydrology in this area.
As part of the landscape management plan, turf grass will be planted and native grass species will be established around the pond including tussock sedge, pickerelweed, arrow arum, lizard's tail and soft stem bulrush. On the Eastern Shore, an approximately 1.1 acre site will be treated for invasive species and replanted with native species.
Additional information is available at mdta.maryland.gov.

title: Maryland debates “local” wind farm, way offshore
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content:
Maryland debates “local” wind farm, way offshore

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 644
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland wants to expand its use of renewable energy by encouraging local projects like wind turbines.But one company's plan to build windmills in waters off the coast is running into trouble this session in the General Assembly, where lawmakers worry about giving their economic support to a project that isn't exactly local.
The proposed project would be built off the coast of Virginia Beach — close by, but technically outside Maryland waters.
One lawmaker wants to help the company building it, Avangrid Renewables, by making a wording change in a Maryland law that defines who is eligible to sell energy credits to the state. Her bill would expand the current law to let Maryland buy and sell energy credits from a company whose planned wind turbines are closer to the shores of Virginia and North Carolina.
The measure is "a crucial step towards removing obstacles to offshore wind development in Maryland," said Sen. Mary Washington (D-Baltimore City), who is sponsoring the measure. "This bill has the potential to expedite the state's transition to renewable energy."
But when the General Assembly bought into a set of ambitious renewable energy goals last year, they did so partly because advocates had convinced them they would be beneficial to the local economy. Sen. Malcolm Augustine (D-Prince George's) argues that those local economic benefits would not materialize for Marylanders if the wind farms were built in other states.
"We want to have the power, of course — we want to have the renewable energy," Augustine told Capital News Service. "But we also want to have that economic benefit that's associated with the development… stay here."
The bill follows last year's POWER Act, which established Maryland's goal of procuring 8.5 gigawatts of offshore wind by 2031, dramatically increasing the state's previous goal.
Renewable energy generators like Avangrid said this bill could help the state meet its goal by supporting the construction of more than one local offshore wind project on the PJM grid, a power grid that connects several states, including Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Maryland. Maryland's pledge of support as a future energy credit buyer would help advance any project.
"This lease area that we're talking about is gigantic," said Ken Kimmell, Avangrid's vice president of development for offshore wind. "So it's quite possible that the lease area could support a project for Maryland and also a project for Virginia."
Both states would benefit environmentally and economically, Kimmell said. There are proposed "marshaling ports" in Baltimore where the wind turbine's parts would be staged for installation, he said. In addition, the use of union laborers at these ports would benefit Maryland, Kimmell added.
Other lawmakers are not yet convinced. Some are worried about the negative impacts of offshore wind in general and have concerns about the costs of expanding these initiatives.
Ocean City residents have voiced concerns about offshore wind's impact on the tourism industry, said Sen. Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Worcester and Wicomico). She has raised concerns about the potential impact on military training and exercises in the area, as well as fishing and marine life.
"There was an expert that testified at the congressional hearing in Ocean City that talked about the impact of the noise on the whales . . . whether it's the drilling of the turbines or whether it's the sound from the turbines themselves that would cause harm to the whales and other marine life," she said. "You also have then whether the project even makes sense from a cost perspective."
Augustine is also concerned that it doesn't make sense. "How in the world does something landing in North Carolina benefit Maryland?" he asked in the bill hearing last week.
Lawmakers are open to other legislation this session that would propel the state further toward its renewable energy goals.
But legislators still aren't big fans of this particular effort. And with time running out before a crucial session deadline, the bill may stall for now.

title: Cambridge city manager resigns over concerns with CWDI
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge city manager resigns over concerns with CWDI

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 909
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Tom Carroll, Cambridge's city manager of two years, submitted his resignation on Monday.In a letter addressed to the mayor and commissioners, Carroll said his last day as city manager will be no later than May 17.
Carroll shared the news of his resignation with City Council Monday night in a closed session following the council meeting.
"This was a hard decision for me to reach, but I do know it is the right decision to make," he wrote in an email to the Star Democrat Tuesday morning.
In an interview Tuesday afternoon, Carroll said he has accepted a city manager position for the City of Lexington, Virginia. He said that in December, he came to the decision to pursue employment outside of Cambridge in the new year.
The reason for this decision, he said, was his concerns with Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.'s Cambridge Harbor project, a project to develop the space along the Cambridge waterfront. Specifically, Carroll pointed to three events that led to his decision.
The first was a Dec. 15 email from CWDI Executive Director Matt Leonard. The email, sent to CWDI stakeholders, said the city's words and actions were jeopardizing CWDI's deal with a company to build a hotel, Carroll said.
When Carroll, at the request of City Council President Lajan Cephas, reached out to two of the city's representatives on the CWDI board, he said he didn't hear back from them on the topic for months.
Along with this, Carroll said CWDI's "fussiness" regarding a now indefinitely tabled ordinance that would give the city the authority to appoint an individual to represent the city on a non-city governed board — and also remove that individual, and subsequently impose a fine or jail time if the individual continued to act as a representative of the city on said board — made it clear that CWDI was unwilling to change any part of its plan in response to criticism from the city.
Carroll said the third event that led to his decision was when he learned of a "significant ethical issue" involving CWDI's attorney. CWDI is represented by the law firm Miles and Stockbridge.
This is not the first time Carroll has spoken about his concerns with the Cambridge Harbor project.
In late October, a letter addressed to Leonard and signed by Carroll stated that Cambridge City Council was not in support of the plans for the project. The letter stated concerns with the CWDI's governance, the proposed tax increment financing and the lack of a private sector development partner for a project of this size.
Carroll himself said in a September interview that having spent 27 years in local governments and having been a part of two major economic development projects, he had concerns with the financial feasibility of CWDI's plan.
In his email to the Star Democrat, Carroll said he hopes that he is wrong and that Cambridge Harbor will "become a story book success."
"But I fear that I will be correct in its lasting and long-term negative impacts for Cambridge unless it is fundamentally changed," he wrote. "I can no longer standby while this project moves forward in its current form and with the current governance structure."
Leonard said Carroll's reasons for leaving are his reasons.
"I don't know what all the reasons are," Leonard said. "If that's the one he has chosen promote, I'm sorry to see that. It doesn't make a lot of sense to me, but his reasons are his reasons."
Leonard said one of the reasons CWDI was formed was to have an organization in place that can "transcend political turmoil or disruptions in leadership."
"We've done everything we can to make sure that we can continue the progress on the project despite political changes," he said.
In his Monday letter to the mayor and commissioners, Carroll mentioned some of the city's accomplishments since he began serving as city manager, including the Cambridge Police Department's commitment to community policing and the city's undertaking of significant capital projects.
He said he was "particularly proud" of the city's wages and classifications system that has helped the city's workforce become more reflective of the community.
In a press release, Mayor Stephen Rideout said he and the commissioners are saddened by Carroll's decision to leave, and his expertise will be missed.
In an interview, Rideout called Carroll leaving a a significant loss for the city. He said the city has been making progress like he hasn't seen since it established its current form of government in 2015.
City Council President Lajan Cephas called Carroll a gift to Cambridge, adding that he has made a lasting impact on the city.
"Although he's leaving, he's still going to be with us, with the changes that he's made," she said.
Both Rideout and Cephas said they still have concerns about Cambridge Harbor. Cephas said her concerns lie with the direction CWDI's leadership is going in.
Rideout said this search for the next city manager will begin soon. The mayor and commissioners are responsible for hiring for the position. Carroll said he has offered to assist with the first steps in recruiting the next city manager.
In the interview Tuesday, Carroll said he expected to serve the rest of his career in Cambridge.
"I love Cambridge and think it has so much potential," he said. "I think this community will benefit by getting very serious about structural racism that we have in this community. And CWDI, the Cambridge Harbor project is something that makes me feel like their approach to this project demonstrates that Cambridge isn't serious about that important conversation."

 This report has been updated from an earlier version to correct information pertaining to the cost of the renovations.EASTON — The Talbot County Council's Thursday evening to discussion of the county's enterprise funds budgets for the upcoming fiscal year included a lengthy talk about the renovations of the Hog Neck Golf Course.
Rich Setter, general manager at Hog Neck Golf Course, came to the council with a plan for the future of this golf course.
The plan includes improvements such as driving range enhancements, venue operations and a new kitchen so the golf course can generate significantly higher revenues in the future.
Setter focused on the need for funds for kitchen improvements. This project would require $105,000, including items like a flat-top grill, oven, fryer and hood unit.
Setter provided financial projections to the council, showing that with the new projects, revenues could increase to around $3 million annually once the new facilities are open and fully operational.
The goal, Setter said, would be for the golf course, which is owned and operated by the county, to become more financially self-sufficient over time and generate enough revenue to pay for its capital projects and operations without needing as much subsidy from the Talbot County general fund.
"We're basically creating a whole new business," said Settler of the golf course's renovations, many of which are already underway.
The project will cost about $2.4 million as laid out in a previous meeting, not including Setter's $105,000 ask.
Council members Lynn Mielke and Dave Stepp supported the changes to the golf course.
"I'm the only one that has seen one of these driving ranges and how popular and successful it is," Mielke said. "That makes an impact on me in terms of my view on proceeding on this and making an investment."
Council members Chuck Callahan, Keasha Haythe and Pete Lesher were more hesitant about investing further into the project.
Haythe said it was essential to treat this as a new business and take a more conservative approach to the revenue produced during its first fiscal year. Funds have already been provided for other capital projects, like the driving range enhancements.
Callahan suggested that they wait a bit longer before approving the decision. Haythe and Lesher agreed with this statement.
"It's a business decision that we have to make with the taxpayers' money," Callahan said. "I would feel a bit more comfortable waiting to see."
Stepp and Mielke protested.
"My theory on this is if we're going to do it, let's do it right," Stepp said. "Let's get everything in place because we're going to have an opportunity here for a lot of first impressions."
Setter stressed that revenue would drastically decrease if the business were unable to sell hot food, which ultimately changed the minds of Callahan, Haythe and Lesher. The council approved fully funding the kitchen improvements at the golf course.
If approved in FY2025 budget and advance funds are allocated. Setter said they hope to complete kitchen renovations before the "true grand opening" in 2025.

title: Pier length changes could soon require variance
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Pier length changes could soon require variance

 March 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 468
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Pier length proved to be a contentious topic during the Queen Anne's County Commissioner's public hearing on a conditional use ordinance on the same.If passed the new ordinance would require approval of a variance for new piers constructed in excess of 150 feet in length.
A variance is a departure from a minimum standard set forth in the Zoning Code and are most often affiliated with a bulk standard like a distance from property lines or the size of an accessory structure, according to Amy Moredock, planning director. Conditional uses are uses listed in each zoning district permitted under certain conditions of the Town Code.
Variances require more unique circumstance standards for the Board of Appeals to review than current conditional use permits, Moredock said.
At the March 12 public hearing, with concerns that longer piers can affect public use of waterways, residents spoke in favor of the ordinance to tighten up reviews for pier extension applications further than the normally allotted 150 feet.
Jay Falstad of the Queen Anne's Conservation Association noted property ownership stops at the shore line and it wasn't unreasonable to ask a landowner to have a higher burden when requesting longer piers.
The change to the ordinance would not automatically deny applications for a longer pier but "puts forth a little bit higher of a standard," he said.
If allowed to go unchecked, longer piers jetting into the water could create an eyesore, and larger boats can utilize marinas, he said.
Billy Benton, vice president of the Queen Anne's County Watermen's Association stated longer piers can impede on the working areas of crabbing and clamming.
On the other side, representing a client that has had a conditional use application in the works for months, Jeff Thompson of Thompson and Richard LLP requested the variance ordinance provide a grandfather condition.
Pier extension requests can be for a number of factors including water depth not just boat size, he said.
His client's request has been in the queue for months and Thompson was worried the variance bill approval would trump that.
It had not been the Board of Appeals' intention to "pull out the rug" from under current conditional use applicants with the proposed amendment, Moredock, said, noting it had not been realized that projects in the pipeline would be affected by the ordinance.
"Since 2002, we've had 45 conditional use applications for pier extensions greater than 150, all were approved. The greatest distance was 495," Long Range Principal Planner Stephanie Jones said.
Commissioner Jack Wilson requested additional information about the average pier length requested more than 150 feet.
Public comment will be open until the commissioners will return to discussion at its next meeting March 26.
In other business, the council approved a map amendment to upgrade the sewer and water services of the Foxx Farm property in Sudlersville to permit services on demand, calling it "long overdue."

title: Returning Bay ferry servicey faces choppy waters
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Returning Bay ferry servicey faces choppy waters

 April 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 500
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On June 30, 1952, a ribbon-cutting in Anne Arundel County marked the beginning and the end of transportation options between Maryland's Eastern Shore and western shore. On that day, the first Chesapeake Bay Bridge opened for vehicular traffic. That same day, a ferry service that had carried 2 million passengers and 1 million vehicles on the Bay since being launched in 1930 ended.Conventional wisdom then was ferry service would never return to the Bay. Now an effort is underway to return ferry service that is very different from that which ended abruptly 72 years ago.
Currently nine Maryland counties — Queen Anne's, Anne Arundel, Calvert, Somerset, St. Mary's, Wicomico, Talbot, Kent, and Dorchester plus the city of Annapolis — are working with a consultant to study the feasibility of a new passenger only ferry service on the Bay. Their final report will include recommendations on next steps if the consultant's feasibility study concludes such a service is viable and sustainable. It is a work in progress. Routes may be added deleted or modified.
With all due respect to the supporters of this concept, I suggest there are two critical issues they need to consider if they have not done so already.
One issue is the ferry vessel under serious consideration for the proposed new service. It is the Candela P-12 all-electric ferry. It sells for approximately $2 million, does not carry vehicles, seats a maximum of 30 passengers, and has limited storage space for carry-ons such as bicycles, strollers and wheelchairs.
This vessel will not be a practical alternative for the huge number of tourists who use Route 50 when going to Ocean City ("downy shore").
Accordingly, this proposed new ferry service is not likely to generate significant support from Eastern Shore residents and public officials hoping for a solution to regular summer traffic jams on Route 50.
The second issue is the increasingly limited potential for state funding for this concept.
During the past several weeks in the General Assembly, there has been intense (and yet to be resolved) differences of opinion on how to address structural deficits in the state transportation trust fund and projected structural deficits in the state budget. Those deficits are almost certain to become worse based on the devastating impact on the state economy and state revenues from the tragic collapse of the Key Bridge in Baltimore.
Securing state funding for the launch and operation of a new ferry service on the Bay is not going to be a high priority in Annapolis in the foreseeable future.
I am not suggesting these are insurmountable obstacles or the only obstacles. I am suggesting they are very serious obstacles that cannot be ignored by the proponents of returning ferry service on the Bay.
One path forward may be securing private investment for this concept from investors with the resources to launch and operate it.
Otherwise, returning ferry service to the Chesapeake Bay may be an interesting idea whose time has not yet come.
David Reel is a public relations and public affairs consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Cambridge mayor proposes amendments to CWDI Articles of Incorporation
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge mayor proposes amendments to CWDI Articles of Incorporation

 April 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 762
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — In an effort to get the relationship between Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. and the City of Cambridge "back on track," Mayor Stephen Rideout is proposing amendments to the organization's Articles of Incorporation.According to CWDI's Articles of Incorporation, the mayor of Cambridge is its sole member. This means that Rideout has the authority to make amendments to the Articles of Incorporation.
Tuesday morning, Rideout conducted a meeting to share and review his proposed amendments to the Articles of Incorporation. He said he thinks these changes will benefit CWDI's Cambridge Harbor project, a project to develop the space along the Cambridge waterfront that would include a promenade, parks and a boutique hotel with a restaurant and bar.
"These amendments to the articles make it more likely for the project to be successful," Rideout said.
Cambridge Harbor has been a hot topic of conversation in recent months. On March 18, Cambridge City Manager Tom Carroll submitted his resignation and said he was resigning over concerns with the Cambridge Harbor project.
In late October, a letter addressed to CWDI Executive Director Matt Leonard and signed by Carroll stated that Cambridge City Council was not in support of the plans for the project.
At the meeting Tuesday, Rideout discussed four main areas of the six-page CWDI Articles of Incorporation document that he wishes to amend. He said he will convene another meeting in the next 10 days to make his final decision regarding the amendments, and he welcomes comments and advice from the CWDI Board of Directors and the public.
PROPOSED AMENDMENTSThe first change Rideout proposed has to do with CWDI's membership. The amendment would make it so that Cambridge's commission president would become CWDI's sole member in the event that the city is without a mayor.
Currently, according to a red-lined document of the Articles of Incorporation that Rideout handed out at the end of the meeting, CWDI's Board of Directors would become the members of CWDI if the city did not have a mayor.
"Given the differences of opinion that have developed between the city and CWDI, having the CWDI board become the sole member in the future is not acceptable," Rideout said.
Rideout's second proposed change would give CWDI's sole member the exclusive right to amend the Articles of Incorporation and the ability to inspect all CWDI records and attend all open and closed CWDI board meetings.
Rideout called it "critical" for CWDI to be transparent and accountable to its sole member.
The third main change would make it so that the Articles of Incorporation "prevail" over CWDI's bylaws in the case that there is an inconsistency between the two. It would also require the Board of Directors to provide any proposed bylaw amendments to the sole member of CWDI at least 15 days before adoption of that proposed amendment.
The fourth change to the document would explicitly give the city, county and state the authority to remove and replace their appointees to the board at any time.
Rideout said he believes that — at least for the city — this authority already exists. But he said the amendment would ensure that authority.
This is not the first time the city has considered clarifying that authority. In the beginning of the year, the council considered an ordinance that would have given the city the authority to appoint an individual to represent the city on a non-city governed board; and also remove that individual, and subsequently impose a fine or jail time if the individual continued to act as a representative of the city on said board. At a Feb. 12 City Council meeting, the ordinance was tabled indefinitely.
The proposed ordinance had garnered attention from CWDI.
In November, Attorney J.W. Thompson Webb of Miles and Stockbridge, representing CWDI, wrote the council that the city was overreaching its authority with the ordinance. In a Jan. 2 letter from Leonard to Rideout, Leonard asked the city to abandon the ordinance altogether.
CWDI city-appointed board member Shay Lewis-Sisco also asked for this at a Jan. 8 City Council meeting.
Toward the end of the meeting Tuesday, Rideout said that CWDI can "regain the complete confidence of" the city through embracing these proposed amendments.
"I hope my friends on the CWDI Board of Directors embrace this opportunity," he said.
After the meeting, Leonard, who was in attendance, said he didn't have a lot he could say about the meeting because he hadn't yet had a chance to review the amendments Rideout is proposing.
"I believe anybody who wants to make CWDI better comes in good faith," Leonard said. "We're always happy to listen to their suggestions. And so I'm going to look at it that way."

title: Talbot Council introduces 2025 budget
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado

Talbot Council introduces 2025 budget

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, the Talbot County Council voted unanimously to introduce the proposed fiscal year 2025 general fund budget of $163,970,000.The budget will include an education increase of $3.65 million from the 2024 budget.
Talbot County Public Schools will receive $54.6 million in total funding, according to the proposed budget. This increase will go toward the capital project request for planned Chapel District Elementary School renovations and other capital projects.
The increase in the education budget is due, in part, to the implications of the Maryland Blueprint for Education plan. Blueprint is a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state by increasing education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years.
"Maryland Blueprint required local share funding to increase by $1.053 million for FY2025 budget," Martha Sparks, finance director for Talbot County, said at the Tuesday meeting. "In addition to the mandated funding, the county has included an additional appropriation of $2.6 million. Funding to support Talbot County Schools increased overall by $3.65 million above FY24 levels."
Education spending represents 37.7% of the county's total proposed budget. These numbers include Talbot County Public Schools, Chesapeake College and the Talbot County Free Library expenses.
The budget also allocates an additional $1.5 million in capital improvement project funding for Talbot County Public Schools to prioritize other projects.
The budget discussion included the option to expand the amendment of the 1-cent increase in property tax rates for public safety.
In November 2020, Talbot County voters approved an amendment allowing a 1-cent increase to the property tax rate to support public safety spending. This increase began in the FY2022 budget and will continue until the FY2026 budget.
Revenues from the 1-cent increase have been used to fund 26 new public safety positions across departments, such as deputies, paramedics, emergency medical technicians and 911 operators. The funds from the amendment have allowed for inclusion of sheriff's office, paramedics/EMTs and correctional officers in enhanced retirement programs for public safety employees.
Sparks noted that the county has used more than the funds provided by the 1-cent increase to public safety.
"The county has used more than the revenues generated from the 1 cent to enhance public safety personnel serving the citizens and visitors of Talbot County," she said.
The council has the option to allow county residents to extend the 1-cent increase beyond FY2026 through a ballot initiative for voters in the November 2024 general election.
Clay Stamp, county manager for Talbot County, expressed his admiration for the county's finance team for their work on the budget.
"There's a lot of hard work that went into drafting the FY 25 proposed balanced budget," Stamp said. "While we're here tonight, I want to thank the council for your cooperation and support over the last number of months."
Two public hearings will be held to gather community input before final approval.
A public hearing will be held on May 7 at 2 p.m. in the Talbot County Courthouse and at 7 p.m. in the Easton Elementary School cafeteria, located at 307 Glenwood Avenue.

title: 1st District GOP forum held at by League of Women Voters
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
1st District GOP forum held at by League of Women Voters

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News

 The League of Women Voters hosted a forum for 1st District Congressional candidates on Sunday afternoon. The two Republican candidates were represented and found common ground on many issues, but especially for their contempt for incumbent Rep. Andy Harris who did not attend the forum.Republican candidates Chris Bruneau and Michael Scott Lemon, replying to a question, said Harris, who has been in Congress since 2008, initially promised to serve only six terms, for a total of 12 years in the House, but opted to run again in 2022 and is running in the upcoming election.
During the forum, Lemon criticized the Harris campaign for the running of his reelection campaign.
"I've not seen the hide nor hair of Andy Harris," Lemon said. "So his strategy is, 'My name is already on there. I'm an incumbent; I'm already going to win.'"
When asked about the incumbent, Bruneau told a story of how he reached out to Harris about his candidacy because he assumed Harris would not run again. In the same email, Bruneau asked how he could take on Harris' conservative legacy. When Bruneau received a reply from Harris, he said it "wasn't a nice reply."
"There's new blood, new people, grassroots guys, he can get down there and make a difference," Bruneau said. "So his term may be limited May 14, 2024, by voting a new candidate ... and start doing some work."
The Democratic forum, scheduled to run before the Republican forum, was canceled when only candidate Blane Miller showed up. Candidate Blessing Oluwadare did not attend.
Among other topics discussed and agreed upon among the Republican candidates was a similar frustration with excessive government spending and the large national debt, term limits for members of Congress, advocating for prioritizing American needs over large amounts of foreign aid spending and a desire to lower taxes while also reducing the deficit though they differed on specific approaches.
When asked about the federal role of abortion, Lemon said it should be left to the states to decide.
Lemon stated that it was a "difficult issue," and by leaving it up to the states, the government allowed the voters to make informed decisions for their area.
Bruneau said that it should be up to the individual to decide whether or not they would like to have an abortion because of how complicated and potentially dangerous it could be to the mother's life and to the fetus's life.
"These are decisions individuals need to make. I don't know where the basis comes from for the government to get involved in these things," Bruneau said. "I'm not quite sure it's constitutional for the government to get involved in these things."
In closing statements, Brueneau said he is not a politician; he is a businessman. He made clear that Harris is a candidate like himself and Lemon and that he should have been at the forum so the voters could consider rehiring him as their representative.
Bruneau accused the Harris campaign of not appearing in the forum because he was leading in the polls. Calls made to the Andy Harris congressional office were referred to his campaign office, but no one answered the phone Monday afternoon.
In his closing statement, Lemon said he would give the voters his most authentic, honest version of himself. He emphasized that voters need to make their voices heard on May 14.

title: Hurley wins reelection to Ridgely commissioner seat

 RIDGELY — The classic battle between new voices and the incumbent's steady hand was played out in the Ridgely Commissioner's race on Monday. There were three people seeking one of the commissioners' seats representing this town of 1,605. These included Lakia Harris-Pierce, Chad Leister and John Hurley.John Hurley was elected to another term as a commissioner for the Town of Ridgely Monday.
Hurley won a three-way election against Lakia Harris-Pierce, Chad Leister with 69 votes. Leister had 53 and Harris-Pierce had 18.
Hurley joins Anthony Casey and Leonard John Buckle on the commission. He will serve a three year term.
Stephanie Berkey, the town clerk and treasurer said, "It was a good turnout. It was very nice to see this many turn out for the election. There were lots of younger voters."
Hurley has serves as a Ridgely commissioner since 2012.
"I feel thankful," he said. "In my 12 years in the town, we have gone from a deficit to a surplus. We have not raised taxes. It was a large turnout for the town. I know it was over 100 people who came out and voted."
Looking forward, he said he is well aware that the tax base of a town of 1,605 is small, and he plans to work to maximize the town's financial security and responsibility.
"There is only so much money in the pot to go around. I think we make very good use of our money. We have one of the lower water and sewer rates in the county. I hope to not raise taxes in the future," Hurley said.
According to the Town of Ridgely website, "Ridgely is governed by three Commissioners who are elected to three-year terms. Terms are staggered, so one Commissioner is elected each year in April. Town elections are held on the 4th Monday of April. There are no term limits for Town Commissioners. Each Commissioner serves as President in the final year of their term."

title: 1st District GOP forum held by League of Women Voters
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
1st District GOP forum held by League of Women Voters

 The League of Women Voters hosted a forum for 1st District Congressional candidates on Sunday afternoon. The two Republican candidates represented found common ground on many issues, but especially in their contempt for incumbent Rep. Andy Harris, who did not attend the forum.Republican candidates Chris Bruneau and Michael Scott Lemon, replying to a question, said Harris, who has been in Congress since 2008, initially promised to serve only six terms, for a total of 12 years in the House, but opted to run again in 2022 and is running in the upcoming election.
During the forum, Lemon criticized the Harris for the running of his reelection campaign.
"I've not seen the hide nor hair of Andy Harris," Lemon said. "So his strategy is, 'My name is already on there. I'm an incumbent; I'm already going to win.'"
When asked about the incumbent, Bruneau told a story of how he reached out to Harris about his candidacy because he assumed Harris would not run again. In the same email, Bruneau asked how he could take on Harris' conservative legacy. When Bruneau received a reply from Harris, he said it "wasn't a nice reply."
"There's new blood, new people, grassroots guys, he can get down there and make a difference," Bruneau said. "So his term may be limited May 14, 2024, by voting a new candidate ... and start doing some work."
The Democratic forum, scheduled to run before the Republican forum, was canceled when only candidate Blane Miller showed up. Candidate Blessing Oluwadare did not attend.
Among other topics discussed and agreed upon among the Republican candidates was a similar frustration with excessive government spending and the large national debt, term limits for members of Congress, advocating for prioritizing American needs over large amounts of foreign aid spending and a desire to lower taxes while also reducing the deficit, though they differed on specific approaches.
When asked about the federal role in regulating abortion, Lemon said it should be left to the states to decide.
Lemon stated that it was a "difficult issue," and by leaving it up to the states, the government allowed the voters to make informed decisions for their area.
Bruneau said that it should be up to the individual to decide whether or not they would like to have an abortion because of how complicated and potentially dangerous it could be to the mother's life and to the fetus's life.
"These are decisions individuals need to make. I don't know where the basis comes from for the government to get involved in these things," Bruneau said. "I'm not quite sure it's constitutional for the government to get involved in these things."
In closing statements, Brueneau said he is not a politician; he is a businessman. He made clear that Harris is a candidate like himself and Lemon and that he should have been at the forum so the voters could consider rehiring him as their representative.
Bruneau accused the Harris campaign of not appearing in the forum because he was leading in the polls. Calls made to the Andy Harris congressional office were referred to his campaign office, but no one answered the phone Monday afternoon.
In his closing statement, Lemon said he would give the voters his most authentic, honest version of himself. He emphasized that voters need to make their voices heard.
Miller and Oluwadare will compete in the Democratic primary and Bruneau, Lemon and Harris in the Republican primary for the congressional seat on May 14. The winner of each primary will face off in the November general election.
