title: Port Street housing project nearing completion
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Port Street housing project nearing completion

 August 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Nine affordable housing units and a new headquarters for a local nonprofit organization are nearing completion on Port Street. The Port Street Commons, a project led by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, is slated to finish construction in October.The project includes nine apartments — seven two-bedroom units and two three-bedroom units — and approximately 10,000 square feet of space for The Arc's new regional headquarters, featuring offices and a behavioral health suite.
On Tuesday afternoon, Jonathon Rondeau, president and CEO of The Arc, gave a tour of the 24,000-square-foot space to Jake Day, Maryland's secretary of housing and community development.
Construction workers were in action on the site, and drywall and insulation was installed on the first and second floors of the three-story building. Day called it a "great looking building."
Rondeau pointed out the importance of bringing immediate assistance to those in need of housing in the Easton area, which is why his team has worked to aim for completion in under four years. The site was identified in July of 2021, and construction began last June. "We want to move quickly," Rondeau said.
$6.5 million of the project's approximate $11-million price tag has been raised, and The Arc is nearing the end of its capital campaign. Rondeau told Day that The Arc is financing the gap of around $4.5 million.
"If we wanted to raise the full $11 million, that would've taken us about eight years," Rondeau said.
Day was impressed with the pace of the Port Street project, asking Rondeau, "can we set you up with lots of other developers to help guide them through the process as speedily as The Arc has gotten through?"
A ribbon cutting is planned for Nov. 7. Rondeau said the first batch of tenants will move in Dec. 1, with a second batch coming in on Jan. 2. The Arc's headquarters will open in January.
Eight of the nine units will accept tenants based on a public lottery system. The ninth unit is designated to the Talbot Interfaith Shelter to house someone transitioning out of the shelter.
"Because of the site plan, all nine units are slightly different," Rondeau said, "which was not the most economical, but it was the only way we could maximize getting nine units into the available square footage."
All of the units will feature free Wi-Fi and appliances including a microwave, along with "solid surface countertops" and carpet in bedrooms to save money in the back end for property management. The units will be managed by Chesapeake Neighbors, a housing subsidiary of The Arc.
Rondeau said two of the units on the first floor are "universally designed," with accessible bathrooms and appliances meant to accommodate those with disabilities.
As Day and other members of the Department of Housing and Community Development toured the space, Rondeau pointed out how the office spaces will support The Arc's overarching goal of providing counseling and assistance to those with intellectual and developmental disabilities.
The headquarters are expected to add around 35 jobs to the area. Rondeau said employees at the Easton site will have health insurance. A full-time nurse will also be in the building.
"Three years ago, The Arc decided to self-insure our health insurance for our employees," he said. "And we have a partnership. We provide free urgent and primary care to all of our employees."
Rondeau is excited for The Arc's services to continue expanding outside of Anne Arundel County, which is where the organization was founded and has the largest presence.
"We've grown significantly over the last 25 years here in Easton," Rondeau said. "We wanted to have an Eastern Shore headquarters."
The project is the first building in Easton to fall under the town's mixed-use waterfront zoning district regulations, Rondeau said. Passed in 2019, the zoning code emphasizes connecting the Easton Point waterfront to the town's downtown area. Rondeau said The Arc made sure to have the front doors of the project facing Port Street as part of the zoning expectations.
After the tour, Day thanked Rondeau and expressed his support for The Arc's fast-moving efforts.
"It's an awesome project, it's an incredible project," Day said.

title: Oxford commissioners interview recruiting firms for open town manager position
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Oxford commissioners interview recruiting firms for open town manager position

 August 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 530
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — In an effort to move past the town's recent fruitless town manager hire, the Commissioners of Oxford held workshops Wednesday to interview two recruiting firms.This workshop was held a month after the town passed resolution requiring the hiring of a search firm for the town manager position as a result of controversy concerning the former town manager hire, Michael Calvert.
Calvert — who was previously a city administrator for Liberty, South Carolina — had been slated to get sworn in as Oxford's next town manager in July. But just three days after announcing the hire on June 24, the Commissioners of Oxford announced the town and Calvert had "mutually agreed to part ways."
Shortly after the news of Calvert's hire, some community members expressed concerns about the town's candidate vetting process.
In an effort to move forward with finding a new candidate, Commissioner Katrina Greer introduced the resolution during a July 9 meeting, requiring the town to use a "professional search team that specializes in local government."
During the workshops Wednesday, separate interviews were held for the two firms, GovHRUSA and Berkley Group.
Each firm gave a presentation showing the goals, working timeline and outreach that could be done if they were hired. After each presentation, the commissioners asked questions of the firms.
Commissioner Katrina Greer requested a thorough understanding of the background checks each firm conducts on candidates.
Charlene Stevens, executive vice president for recruitment services at GovHRUSA, said her firm prides itself on ensuring well-researched candidates.
"We do media searches on candidates, to understand what is out there on them, as well as be able to have a conversation with them," Stevens said. "If there's media that is concerning, then … Mike (senior consultant) will review that information with you and make sure that you are comfortable moving forward with the candidate."
Kelsey Wong, chief operating officer for Berkley Group, said her firm uses a third-party background check to assess candidates but at the time could not remember the name of the company and said she could provide that information later.
Greer stated it was vital for the firm to come back with the company name since the background check was essential for hiring a new candidate.
"We had a problem with (background checks), and we would want criminal search to go back a number of years, do the credit check, do the civil check, etc. because people are handling money and purchases, etc.," Greer said. "And a national criminal check going back 23 years."
Each commissioner asked questions concerning issues of the timeline of hire, whether or not the firms have worked with communities with populations below 1,000, networking and how the firms involve the community in the hiring process.
Commissioner Tom Costigan said the workshop was informative and helpful for the process of finding a new town manager.
"It's important to us because we're basically doing our due diligence to find the best possible candidate for our town manager position," Costigan said.
A decision will be made in the "next couple of weeks," and a follow up meeting with Berkley Group was requested to be scheduled to meet the rest of the team and to have a better understanding of the firm's background check process, according to Greer.

title: Bradshaw running for Cambridge mayor against Lajan Cephas
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Bradshaw running for Cambridge mayor against Lajan Cephas

 August 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 655
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Former Cambridge Mayor Andrew Bradshaw has thrown his hat in the ring for the city's mayoral election in October.Bradshaw, who served as mayor through 2021, resigned in January 2022 after being charged with 50 counts of distributing revenge porn on Reddit. In April 2022, Bradshaw pleaded guilty to five counts of distributing revenge porn.
Current Mayor Stephen Rideout, who is not seeking reelection, was elected to fill the remainder of Bradshaw's term.
Bradshaw will run against Cambridge Commission President Lajan Cephas, who served as the city's interim mayor after Bradshaw resigned and before Rideout took office.
Cephas also has faced legal issues. In 2022, she was charged with second-degree assault in connection with a domestic violence incident in her Cambridge home. The charges were dismissed in January 2023.
As of Monday, Bradshaw and Cephas were the only two listed as approved candidates for the Oct. 19 mayoral election on the city's website. The deadline to file is Tuesday.
In an interview with the Star Democrat, Bradshaw said he is running primarily due to an "outpouring of support" that he has received.
"And that was, I think, largely based on the background that I had when I was in office previously and our ability to move forward various parts of a broad-sweeping agenda that was aimed at improving Cambridge throughout the city," he said. "Not just in one neighborhood or in one aspect of the city's needs, but across all the various areas of need and geography in Cambridge."
Bradshaw wants to keep the focus of his campaign on where Cambridge is now and where it is going, rather than on his past legal issues. He said he thinks voters feel the same way.
"While I understand that there will be some thoughts and some attention given to those things, I think that where we stand now and where we can go in the future is really where I want to keep the focus," he said.
A news release from the Bradshaw for Cambridge Committee said during Bradshaw's time in office, the city started giving residential property tax credits for public safety officer recruitment, increased salaries for police officers, replaced and upgraded Cambridge Police Department and Public Services Department vehicles, expanded ethics reporting requirements for city representatives and began the planning and implementation of the Homeownership Works program, a state pilot program created to increase affordable homeownership opportunities.
Bradshaw said he thinks that as mayor, he served as a catalyst for the City Council to move issues forward and work toward solving them.
"And I think the same will be true this time," he said. "That though there will be commissioners that have excellent ideas, that I'll be able to serve as a catalyst to get those ideas from the point of discussion to the point of decision."
Cephas, who has served on the city council since 2021, said in a text that being qualified for the position of mayor doesn't make you the best candidate. She said that after Bradshaw's resignation, she proved that she is capable and committed in the position of mayor.
"During (those) nine months with powers of mayor, we established the Gun Violence Task Force, resulting in 65% decrease in murder and decrease in violent crime in the city," she said.
Cephas said it's important for voters to believe in the legal system and "allow it to work."
She spoke about the importance of moving forward with a vision of a one Cambridge.
"We've notice Cambridge is divided on many platforms from policing, CWDI, businesses, race relations, community development and housing to name a few," she said. "We are divided in many ways in Cambridge, and (the) mayor should be the unifying agent bringing the city's business forward, not back."
Cephas said that if elected mayor, she will be committed to moving the city's business forward "with the spirit of ONE Cambridge."
Cambridge's city election will be held Oct. 19. All five Cambridge City Council seats will be up for grabs, along with the mayor's seat.

Foster, who ran in Cambridge's last mayoral election, said she is running again because she thinks she has expertise that will benefit the city. She talked about her more than 30 years of experience as a social worker and community organizer, which she said puts her in the right position to help move Cambridge forward.
Foster said the city needs to invest in its children. She said there needs to be activities that meet the needs of the majority of Cambridge's children. She said lot of the activities available now are not affordable for all families.

"And I feel that I am that candidate that will bring Cambridge together holistically."
COMMISSIONER RACESIncumbent Commissioner Laurel Atkiss is running against Brett Summers for the Ward 1 seat. Atkiss was elected in June 2023 in a special election to finish the unexpired term of then Ward 1 Commissioner Brian Roche.
Jenna LeCompte, Nancy Jackson, Jermaine Anderson and Shay Lewis-Sisco are running for the open Ward 2 seat, which is currently held by Lajan Cephas.

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Republican Central Committee has set up shop on Gay Street in downtown Cambridge.Committee Chairman Michael Dodd said the organization has been occupying the space at 322 Gay Street since late July.
This is something the committee does every two years, though not always in the same location. Dodd said each election cycle, they open a brick-and-mortar headquarters "for the run-up to election day."

Dodd said that since setting up on Gay Street, the headquarters has received a positive response from the public. He said there has been a "massive demand" for campaign materials from the committee.
Although store hours have yet to be announced, the committee will be hosting a grand opening for its new digs on Friday, Aug. 9 at 6 p.m. Dodd said the committee plans to have light fare and merchandise giveaways at the event, which is open to the public. He said they will also have some "special guests" at the event.
Attendees will be able to purchase merchandise for the committee's Choptank River Boats for Trump Parade, which will be held Aug. 11 at 1 p.m. The parade will start at Long Wharf in Cambridge and end at Suicide Bridge Restaurant in Hurlock.
Dodd said the committee can be reached via Facebook or email at docomdgop@gmail.com. He said it always welcomes volunteers.

 EASTON — A public hearing for a proposed 33-unit housing development at the site of the former Safeway closed during Monday's Town Council meeting. Despite mixed public reactions at past town meetings, no members of the public spoke Monday evening.The proposal comes from Lane Engineering on behalf of NAI Saturn Eastern and Safeway, along with Miller Development Corporation, the potential developers of the project. It includes 24 partially-connected townhomes and nine standalone units. The property, which has been vacant since 2017, sits at 139 N Washington St.
Council members mentioned discussions with developers about a per-unit contribution to the town's affordable housing efforts. Ward 1 Council Member Maureen Curry said it's her "understanding that the developer has agreed" to those contributions.
"We discussed the possibility of a $10,000 per-unit support of the affordable housing fund," Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello said, "with $5,000 coming at the building permit stage and $5,000 at the moment of getting the permit of occupancy."

FIRE DEPARTMENTSonny Jones, chief of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, presented a report to the Town Council on Monday detailing the station's activity through the month of July.
As of July 31, the department has responded to 540 fire or rescue incidents this year, 255 of which came in the months of May, June and July, Jones said.
"I really want to point out that this is an all-volunteer organization, and as of July 31, our members have spent 8,515.07 hours in service to the community," Jones told the council. "And I'm very, very proud of all the men and women who do that."
Jones pointed out that Mondays around 3 p.m. tend to be the department's busiest time. He also said there's been a decrease in the number of false alarms.
"(Ward 2 Council Member Don) Abbatiello has assisted us with that in taking great strides to try to reduce the amount of false alarms," Jones said. "We have done some outreach to businesses which were problematic, and encouraged them to have a system to maintain."

The new training facility, which will be located at 9095 Mistletoe Drive in Easton, will be a hub for all volunteer firefighters across the Mid-Shore region who are looking for specialized education.

title: 'It's iconic': Tunis Mills residents push back against county design for bridge replacement
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
'It's iconic': Tunis Mills residents push back against county design for bridge replacement

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 692
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TUNIS MILLS — More than 50 people gathered at St Stephens AME Church Wednesday evening to engage with county leaders regarding proposed construction to replace the Leeds Creek Bridge in Tunis Mills.County employees and project engineers presented plans to replace the 345-foot wooden bridge. Designs propose a structure with a "laminated timber deck" and "asphalt wearing surface."
Residents living in and around Tunis Mills expressed a bevy of concerns about county designs Wednesday evening. Many testified to the bridge's uniqueness and fit in the community, while others are worried an asphalt surface would jeopardize the safety for residents, particularly children and teenagers.
"People love this bridge, it's iconic," Doug Marvin, who lives near the bridge, said. "I didn't grow up here, and I heard about it years before I bought the house where I did. It's like tradition for every kid that goes to school in this county to jump off the bridge … It's used in photographs, for tourism, to get people to come to this county."
Prompted by a question from the audience, nearly every single attendee raised a hand when posed with the choice of a timber surface versus an asphalt one.
At the end of the meeting, County Manager Clay Stamp said that the county and its public works department "will go back to the drawing board to a degree" to explore the wooden surface option.
"At this point I think it's fair to assure you that moving in the direction of a wooden deck bridge is the direction we are seeking," Stamp said.
PROJECT DESIGNSThe meeting began with a presentation of the proposed designs, which the county has said is around 90 to 95% complete.
Proposed changes to the bridge include adding an additional two feet of clearance, replacing timber piles with steel piles, adding a wooden laminated deck that can be paved over, widening the bridge slightly for walkers and improving a ramp and unloading platform. Several other bridges in the county have undergone similar laminated deck replacements.
The Talbot County Council first discussed replacing the bridge in 2007, allocating $1.8 million to the replacement project. Now, the project's estimated cost is around $6 million, with around $4.5 million federally funded.
Mark Ledebur, an engineering consultant, noted drawbacks to a full timber structure at Wednesday's meeting.
He said county experiences show an asphalt surface is less labor-intensive, easier to plow, smoother and easier to replace. Ledebur also presented quotes obtained by the county for timber boards in the case of replacement.
One resident asked if the county could compare costs for timber boards and asphalt, along with how often each material may have to be replaced. County Engineer Ray Clarke said his department could work on those comparisons.
A project schedule shown to attendees on Wednesday projected a final decision for the bridge replacement this September, though Clarke emphasized the county is not ready to submit and is keeping the option of a wooden surface open.
RESIDENT INPUTSusan McDermott leads a citizen group vowing for the bridge on Tunis Mills Road to remain as a full wooden structure.
The group, which has met with the county in the past, asserts that a timber structure is more durable than other materials and has environmental benefits. During the meeting, McDermott emphasized that the Leeds Creek Bridge is unique compared to busier bridges in Talbot County.
"Don't put an asphalt smear in the middle of our community," McDermott said. "We don't want it, and we don't need it."
Many residents that spoke Wednesday said an asphalt surface would only encourage speeding across the bridge. Both the current posted speed limit and the proposed one are 15 mph.
Some were worried for the safety of children and teenagers who jump off the bridge into the creek as an unofficial tradition in the area. Resident Claudia Donegan said kids "interact with this bridge intimately."
Peter Stifel lives right across from the bridge and has driven over it for almost 60 years. On Wednesday, Stifel said his support for a wooden replacement is a "vote for tradition."
"It is the heart and soul of a village," Stifel said of the bridge. "And I'd hate to see it succumb to the plastic, push-button world that we are all being forced into."

title: Hurlock opens walking trail, first of three-phases
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Hurlock opens walking trail, first of three-phases

 August 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 570
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HURLOCK — Hurlock residents have a new place where they can soak up the final weeks of summer: a paved walking trail.Using funds from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the town has completed the first phase of a three-phase, 1.5-mile trail project. This first part of the project, a 2,080-foot trail, stretches from Jackson Street to Delaware Avenue.
Hurlock Town Manager John Avery said the trail is a "relatively flat," six-foot-wide, paved asphalt trail with eight solar streetlights, three steel benches and trashcans placed along it.
Since its opening, the path gotten a lot of use. Avery said residents have reacted positively to the new public space.
"Everybody said that it's great they can have a place they can walk that's safe, that's lit at night," he said.
Hurlock Town Council Member Russell Murphy said in an email that the trail has been used "much more than expected."
"Every time I have been on it or ridden by it, there are people using it," he said. "We are so looking forward to completing phase two and phase three."
Murphy said he first introduced the idea for the trail as a way to light up Railroad Avenue and make it safer.
"Once seeing some of the rails-to-trails projects going on, it was brought up again as a way to provide a path from one end of town to another with safety and health also being in the forefront," he said.
Once all three phases of the project are complete, the trail will stretch 1.5 miles from one end of the town to the other, ending at North Main Street Park. To complete the last two phases of the project, Murphy said the county will need to take ownership of the railroad and then the town can ask for the county's permission to proceed with applying for grant funding.
Murphy said the Town Council hopes the trail will draw in visitors.
"We are hoping that anyone passing through will want to walk the trail and see what Hurlock has to offer," he said.
On Aug. 3, the town held a grand opening for the trail. Avery said the event went well, with Hurlock Mayor Rev. Charles T. Cephas and four of the Town Council's five council members in attendance.
Murphy called the grand opening "a monumental event." He said although the turnout was light, he hopes that word will get out and the trail will bring in prospective residents and businesses.
It took about two years for the trail to get built. Avery said the majority of that time was spent securing grant funding from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, which funded $82,000 of the approximately $105,000 project through the Community Parks and Playgrounds Program.
"The property is owned by Delmarva Power, so there was a joint-use agreement that had to go in place between Delmarva Power, the Department of Natural Resources and the town," Avery said. "And it took quite a while to get that worked out."
Avery said that after the agreement was worked out, the town was able to secure the grant funding for the project.
Murphy said the project could not have come to fruition if not for Avery and Cephas. He said the trail can bring residents closer together.
"When an activity, such as a park or trail, gets people outside, it will bring the community closer together," he said. "Its great to see neighbors and friends out and about so we can communicate and stay in touch with each other."

title: Motion fails for Trappe softball field grant application
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Motion fails for Trappe softball field grant application

 August 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 TRAPPE — A motion to approve grant funding application requests to add a softball field to HomeRun Baker Park failed at the Trappe Town Council's most recent meeting. Now, the council has scheduled a special session to again go over the requests before the application deadline passes.During the meeting on Aug. 7, community member Cheryl Lewis went before the council and requested approval for two items.
The first was permission to submit an application request on Aug. 21 to the Maryland Department of Natural Resources Community Parks and Playgrounds Program to obtain funds for a girls softball field.
The second was to make a motion to approve, contingent on the state, a change in the joint agreement between Talbot County and Trappe required for the grant fund application. The change would name the county as the local government responsible for the park maintenance.
According to Lewis, Maryland has pre-prepared a joint agreement for seeking park funds stating the local town government is responsible for maintaining the park's "attractive appearance."
Lewis requested the town council pass a motion changing the joint agreement to clarify that Talbot County will be responsible for the park, not Trappe.
Commissioner Walter Chase, a member of the county park advisory board, said Lewis should attend a park advisory board meeting for further approval.
"I'm on the park board, so I'm gonna have to get a field from the park board before I sign anything right here because I don't get myself in trouble," Chase said.
Lewis said she had met with the county's parks advisory board during their last meeting and they had approved the concept of the softball field.
"(The park advisory board) did approve the concept of the softball field," Lewis said. "The joint agreement part they don't have authority to do. That's between (Trappe) and the Talbot County Council, and I'm talking to the... County Council at their meeting next week."
Lewis urged the council to pass the two motions, stating that applications are only accepted within the month of August and once the month passes they will not be able to apply until next year.
During the vote, Commissioner Rosalee Potter and Chase did not approve the motion to approve the application, and it failed to pass.
Chase said he would like to bring it back up with the parks board for approval. Potter said, "this is not anything personal. I am just accustomed to doing things more in order."
In order to stay within the August deadline, the Trappe Council will hold a special meeting the morning of Aug. 19 with the purpose of reviewing the grant funding application requests to be submitted. The public is welcomed to appear.

title: Oxford adopts administrative guide, clarifies agenda setting
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford adopts administrative guide, clarifies agenda setting

 August 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 344

 OXFORD — On Tuesday, the Commissioners of Oxford approved a resolution to adopt an administrative guide for town employees and commissioners and to clarify the authority to set agendas for commissioners meetings.The resolution also makes it so that commission meeting agendas will now have a consent agenda, which groups agenda items to be voted on together. Department head reports will be placed on the consent agenda. Commissioner Katrina Greer said this will allow for more legislative time at meetings.
The resolution, effective immediately, permits the commissioners to develop and adopt administrative policies that "promote good governance and transparency."
Greer made the motion to pass the resolution at the commission meeting on Tuesday. The resolution was passed unanimously.
"We've been talking about how to best deal with each other and the staff and setting up some norms," Greer said before the vote.
When it comes to agenda setting, the resolution sets deadlines for when items can be submitted and states that the commissioners must approve the agenda.
The administrative guide will break down what commissioners must approve and be notified of and what decisions and tasks are under the authority of the town manager or clerk treasurer. The guide will also details that in the event there is not a town manager, those duties will be taken on by the clerk treasurer with guidance from the commissioners.
The town has been without a manager since the retirement of former Town Manager Cheryl Lewis at the end of June.
The commissioners' next open session meeting will be next Tuesday, Aug. 20 at 6 p.m.
Greer said the commissioners will also be holding a special closed meeting on Friday to discuss search firm contracts. The town is seeking a search firm to help in its search for the next town manager.
Commission President Norm Bell said the commissioners started with a list of seven search firms and have since narrowed it down to five. He said some due diligence is still needed before the commission can come to a decision, but if all goes well, the commissioners will vote on a search firm next Tuesday.

title: Oxford residents share concerns over Delmarva Power's tree trimming
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford residents share concerns over Delmarva Power's tree trimming

 August 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Concerns over tree trimming — from tree safety, to property safety, to aesthetics — took up much of the first half of a Commissioners of Oxford meeting on Tuesday.At the meeting, two representatives from Delmarva Power and Light spoke about the tree trimming they have done in Oxford and other towns on the Shore every four years.
Renee Sheehy, senior public affairs manager at Delmarva Power and Light, acknowledged that residents had questions and concerns regarding the trimmings this year. She said Delmarva Power and Light recently met with the town about it.
Jeff Middleton, senior program manager for vegetation management at Delmarva Power and Light, said that across the nation, between 40 and 50% of all electrical outages are caused by trees, making the maintenance of vegetation near power lines important. He said the company follows industry standards when it comes to trimming trees, including using directional pruning to "encourage vegetation to grow away from the power lines."
During the meeting, residents expressed concerns that the trees had been trimmed back too far. Art Murr said his neighbor's tree was trimmed all the way back to the bird's nest.
"The tree, honestly, was butchered," he said.
Resident Barbara Paca said the tree Murr is referring to will probably die of sunscald due to the way it was trimmed by the contractors hired by Delmarva Power and Light.
In response to residents' concerns, Middleton said he understood the change can be "stark" and "jarring."
"But please know the trees that we're looking at, they were trimmed four years ago," he said. "The trees that were lush, they are going to be lush again. I wouldn't have a job if I killed every tree along the power lines and if they didn't grow back."
Murr said he understood what Middleton was saying, but wanted to point out the "stark" difference in how his neighbor's tree was trimmed this year compared to four years ago.
Other concerns brought up by residents include the look of the trimmed trees, Delmarva Power and Light's notification standards and safety to personal property.
Resident Leslie Howells said when the tree outside her home was trimmed, no one knocked on her door to notify her to move her car, which was parked beneath the tree in the driveway. She said her car was within four feet of the tree that they were pruning "big tree limbs" from.
Middleton said that if there is any concern about damaging private property, the workers will not proceed.
"Apparently the people that were there, they felt comfortable that they could perform the work safely, and they proceeded," he said.
Howells said that was unacceptable and residents should be properly notified of when the tree trimmings will take place.
Oxford commissioners also voiced some concern at the meeting. Commissioner Katrina Greer said when she and Oxford Wastewater Superintendent Matt Ozman approached one of the sites where trees were being trimmed, there was no supervisor.
Both Greer and Commission President Norm Bell, acknowledging they aren't arborists, said some trees looked over-cut.
Sheehy said this reaction from residents is common when the trees are trimmed. She said utility directional pruning is different from how an arborist might prune because some limbs need to be trimmed in a way that could seem over-cut.
"But it has to be done there because of the nature of directional pruning," she said.
Middleton said he suggested to the commissioners that the community put together a tree council.

title: Bradley Park suggested for future dog park in St. Michaels
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Bradley Park suggested for future dog park in St. Michaels

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 679

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — A group of St. Michaels residents want a dog park in what they call an "underutilized park," but the town administrator and some commissioners seemed reluctant to commit to it at a Wednesday night meeting.The Commissioners of St. Michaels did not vote on the issue, and the item was moved to the next meeting in September.
Mitch Ettinger, founder of Friends of the Dog Park, came dressed for the occasion — a shirt decorated with dog drawing and a folder covered with dogs wearing sunglasses.
For over three years, Friends of the Dog Park, a group of St. Michaels residents and dog owners, have been advocating for a park to bring their dogs and create community.
Now in front of a new commission, Ettinger recommended Bradley Park for the dog park. According to Ettinger, the one-acre park is underutilized; there are few residential homes located nearby. Bradley Park is also already unkempt by the town, and it would not require additional acquisition funds.
Ettinger said the overall cost of the park would be approximately half a million dollars to remove the old playground equipment, create a fence and renovate the park to better fit a dog park. The Friends of the Dog Park has filed to become a nonprofit and will plan to raise the funds through donations and grants so the cost would not fall on St. Michaels residents.
Ettinger asked commissioners to tentatively approve Bradley Park as the future St. Michaels dog park and to direct town staff to retain an engineering firm to prepare a site plan that will be submitted to the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board and Planning Commission.
The group asked for about $7,000 for the site survey because all efforts up until now have been completed and paid for by residents.
"[Friends of the Dog Park] might feel that the town has skin in the game," Ettinger said. "That we don't have to go out and raise $7,000 in our pockets to have a site plan that ultimately could be shut down."
Rob Straebel, town administrator, raised concerns he had with the park, stating a need for more public comment from residents before moving forward.
"I know that this community, they take their parks very seriously," Straebel said. "And unfortunately, this is going to be a fair amount of people that are opposed to it, and there's probably going to be a fair amount of people that would love to see a dog park there."
Commissioner Katrina Whittington raised questions over the town's prioritizes when it comes to supporting projects. According to Whittington, the town was deciding whether to pay over $200,000 for a small plan for a dog park and yet there is concerns over funding a site plan for Bradley Park.
Straebel said the $200,000 would have been a "policy decision" by commissioners for a different property.
More questions and potential ideas were raised by commissioners. Some suggesting bifurcating Bradley Park and updating the playground equipment, others sharing concern for the price of the park and public opinion of the park.
Ettinger reminded commissioners that he had offered to do a survey the last time he was in front of the council and he was told not to.
Additionally, he said, when the town hired an architect to come up with a master plan for the seven acres at San Domingo Park, a survey of the entire town was done and from the residents who participated, their No. 1 request was a dog park.
A few resident commented that there is a responsibility from the new commissioners to work toward a dog park since during the commission election last spring they had said they would approve it.
Whittington suggested the commissioners move the subject to the next meeting but noted that the idea of a dog park has not seen much progress in years.
"This seems like Groundhog Day all over again," Whittington said. "... This is ridiculous just to get a dog park here at St. Michaels."
After a bit of back and forth from commissioners and town residents, the council decided to delay further discussion on the park until the September meeting.

title: Town Council approves 33-unit housing project at former Safeway site
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Town Council approves 33-unit housing project at former Safeway site

 August 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A proposal for a 33-unit housing development at the site of the former Safeway in downtown Easton was unanimously approved by the Easton Town Council on Monday evening.The proposal came from Lane Engineering on behalf of NAI Saturn Eastern and Safeway, along with Miller Development Corporation, the potential developers of the project. It includes 24 partially-connected townhomes and nine standalone units. The property, which has been vacant since 2017, sits at 139 N. Washington St.
The town's planning and historic district commissions reviewed the proposal before it landed on the Town Council's agenda this summer. On Monday, council members gave the green light to the project, which fell under the town's planned unit development infill subdistrict.
"I can assure you that we all thought long and hard about this," Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello said before the vote. "This was not a quick decision. … This is going to be a decision that is going to outlive our tenures on the council."
Town Attorney Sharon VanEmburgh discussed three conditions included in a findings of fact for the application prior to the vote.
The first condition requires developers to contribute $10,000 per unit to the town's affordable housing fund, with $5,000 due when the unit's building permit is issued and the other $5,000 due when the unit becomes occupied.
The second condition indicates the units "shall be privately maintained by a homeowners' association established for the community, which shall also provide private trash collection for all residences of the PUD District."
"They have to include that in their covenants," VanEmburgh said, "so there is notice to everyone who buys a piece of property there that it will be private trash pickup."
The final condition states if developers stray too much from the approved architecture of the homes, the project will have to return to the town's planning and historic district commissions for review.
While an Aug. 5 public hearing went by without resident input, many concerns were brought to the council at the project's previous public hearings in June and July. Abbatiello directly addressed those concerns prior to the vote Monday, including traffic, parking and the prospect of building a grocery store at the site.
"Traffic was another concern that was raised by many of my constituents," Abbatiello said, "and while the 33 units will add some traffic to the area, it will be significantly less than what was there when Safeway was open."
Abbatiello added that after following up on Town Council discussions about parking, he learned there are "over 550 parking spots, not including on-street parking, in the downtown area." Some residents' wishes that a grocery store replace Safeway "comes down to the fact that the current owner of the property is not going to sell it with the idea of developing another grocery store in that spot," he said.
Abbatiello's most difficult hurdle in fully supporting the project was the affordability aspect, he said.
"None of these units are going to be affordable," Abbatiello said. "We need housing for seniors, which was mentioned a lot. We need apartments that don't charge $1,600 for a one-bedroom. We do need those things. But when you look at the sale price for this property, there's no way a developer could purchase that and turn it into an affordable housing project."
Abbatiello thanked Robert Miller, the founder of Miller Development Corporation, for listening to council concerns and agreeing to "financially support an infrastructure project that's going to provide necessary workforce housing to town employees."
Ward 1 Council Member Maureen Curry echoed Abbatiello's statements and thanked developers.
"I could not have said it any better and I thank you for all the same reasons," Curry said. "And I appreciate the Miller (Development Corporation) stepping up and donating $10,000 per unit to our affordable housing fund."

title: Farmers, residents raise safety concerns regarding potential Route 662 closure
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Farmers, residents raise safety concerns regarding potential Route 662 closure

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 758
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As site preparation is underway for a new regional medical center in Easton, many residents are concerned about the looming closure of Route 662, or Longwoods Road.The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new hospital is expected to begin construction in the spring of 2025. Since designs have a corner of the hospital sitting in the middle of existing Route 662, a section of the road is expected to be temporarily closed from Oct. 1 to May 1.
Greg Gannon, a co-operator of family-owned grain farming operation C.H. Gannon & Sons on Longwoods Road, is not necessarily opposed to the closure. But Gannon said that the closure will "represent an inconvenience at some level" to not just the agricultural community, but everyone who uses the road.
"Moving large farm equipment and construction equipment these days is dangerous," Gannon said.
Instead of using Route 662, many farmers may have to travel on nearby county-owned roads. Gannon noted the visibility is worse on those county roads compared to Route 662.
Shore Regional Health representatives have stated that delaying construction of the hospital until a new route is complete would present significant financial and time barriers to the project. Hospital construction is estimated to complete in the summer of 2028.
"The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health is committed to advancing the health of Mid-Shore residents and the new Regional Medical Center project is one of the most significant developments in the history of Talbot and its surrounding counties," Shore Regional said in a statement enailed to the Star Democrat. "We recognize that building a state-of-the-art hospital to replace an aging and outdated facility may cause inconveniences and have worked tirelessly with state, county and city officials to ensure interruptions to daily activities are minimized. The necessary decision for a temporary closure of Route 662 was made in conjunction with the State Highway Administration, Talbot County officials and the Talbot County Sherriff's Office."
Nearly 70 residents wrote to the Talbot County Council in opposition of a bill that acts as a land transfer agreement between the county and Shore Regional, amending old legislation that required Shore Regional to build a new route before closing the current one.
A request signed by 67 residents asked that the county stick with the original plan that dated back to 2013. Council members voted 4-1 to approve the bill at their most recent meeting, with Council Member Lynn Mielke the sole no vote.
The letter presented four main concerns: increased traffic on local county roads, potential backups if there's an emergency situation on U.S. Route 50, effects on farmers who use Route 662 for equipment and access to the Talbot County Community Center.
Wittman resident Mark Marshall, who signed the letter, uses the road to travel to and from work. He believes it'll be a detriment to safety for farmers and residents alike.
"It's going to put a hardship on a lot of people who basically depend on that road," Marshall said, "especially on weekends with the traffic and everything going to and from Easton."
As part of the bill passed Tuesday, the transfer of the land from the county to Shore Regional Health is contingent upon the fulfillment of a road inspection and contribution agreement. That agreement requires Shore Regional Health to contribute to surrounding road work.
Surrounding county roads — Hailem School Road, Hiners Lane, Airport Road and Goldsborough Neck Road — will all receive paving work this September, County Manager Clay Stamp said. Though that paving is unrelated to the potential Route 662 closure, Stamp said Shore Regional Health will be contributing financially to the effort.
Since Route 662 is a state road, the Maryland State Highway Administration is responsible for approving its temporary closure and providing an official detour, which is expected to be U.S Route 50.
"SHA continues to work with all involved parties and will review the proposed detour plan to ensure it meets standards and provides for a safe alternate route," SHA wrote in a statement to The Star Democrat.
While the bill approved by the county facilitates the transfer of the road from the county to Shore Regional Health, the Maryland Board of Public Works first must approve the transfer of the land from the state to the county.
Upon successful transfers and State Highway Administration approval, the road may be partially closed for drivers come Oct. 1. Marshall, who drives Route 662 nearly every day and sees large farm equipment, is worried for the safety of the operators when that time arrives.
"If you have to go down (Route) 50, you're taking your life in your own hands," Marshall said.

title: Washington College court win confirms partial demolition of armory will proceed
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Washington College court win confirms partial demolition of armory will proceed

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Chestertown Historic District Commission's May 1 decision to grant an application to Washington College to partially demolish the John H. Newnam Armory will most likely stand following a judge's ruling Wednesday.Over the summer, the college hit a speed bump in its plan to build a boutique hotel and conference center on the property that once headquartered the National Guard.
After the Historic District Commission's decision, there was a citizen's appeal made to the circuit court by residents Barbara Jorgenson, Tom Kocubinski and Steve Mitchell. They were opposed to the college's plan, favoring restoration over partial demolition.
But on Wednesday, with local Judge Harris Murphy recusing himself, visiting Judge Sidney Campen sided with the college.
Campen's decision came on the grounds that the petitioners didn't have legal standing to make their appeal.
In his opening argument, Collin Wojciechowski, an attorney representing the college, brought up a case he said was similar to this one.
Ray v. Mayor and Maryland City Council of Baltimore, he said, had "striking parallels in this matter."
In that case, citizens lived within 1,000 feet of the property, but the city still moved to dismiss the case, a move with which the Maryland Supreme Court agreed.
Unlike in that case, the petitioners, Wojciechowski claimed, can't argue by proximity since none of them live within 1,000 feet of the applicant property.
He said other than proximity, the burden of proof for the petitioners is to prove their "personal or property rights are adversely affected in a way different than the rest of the public."
"... Petitioners can't show that here. None of the history of the individuals is unique from their neighbors. That uniqueness is needed and Maryland courts have never found it to exist," Wojciechowski said.
Nelson rebutted, saying this case was indeed unique.
"There's no appellate authority that addresses the question of standing in the historic district," Nelson said.
Furthermore, he said he had actually worked the case referenced by the defense, arguing it in every stage of litigation.
That issue, he said, was a zoning decision over a 200,000-square-foot Walmart, not an historic district decision of a building constructed in 1931 in a small town.
He firmly disagreed with Wojciechowski. Residents within the Chestertown historical district are the exception, he said, because demolishing and rebuilding will affect the petitioners' taxes, property values and insurance.
Then pointing to the Historic District Commission guidelines, he read, "If an owner within the historic district allows a building to fall in disrepair, that adversely affects the character of the district."
And again in the guidelines, "The loss of any contributing historic building diminishes the district and can never be replaced."
Nelson said in this situation, the college allowed the building to go into disrepair. Additionally the Historic District Commission then violated guidelines by not issuing a written statement summarizing their decision on May 1, he said.
Combined with the written testimonies from the petitioners, it proves they should have standing, he said.
Wojciechowski countered, stating this is straightforward case, and the arguments about the Historic District Commission were merit questions, not about standing.
He said if the judge allowed this, it would set a precedent encouraging the appeal of Historic District Commission decisions.
After both sides presented their arguments, the judge agreed with Wojciechowski, dismissing the petitioner's claim.
He said Nelson did not present enough evidence or case law to show the petitioners would be adversely affected differently than any other resident in the district.
Mike Sosulski, president of the college, said he was satisfied with the judge's decision. "I think's it's the right result," he said. "While we appreciate our neighbor's position, we're pleased that the project's going forward."

title: St. Michaels proposed dog park must find new location
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
St. Michaels proposed dog park must find new location

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The long-desired dog park for St. Michaels has faced yet another barrier in its journey to becoming reality. Friends of St. Michaels Dog Park, a volunteer group advocating for the park, have decided to move away from the proposed Bradley Parks location due to concerns from residents.During the Aug. 14 Commissioners of St. Michaels meeting, members of Friends of St. Michaels Dog Park spoke up and suggested Bradley Park as the location for the future park. According to Mitch Ettinger, the founder of Friends of St. Michaels Dog Park, the one-acre park was "underutilized" with few residential homes located nearby and had the added bonus of already being maintained by the town.
But last week, St. Michaels residents were sent a message from Ettinger stating the group had requested the commissioners remove the planned dog park discussion from the Sept. 11 meeting.
Ettinger said the decision came after hearing concerns from those living adjacent to Bradley Park. These concerns included noise from barking and the effect the park would have on the property value of their home, Ettinger said.
"Quite frankly, I just couldn't see myself standing up and saying, 'disregard these neighbors.' That's not the way that I think. That's not the way that my committee thinks," Ettinger said. "And so we withdrew the proposal for Bradley Park and asked the commissioners to take it off the agenda for this week."
The effort to have a dog park built in St. Michaels has been ongoing for more than three years. Ettinger said the dog park has been volunteer-led since its origins and is widely supported by residents of the town, according to a survey conducted when an architect was coming up with a master plan for seven acres at San Domingo Park. The site did not work for a dog park due to grant requirements that would prohibit fencing.
Moving forward, Ettinger said he would like to see commissioners of St. Michaels to take initiative and assist with the finding of a new property.
"It's time for the commissioners to step up, and they've been supportive of this concept, but they have yet to propose a location," Ettinger said.
Ettinger said his group would continue to work behind the scenes to assist commissioners in picking a location, and currently there are a couple of options that are under consideration.
Dan Conway, a member of Friends of St. Michaels Dog Park, said he and the committee are still committed to the dog park project. For him, it is more than just a place for dogs to run around. It is a community building area and would benefit owners and dogs alike in St. Michaels.
"Dog parks aren't really for dogs ... They're for people, and they help make a municipality, a community," Conway said. "In my experience, it's where townspeople can get together and renew acquaintances and make friends and share experiences. And so that, to me, is the beauty of a dog park."

title: CWDI Board accepts member resignation, fills two open seats
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
CWDI Board accepts member resignation, fills two open seats

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — During the closed session of a Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. Board of Directors meeting on Wednesday, the board accepted the resignation of board member Dion Banks and accepted appointments from the City of Cambridge for two vacancies.In an interview with the Star Democrat, CWDI Board President Angie Hengst said Gaver Nichols and Natalie Chabot will fill the seats of Banks and former board member Rich Zeidman.
Cambridge City Council President Lajan Cephas said the new board members were the "best candidates" for the open seats.
"(They are) people who know this community, and they understand it," Cephas said. "And I know they have the best interest at heart."
Hengst said both new members have the experience the board was looking for and fill in knowledge gaps on the board. She said Nichols has development and architecture experience and Chabot has a long history with the community.
Nichols, who is an architect, is currently a member of the Cambridge Board of Zoning Appeals. Hengst said Nichols will be resigning from that board.
Cephas said Nichols' experience with the Board of Zoning Appeals will give CWDI the advantage of understanding what's expected when it comes to zoning.
"That should build an even stronger relationship between the city and CWDI so that they're prepared before they go to the table knowing what will pass and what likely is not going to pass," Cephas said.
In an interview with the Star Democrat, Nichols said he is proud to be on the board. He said he hopes to see the waterfront become "an outstanding place to go" as a local and as someone visiting Cambridge.
Hengst said Chabot is "invested in the community." In her career, Chabot has served as Cambridge's economic development director and Dorchester County's tourism director. She also served on the Sailwinds Park Board for more than a decade.
Cephas said throughout Chabot's career, she has "always protected the historical fabric of our community." Cephas said Chabot is "well-versed" when it comes to grant money that is available for development projects.
In an interview with the Star Democrat, Chabot said she views the appointment as a great opportunity for herself and for the board. She said she thinks she can bring a lot to the table with her experience and passion.
Chabot said she is looking forward to being a proactive member on the board and seeing significant action on the waterfront.
Zeidman, who was appointed to the board by the city in 2018 and reappointed in 2021, resigned in May. In a May 23 news release from CWDI, Zeidman mentioned the progress that CWDI has made on Cambridge Harbor and his desire to spend his retirement years in actual retirement as reasons for his resignation.
That month, amid a lawsuit with the city, CWDI alleged in a court motion that Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout had sent a letter to Zeidman in October requesting his resignation from the CWDI board.
Banks joined the board as a city appointee in 2022. Hengst said in a text message that Banks resigned due to "increased travel demands in his current position at work," which made him unable "to devote the necessary time to the board."
Cephas said she is sure this decision is something Banks thought long and hard about and felt was best, not just for himself, but for CWDI.
"That's just the type of person that Dion is," she said.
Banks did not immediately respond for comment.

title: Easton, can you spare a dime for a paper bag?
author: MARION O ARNOLD
content:
Easton, can you spare a dime for a paper bag?

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARION O ARNOLD | Section: Columns 
 
 714
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus has introduced an ordinance aimed at the town's Plastic Bag Law by doing away with the paper bag fee.The law prohibits stores from providing plastic bags and requires retailers to charge a 10-cent fee for paper bags. The fee helps retailers with the higher cost of paper bags. According to Maryland Retailers Association's Sarah Price, who testified at the last Town Council meeting, the 10-cent fee helps level the playing field between retailers allowing them to recover the cost of paper bags for shoppers who take them, reducing overhead and keeping prices lower for all shoppers. It's a fee, not a tax. Retailers keep the fee.
Paper bags come at an environmental cost, so the 10-cent fee also helps the law from inadvertently substituting one environmental problem with another. Paper bags require trees and a polluting process to make them. Paper bags can be recycled or composted, but most will end up in landfills where they become a source of planet-warming methane gas.
For shoppers, the fee makes things more equitable. Those shoppers who take paper bags pay for them. Not having a fee will raise prices on other goods since retailers will have to recoup the increased costs of giving out "free" paper bags. Those of us who bring our own bags will end up paying higher prices, even though we won't be using disposable paper bags.
Most importantly, the 10-cent fee incentivizes shoppers to bring their own bags. It's your choice. You don't have to spend a dime if you bring your reusable bags.
I think of major environmental laws like the Clean Air and the Clean Water acts. Businesses had to make big investments to meet the demands of the laws or meet up with stiff penalties and fines. Here, with our plastic bag law, we're just asking businesses to charge a small fee for paper bags and to keep every dime they collect.
Without the 10-cent fee the law loses a part of its environmental impact. No one is saying let's bring back plastic bags, but if free, paper bags will fly out retailers' doors — and smaller retailers will bear the cost. Laurel, Maryland, passed a bag law in 2022 without a fee. Two years later, they changed their law to add a 10-cent paper bag fee because more than two-thirds of shoppers there just took the free paper bags. Since January, shoppers in Laurel taking paper bags has dropped to 32%.
Easton's plastic bag law was the result of months of work by a team of town leaders, Easton residents, and community representatives, with encouragement and backing from Talbot watermen, local businesses and environmental organizations. Since then, plastic bags no longer hang from our trees, pile up in hedgerows and ditches, and end up in our waterways. The economic and environmental benefits for Easton are many.
Jeff Harrison, president of the Talbot Watermen Association, was an early supporter of the plastic bag law. He has said, "We have to understand, whatever we do on the land eventually ends up in the water." At the last town council meeting, he testified to the law's success, saying he "doesn't see bags in the water anymore."
The law works, and we can readily see the results.
Mr. Gunsallus argued that repealing the 10-cent fee was for those "who are struggling." I have no doubt that people struggle, but no one shopping in Easton is required to pay that 10-cent fee either. There's no fee if you bring your own bag. Bing Crosby's big hit from 1932, "Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?" came to mind. Back then you could go to a five and dime store and do some damage with that dime in your pocket. You could get two pairs of socks or two cups of coffee. Today, about all you can get for a dime is a brown paper bag.
Mr. Gunsallus does not take into account the greater cost of pollution from paper bags. It affects us, the creatures we share this space with, and causes economic and environmental damage. The 10-cent paper bag fee helps the plastic bag law work. Thanks to our enlightened town leaders, the law is a great success and a benefit to us all. As the old saying goes, "If it ain't broke, don't fix it."

 NORTH EAST — The new trail system to Turkey Point Lighthouse is now open to the public since construction is complete, according to Mary Ironside, manager of Elk Neck State Park.The trail was closed in March to allow Kibler Construction to build a new trail and a new parking lot for the popular spot overlooking the Elk River and the Chesapeake Bay, at a cost of $3.8 million. It was finished five months ahead of schedule.
"We now have more parking," Ironside said. "The new trail gives easier access to the lighthouse."
To get that new trail, Park Ranger Shannon Whalen said the original parking lot is now a turnaround for vehicle traffic and another field was used to create the larger lot with 52 parking spots instead of 26. Ironside said residents of the neighboring Chesapeake Isles community will no longer fight with traffic.
"Our goal was to alleviate the heavy traffic at Turkey Point Lighthouse," she added, noting there is a new route connecting the larger parking lot to the historic lighthouse.
Whalen said there is now dedicated handicapped parking closer to the lighthouse.
"They can drive right up to the lighthouse," Whalen said. Handicapped visitors need only call the park ranger at 443-252-4258 and ask for access, which will unlock the gates.
Repositioning the location of the trail also mitigates erosion issues on the high shore line.
"We abandoned the old trail, which will be replanted to stabilize the soil and eliminate erosion," Ironside said. "We will turn that back with native vegetation."
Meanwhile, progress continues on the renovation of the campgrounds at Elk Neck State Park.
"We have limited camping for the campground," Ironside said. "A lot of loops are being shut down."
It reduces the available spaces from 300 to 76. Only two loops will remain open plus the youth group camp.
"The beach and Rogues Harbor will remain open throughout," she added. So will Turkey Point Lighthouse.
Whalen said the work to address parking made slight changes to the trail.
"It's the same loop but now it's .8 miles instead of 1.2," Whalen said. "And we have port-a-johns in the parking lot."
Turkey Point Lighthouse will be open every weekend in October from 10 a.m. until 2 p.m. for tours. The park itself is open seven days per week from 7 a.m. until sunset.

title: Oxford Commissioners pass meeting policy, residents express concerns
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford Commissioners pass meeting policy, residents express concerns

 September 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 651
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Gasps, sighs and exclamations could be heard throughout a Commissioners of Oxford discussion on Tuesday evening that ended in a 2-1 vote to pass a resolution establishing town meeting procedures.The resolution, introduced by Commission President Norm Bell at a town meeting on Sept. 10, establishes general rules and procedures regarding public participation at town meetings. During the Sept. 10 meeting, Bell said the purpose of the policy "is to create an atmosphere where the elected officials, staff and members of the public can attend to business efficiently, fairly and with full participation."
Specifically, the policy limits when and for how long public commenters can speak and prohibits heckling, defamatory comments and profanity. The resolution also makes it so commissioners do not have to answer questions residents ask during public comment.
The different limitations, as well as the way in which the resolution was passed, drew concern from residents.
Both Bell and Commissioner Tom Costigan said during the discussion that the commissioners had been receiving responses from residents regarding Bell's proposed resolution since the previous town meeting when it was introduced.
Commissioner Katrina Greer — who voted against passing the resolution — brought up the town's charter, which says, "the rules of the commissioners shall provide that residents of the town shall have a reasonable opportunity to be heard at any meeting in regard to any municipal question."
Greer said she is proposing a different resolution, which hadn't yet been posted on the town website prior to Tuesday's meeting. Greer said she wanted to schedule a workshop, gather input and put together one merged resolution to vote on.
"There is a need, and most towns have it, for a little bit of rules," she said. "But this is something that the town needs to participate in and see the documents."
Greer said that unlike Bell's proposal that restricts public comment to the end of a meeting, hers would allow for public comment before actionable items, or items that are voted on.
"Letting people talk at the end of the meeting about something that has already been voted on is useless and does not satisfy the requirement for a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the meeting," she said. "It is also dismissive of the right of citizens to participate."
Tensions rose throughout the discussion, which public comment was not allowed during. At one point, one resident asked the commissioners, "Are you really not going to allow public comment on this?"
Bell responded that the commissioners had received feedback prior meeting. When another resident spoke up, Bell said, "Excuse me, there will not be back talk. Please."
At another point, when resident Susan Kordell started to make a comment, Bell banged his gavel and told her to "sit down, please."
At the end of the meeting, Bell said he acted "quickly" to try to stop commenters due to concerns about the commissioners' time to discuss the matter at hand.
Although Greer felt the commissioners should not vote on meeting procedures Tuesday evening, both Costigan and Bell said they were ready to vote.
"It's a resolution, and if there are any amendments to it, we can certainly address them in the two weeks, and we (can) vote on any amendments or changes or adoption of one over the other," Bell said.
Along with approving Bell's proposed resolution, Bell and Costigan agreed to schedule a workshop on the topic for next week so at the next town meeting, the commissioners can consider any amendments that might be suggested.
At the end of the meeting, resident Emilie Knud-Hansen said she though thought the procedure around the resolution at the meeting was unfair.
"We deserve to find out what you're voting on before you say, 'We'll vote on this resolution and then we'll deal with amendments,'" she said. "I think that's really backwards."
Resident Dave Donovan said at the end of the meeting that there was irony in the fact that a resolution on public comment "was itself enacted without public comment."

title: Attorney general: Sheriff has limited role in electoral process
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Attorney general: Sheriff has limited role in electoral process

 October 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 652
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown wrote a letter to Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gable detailing the "limited role of local law enforcement, including our sheriff's office in the electoral process."The letter from Brown was read aloud by Tammy Stafford, election director for Talbot County, during an Oct. 7 Board of Elections special meeting.
Although the letter is not an official opinion of the attorney general, Brown said he hopes the letter is helpful in setting forth the roles of law enforcement officers during elections.
The letter is the latest salvo on the topic of sometimes tense back-and-forth between the Talbot County Board of Elections, the Talbot County Sheriff and local elected officials in recent weeks.
Brown's letter responds to a letter sent by Gamble to the Board of Elections on issues concerning the upcoming election, in which Gamble "strongly" urged the board to follow state law.
In Brown's letter, he addresses the role of law enforcement, security, authority on election law violations and concerns involving election judges.
"State law does, specifies and carefully circumscribes the authority of local law enforcement and polling places while conferring primary responsibility for election law enforcement on other agencies," Brown said. "I understand that local law enforcement agencies do provide assistance to local boards of elections in some jurisdictions, including deploying personnel to provide security and transporting election materials. But importantly, this is done at the request and under the direction of the local Board of Elections itself."
Gamble's letter came in the midst of intense discussions centering concerns over the partisan breakdown of election judges ahead of the Nov. 5 General Election.
According to the most recent breakdown from the Talbot County Board of Elections, 62 judges are Democrats, 50 are Republicans and 11 are unaffiliated.
Maryland election code states "each polling place shall have an equal number of election judges" from "the majority party" and "the principal minority party."
State election law permits judges not affiliated with either party for precincts with six or more judges, as well as "one or more election judges who are minors." The number of unaffiliated judges "may not exceed the lesser of" the majority or minority party, law states.
Discussion about the imbalance of election judge political party affiliations surfaced after Talbot County Council Member Dave Stepp raised it in a council meeting Sept. 24. He voiced concerns the county Board of Elections was not following state law for election judges, though his motion for the council to send a letter to the elections board failed by a 3-2 vote.
In his letter, Brown emphasized state law "does not require equality in the total number of judges" recruited and trained by the local Board of Elections.
"Even at the individual polling place level, while all local boards make best efforts to achieve exact party balance, this is not always possible for reasons outside the local board's control, including the number of judges from each party who volunteer," Brown said.
Toward the end of Brown's letter, he advised that opening a polling place, even if the number of judges from each party is not exactly equal, is preferable to "closing the polling place and disenfranchising all the voters who would have voted there."
After the reading of the letter, the county Board of Elections weighed whether to release its own letter or statement to the public addressing the election judge concerns.
Denise Lovelady, a member of the board of elections, said the issue with Brown's letter is it is still subject to "clarification." She said the letter speaks more to security issues than election judge equality.
After a bit of discussion, board members voted 3-1 to sent out Brown's letter instead of drafting their own. Lovelady voted against sending Brown's letter.
"I don't feel that it services the public, that it's giving them the full information that they need," Lovelady said. "The board is kind of skirting the issue that it needs to be defined better than what it has been in these meetings."

title: Caroline County landowners offer different perspectives on expanding solar
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline County landowners offer different perspectives on expanding solar

 October 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Converting Caroline County land into solar is a contentious issue.Some landowners see a chance to repurpose their land, add to the tax base and make some money. Others think it is against the rural character of the county.
Dave Tribbet owns farmland in Ridgely. He said he has been approached a couple of times by solar companies, and he has declined their offers.
"If you are taking up farmland, is solar going to feed anybody? I don't like solar. I am an adamant farmer who believes in feeding people," Tribbett said.
But he acknowledges that not all farmers in the county take the same stance on the issue as he does. He said he sees some landowners going for solar, attracted by the stable profits that farming can't always provide.
"A lot of the younger generations that inherited farms, that did not do the work, the backbone of the farm, to really appreciate the farm, and they see the money that is offered them. They are the ones probably jumping in on that," Tribbett said. "There is less risk, and they are guaranteed the pay at the end of the day."
Another farmer, Jim Lewis, sold 200 acres, a part of his farm, to Enel, a multinational corporation, for the Waypost Solar Project. It is near Templeville and Marydel.
Enel claims it will supply carbon-free electricity to 15,000 homes with this project. The company bought land from nine landowners and have 550 panel acres.
"I am not one to say 'everything is for sale,' but at the right price 'everything is for sale.' They offered 1.5 times my land's value. The piece of land was not the best farmland that I farmed. If I can trade one piece of land and walk away with some money, then I essentially doubled the size of the land that I had by doing it," Lewis said.
"If I can make $1,000 an acre with solar, and I can only make $100 growing corn or soy beans, it is back to economics," Lewis said. He later added that because he is making more money off the land, more of his income can be collected in taxes.
Solar relies on the transmission lines in Caroline County, which are used to move the energy. If land is not adjacent to the lines, it isn't as useful to solar companies.
The county government has put a cap of 2,000 acres that are available for solar development. Most of those acres have been developed already.
Decommissioning, the process of dismantling the solar panels and steel posts at the end of their lives, has county leadership worried that solar will leave an eyesore that is hard to get rid of.
Lewis said that solar companies have told him that when 20 years go by, they will take the panels because they are valuable.
"If they leave me a farm that has steel stakes that the panels were on, I can with a mini excavator with a thumb and a roll off can, I can clean up 20 or 30 acres a day and make it back into ag productive land," Lewis said.
But Lewis said he can see the aesthetic downside. And he can see if you are a farmer that rents land, that solar is competition.
"The commissioners shouldn't care about people's private business deals," Lewis said.
At a council meeting Commissioner Larry Porter said, "This is a fight that we better gear up for. I am not going to see this county covered in solar."
