title: Queen Anne's looking to connect county trails
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's looking to connect county trails

 October 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 494
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Cross county trail connectivity is on the right path as Steve Chandlee, Queen Anne's Parks and Recreation director and Steve Cohoon, public works public facilities planner, presented updates on the ongoing multi-phase county trails project Sept. 24.From Matapeake to Route 50, the six-phase project seeks to establish pedestrian and biking routes and safely connect existing South Island and the Cross Island trails, according to Chandlee.
Phase 1 of the Queen Anne's County Trail Project includes Ellendale Connector near Waterman Joe and is currently under construction, Cohoon said.
Phase 2 entails the Matapeake School Complex to Mowbray Park is permitted and construction is expected from Oct. 1 through Feb. 28, 2025, and will include tree clearing, stone base and stormwater installation and extensive grading.
Phase 3 involves the wooded area through the back of Mowbray Park to Waterman Joe and is currently in design and engineering and waiting on final construction plans and permits with estimated construction expected March 5 through May 30.
Phase 4 involves the Route 8 crossing to Christ Church to the Matapeake Trailhead and is seeking design and funding. This portion is expected to be the most expensive due to the marshy area and many trees to be removed.
Phase 5 entails the Thompson Creek and is seeking design and funding with funding needed for the construction of the road.
Phase 6 involves U.S. Route 50/301 overpass crossing.
There are three potential locations for crossing that take into account county-owned property or easements, Cohoon said.
A key aspect of the project moving forward will be a required feasibility study by the State Highway Administration to determine where the best crossing location would be and where connections to existing trails systems can be made, he said.
This study will take into account future plans including bay crossing and the widening of Route 50.
The department is currently seeking grant funds for the approximately $120,000 to $150,000 feasibility study, Cohoon said.
A timeframe for completion is undetermined at this point as the different potential locations may have different impacts, he said.
Many of the construction aspects are weather dependent, he said.
Progress also is developing on the Cross County Connector Trail Extension, according to Cohoon. Queen Anne's County received $80,000 from the Baltimore Regional Transportation Board through the adoption of the 2024 Pedestrian and Bicycle Master Plan earlier this year. This grant is to conduct a feasibility study to extend the Cross County Connector Trail from Long Point Park to the Nesbit Road overpass by 2.8 miles.
This study includes feasibility of pedestrian and bike facilities on existing overpasses crossing U.S. 50/301 at Chester River Beach Road and Nesbit Road, Cohoon said. Work is underway with RK and K Civil Engineering as the consultant for this portion and is expected to be completed by the end of the year, he said.
"The ultimate goal with any of these crossings is to connect the South Island Trail with the Cross Island Trail. That's been a long-standing goal for many, many years for the county," Cohoon said.

title: Central committees on the Shore encourage voting early, mail-in ballots
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Central committees on the Shore encourage voting early, mail-in ballots

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 479
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With Election Day less than a month away, Democrat and Republican officials across the Mid-Shore are encouraging voters to participate in early voting.Sarah Gavian, chair of the Dorchester County Democratic Central Committee, encourages voters to make a plan, whether that plan includes mail-in voting, early voting or voting on Nov. 5.
"(If) you want your people to vote, you start encouraging them to do so at the first opportunity," Gavian said. "Because if they miss the first one, they can catch the second one. If they miss the second one, they can catch the third one."
Richard Osborne, chair of the Talbot County Republican Central Committee, said it's important for everyone to vote and encourage those that they know to do so as well. He said a benefit of early voting is avoiding a situation on Election Day where results begin to trickle in while polls are still open.
"The reason why you want to do that is because if you wait until the last day and you see maybe elections lost, it might discourage you from voting," Osborne said.
Across Maryland, more than 150,000 people participated in early voting during the presidential primary election in May.
In Talbot County, 7.08% of eligible active voters voted early, tied for the highest percentage of any county with Kent. In Caroline and Dorchester, 4.43% and 4.1% of voters participated in early voting, respectively.
At a Sept. 14 rally in Denton, local Republican politicians gathered to campaign in front of Caroline County voters. During the event, many calls for early voting surfaced.
First District Congressman Andy Harris (R-Md.), the featured speaker at the event, asked attendees to vote early for Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump. Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said the same.
"You need your vote in the bank," Harris said. "You must bank your vote."
"It's incredibly important," he continued. "We have to beat the Democrats at their game, and their game is voting before Election Day."
Chairs of local central committees, such as Talbot's Democratic Committee Chair Patrick Firth are noting that the unexpected can happen on Election Day, such as long lines, car troubles or work emergencies.
Firth said all voters should make a plan, emphasizing the security and efficiency of not just early voting days, but mail-in ballots.
"Sometimes the easiest way to make sure that your voice is heard is get it done along the way," Firth said. "And that's what's so efficient and common sense about participating in the election via the mail-in ballots."
Julie Quick, chair of the Caroline County Republican Central Committee, said her team is emphasizing to voters the multitude of voting options in the first post-COVID general election cycle.
"I think a lot of people here are so used to voting in person, and we just really want to raise awareness that there are so many options," Quick said.
General election early voting in Maryland begins Oct. 24 and runs through Oct. 31.

 EASTON — During Tuesday's public meeting, members of the Talbot County Council revisited the ongoing dialogue surrounding the partisan breakdown of election judges in Talbot County for the upcoming election.Council Member Dave Stepp originally raised concerns at a Sept. 24 council meeting regarding an imbalance of election judges selected by the Talbot County Board of Elections to work polling places this November. At the time, the board's breakdown of judges was 62 Democratic, 50 Republican and 11 unaffiliated.
At Tuesday's meeting, Stepp said the difference between Democratic and Republican judges had lowered to seven. "I ask that we keep up that work," Stepp said.
He also thanked Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble for sending a letter to the Board of Elections and Election Director Tammy Stafford last week. In that letter, Gamble "strongly" urged the board to follow state election law.
Council Member Lynn Mielke, as she did on Sept. 24, disagreed with Stepp. She brought up a letter written by Attorney General Anthony Brown that was sent to Gamble on Monday.
In that letter, Brown addressed the "limited role of local law enforcement … in the electoral process." While not an official opinion of the attorney general, Brown said achieving "exact party balance" isn't always possible for local election boards due to volunteer rates, training and no-shows on Election Day.
"My Office has consistently advised that opening a polling place, even if the number of judges from each party is not exactly equal, is preferable to closing the polling place and disenfranchising all the voters who would have voted there," Brown wrote in his letter.
Mielke said Tuesday, "We have rulings from the attorney general that the procedure that was started by (Council Member) Stepp and others, were overruled … And that there was nothing found … that the local board of elections have done wrong."
ZONING WAIVERCouncil members unanimously approved a zoning change waiver for around 17 acres of land off of U.S. Route 50 that developers aim to use for an affordable multifamily housing project in Easton.
The development on the east side of Ocean Gateway is planned by developers Corrigan & Trippe Ventures. Easton Town Council approved the annexation of the land in July.
The resolution passed Tuesday approves a waiver that will allow a proposed zoning change to take immediate effect without a five-year hold. The area will be rezoned from the county's town conservation zoning to the town's residential zoning, providing developers with a higher approved density.
"They would essentially be locked into the uses that are permitted under the county's TC zoning now for a period of five years," County Attorney Patrick Thomas said if the waiver was not passed.
Zach Smith, an attorney representing the developers, said the maximum density under the town's residential zoning is 3.5 units per acre, along with a 5-unit-per-acre mark permitted by the town's multifamily housing special exception.
If developers plan to exceed those marks, they will have to come before the Easton Town Council for a planned unit development approval. Smith noted developers would then need to revisit the County Council for a supplemental waiver.
Smith emphasized to council members that while developers are obligated within the annexation agreement to reach a 50% mark of affordable units, the goal is for 100% of the units to be affordable.
"This housing is not necessarily housing designed to attract new folks to our community, it's really to serve folks that are already in our community," Smith said.

title: Cambridge candidates talk local issues at candidate forum
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge candidates talk local issues at candidate forum

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 936
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge City Council candidates and the city's residents flowed in and out of the Chesapeake Grove Intergenerational Center Saturday afternoon for a nearly five-hour candidate forum conducted by the League of Women Voters.Ten of the 14 commissioner and mayoral candidates running in the Oct. 19 election were at the forum.
The forum was split into three sessions for the different races. Ryan Anthony of the Cambridge Spy, Sharon Smith of the Cambridge Association of Neighborhoods, Jim Johnson of the Dorchester Star and Jim Brady of WHCP moderated the forum.
Ward 2 candidate Jenna LeCompte, Ward 4 candidate Dave Cannon, Ward 3 candidate Frank Stout and Ward 5 candidate Brian Roche — who is running uncontested — were not at the event.
In an email to WHCP on Friday, LeCompte said she is "taking a step back" from her campaign and would not be at the event. She did not respond to requests for clarification from the Star Democrat on what that means.
MAYORAL FORUM
Sandwiched between two commissioner candidate sessions, the mayoral forum gave candidates Lajan Cephas, Andrew Bradshaw and La-Shon Banks-Foster the opportunity to share their perspectives on an array of Cambridge issues, from the waterfront, to revitalizing the city's downtown, to race relations.
During the session, candidates were asked whether the city should get more involved in Dorchester County Public Schools, which is one of Maryland's lowest ranked school systems.
Bradshaw said he would like to implement a mentorship program, which would reach across racial and socioeconomic lines, and encourage the Board of Education to implement a charter school program. He said charter schools across the state tend to perform at the state average, which is "significantly better" than Dorchester schools.
"And they are only located in counties and jurisdictions with poor performance," he said, "so there's corollaries where they can succeed in places like Cambridge."
Foster, who attended the forum virtually, said every graduate from Dorchester County high schools is a county resident and could be a Cambridge resident.
"We cannot ignore the fact that whoever graduates from either of the schools that I mentioned can and will impact the City of Cambridge, and we must have an active role," she said.
Cephas said it is important for the city to be "extremely supportive" of the county, but there is no need to "reinvent the wheel." She said there are nonprofits already in place to address education concerns.
"So it's extremely important that we understand what's already in place, support those nonprofits that are already in place, and each of us just pick up a book and read to someone," she said.
COMMISSIONER FORUMS
The seven commissioner candidates at the forum were split into two groups. All commissioner candidates were asked the same questions from the moderators.
Kicking off the event were Ward 1 candidates Brett Summers and Laurel Atkiss, as well as Ward 3 candidate Gary Gordy. Ward 2 candidates Jermaine Anderson, Shay Lewis-Sisco and Nancy Jackson, as well as Ward 4 candidate Sputty Cephas, closed out the event.
When asked about code enforcement and overall housing quality in the city, Summers said hiring tenant advocates to promote a tenants bill of rights would be beneficial.
"Because if the tenants feel like they can contact the city inspector and have them come out without fear of getting evicted or some other kind of retribution, then the tenants are empowered to improve our housing stock," he said.
Atkiss said the city has implemented a software system to make it easier to enforce things like building code violations. She said Cambridge is doing city-wide building inspections and recently hired a new code enforcement officer.
"We've invested money, we've invested time," she said, "and now we're going to invest the manpower, and we're going to start to see some results that I hope everybody's going to be really happy with."
Lewis-Sisco said code enforcement should strategically target houses where renters are living in deplorable conditions. She said community engagement should also be a focus.
"So that when code enforcement officers go out to a homeowner or a property, they are able to offer those additional supports or let them know what additional resources exist," she said.
The issue of addressing crime in Cambridge was also brought up during the forum.
Gordy said improved lighting, more cameras and more monitoring of those cameras are needed in the city's "hot spots" in order to lower crime rates. When talking about monitoring cameras, he brought up a shooting that occurred over the weekend.
"Because last night police got there so fast, but they couldn't see who it was," he said about the need for 24-hour camera monitoring.
Jackson said addressing the issue of crime in Cambridge might start with more than detaining people. She said she would work to help resolve those problems if elected.
"There is something deep where this person is committing these acts," she said. "It could be the home life or it could be the environment."
Cephas said strengthening the police department's community policing division is important. He talked about programming for youth to attract "local and diverse talent" as another solution.
"Let's do a cadet program to get some of these young people before they get out into the community and do wrong things or bad things," he said.
Anderson said these problems have existed for a long time and won't be a quick fix. He stressed the importance of being proactive and communicating.
When asked about the greatest threat to the city, both Atkiss and Anderson talked about the city standing in it's own way.
"But the biggest opportunity is imagine if we get out of our own way," Anderson said. "Think about the opportunity that would pose for this city ... how much of a difference that would make."

title: Changes made to St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Changes made to St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The Commissioners of St. Michaels have made changes to the controversial Tourism Advisory Board, including additional members and updated language.According to Commissioner David Wojciechowski at a Wednesday meeting, the ordinance establishing the board was "re-drafted" to take into consideration comments from the commissioners and the public.
The idea of a tourism board was brought forth during the town election last May. Wojciechowski, Alexis Roiter and Jay Hudson, who were all later elected as commissioners, said during their campaigns that they would work with business owners to make the town more friendly to their needs.
The purpose of the board, according to a town memo, would be to assist the town in its efforts to encourage businesses to locate or remain in the town and to make recommendations to the commissioners. The board would also "work closely with the Talbot County Tourism Board on a unified, regional marketing approach."
During an August commission meeting, the proposed tourism board was met with pushback from residents, who raised an array of concerns about potential conflicts of interest and a lack of data supporting the board's creation.
A major change to the ordinance Wojciechowski pointed out was a change in language. For the purpose of the board, language was changed to "manage, promote and stabilize the economic health of the town's tourism economy."
"One of the objectives here is to stabilize tourism, to make it to the right size, if you will. Not too large for the town, not too small, but to manage tourism doesn't get out of hand," Wojciechowski said.
Additionally, there were changes to the amount of members on the board. Originally, the board would comprise seven members serving four-year terms, all appointed by the commissioners. Membership would include a resident not associated with a business and representatives from the lodging, eating/drinking, retail or service, marinas, museums and nonprofit sectors.
There was outcry by residents over the low number of residents on the board. Now membership has been changed to include two town residents.
Public CommentDuring public comment, resident Daniel Spiegel, who in the past has shared concerns over the establishment of the tourism board, said he and other residents have marked issues with what he describes as a "seriously flawed ordinance."
Spiegel's main concerns involved potential conflicts of interest and the town's level of involvement in private business operations and gathering data. He stressed there are already small business associations, such as the lodging association, which could gather the necessary information that the tourism board would gather.
According to Spiegel, by creating a government board rather than an advisory board outside of the town's legal boundaries, it will create conflict of interests where the business owners on the board could propose budgetary expenditures that could directly benefit them.
"There's nothing wrong with promoting tourism," Spiegel said. "The question is whether the town wants to be deeply engaged in the way that this ordinance is. Which for a town of (this) size, is really surprising. We're not a county, we're not a big city, we're a small town, and I think you will regret that you've set it up this way."
After public comment, the board unanimously approved moving the ordinance toward a public hearing. The hearing will be held on Nov. 13.

title: Idlewild Park's cherished tile wall to remain up until the spring
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Idlewild Park's cherished tile wall to remain up until the spring

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 572

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Town of Easton's plans to tear down an Idlewild Park walkway adorned with hand-painted tiles has brought back cherished memories for many Easton residents.Like many others, Easton resident Michael McCormack remembers painting his tile around 17 years ago. He was eight years old, and it included trees and grass, which fit with his then-involvement in Boy Scouts and camping outdoors.
His tile is one of hundreds that make up a winding path next to the playground at Idlewild Park — some include handprints, names or school classes. While the tiles remain, they are weathered and damaged from the time that's passed.
After the town initially announced on Sept. 25 that the tile walkway would be taken down in October, many town residents asked to retrieve their tiles, with others suggesting a new community art project go in its place.
The town has said the tiles have too much wear and tear to be retrieved without damaging the wall entirely. But the outpouring of community input led town officials to delay the removal of the tiles to the spring of 2025.
"It has been truly heartwarming to see all of the community response regarding the tile wall at Idlewild Park," the town wrote in a Facebook post on Sept. 27. " … Hopefully this way everyone who wishes to visit will have a little more time to make the trip and take photos before the tiles are gone."
McCormack said he's reconnected with old friends in recent weeks after going to Idlewild Park to look at the tiles.
"You bring back these memories that aren't necessarily attached to the tile, but they're attached to the person," McCormack said. "Just seeing their name and seeing what they did makes you laugh."
Mayor Megan Cook was a driving force behind Idlewild Park's construction in 2006. As co-chairman of Project Idlewild at the time, Cook helped spearhead a community-led effort to fund and build the park that opened in the summer of 2007.
"The whole thing from start to finish was a massive undertaking with so many volunteers," Cook said, "and then so many people came to build it over a two-week period."
Cook said hundreds of people showed up to help construct the park. There was even a dedicated team in charge of watching over the kids so parents could come chip in.
The hand-painted tiles cemented the park as a community-driven project, the mayor said.
"The hope had always been that, as a community project, … there would always be that link back in community," Cook said.
She said the town is considering ideas to incorporate the tiles into a new design once the tile wall is taken down. The town's Parks & Recreation department is "all ears" on ideas from residents, it said in a Facebook post.
McCormack hopes to see the piece of Easton history commemorated, even if all of the tiles cannot be saved.
"It would be cool to save the ones they can," McCormack said. "People my age are starting to have kids, so it'd almost be cool to have their kids paint it. And then you could connect two generations together out there."
"You can see the weather, you can see the time has taken its toll on those things for sure," he said. "So you can see why they need to be taken down. It's just one of those things that I don't think people in the town really appreciated until they realized it was going to be gone."

title: Property owners learn about potential compensation for Rails to Trails
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Property owners learn about potential compensation for Rails to Trails

 October 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HURLOCK — Landowners with property adjacent to future Rails to Trails projects may be entitled to compensation, according to attorneys from Missouri-based law firm Lewis Rice.The law firm is representing about a dozen Mid-Shore residents who have signed onto a lawsuit seeking compensation from the federal government for potential trail projects.
A handful of people sat in the Unity-Washington United Methodist Church on the evening of Oct. 14 to learn about what this effort looks like in Dorchester County.
The county is in the process of obtaining the rights of way for rail lines from Preston to Hurlock and Linkwood to Cambridge. When the state grants them these rights of way, the county will be able to implement Rails to Trails on those pathways.
In an interview Tuesday, Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said the county has no immediate plans to implement Rails to Trails in those places. He said the county hasn't even started to discuss implementation and would need to seek public input first.
"It would be a community process," he said. "And again, we don't have any money to do anything like that. So it's nothing that's going to happen in the near future."
But during the event at Unity-Washington United Methodist Church, attorneys gave a presentation to inform landowners with property adjacent to the rail lines about potential compensation from the federal government.
Attorney Meghan Largent led the presentation, which detailed the process of making a claim. She said neither the government, nor the railroads, nor the trail groups involved are required to notify landowners when a certificate of interim trail use is issued by the Surface Transportation Board.
"We have challenged that," Largent said. "What the courts have found is that publishing it in the federal register is effective notice."
Largent said landowners usually don't know what's happening or what their legal rights are until lawyers show up.
Pfeffer said in an interview that in this particular situation, the state had made notice of the easements, but he was unsure of the exact status. He said his understanding is that the state published a press release and then law firms directly contacted property owners of land adjoining the rail lines.
Largent said that once the certificate of interim trail use was issued on Aug. 30 for this potential project, it triggered a six-year statute of limitations. This means property owners have six years to file a claim for compensation. She said that although six years seems like a long time, it can sneak up quickly.
Largent said that within a week of the issuance of the certificate, Lewis Rice filed a lawsuit seeking this compensation for residents. The U.S. Department of Justice has 60 days from the filing of the lawsuit to answer.
Lewis Rice is currently representing about a dozen local property owners, but there are more than 50 property owners who they believe have a good claim. Largent said they have sent mail to property owners who they believe will be successful in receiving a claim.
"We do have to follow the solicitation rules in the state, which require us to market as an advertisement," she said in an interview. "So, whether everybody got that information, I can't confirm, but we certainly sent it."
Currently, Lewis Rice can still add landowners to the lawsuit. Largent said she doesn't have an exact date that this period of adding landowners will end. She said that if property owners don't file a claim, they won't be compensated.
"It's not a class action," she said. "Government's not going to reach out to them and offer them money."
After the presentation, one resident said he appreciated the attorneys reaching out because neither the federal government nor county government notified him of the turning over of rights of way.
Largent said she wanted to make it clear that Lewis Rice wasn't there to advocate for or against the trail. She said compensation to property owners doesn't mean less funding for the trail.
"We might have clients that love the trail," she said. "We might have clients that really dislike the idea of a trail. Some that are ambivalent. But that's not what we're here to do. They'll be hosting the trail through their property, and they should be compensated."

title: Republicans continue to push Talbot Board of Elections on election judge breakdown
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Republicans continue to push Talbot Board of Elections on election judge breakdown

 October 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 775
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — County Republicans continued to push the Talbot County Board of Elections to equal its selection of election judges during the board's monthly meeting on Wednesday morning.The breakdown by party was 62 Democratic judges, 50 Republican judges and 11 unaffiliated judges in September, according to Election Director Tammy Stafford. Local officials have indicated at meetings that the number of judges for each party may now be closer to equal, but this has not been confirmed by the Board of Elections.
Election officials have said the makeup is "fluid" and will change up until Election Day. During Wednesday's meeting, Stafford said "judges are always needed" and that her office "continuously" accepts interest forms.
According to Sept. 18 meeting minutes read aloud Wednesday, staffing for the election began in June of 2023. Training for those who filled out interest forms began in early 2024.
In the last month, concerns have circulated regarding a party imbalance of election judges, or those who staff polling places on Election Day.
Local officials, including Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and Talbot County Council Member Dave Stepp, have cited that the board is not in compliance with state law.
Maryland election code states "each polling place shall have an equal number of election judges" from "the majority party" and "the principal minority party."
State election law permits judges not affiliated with either party for precincts with six or more judges, as well as "one or more election judges who are minors." The number of unaffiliated judges "may not exceed the lesser of" the majority or minority party, law states.
These concerns led to a flurry of responses from state agencies emphasizing the security of the electoral process. In an Oct. 2 statement responding to a letter sent by Gamble to the Talbot Board of Elections, State Board of Elections Administrator Jared DeMarinis said voters should feel "confident" in the state's election security and "compliance with the law."
Attorney General Anthony Brown weighed in as well, writing a letter to Gamble on Oct. 7.
"Even at the individual polling place level, while all local boards make best efforts to achieve exact party balance, this is not always possible for reasons outside the local board's control, including the number of judges from each party who volunteer," Brown wrote.
Stafford stated at the Sept. 18 meeting that the training for election judges can no longer be done after Oct. 8 since the room used for training is also used for canvassing.
During Wednesday's public comment, Gary Judy, a member of the Talbot County Republican Central Committee, said he's heard from Republicans who applied to be an election judge but were not told there are no vacancies for this year's general election. He said the fact that the board did not achieve exact party balance is "extremely alarming to Talbot County voters."
"We decided to keep close track on it this year," Judy said, "and can confirm that there were more than enough Republicans who signed up to be election judges to fill the available Republican positions of the equal representation required by Maryland election law."
On Wednesday, Judy provided board members with copies of a letter written by the Maryland Republican Party addressing election judge concerns in Talbot County. Adam Wood, executive director of the Maryland Republican Party, later told the Star Democrat that the letter was a "draft" letter and had not been sent to the state board.
Shari Wilcoxon, also a member of the Republican central committee, spoke during public comment, asking the board to ensure "parity" of election judges.
"I think that it is an actual embarrassment that this board is allowing the executive director free rein to break the law," Wilcoxon said. "It is your duty to hold her feet to the fire, and that she does what is Maryland law."
Wilcoxon questioned why election judge applications were denied in February and March.
"February and March had to do with the primary," Stafford responded. "Let's be specific here. That was the primary. Those were the first people who were contacted for the general (election)."
This led to tense back-and-forth between Wilcoxon and Stafford.
Board President Susan MacKinnon stepped in, asking Wilcoxon to stop speaking.
"You have had the opportunity to speak, you are now being disruptive," MacKinnon said to Wilcoxon. "You are being disruptive, and if you continue being disruptive, I will call a recess and have you removed."
Wednesday's meeting was the board's last regularly scheduled meeting before the election Nov. 5. During Stafford's report to the board, she said "logic and accuracy testing on the electronic equipment was completed" on Sept. 16. The Board of Elections will have its logic and accuracy testing documentation available for public inspection Friday at 10 a.m. at 215 Bay Street in Easton.

title: Caroline commissioners talk new regional detention center
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline commissioners talk new regional detention center

 October 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 333
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Oct. 15 the Caroline County Commissioners discussed a plan to build a new regional detention center in Queen Anne's county.The financial burden would be split between Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent counties, but it is still unclear how that would be managed or what would happen to the detention center on 101 Gay Street in Denton, commissioners said at the meeting.
The new facility is being designed to hold 338 beds for men and women. The current Denton jail holds 130 inmates.
The warden of the Caroline County Detention Center, Charles Scott, said there are mental health needs among the inmates that could be better managed with a designated space, which could be incorporated into the design of the new facility.
"There should be a wing just for mental health. Juveniles and mental health are just piling up in the jail," Scott said.
He said there is plenty of land in Queen Anne's County to build this new detention center. The new facility will be located in Church Hill on the site of the Eastern Pre-Release Unit.
Commission President Travis Breeding cited the economies of scale and how the new detention center could serve the needs of the counties for less money.
The commissioners discussed who would be the authority on this tri-county project. Right now, one county commissioner and one county administrator oversee the jail in Denton. The commissioners said they wanted more clarity on how that would work in a tri-county context.
The commissioners also discussed the employment possibilities for current Caroline County Detention Center employees. Employment decisions would factor in tenure and managing workers who have fulfilled this amount of time as they work in a new county.
Scott said it is hard to find correctional officers, so everyone's job should be safe.
County Administrator Katheleen Freeman said the new facility will offer better services at lower costs, but the devil is in the details.
The commissioners agreed to discuss this further at the next meeting on Oct. 22 at the Health and Public Services building.

title: Three national races top the ballot in Maryland
author: Tom McCall
content:
Three national races top the ballot in Maryland

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 393
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot, Caroline and Dorchester voters are gearing up to elect their next president, senator and congressman on Nov. 5.Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Kamala Harris are on the top of the ticket as they run for president. There are several others on the presidential ballot including Jill Stein and Robert Kennedy, Jr. (although he dropped out of the race, he is still on the ballot).
For U.S. senator there is Democrat Angela Alsobrooks and Republican Larry Hogan. Running for Congress in District 1 are Republican Andy Harris, Democrat Blane Miller III and Libertarian Joshua W. O'Brien.
For the Appellate Court of Maryland Stephen H. Kehoe is on the ballot.
There are different ways to vote.
Registered voters can vote by mail-in ballot if they do not want to go to an early voting center. You can request an early voter mail-in ballot if you have a Maryland driver's license or a MVA issued ID card. There is a mail-in ballot request form on the Maryland Board of Elections website.
Anyone who is registered to vote can vote during early voting.
The polling station for Talbot is Easton Fire Hall at 315 Aurora Park Drive in Easton. If you are in Dorchester, go to the Dorchester Election Office at 1000 Goodwill Avenue, Cambridge. Caroline County's station is at the Health and Public Services Building 403 S. Seventh St. Room 112, Denton.
You can register to vote if you are a U.S. citizen, a Maryland resident and at least 16 years old. You can register to vote Election Day at your local polling place.
These voters can satisfy the identification requirement by providing one of the following:
The voter's driver's license number, MVA ID card number or the last four digits of the voter's Social Security number, and election officials will attempt to verify this information with MVA or the Social Security Administration.A copy of a current and valid photo identification (Maryland driver's license, MVA ID card, student or employee photo ID card, military ID card, passport or any other state or federal government issued ID card).A copy of a current utility bill, bank statement, government check, paycheck or other government document that shows the voter's name and address.
Voting is a civic duty and a relatively easy one to participate in. Most voters are on the voter list in their county. After voting you can show off your "I Voted" sticker.

title: Cambridge election results in, mayoral race goes to runoff
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge election results in, mayoral race goes to runoff

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 1017
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Throughout Saturday, Cambridge residents visited 447 Race Street to cast their votes in the city's election for a mayor and commissioners.A total of 14 candidates ran to fill the city's mayoral and five commissioner seats. The mayoral race will go to a runoff election in December.
A total of 1,543 Cambridge residents showed up to the polls Saturday. Cambridge Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson said there are 8,982 active registered voters in Cambridge.
Hesson said the number of registered voters in Cambridge is an "incredible amount." He said it is important they vote for their preferred candidates.
"Every other Monday is a council meeting where important decisions are made," he said. "And the residents are going to want people in those seats that represent them and their thoughts on where this community should and shouldn't be going."
MAYORAL RACECambridge Commission President Lajan Cephas and former Cambridge Mayor Andrew Bradshaw will go head to head in a runoff election to determine the city's next mayor.
Cephas received 637 votes Saturday, or 42.52% of the vote. Bradshaw received 614 votes, or 40.99% of the vote.
Cephas said the results tell her that residents have faith in the city's current leadership.
"They're saying that we would like for you to do this another four years," she said. "So that's how I feel. It's a good feeling to know we are going in the right direction."
Cephas said now it is a matter of making reconnections with voters.
Bradshaw said he is confident going into the runoff, but he knows Cephas is a "very solid candidate as well." He said that now, the voters will be able to directly compare him and Cephas.
"We can talk about policy versus a lack of policy direction," he said. "And we're in a position where we can now contrast the candidates for people in a really direct way."
Former Cambridge Commissioner La-Shon Foster, who also ran in the race, received 247 votes, or 16.49% of the vote.
The run-off election will be held on Dec. 3 at 447 Race Street. The candidate that secures the most votes in the run-off election will take Mayor Stephen Rideout's seat.
In June, Rideout said he would not be running for reelection. He told the Star Democrat that when he ran in 2022, he only intended to fill the remainder of the term of Bradshaw, who resigned in January 2022 after being charged for distributing revenge porn on Reddit.
WARD 1Brett Summers won the Ward 1 commissioner race with 293 votes, or 54.56% of the vote.
Incumbent Commissioner Laurel Atkiss received 244 votes, or 45.44% of the vote. Atkiss was elected in June 2023 in a special election to finish the unexpired term of then Ward 1 Commissioner Brian Roche.
Summers said he is looking forward to working to implement the ideas he ran on including advocating to hire a commercial real estate broker for the Cambridge Harbor project, hiring a tenant advocate, building a dog park and returning the Cambridge Police Department to a 25-step pay scale.
"I'm eager to work with my other city council members and see if we can implement some new things that make Cambridge better," he said.
WARD 2Shay Lewis-Sisco won the Ward 2 commissioner race with 106 votes, or 50.96% of the vote.
Nancy Jackson received 66 votes, or 31.73% of the vote. Jermaine Anderson received 20 votes, or or 9.62% of the vote. Jenna LeCompte received 16 votes, or 7.69% of the vote.
Lewis-Sisco said she anticipated the race would go to a runoff and said she is overwhelmed and excited.
"I'm absolutely looking forward to serving the community, representing Ward 2 to the best of my ability, engaging the community leaders to be a part of the process, to be able to work collaboratively (and) to be responsive to community," she said. "I'm also super excited to serve with the other commissioners that were elected tonight."
Currently, Lajan Cephas is the Ward 2 commissioner.
WARD 3Frank Stout was voted in as the city's Ward 3 commissioner. Stout received 191 votes, or 73.46% of the vote.
Gary Gordy received 69 votes, or 26.54% of the vote.
Stout said he is "very thankful" for the support he's received and he is looking forward to representing Ward 3 and the city to his "fullest and best ability." He said he's also looking forward to serving with the other elected commissioners.
"I'm really thankful for the total outcome," he said about the election. "I think there's a great group to work with."
Jameson Harrington is the current Ward 3 commissioner. In June, Harrington told the Star Democrat that he would not be seeking reelection. He said he likes to volunteer and help, but politics is "just not my forte."
WARD 4Incumbent Commissioner Sputty Cephas took the city's Ward 4 commissioner seat. Cephas received 144 votes, or 54.14% of the vote. Sputty Cephas has served as commissioner since 2021.
Sputty Cephas said he's excited to be able to "continue forward" as commissioner of Ward 4.
"I definitely felt that my work wasn't complete," he said. "And I'm grateful to the citizens and constituents of the fourth ward that they agreed and that they have reelected me for another term."
He said he's looking forward to continuing to engage the city's youth, continuing to move the city forward and continuing to unify the city.
Former Commissioner Dave Cannon received 122 votes, or 45.86% of the vote.
WARD 5With no other candidates on the ballot, incumbent Commissioner Brian Roche will keep his Ward 5 commission seat. Roche received 158 votes.
In a text, Roche said moving into the next term, he hopes the newly elected mayor and commissioners will understand "how to truly raise the quality of life" for Cambridge's underserved.
"I've seen first hand how Cambridge has become so dependent on government transfer payments to survive... we often fail to put these programs through the filter of 'will this lift us out of poverty' or 'will it finally empower our citizens to build generational wealth?'" he said.
Roche was elected as commissioner of the ward in June 2023 in a special election to finish the unexpired term of former Commissioner Chad Malkus. Before that, Roche served as commissioner of Ward 1, which he was sworn into in 2021.

title: State officials, County Council discuss Talbot transportation projects
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
State officials, County Council discuss Talbot transportation projects

 October 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 602
 Words

 EASTON — State transportation leaders and officials filled the chamber of the Talbot County Council on Tuesday afternoon to discuss local transportation projects and a tightening state budget.Paul Wiedefeld, secretary of the Maryland Department of Transportation, explained the "significant budgetary challenges" his department is facing, due in part to the state's economy, increasing material costs and lower than expected revenue.
Wiedefeld noted that MDOT's Consolidated Transportation Program for fiscal years 2025 to 2030 — which has an $18.9 billion balanced plan — experienced a $1.3 billion reduction compared to last year's program.
He and Will Pines, administrator of the State Highway Administration, emphasized safety as the state's top priority.
"While we must live within our budget, we'll continue to do big things to support projects and programs throughout the county," Pines said.
Pines noted a bevy of improvements, which included higher visibility at Maryland 322 and U.S. Route 50 intersections, traffic signal improvements at Route 50 and Airport Road, a new signal at Black Dog Alley and Dover Road, and resurfacing on Matthewstown Road.
He also thanked the St. Michaels community for its patience as the state worked on sidewalk reconstruction.
Representatives from the state's Transportation Authority, Motor Vehicle Administration, Aviation Administration and Port Administration provided updates to the council.
Ashish Solanki, director of the Office of Regional Aviation Assistance, told council members about the $1.4 billion in "economic activity" generated from the state's 34 public airports.
"We recognize that certainly (Easton Airport) is one of those strong contributors to that economic impact," Solanki said. He stated upwards of 500 jobs and more than $91 million in business revenue stems from the Easton Airport.
He added that the state is providing $560,000 in grant assistance to Easton Airport this year.
After thanking state officials for their updates and assistance to the county, Council Vice President Pete Lesher asked Pines about improvements at Route 322 and Glenwood Avenue in Easton. That project was listed for potential deferral by the state.
"I know that our partners at Easton are looking forward to that project as part of the rail-trail safety," Lesher said. " … I just wanted to ask about the likelihood of that and whether that might be reconsidered."
Pines said that the state is "evaluating" that project and others to see if they fit within the Federal Highway Administration's Highway Safety Improvement Program. If so, federal funding could be unlocked, but if not, that Glenwood Avenue project would have to "compete it out against many other projects that need the state funding," Pines said.
"This very well could be a great candidate, it just has to go through the more detailed evaluation for us to confirm," he said.
Council President Chuck Callahan thanked Wiedefeld, Pines and District 2 Engineer Ken Fender for their help in improving safety at the airport and its surrounding roads. "It's those little things that mean a lot to us, and we really appreciate it," Callahan said.
Callahan added that he's grateful for the state's partnership in facilitating the temporary closure of a portion of Route 662, which is allowing construction of the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new hospital. Route 662's partial closure began earlier this month. The road will reopen in May.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) was in attendance, and echoed the same about the hospital, saying it's going to "have a huge impact on transportation in the county." Mautz encouraged the County Council to stay on top of transportation challenges in the coming year.
"I think we're going to have some challenges," Mautz said, "and I just would urge the council and the town to communicate with MDOT and hopefully MDOT will be looking for that communication."

title: Transportation departments share projects during Caroline County meeting

 DENTON — On Tuesday morning, the Caroline County Commissioners gathered to discuss the state's Consolidated Transportation Program. Members of the Maryland Department of Transportation shared an annual presentation that included various infrastructure projects and funding challenges.Representatives from MDOT, Maryland Aviation Administration, Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration, Maryland Transit Administration, Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration and Maryland Transportation Authority shared information affecting local transportation as well as statewide transportation.
LOCALWill Pines, administrator for the State Highway Administration, shared various transportation projects in Caroline County, both pending and completed.
"We understand the fiscal challenges Maryland is facing," Pines said. "However, I want to assure you of two things. First, SHA will continue to do big things moving forward, multimodal projects that improve safety, and accessibility and equity. And second, safety will always be our highest priority."
According to Pines, the newly constructed bridge on Maryland 16 over Mill Creek was reopened to traffic in September.
Additionally, Pines said two county priorities are the focal point of the fall. The first is the construction of pavement widening and signalization upgrades to provide a dedicated left turn lane from Maryland 328 to Maryland 404. This $2.1 million project is anticipated to be completed near the end of 2025.
The second is the conversion of the flashing signals at Maryland 313 and Maryland 317 to full color signals. This improvement will facilitate safer traffic movements at the intersection.
SHA hosted the second public meeting for the Maryland 404 Planning and Environmental Linkage Study. The meeting was well attended, according to Pines, and the study is anticipated to be completed by the end of the year. Once completed, SHA will work with Caroline County to identify potential breakout projects along the corridor, pending available funding.
SHA has begun a pipe replacement project on Maryland 328, near Salisbury Road. Construction crews will work daytime hours this week for site preparation, then switch to overnight hours to minimize the impacts to traffic.
Travis Johnston, local transit support director for Maryland Transit Administration, said MTA provides nearly $1 million in operating and capital grants to support local transit operations provided by Delmarva Community Transit in conjunction with Kent and Talbot counties. In addition to continued preventative maintenance, the funds will also provide one new small bus.
Earlier this month, Gov. Wes Moore announced additional grant funding to the county aimed at helping the Caroline County Sheriff's Office and the Denton Police Department address speed impairment and aggressive driving.
Finally, Atkins Arboretum was awarded nearly $180,000 in recreational trails program funding to support the bridge deck replacement, the creation of a new trail and the necessary accessibility and maintenance improvements for its "Over The Creeks and Through the Woods" project.
STATEWIDEPaul Wiedefeld, secretary for MDOT, presented updates and plans for statewide projects.
According to Wiedefeld, major projects include working on the Howard Street Tunnel in Baltimore, major construction on aviation courses and connections, future growth of Southwest Airlines at BWI Airport and bringing the FBI headquarters to Green Belt.
Commission president Travis Breeding, took the time to thank Wiederfield and the rest of the representatives for their continued work for the county.
"Thank you, Secretary Wiederfield, for visiting Caroline County today with your entire leadership team," Breeding said. "Thank you for your continued investment in MDOT infrastructure within Caroline County."

title: Talbot County voters to see 1-cent amendment on ballots
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County voters to see 1-cent amendment on ballots

 October 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Voters in Talbot County will see Question A on ballots at the polls, which asks if they are for or against a charter amendment that will extend the county's ability to raise residents' taxes for public safety funding.The 1-cent amendment would authorize the Talbot County Council to raise property taxes one cent per $100 of assessed value each fiscal year. It is currently in effect, though it expires after fiscal year 2026.
This year's charter amendment would extend the County Council's ability to raise revenue derived from taxes by seven fiscal years, or until and including fiscal year 2033.
This July, the Talbot County Council passed a resolution to place the question on the ballot. Martha Sparks, the county's finance director, said at a July county meeting that the 1-cent resolution has allowed the county to add 26 public safety positions, including paramedics, EMTs, school resource officers and 911 operators.
Voters may mark that they are "For the Charter Amendment" or "Against the Charter Amendment." They may also leave the question blank.
In 2020, county voters approved a charter amendment, which gave the Talbot County Council the original authorization to increase revenue above the cap by the 1-cent mark. Just over 10,000 voters approved the amendment back in 2020, with about 7,200 voting against it at the time.
Early voting in Talbot County began Thursday, Oct. 24 and closes Thursday, Oct. 31, at the Easton Fire Hall each day from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Election Day is Tuesday, Nov. 5, with polls open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.

title: Talbot County places burn ban
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County places burn ban

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 244
 Words

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council has enacted a burn ban as a dry spell has rendered the county without rain for weeks.Council members held a special meeting Friday morning to pass the burn ban, which prohibits all "open-air burning." Effective Friday, it will last for 30 days, unless it is extended or terminated.
A county press release defined open-air burning as "burning any material in the open or in a receptacle other than a furnace, … including use of fireworks, sparklers, or sparkling devices."
Brian LeCates, county director of emergency services, said in a memorandum to the county that the request for a burn ban came from volunteer fire chiefs. The county's burn ban committee requested the council enact the 30-day ban.
"Their concern is that we have had abnormally dry conditions with no appreciable precipitation in the weather forecast," LeCates wrote.
LeCates noted that the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is "currently classifying Talbot County as having abnormally dry conditions."
"Looking at our weather forecast, we do not show any significant precipitation in the near future," he wrote. "The Maryland Department of Natural Resources Forest Service has listed our area as highly susceptible to fire due to these conditions."
Last week, Dorchester and Wicomico counties each enacted burn bans due to drought-like conditions. On Oct. 22, Wicomico County voted to extend its burn ban.
Talbot County most recently enacted a burn ban on July 21, which was placed due to similar dry conditions and a significant heat wave.

title: Parties should stay out of school elections
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Parties should stay out of school elections

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 767
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The official voter guide and sample ballot of the Talbot County Board of Elections for Talbot County voters includes the following introduction on upcoming Board of Education elections:Non-Partisan Contest
Candidates in this contest may or may not be affiliated with any political party.
This election cycle, at least four Maryland political party organizations will be involved in local Board of Education elections at significantly different levels.
One is the Maryland Democratic Party. Recently Maryland Matters reported "The Maryland Democratic Party will spend 'tens of thousands of dollars' targeting at least eighteen school board candidates that they maintain are looking to bring a 'hateful' and 'right-wing agenda' to schools." The article noted the Maryland Democratic Party has never before been involved in nonpartisan races for local boards of education.
The article also noted the Maryland Democratic Party plan includes hiring workers to canvass, knock on doors and urge voters not to elect 26 school board candidates whom the Maryland Democratic Party says support rewriting history, discriminating against kids and book bans. The Maryland Democratic Party will also provide resources to local Democratic central committees for helping candidates who support "Democratic and inclusive values."
Nowhere currently on the Maryland Democratic Party website is a definition of "Democratic values," nor a mention of supporting candidates who back efforts to improve student achievement scores and ensure safe classroom learning environments.
Maryland Democratic Party leaders say this unprecedented initiative is needed to fight "extremist" agendas favored by certain candidates in 11 Maryland counties — Anne Arundel, Calvert, Carroll, Frederick, Howard, Montgomery, St. Mary's and Talbot. The party also plans to warn against eight other candidates in Allegany, Cecil and Washington counties.
In Anne Arundel County, the Maryland Democratic Party has identified three candidates as "extreme" candidates who not only support book bans but are also against those in the LGBTQ community. In a post on "X," the Maryland Democratic Party has referred to the three candidates as the "Anne Arundel Hate Slate."
The Maryland Democratic Party is not the first or only political organization to target candidates in school board elections. At least three Republican County Central Committees have either done it or are doing it, albeit on a much smaller scale than the Maryland Democratic Party.
In this election cycle, the Talbot County Republican Central Committee has paid for a vote early for the school board mailer promoting a school board candidate candidate. The Cecil County Republican Committee endorsed three school Republican board candidates in 2022. The Calvert County Republican Central Committee endorsed Republican school board candidates in at least two election cycles — 2022 and 2024.
Going forward, it is impossible to predict if, how or how much, state, and local political party organizations may be involved in local board of education elections and what their campaign messages may be.
Some may suggest state and local political party organizations have a right to endorse and support local school board candidates.
They do have that right. The larger question is if they will exercise that right in the correct way.
The correct way is embracing the principle of civil discourse even with those who hold widely differing opinions. In other words — agree to disagree without being disagreeable.
Incorrect ways include referring to certain school board candidates as the "Anne Arundel Hate Slate" and targeting at least 18 school board candidates who are characterized as looking to bring a "hateful" and "right-wing agenda" to school boards.
Our society is already dealing with deeply held and seemingly irreconcilable differences on a wide range of public policy issues based largely on vitriolic and divisive messaging from political party organizations. Their continued involvement in local school board elections is almost guaranteed to generate even more divisiveness.
Voter access to information to make informed voting decisions is not an issue.
Voters already have numerous opportunities to research and evaluate every school board candidate's background, experience and views on what they consider to be the most critical issues of the day, as well as their positions, or lack of positions, on those issues.
These opportunities include but are not limited to information posted on candidate websites, candidate campaign literature, candidate meet and greets and candidate forums where all candidates are invited to speak and answer questions from attendees. Voters can use all these opportunities to draw their own conclusions on which candidates have views on education matters that resonate best with their views.
Voters do not need any political organizations to make those conclusions for them. Let the voters and the voters alone decide.
Accordingly, with regard to all future local school board elections, no state and no local political party organizations need to be or should be involved in any way in those elections.

title: Cambridge elects strong, capable commissioners
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
Cambridge elects strong, capable commissioners

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 596
 Words 

 Read News Document

 So, the votes are in from the Oct. 19 Cambridge city election, and all of the races, except for the mayor, are decided.Congratulations to those who won and thank you to all of the candidates for their willingness to run and offer to be representatives for our community.
While the numbers of people who voted continue to trouble me, because there were so few in some races, the only way for an engaged community to go is up.
The Dorchester Star reported that 1,543 residents voted out of 8,982 registered voters. That is a little over 17% of the total registered voters that voted.
I know that the citizens of Cambridge can do better than that. How does the community find ways to do better? Maybe the next City Council should consider allowing people to vote who have second homes here or own a business in the city but live in the county.
They have an interest in the city and who runs it and might be offered the opportunity to vote here.
As the five wards have approximately the same number of registered voters, the average would be 1,796 eligible voters in each ward. When you look at the results from the different wards and compare the total votes to the eligible voters in each ward for the commissioner races, the numbers are surprising.
Ward 1: 537Ward 2: 208 (4 candidates)Ward 3: 260Ward 4: 266Ward 5: 158 (uncontested)
Despite the low turnout, Cambridge will have a strong and capable group of commissioners for the upcoming term. People who have served before. People who are and have been actively engaged in the community in their work and their volunteerism. People who want to see the city do more for the youth who live here.
With the race for mayor, the total votes cast were 1,498. That vote total was just under 17% of the total registered voters in Cambridge. In watching the vote count on the evening of the 19th, I noticed that there were a few voters that did not vote for any of the mayoral candidates.
As with prior mayoral races, neither of the two finalists have a lock on winning the runoff on Dec. 3. If you can vote in this election, whether or not you voted on Oct. 19, you need to learn more about both candidates and make your voice heard by casting your vote.
As our local system of government is what is known as a "weak mayor" system, having knowledgeable and engaged commissioners is critically important as the city continues the improvements that have been taking place since the city council-city manager form of government was established in 2015. Having a qualified and respected mayor is important for our community and how we are seen by the rest of the state.
The other critical piece for continuing improvement here is having a good and solid city manager to run the day-to-day operations. We have that now in Glenn Steckman. The City Council needs to allow him to do his work and lead city staff to address the challenges of local government while they address the policy issues and pass needed legislation. It is clear that Mr. Steckman is the right person for Cambridge at a critical time in our continuing growth.
Even though the city vote is almost completed, please remember to vote on Nov. 5 for that other election; and in particular please vote in favor of the six proposed county charter amendments that will help our county to be run more effectively and efficiently. These affect you just as much as does your vote in the city elections.

title: Easton Club East resident requests court to order delay of HOA election
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton Club East resident requests court to order delay of HOA election

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News

 EASTON — A resident of Easton Club East has filed a complaint requesting an injunction against the Easton Club East Community Association's board election after his candidacy was rejected.Jerome Wade, represented by attorney Lyndsey Ryan, filed the complaint on Oct. 21, according to Talbot County Circuit Court records. It outlines why he is "challenging the unlawful rejection of his nomination" and his claims that the association exceeded its authority and violated its bylaws.
Easton Club East, a single-family home neighborhood located off of Dutchmans Lane, is home to more than 800 residents, according to its website. Its Board of Directors, made up of three to seven members, sought nomination forms for three expiring positions on Sept. 16, according to the complaint.
Election voting takes place from Oct. 23 to Nov. 6. Wade is requesting the Circuit Court issue an injunction to prevent Easton Club East from holding its election until the court issues a judgment.
In Wade's filing, which also requests a declaratory judgment and temporary restraining order, he stated that residents wanting to be board candidates were "asked" to answer a list of questions in 100 words or less for each question.
After submitting the candidate nomination form on Sept. 30 — the deadline day — to Easton Club East Community Manager Rhonda Bennett, Wade says he was asked shorten his answers to be within the 100-word limit and given until the next morning to do so.
The complaint states that Wade sent a revised form on Oct. 1. Later that day, the association's nominating committee informed Wade his nomination submission was rejected "due to noncompliance" with Easton Club East guidelines.
Four other candidates submitted nomination forms that were accepted, three of which included responses more than 100 words, the complaint states.
"The unequal treatment of the Plaintiff led to the denial of his nomination and preclusion from participating in what should be a democratic process," the complaint reads.
The association's bylaws prescribe a nominating committee to collect written candidacy submissions "within the timeframe and in the format established by the Board of Directors."
Bennett declined to provide comment when reached by the Star Democrat Wednesday.
A hearing for the injunction originally scheduled for Wednesday was postponed. As of Wednesday, no replacement date had been set.

title: Cambridge mayor planning to leave before term is up, looks back on term
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge mayor planning to leave before term is up, looks back on term

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 765
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout is planning to step down as mayor a few weeks before his term ends.In an interview with the Star Democrat, Rideout said he and his wife are planning to move to a continuing care retirement community in Frederick. He is planning to resign sometime in early December as a result.
"Our children are in Alexandria or in North Carolina, and so we wanted to get closer to them," he said.
Rideout said although he hasn't made a formal announcement, he has advised multiple people of his plan to resign, including City Manager Glenn Steckman and City Council President Lajan Cephas.
Steckman said that when Rideout leaves, it will be up to the commissioners how they fill the open seat.
The last time the seat was made vacant — when former Cambridge Mayor Andrew Bradshaw resigned in January 2022 after being charged for distributing revenge porn on Reddit — Cephas took on the duties of mayor until Rideout took the helm.
Cephas and Bradshaw are currently vying to be mayor in the next term. The two candidates will go head to head in a runoff election on Dec. 3.
'PROGRESS IS BEING MADE'Looking back on his time as mayor, Rideout said his goals in office centered around crime and kids, two areas he felt the community most wanted addressed.
He talked about the importance of reducing criminal behavior and delinquency and finding ways to effectively divert children into programming.
Rideout said a challenge of the Eastern Shore and Cambridge is that there aren't enough strong nonprofits. He mentioned New Beginnings Youth and Family Services, the Cambridge Empowerment Center and MidShore Meals til Monday as nonprofits that have "really stepped up" and made significant progress over the last few years.
Rideout also talked about the Portia Johnson-Ennels Youth Internship Program, a summer program for Cambridge residents between the ages of 16 and 23 that are interested in local government.
"That's the kind of thing that I think we need to do," Rideout said.
Rideout thinks "progress is being made," in Cambridge but doesn't see that improvement as his or the City Council's accomplishment. He credits past city managers, city staff and staff leadership.
"We need to strengthen the existing programs so they can expand," he said. "And we need to find other people that have great ideas who want to bring another resource to the community for the kids."
One of the things Rideout is most proud of during his time in office are the recent changes in management and ownership at the Bradford House Apartments, which offers multifamily, subsidized housing for low-income individuals who are elderly or have special needs.
Over the past year and a half, residents have expressed concerns about the safety of the building, from bed bug infestations to call-for-aid systems not working to a lack of security.
Rideout said the city was able to get the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.), Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) and the local state delegation involved, and city staff put in "so much work" to get the issues at Bradford House addressed.
"The changes now are happening," Rideout said. "And that to me is how government can work, should work."
Rideout said he decided to run for mayor after striking out on trying to find someone else for the job. He said he went to different people in Cambridge who he thought would make a good mayor and none of those people were interested in running to fill Bradshaw's seat.
"I felt it was important to have a calming voice during what I anticipated and expected would be a transition until this election," Rideout said. "Because I was only going to do it for the two years."
Cephas said Rideout "brought stability back to Cambridge" following Bradshaw's resignation. She said he also brought "steady decision making."
"He was extremely thoughtful of everyone on both sides," Cephas said. "It's something that I learned from him being the commission president while he was the mayor."
Rideout's main piece of advice to the next mayor of Cambridge is to listen.
"And listen again," he said.
He said the mayor should match their ideas to what the community wants and make sure the community knows they've been heard.
A decade from now, Rideout hopes Cambridge will be a place where students excel in schools, early childhood education programs are teaching kids how to read and write, and new businesses are moving in. He said focusing on the future generations is an important element of making progress in Cambridge.
"Because we aren't going to get businesses who come here who have employees who have children until our school system is improving," he said.

title: Trappe's Post Office reopens after 2-year closure
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado

Trappe's Post Office reopens after 2-year closure

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News

 TRAPPE — Residents of Trappe celebrated the reopening of the town's post office this week after it had been under construction for two years.In Oct. 2022, the Trappe Post Office was forced to close due to a burst pipe. Mark Wahl, strategic communications specialist for the U.S. Postal Service, said construction had to be extended due to complications with the removal of asbestos.
According to Trappe Town Council President Brian Schmidt, the closure of the post office caused significant inconvenience to residents of the town.
Schmidt noted many residents had to travel to Cambridge to pick up their mail since there were many homes in Trappe that could not have mail delivered directly.
"All those people, including the town hall, had to drive to Cambridge every day to pick up mail," Schmidt said. "So the fact that we can now get our mail a lot closer is nice. And the services that (the post office) offers, not just for the town, but for the people outside of the town as well."
According to Schmidt the construction process was slow and disorganized and lacked good communication with town leadership. Schmidt said the town had a hard time communicating with anybody who knew anything about the post office and its ongoing progress.
Schmidt said many of Trappe's residents were pushed to be creative when it came to obtaining their mail. Older constituents of the town could not easily drive to the post office in Cambridge.
Schmidt said he knew of one resident who changed her address to one of her neighbor's. According to Schmidt, the resident was also caring for her husband whose health was failing, and the closure of the post office created another burden for her.
Ann Frock, a resident of Trappe, said before the closing of the post office she had maintained the same P.O. Box for 28 years. She had to find new arrangements to get mail after the office's closure. Frock said she would drive to Cambridge to retrieve her mail and her friend's mail.
"We're really glad that it reopened, and we're sorry that it took so long," Frock said. "And the whole community wishes that we would have been more informed about what was going on. But we're just really glad to have it back open again."
