title: When can Marylanders expect election results?
author: Aidan Hughes and Shaela Foster Capital News Service
content:
When can Marylanders expect election results?

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Aidan Hughes and Shaela Foster Capital News Service | Section: Local News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Even before Election Day, the 2024 election generated immense enthusiasm in Maryland, with nearly 1 million people having voted early in-person and over 600,000 more voters casting their ballots by mail as of Tuesday morning.In the past, counting votes in the state has been a slow process. Only about 8% of votes cast in Maryland were reported by midnight on Election Day 2020, and The New York Times has reported that officials expect this year's pace to match 2020 and 2022.
Katherine Berry, deputy administrator of the State Board of Elections, said in an emailed statement to CNS that "results will be released after all polling locations statewide do not have lines and are able to begin tabulating election day results."
Updates will be available on the State Board of Elections website as results are released.
"The first sets of results will be the mail-in ballots canvassed so far and the early voting results followed by election day," Berry said, adding that results will be refreshed every 10 minutes.
In most counties, canvassing mail-in ballots began on Oct. 15.
Three counties — Cecil, Dorchester, and Somerset — won't begin canvassing mail-in ballots at all until Nov. 7.
Mail-in ballots can also be postmarked or placed in drop boxes until 8 p.m. on Election Day and arrive as late as Nov. 15, meaning some ballots — for example, from some military and overseas voters — won't be canvassed until days after polls close.
Provisional ballots aren't counted in Maryland until Nov. 13, according to Berry. Over 78,000 provisional ballots were cast in 2016, and more than 112,000 were cast in 2020.
Because results from election officials can take a while to release, media outlets are usually the first to declare the winners of elections. These calls are unofficial and have no power to determine who actually won.
Major news organizations rely on "decision desks" composed of experts that attempt to determine when a race is clear enough to announce a victor.
Those decision desks rely on a wealth of data, like voter surveys or exit polls, historical trends and incoming vote returns on election night. When a decision desk believes one candidate has an insurmountable lead, the outlet will call the race.
In some instances though, decision desks will declare a winner before most — or any — results are reported by election officials.
This was the case in Maryland during the last presidential election. As soon as polls closed at 8 p.m., the Associated Press declared Biden won the state in 2020, even though the first votes weren't reported by election officials until 8:55 p.m.
The state was similarly called for Hillary Clinton at 8 p.m. in 2016 and for Barack Obama at 8:01 p.m in 2012.
According to an explainer from AP, the outlet doesn't declare the outcome of races considered competitive until enough votes are counted to make clear who won.
Although most decision desks take a cautious approach to calling races and are generally reliable, that doesn't mean they're infallible.
The Associated Press and other outlets had to retract incorrect calls for a California House race in 2018, and in 2020 some critics suggested that Fox News irresponsibly called Arizona for Joe Biden before they could have been sufficiently certain of the winner.
Marylanders shouldn't be surprised if outlets call the state's presidential choice on a similarly quick timeline again this year. If other down-ballot races — such as closely-watched contests for the Senate and House — are more competitive, it's possible that those calls would come later.

 EASTON — The retirement neighborhood Easton Club East has restarted its board election following the settlement of a lawsuit in which a resident alleged his nomination was unlawfully rejected.On Oct. 21, Jerry Wade filed a complaint in the Talbot County Circuit Court claiming the Easton Club East Community Association violated its bylaws and exceeded its authority when it rejected his application to run for a board position.
Easton Club East is located off of Dutchmans Lane and is home to more than 800 residents, according to its website. The homeowners association's election began Oct. 23, with voting scheduled to close Wednesday.
Four candidates, three of whom were incumbents, were originally accepted on the ballot to vie for three open spots.
However, a settlement reached Oct. 31 between Wade and Easton Club East will restart the election beginning this Thursday, permitting Wade's candidacy. All votes already cast are "null and void," the association wrote in a notice sent to residents on Oct. 31.
Wade initial's filing, which requested an injunction be granted by the court, centered around the 100-word requirements for answers on the open nomination form that candidates completed. Wade claimed Easton Club East's nominating committee denied his nomination "due to noncompliance" despite other accepted nominees also having answers above the 100-word limit to the candidate questions.
"The unequal treatment of the Plaintiff led to the denial of his nomination and preclusion from participating in what should be a democratic process," the complaint read.
In an email to residents, the current Easton Club East Board of Directors stated the reason for the delay of the election was Wade's complaint. The email stated the board "takes any allegation of a violation of the Bylaws extremely seriously."
"The Board believes that this resolution is the best path forward for a timely completion of the election process in accordance with the Bylaws and applicable law," the email reads. "The Board also does not wish to engage in costly litigation with any Member of the Community."
In an interview, Wade said the settlement process was "quite business-like" and "in no way uncordial."
Wes Hagood is the only non-incumbent running other than Wade. He says he was the only candidate to initially adhere to the nomination requirements, noting that Easton Club East didn't enforce the 100-word requirement when reviewing nomination forms from the incumbent board members.
"I think they've treated Jerry (Wade) very unfairly," Hagood said. "I think they've treated me unfairly."
Hagood says in his discussions with neighborhood residents, "this is not the first time this has occurred."
"They don't want it to be open and democratic," he said.
Easton Club East Community Manager Rhonda Bennett did not immediately respond to request for comment Tuesday afternoon.
The Easton Club East Community Association will hold a meeting Wednesday evening to distribute candidate bios and accept any further nominations for the open board positions. Voting in the election begins Thursday and closes Nov. 13.

title: Mid-Shore voters express hopes, anxieties at the polls Tuesday
author: Tom McCall
content:
Mid-Shore voters express hopes, anxieties at the polls Tuesday

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 771
 Words 

 Read News Document

 From the next president of the United States to local board of education races, Mid-Shore voters had both national and local decisions to make at the polls Tuesday.Mid-day Tuesday, multiple election judges at different polling places in Talbot, Dorchester and Caroline counties noted a steady flow of voters.
Some of those flows were bigger than others, however.
Edward Forte, chief judge at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department on Leonard Rieck Drive, said turnout was "busy, as expected." He said there were about 45 people standing in line at 7 a.m.
At Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, chief judges Chris Dawson and Emily Zobel said turnout was slow and steady, adding that other polling places in Dorchester County were busier.
In Caroline County, 658 people had cast their votes at the Denton Volunteer Fire Company by lunchtime. Chief Judge Shawn Howeth said it had been busy at the fire department since 7 a.m. He said there were a lot of new voters.
"People are passionate about this election, I guess," Howeth said.
Going into election night, at the national level, Democratic presidential candidate Vice President Kamala Harris faced Republican candidate former President Donald Trump.
At the state level, Democratic candidate and Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks vied with former Republican Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan for retiring Sen. Ben Cardin's (D-Md.) seat.
On the Eastern Shore, incumbent Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st) faced Democratic candidate Blane Miller III and Libertarian candidate Joshua O'Brien for the Congressional District 1 seat.
Depending on the county, some Mid-Shore ballots also had board of education races on them.
At some polling locations, local Democratic and Republican committees had tables and tents set up, ready to talk to voters.
Talbot County Republican Central Committee member Shari Wilcoxon said she had been outside the Easton Volunteer Fire Department for hours talking with voters.
"I'm feeling extremely positive," she said. "Because I'm getting so many thumbs up. And I'm also getting so many fully-educated voters that know what's on the ballot."
Caroline County Republican Central Committee Chairman Julie Quick said people had been coming over to their tent at the Denton Volunteer Fire Company to take pictures with a cardboard cutout of Trump.
"I have (heard) lots about the direction of our country and how important this election is," she said. "That is why we are here."
Outside the Talbot County Community Center, Judy Wixted handed out voter guides with the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee. Wixted said she was feeling good about the Talbot County elections and was feeling "cautiously optimistic" about the national elections.
"What I know is a truth is, in close elections, ground game wins," Wixted said. "And I really believe that the Harris Walz campaign has the best ground game I have seen since Barack Obama."
Talbot County voter Donna Young said she considers this one of the most important elections she's voted in.
"Because women's rights are being taken away from them left and right, and nobody seems to care," she said.
Multiple voters talked about the importance of the single state-wide question on the ballot, which asks voters whether the Declaration of Rights in the Maryland Constitution should be amended to add a new section that guarantees a right to "reproductive freedom."
Talbot County voter Alecia Weaver said her "main thing" is voting against adding this section.
"Because I don't believe in abortion," she said. "I don't believe in killing babies."
Dorchester County voter Beverly Mundorf said inflation, crime and borders were the most important issues to her going into the election. She said she is excited for Trump. Mundorf also said she is excited for Andy Harris, who she said does a lot for the Eastern Shore, an area that can often get overlooked.
Aaron Woolford, a Dorchester County voter, said he is worried about how the world could change if Trump is elected. He said he thinks it could make life harder for himself and other Black Americans.
Ed Weaver, who is registered as an independent, voted for Trump. He said he sees Trump as "the better of two evils."
"Candidates, they really don't talk about the issues," he said. "All you hear is just a smear campaign." Weaver said this has made it more challenging when it comes to making voting decisions.
Talbot County voter Brendan Wazniak — who considers himself an independent — said he voted blue in the presidential, senate and congressional races but said he didn't think there were any "perfect" candidates.
"I think a lot of the people probably feel that way as well," he said. "So, yeah, it does make it a little bit difficult."

title: Talbot County Democrats marked election night with celebration of campaign efforts
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot County Democrats marked election night with celebration of campaign efforts

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 691
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Cheers filled the BAAM Center on election night as dozens of local Democrats watched votes roll in for the 2024 general election and celebrated the end of a highly divisive election campaign.To be in community among like-minded residents, Talbot Democrats hosted an election watch party filled with food, drinks, guests dressed in their best campaign gear and deep discussion about hopes and fears for the future.
Patrick Firth, chair of the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee, said this celebration was needed for the community on the Shore. Firth said the people gathered on Tuesday are the heartbeat of the Democratic community and more than anything deserved a celebration and to feel appreciated for all their work.
"We had a record of over 200 individual volunteers helping us throughout the election, from greeting voters to canvassing, to phone banking," Firth said. "Talbot led the Eastern Shore this past weekend in canvassing, knocking on over 1000 doors in Talbot County."
Lined around the room were political signs showing support for Vice President Kamala Harris, Maryland Senate candidate Angela Alsobrooks and Talbot County candidate for Board of Education Candace Henry.
Kathy Hostetter, resident of Wye Mills, said she was feeling hopeful Tuesday night though she understood the presidential race would be close. Hostetter shared her enthusiasm for Alsobrooks, who hours later would win a U.S. Senate Seat in Maryland.
"Talbot County is one of the most beautiful places," Hostetter said. "We have a great state here in Maryland, we've got a great blue state. So tonight, we're very hopeful, and we want to keep it blue."
Hours after the party ended, former president Donald Trump triumphed over Democratic opponent Kamala Harris. Though initially expected to be a close race, Trump flipped several swing states in his favor and won the popular vote for the first time as a candidate.
Election night was a mix of triumphs and defeats for Democrats in Maryland. Alsobrooks claimed victory over incumbent Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan. Additionally, Maryland voters overwhelmingly supported an amendment to Maryland's constitution for reproductive freedom.
Michele Dappert, president of the Talbot County Democrat Party, said though Maryland is a famously blue state, this year's election has divided voters, especially in Talbot County.
According to the State Board of Elections' unofficial 2024 General Election Results for Talbot County, over half of voters chose former President Donald Trump as their presidential candidate and an overwhelming number of residents voted for Republican candidate Larry Hogan for U.S. Senate.
Dappert said though there is political separation among those on the Eastern Shore, all voters have essentially the same end goal: to have their values understood, heard and put into practice.
"Look, I get it, politics can be contentious, but when you meet people locally at the door, most of us are just trying to get by, and we're just trying to send our kids to school, have clean water, be able to walk outside and feel safe no matter what you look like and who you are," Dappert said. "And those are all very universal values, so I find it very important to defend them."
Sitting next to Dappert in a Kamala Harris camo cap and a blue shirt, which showed "CLXXVII Minutes" on the front and "11,780 Votes" on the back, was her father George Dappert. George Dappert explained the meaning behind his shirt.
The front represented, in roman numerals, the 186 minutes Trump watched TV during the Jan. 6 insurrection. The back represented the number of votes Trump was trying to find in Georgia to turn the state in his favor during the 2020 Presidential Election.
George Dappert said the Democratic Party has done everything they could in terms of getting out to vote, talking to people and getting the message out there for others to vote. For him, practicing the political right of voting is essential to democracy and he urges everyone to continue to be politically active regardless of major elections.
"It is what generations of our forefathers and foremothers have fought for, bled for, marched for, done everything that they could," George Dappert said. "To willfully not vote is an abdication of your responsibility and what they have given from their past to our future."

title: 4 of 6 charter amendments pass in Dorchester County
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
4 of 6 charter amendments pass in Dorchester County

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 514
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Voters in Dorchester County this general election were posed with six questions asking residents whether or not certain changes should be made to the county charter.Four of six proposed charter amendments were passed by Dorchester County voters, according to unofficial results from the Maryland Board of Elections.
As of Friday afternoon, Dorchester County election workers still had about 1,100 mail-in and provisional ballots left to canvas. This is not enough votes to alter the outcomes of these amendments, but exact vote totals may change in the coming days.
QUESTION AThe first question on the ballot for Dorchester County residents asked whether the county charter should be amended to say that the review of administrative structure be conducted within the first fiscal year of each Dorchester County Council term.
Currently, the charter says a review of administrative structure should take place at least every four years, but it does not state when in that four years it should take place.
Nearly 90% of Dorchester County voters chose to approve the amendment as of totals posted Friday.
QUESTION BThe second question on the ballot asked whether budget-related due dates should be pushed back 15 days in the county charter.
The first due date is for when the county must prepare the budget by. The ballot question asked if that due date should be changed to May 15 from May 1. The question also asked if the county council's budget adoption due date should be changed to June 15 from May 31.
About 76% of ballots counted by Friday voted to approve the change.
QUESTION CThe third question asked whether the county charter should be amended to remove the residency requirement for the county manager position.
Currently, the charter states the county manager does not have to reside in the county at the time they are appointed but must become a resident within six months. It states that the county manager needs to retain residency in the county for the duration of their time in that position.
About 61% of county voters chose to retain the requirements, according to totals posted Friday.
QUESTION DThe fourth question on the ballot asked whether the charter should be amended to clarify certain responsibilities of the county manager, including day-to-day operations, and establish procedures for certain vacancies.
Currently, the charter has procedures in place for council member and treasurer vacancies, as well as certain board and commission vacancies.
More than 87% of Dorchester County voters had chosen to approve the amendment as of Friday.
QUESTION EThe fifth question asked whether the county charter should be amended to remove the residency requirement for the finance director position.
Currently, the charter states the finance director must become a resident of the county within six months of appointment and stay a resident.
Just under 60% of county voters had chosen not to approve the change as of Friday.
QUESTION FThe final question on the ballot asked whether the charter should be amended to include language to ensure transparency of governmental functions as well as access to open meetings and public records.
Dorchester County voters overwhelmingly supported the amendment, which had received approval from almost 93% of the electorate as of Friday.

title: Support for Veterans Court gains momentum
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Support for Veterans Court gains momentum

 November 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A lobbying effort that could create at least one military veterans treatment court on the Mid-Shore continues to gain momentum.The charge is being led by Josh Marks, a Carroll County resident who wrote to the Kent County News and Bay Times Record Observer this summer stating he is part of a group hoping to establish the court across the Mid- and Upper Shore. His initiative was broached in Carroll County in 2022.
"The proposed veterans treatment court would provide treatment for those veterans suffering from post traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury, accountability and mentoring to former military service members, while helping those veterans to reintegrate into society and connect those veterans who are involved with the justice system with the benefits they have earned," Marks said.
In noting the success his efforts had in his home county, Marks stated it was helped by "written letters of support" from several entities, including veterans groups, the Maryland Bar Association, the American Red Cross and United Way.
"There are currently four veterans courts in Maryland — Baltimore city, Anne Arundel, Prince George's and Dorchester," Marks said.
The court in Dorchester County serves the Lower Eastern Shore region.
Across the U.S., there are just over 600 veteran-focused court programs.
On the Mid- and Upper Shore, Marks continues to gain support.
In August, Marks received letters of support from Maryland Sens. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) and Jason Gallion (R-Cecil, Harford) and Del. Christopher Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Adams wrote, "treatment courts provide a second chance to individuals suffering trauma and illness as a result of their service, while providing ongoing peer support to these Marylanders."
Hershey agreed suggesting, a Veterans Court could also access local resources where a veteran does not qualify for VA benefits. "Veterans suffering from mental health issues and substance abuse would be able to enter programs to assist in recovery and be given a pathway to reintegrate into the community," Hershey wrote in his letter of support.
Mautz too lent his support for "a Veteran's Treatment Court in Kent County, Maryland that would support my District 37 constituents in Caroline and Talbot Counties."
In Kent County, Marks was pleased to hear from Maryland District Court Judge John E. Nunn, who asked the District 3 Criminal Intake Commissioners to do a study of veteran defendants by county.
This is a major first step to gauge case volume, Marks said, and he believes once the data is gathered there will be ample volume to establish a regional court. venue. In Marks' Southern Maryland initiative (District 4), he said, Maryland District Court Judge Kristy Holt Chesser asked for a year of data.
"I believe we have shown consensus with four of the five counties encompassing District 3 for a Veterans Treatment Court," Marks said in an August correspondence to the paper.
Marks has also established contact with Eric Johnson of VAMSA (Veteran and Military Support Alliance) in Queen Anne's County and although working independently of each other, Marks said they are sharing resources to promote this venue. "If in fact this venue becomes a reality, it would be my hope that the VAMSA center could be the Docket Coordinator," Marks said.
During Marks' work in Southern Maryland in 2022, then Calvert County Interim State's Attorney Robert Harvey said he supports "expanding legal resources available to veterans through our court system."
Harvey stated he has spoken to judges from both the local circuit and district courts as well as the public defenders' office about the issue and stated the courts have had problems identifying veterans entering the system. Harvey said there is a move to get changes in the application process at the state level. He also plans to observe the workings of the veterans court in Anne Arundel.
"We'll see how it's done in another county," said Harvey.
Calvert Commissioner President Earl F. "Buddy Hance stated he has received a request for support of starting the veterans treatment court in Calvert and has forwarded the initiative to the veterans affairs commission.
When asked this fall about the possibility of a District 3 court on the Shore, Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson said he would be in favor of such a court. "I see many veterans with mental health and substance abuse issues," he said. "I'm in favor of more options for treatment services. These veterans deserve the assistance as a reward for their service."
Establishing the court would require local funding or grant funding from the state.

title: Dayspring residents face potential eviction amid safety, health concerns
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Dayspring residents face potential eviction amid safety, health concerns

 November 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 724
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — For months, residents of the Dayspring Townhomes have raised concerns regarding the safety and conditions of an apartment complex just outside of Ridgely. Now, around half of them are potentially facing eviction.On Nov. 13, the Dayspring Townhomes filed 23 complaints against tenants for failure to pay rent. The complex, located just outside town limits on School Street Lane, is owned by the county and managed by a Delaware-based company.
Failure to pay rent notices were posted to front doors at Daysprings on Friday. A joint trial date for all of the tenants facing eviction is set for this coming Friday afternoon in the Caroline County District Court.
A number of tenants have raised concerns this year about living conditions at the 46-unit complex, including broken appliances, mold, unresponsive property management and an ineffective work order process.
"I've been here 10 years, I ain't never been through this mess," resident Andrea Conaway said on Friday, echoing some of those same concerns.
Those worries only intensified after a non-fatal shooting outside of the complex in August. The incident lead to the county purchasing security cameras, which are now placed at the front of the complex.
Bridge Maryland Inc., a nonprofit organization based in Baltimore County, has held meetings for residents to air their concerns and is assisting the tenants of Dayspring Townhomes with the court process. Bridge Maryland President the Rev. Angelique Mason says residents have experienced the same problems with living conditions for multiple years with no fixes.
"We do know that some of them are not being vocal because they might be behind in their rent," Mason said in an October interview. "They had this idea that they might be evicted if they speak up. And that's really why Bridge is being the voice for the people, because some of them do have fear of eviction. … Nobody should have to live (like that)."
Amid the worries about living conditions, Caroline County paid $2,530 for an independent inspection of the complex on Oct. 23, completed by First State Inspection Agency.
County Administrator Katheleen Freeman said of the 46 units, one was found to have potential mold or mildew. "Outside of that, generally speaking, the most significant issues (were the) smoke detectors," she said in an interview.
The county administrator said East Coast Property Management, the Delaware-based management company that runs the complex, agreed to install the smoke detectors for all units, among other fixes. Attempts by The Star Democrat to reach the company by phone, by email and at their Milford office were unsuccessful.
On Tuesday, Freeman noted that property management informed the county it has addressed electrical issues, fixed broken door frames and ordered window replacements. She said she's expecting other items to be "addressed by the site manager," along with an update next week from East Coast.
The property, which was built in 1994, has been discussed at numerous Caroline County Commissioners meetings since complaints about the apartments surfaced early this year.
On Nov. 12, Commission Vice President Larry Porter expressed his hope that the county sells the property.
"Our position at this point that we're going to express is the possibility of selling that property to a qualified nonprofit organization," Porter said.
In an interview, Porter said the mortgage on the property is deferred because of state involvement, with that deferral conditioned upon the county's ownership and the prerequisite that the property remain a low-income complex.
The complex was previously developed by a nonprofit entity. At last week's commission meeting, Porter said a management agreement between East Coast and the nonprofit — which is no longer in operation — was completed in 2000, and that the language in the agreement needs to be updated.
On Friday evening, some residents in the Dayspring Townhomes had pulled down the notices off of their doors, beginning to process what the future may hold.
Conaway said it was the first time she's received the notice in nearly a decade of living at the complex. Conaway and her daughter, Tiana Corsey, say the living conditions of the 30-year-old townhomes have significantly declined, particularly under the current property manager.
While talking to tenants who had received the notice last week, Bridge Maryland organizer Hannah Freeman said it's time the tenants stand up for themselves, beginning in court this Friday.
"This is why it's important for us to stick together," Hannah Freeman said.

title: Department of Community Services highlights caregivers and resources

Department of Community Services highlights caregivers and resources

 CENTREVILLE — Proclaiming National Caregivers Month and celebrating all family caregivers in the nation, the Department of Community Services also presented annual updates to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners Nov. 12.Families are often the primary source of support and care for older adults and people with disabilities and according to the National Caregivers Month proclamation, over 53 million Americans are currently family caregivers for loved ones and a large number provide care 24 hours a day.
"Ironically we depend more so on family caregivers than on paid caregivers to manage needs with family, elders, young adults, anyone who is requiring caregiving," said Cathy Willis, director of the county's Community Services.
Caregivers are encouraged to take moments for themselves to re-vitalize and attend caregiver meetings and reach out to the Queen Anne's County Area Aging Agency for support resources.
The Queen Anne's County Department of Community Services includes the Area Agency on Aging, County Ride public transit, Housing Authority and the Local Management Board.
The Housing Authority division is newly a part of the Community Services Department, and putting a face to the names of the essential work, Executive Director Mike Clark of the Housing and Family Services introduced staff to the commissioners during the Nov. 12 meeting.
The Division of Housing and Community Services aims to help residents with affordable housing with the ultimate goal of creating opportunities for brighter futures by offering "a hand up, not a handout," according to Clark.
The county's transit service, County Ride, takes around 100 riders to and from work weekly and goes to all four senior centers on a daily basis, according to Chief of Aging and Transportation Anne Sparks.
County Ride also partners with high schools to teach graduating seniors with special needs how to ride public transportation.
For 2024, County Ride is shaping up to finish with over 5,000 rides more than 2023 and 20,000 rides more than 2022, she said.
"It's very successful," Sparks said.
Currently the Queen Anne's County Local Management Board is focusing on Community Reinvestment Repair Funds, which were established by the Queen Anne's County Local Management Board under Maryland's 2023 Cannabis Reform Act in support of initiatives to uplift communities impacted by historical inequities, fostering economic empowerment, youth development, and housing stability, according to Clark.
Through the Local Management Board and the Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development, priorities include homelessness prevention, after-school programs, community resource needs and minority business programs, Clark said.
The Active Aging Center at the Queen Anne's County YMCA in Centreville is also celebrating its one year anniversary, according to Sparks. With an overall attendance of more than 4,000 participants, the new location has seen over 500 new memberships, as well as a large number of congregant meals served, she said.
More information about community services, including County Ride schedules can be found at qac.org/1291/Community-Services.

title: ‘A force in Washington’: Sen. Cardin stops in Easton for farewell tour
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘A force in Washington’: Sen. Cardin stops in Easton for farewell tour

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 569

 EASTON — Local leaders and officials thanked Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.) for his service to the Eastern Shore on Friday morning as the 81-year-old nears his final days of his 18th year in the U.S. Senate.In his farewell tour to the Eastern Shore, the longtime congressman made a stop at the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy to speak with local representatives, including Easton Mayor Megan Cook, Town Council President Frank Gunsallus and Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan.
These officials and state legislators, including Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), thanked Cardin for his professionalism, ability to work across the political aisle and commitments to the Eastern Shore.
In September, Cardin and Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) announced $10.6 million in federal funding for Chesapeake Bay restoration, $2.8 million of which went to the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy. On Friday, Mautz emphasized Cardin's success in providing money to maintain the shoreline.
"At a critical juncture where we are in the world and all the things that are happening, Sen. Cardin is a force in Washington," Mautz said.
"I'm going to miss you," Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said. "The one thing I respect (about) you most is that you're going out on top. I see a lot of politicians who don't know when to step down."
Revisiting his top initiatives throughout his three terms in the Senate, Cardin noted the work done at Capitol Hill to improve Maryland colleges and universities, expand healthcare on the Shore and upgrade water infrastructure.
"There's so much competition for clean water and wastewater facilities that sometimes rural areas don't get their fair share," Cardin said. "We're able to work together to make sure you get your fair share under the revolving funds, but also then use our earmarks for where gaps have taken place."
Cardin said local leadership on the Shore is as impressive as it gets across the state, and he thanked local councils for ensuring rural areas achieve a balance of having an economic future and maintaining a sense of uniqueness.
Cardin spoke highly of Easton — a town he says is attracting much attention in the nation's capital. The senator added that officials in Talbot County are adequately serving all people.
"You also have challenges, hunger and low-income families," Cardin told members of the Talbot County Council. "And you're taking steps to deal with those issues as well, so we appreciate that. … There is diversity here. And you have helped deal with preserving dignity for all of the people in the county."
PASSING THE TORCHCardin opted not to run for reelection, leaving an open seat in the Senate that will be filled by Democrat Angela Alsobrooks, who defeated Republican opponent and former Gov. Larry Hogan in November's election.
Having worked with Alsobrooks, the Prince George's County executive, Cardin said he's confident in Maryland's newest senator.
"We've had several conversations," Cardin said in an interview. "I think she understands the responsibilities, so she has the whole package. I think she'll do a great job."
Cardin emphasized that former Sen. Barbara Mikulski (D-Md.), a mentor of his who he served alongside in the Senate from 2007 to 2017, taught him the tradition of Maryland's delegation working together instead of separately. He hopes Van Hollen and Alsobrooks carry that torch beginning in January.
"I think that tradition will continue, no doubt about it," Cardin said. "Sen. Alsobrooks will continue to not only be an incredible leader, but also part of a great team."

title: Federalsburg unveils sign to recognize historic 2023 election, people who made it possible
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Federalsburg unveils sign to recognize historic 2023 election, people who made it possible

 November 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 744
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The Rev. Jeffrey Butler, a Federalsburg resident, remembers when Brooklyn Avenue went from being a dirt road to a paved one in the late 1970s. He also remembers the more than 40 years it took for the town to get that road repaved."It was so bad," he said. "I mean, just tearing cars up. And we went to the town to complain. They still didn't do nothing."
"Finally, along with this lawsuit, came them also fixing this road up after 40 years," Butler said.
Since a lawsuit led to the election of the town's first two Black council members last year, the road — which is situated in a historically Black area in town — has been repaved.
On Saturday, with the newly paved Brooklyn Avenue in view, Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner and the Federalsburg Town Council unveiled a new sign that commemorates the town's historic election and the new election system that made it possible.
The sign recognizes the individuals and groups who helped make it possible for Black Councilwomen Darlene Pitt Hammond and Brandy James to be elected to the Town Council in September 2023.
A MARKER OF PROGRESSAfter the unveiling, Hammond looked at the sign, tears forming in her eyes.
"It's a lot," she said, taking a pause, "to think that this small little town was able to stand for the rights of all people, not some people."
Hammond, who was a plaintiff in the lawsuit against the town, said the progress that has been made in the town is "heartwarming" and "breathtaking."
"It's a dream come true for me and for others that (came) before me, that we have established that everybody should be represented no matter what the color of your skin is," she said.
Although Black residents now make up nearly half of the town's population, the town had never had a minority representative on the council in its 200-year history. In June 2023 — through charter amendments, legislation and federal court rulings — the town's at-large election system was changed to a two-district system to ensure more representation of Federalsburg's Black residents.
In April, a $260,000 settlement was reached in the lawsuit filed against the town by the Caroline County branch of the NAACP, the Caucus of African American Leaders and Federalsburg residents regarding its discriminatory election system.
The settlement included a sweeping array of measures aimed at providing reconciliation after the town's previous election system was determined to have prevented Black residents from electing their chosen representatives. This includes the town apologizing to those who brought on the lawsuit, affixing a plaque to its town hall building, proclaiming Sept. 26 as Voting Rights Day and erecting the historical marker in the town's Black community.
Hammond said this sign unveiling and the first annual Voting Rights Day celebration, which was held in September, point to "a new era" in Federalsburg.
"It is a new era where everybody has a voice and everybody will be heard," she said.
After years of Butler speaking out about the need for Brooklyn Avenue to be repaved, Hammond said the new council was able to get the project done in about a year.
Before the sign was unveiled, Mayor Kim Abner said she and the council are excited about the direction that Federalsburg is going in.
"We have great things to come," she said. "We are making great progress in the town, and we are super excited that you're all here to celebrate."
Butler said he is hopeful more positive changes are coming with the current council in place.
"It's coming," he said. "We know Rome wasn't built in a day, so it's coming."
Sherone Lewis, a Federalsburg native and first vice president for the Caroline County branch of the NAACP who was a plaintiff on the lawsuit, called it surreal to be celebrating the changes that have been made.
"But I must say, the struggle continues," she said. "We still have a lot of work to do for diversity, equity and inclusion. I know those are buzz words these days. But I do believe that because I want this for my children, my grandchildren."
Willie Woods, president of the Caroline County branch of the NAACP, said the new sign is something that will be seen and read for generations.
"I hate to talk about it from this standpoint, but in the future, we will be passed on and there will be other generations," she said. "And this signage will remind them of the stance that was taken and of the progress that Federalsburg has embraced as we are moving forward."

title: Rideout’s parting advice: Listen and listen again
author: Staff Writer
content:
Rideout’s parting advice: Listen and listen again

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 639
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mayor Stephen Rideout will be missed when he leaves Cambridge on Tuesday.Rideout was everything a small town would want in a mayor. He had a vision for what Cambridge could become, and he had a strategic plan for achieving that vision.
Most important, Rideout listened. He listened to city residents. He listened to the City Council, and he listened to the city manager.
He took what he heard and turned it into action for the betterment of Cambridge.
In an interview with Star Democrat reporter Maggie Trovato, Rideout said one of the things he is most proud of are the recent changes in management and ownership at the Bradford House Apartments, which offers multifamily, subsidized housing for low-income individuals who are elderly or have special needs.
Over the past year and a half, residents have expressed concerns about the safety of the building, from bed bug infestations to call-for-aid systems not working to a lack of security.
Rideout said the city was able to get the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.), Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) and the local state delegation involved. He added that city staff put in "so much work" to get the issues at Bradford House addressed.
"The changes now are happening," Rideout said. "And that to me is how government can work, should work."
Rideout ran for mayor when then Mayor Andrew Bradshaw resigned in January 2022 after being charged for distributing revenge porn on Reddit.
"I felt it was important to have a calming voice during what I anticipated and expected would be a transition until this election," Rideout said. "Because I was only going to do it for the two years."
Lajan Cephas, who served as interim mayor until Rideout was elected, said Rideout "brought stability back to Cambridge" following Bradshaw's resignation. She said he also brought "steady decision-making."
"He was extremely thoughtful of everyone on both sides," Cephas said. "It's something that I learned from him being the commission president while he was the mayor."
Last week, Rideout was lauded with compliments from the City Council, which presented him with a key to the city in thanks for the work he has done.
"Thank you for leading the city through a very difficult, tough, challenging time," Cephas said. "You helped stabilize the city. And we got in a position where we were able to get department heads in place (and) fully staff our police department."
Commissioner Brian Roche said that although he didn't always agree with Rideout, he will always respect Rideout for his persistence. Roche talked about Rideout's contributions in getting Cambridge to have a professional city manager as the main decision-maker for day-to-day operations rather than the mayor.
"So you left it better than you found it," Roche said about Rideout's impact on Cambridge. "And you did that by fundamentally changing the way that the city and now the county do business for the next generation. So thank you."
The list of Rideout's accomplishments is extensive.
He worked with Dorchester County on proposed changes to the county charter, most of which were approved by voters in the recent election.
He challenged the way decisions were made by Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc., calling for a process that was transparent to city residents.
He fought for improvements in services for youths and families in Cambridge.
A decade from now, Rideout hopes Cambridge will be a place where students excel in schools, early childhood education programs are teaching kids how to read and write, and new businesses are moving in. He said focusing on the future generations is an important element of making progress in Cambridge.
"Because we aren't going to get businesses who come here who have employees who have children until our school system is improving," he said.
Rideout's main piece of advice to the next mayor of Cambridge is to listen.
"And listen again," he said.
That is good advice for anyone in a governing position.

title: Lajan Cephas elected Cambridge's next mayor
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Lajan Cephas elected Cambridge's next mayor

 December 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 1027
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — After months of campaigning in a close election that stirred up controversies and got voters talking, Cambridge Commission President Lajan Cephas has been elected the city's mayor.Tuesday night, Cephas secured 53% of the vote, or 787 votes, in a run-off election against former Cambridge Mayor Andrew Bradshaw, who received 47% of the vote with 697 votes. There were 1,484 ballots counted in the election. Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson told the Star Democrat Tuesday that there are 9,183 active, registered voters in Cambridge.
Cephas said she knew it would be a tight race.
"But I'm truly excited that the majority of the voters, that they've decided that they're happy with the direction the city is going and they want to see four more years of this," she said. "So it's my commitment to make sure these projects (get done) and to also make sure our neighborhoods are improved at the highest level."
A HEATED ELECTIONFrom past criminal charges to residency requirements to campaigning practices, the race gave voters a lot to talk about.
Bradshaw's bid for mayor came a little over two and a half years after he resigned from the position. He resigned after he was charged with 50 counts of distributing revenge porn on Reddit. He later pleaded guilty to five of those counts.
In August, Bradshaw told the Star Democrat he wanted to keep the focus of his 2024 campaign on where Cambridge is currently and where it is going, rather than on his past legal issues. He said he thought voters felt the same way.
During a Cambridge candidate forum conducted by the League of Women Voters in early October, Cephas questioned whether people would feel comfortable associating with a mayor known for an "embarrassing" national headline.
At the forum, Bradshaw said that in a city where many people have made mistakes, a large portion of the population shouldn't be disqualified from serving the city because of the "errors of their past." He said his convictions were withdrawn and removed by the state and his probation has been abated.
According to court documents, a judge ordered in November 2023 that the judgements of guilt for Bradshaw's five counts of distributing revenge porn be stricken and Bradshaw be granted probation before judgement.
Bradshaw wasn't the only candidate who has received criminal charges. In 2022, Cephas was charged with second-degree assault in connection with a domestic violence incident in her Cambridge home. The charges were dismissed in January 2023.
Along with past legal controversies, questions regarding candidate residency were also brought up as the two candidates vied for the open seat.
At a City Council meeting Sept. 9, one resident brought up the importance of verifying candidate applications. In response, Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson said city staff has heard rumors regarding applicants and their residency, but no formal complaints had been filed. He encouraged residents to submit formal complaints so they could be looked into.
The issue was also mentioned during a peace order hearing in early October between family members of the mayoral candidates.
At the hearing, Lejan Cephas' brother Cambridge Commissioner Sputty Cephas, who was running for reelection at the time, was denied a final peace order against Bradshaw's wife, Natalee Bradshaw. Sputty Cephas said he filed the peace order after he noticed Natalee Bradshaw following him around the city one evening.
During the hearing, Natalee Bradshaw's attorney Philip Cronan brought up statements that have been made questioning whether Sputty and/or Lajan Cephas are following the city's residency requirements for candidates. In an interview, Andrew Bradshaw alleged Lajan Cephas has not been residing at the Cambridge address on her application. Lajan Cephas told the Star Democrat she has met every requirement to be a candidate in the city's election.
Cambridge residents also raised concerns regarding campaigning practices in the mayoral election. Last week at a Cambridge City Council meeting, residents brought up concerns with candidates door knocking in apartment complexes where elderly people and people with disabilities live. In a letter partially read at the meeting, resident GeriLeigh Farrow called out Cephas and her campaign for door knocking at Conifer Village at Cambridge, an apartment complex for seniors.
Cephas responded to the comments made at the meeting, noting that she had invites to two apartment buildings for meet and greets. She said canvassing is not illegal.
"And I just really find it a shame that we have other people who are trying to say that (canvassing is) being used to take advantage when we're trying to engage," she said during the meeting.
THE NEXT FOUR YEARSCephas said she is excited and "ready to work."
"What I'm most looking forward to are the residents," she said, adding that on the campaign trail, she was made aware of many concerns from residents.
Cephas said she is excited to follow up with those residents and help get their concerns addressed.
Bradshaw said he reached out to Cephas Tuesday night to congratulate her. He said he hopes Cephas will find a way to move the city forward.
"If that's not the case, then in four years, the voters will get the opportunity to make different choices," he said.
Bradshaw said he is "not giving any thought" to whether he will run in four years. He said he wants his supporters to know that although the campaign was a rough one, he tried to run it as clean as he could.
"And in spite of the loss, I feel a lot of pride that we tried to avoid going into the gutter," he said. "And that I think that though we didn't get the result that we expected or wanted to see, that we can have pride in trying to have been the best that we could as competitors, and as a candidate and as a movement or a campaign."
Cephas said this win means that the networks that have been built in the city can be made "even stronger." She brought up the idea of forming partnerships with the school system in an effort to support the city's youth.
"And economic development falls under that," she said. "So the better schools we have, the better opportunities that we'll have, not only for our youth, but also our young adults trying to get into the workforce."

 EASTON — A permit for the 2025 Delmarva Pride Festival was unanimously approved by the Easton Town Council on Monday evening, a stark change from the council's split decision concerning the 2024 festival permit.Next year's festival, the town's fourth annual, is slated for June 14, 2025. Its expected attendance is around 4,000, according to the permit application. The Easton Police Department recommended approval.
The festival is organized by the Delmarva Pride Center and features vendors, businesses and food, with attendees lining South Harrison Street for the celebration of the LGBTQ+ community.
Council President Frank Gunsallus and Councilmembers Maureen Curry, Don Abatiello and the Rev. Elmer Davis all voted for the permit's approval. Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery was absent from Monday's meeting.
In January, Gunsallus and Montgomery voted against approving the public assembly permit for 2024's event. At the time, Montgomery brought up concerns of "overtly sexualized performances and behavior" from dancers at the festival.
At the January meeting, festival organizers maintained that the dancers were professionals and not "scantily clothed." The 2024 permit was narrowly approved 3-2, with Curry, Abbatiello and Davis in favor.
Montgomery told the Star Democrat on Tuesday that if he was present at the most recent council meeting, he would have once again voted against approving the permit.
Earlier this year, Gunsallus was heavily scrutinized by town residents for questioning whether the town should use funds to hang Pride banners and for stating the Pride flag is "antithetical to America."
But on Monday, Gunsallus initiated the motion to approve the festival permit for 2025, which this time was passed with no back-and-forth council discussion.
Tina Jones, co-founder of the Delmarva Pride Center, thanked the council for its unanimous vote during public comment Monday evening.
"I know in the past we've had some difficult conversations in this room," Jones said. "I'm glad to see that we have moved beyond those. And we look very much in favor of continuing to work very closely with this town.
"Personally for me, it's a great sign for all of our community that this has happened tonight. As Rev. Davis said at the beginning, this is a community that's made better by everybody that's here, and your vote tonight showed that."

title: What happened? Professor explains Trump's victory to local Dems
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
What happened? Professor explains Trump's victory to local Dems

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 843
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What went wrong this November? What happened? Democrats, have been asking that question since President-elect Donald Trump won the White House seat against Vice President Kamala Harris.For Kent County Democrats, last month, they looked to Dan Nataf, professor of political science history, political science and philosophy at Anne Arundel Community College, for the answers.
Since 1995, Nataf has directed the Center for the Study of Local Issues, which conducts surveys of Anne Arundel County residents and students. He's been "passionate how material interests, institutional frameworks and ideology interact to shape political outcomes."
His background makes him a good candidate, pun intended, to explain what happened, lending his expertise to the Zoom meeting attended by members of the Democratic Club of Kent County and the Kent County Democratic Central Committee.
Trump won, Nataf said, but how?
He said because despite what their political opponents claim, it was within a small margin of victory...not by a landslide.
Nataf added, seven million people who voted for Biden in 2020, stayed home this time; that made the difference.
Seven million disappeared, and he explained why, looking into the past.
In 1980, Nataf stated, a democratic model of governance shifted to a more economic model. A newfound emphasis was placed on free trade, low taxes and small government, he noted.
Nataf listed off a multitude of reasons for this shift.
The dependency for the working class waned because of automation. The fear of being attacked after the Cold War was gone, and so the working class were not as valued in some influential circles as they once were.
Companies moved out and found low-cost labor, avoiding unions, Nataf explained.
A gender divide was created too, Nataf said, because there was a new focus on white collar jobs, not blue collar jobs, and so women could compete with men. This also created a college/blue collar divide as well.
In this mode of thinking, Nataf noted, the rich got richer, and America gets split into winners and losers.
Nataf said the thinking was winners went to college and found white collar jobs.
This philosophy affected everyone.
On the Republican side they became neoconservatives; Democrats became neoliberals, Nataf said. And this philosophy drove the parties for years, the professor added.
He illustrated that through those years, neoliberals like former presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama unified their party. The Democrats did not break from that leadership.
But within the Republican camp, there arose a mistrust for neoconservative leadership, Natal said. Under former President George W. Bush, after 9/11, many conservatives were discontent by what they viewed as their leaders' endless wars.
Nataf painted a picture the conditions were ripe for a charismatic leader to move in. With many Democrats attached to the universities, and blue collar Republicans disillusioned, angry, many years later — 2014, enter Trump.
According to Nataf, Trump won using a zero-sum model.
He preached America first and that the country should not be the world's savior. That was different from the Republican leadership, Natal said.
Trump talked about immigration in the negative which goes along with his list of the undeserving, Nataf said. The professor said Trump listed the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) Ukrainians and immigrants especially as undeserving, Nataf said.
Nataf said with this rebellion from traditional leadership, Trump used the zero-sum model to ultimately take over the Republican Party, taking advantage of the lower class.
There were many other reasons Nataf gave for Trump's victory as well.
He said that President Joe Biden should have exited the race sooner. He called those who voted for Trump ill-informed, and at times, "couch potatoes," in their research.
He said that after Covid-19, and the economical instability, it would have been challenging for the incumbent party to win anyway.
Nataf then took some time in his lecture for questions. There were a few. One woman made more of a statement, when she said America was not willing to vote for a "woman of color." She also said that Trump divided men and women as a strategy.
Nataf thought the latter was a good point, claiming that Trump, when faced with Harris, put on the alpha male persona. He said that an angry populace took to Trump's "macho behavior," and Harris' "joy" was not relatable.
Nataf repeated, it was a narrow margin of victory.
He said most of the country already decided on who they were voting for. The votes were already "baked in," he mentioned, therefore it just took a small amount of voters to stay home to make a big change.
Overall, though, Nataf's message was that Trump won the blue collar workers, those who were forgotten about by Democrats since the 80's.
And so the question was what can Democrats do to win them going forward?
Would the Democrats have to move more to the center, Nataf asked his audience.
Or, he said, perhaps Trump will be so bad the Democrats would not have to move at all. They will naturally come back to the party after seeing who they voted for.
"It is going to take some self-reflecting," Nataf acknowledged referring to the Democrat party.
The Democratic Club of Kent County meets most months in Chestertown, on the third Thursday of the month. You can contact them at info@dckcmd.com.

title: Shore residents share mixed views on new Chesapeake Bay Bridge
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Shore residents share mixed views on new Chesapeake Bay Bridge

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1059
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Informational displays lined the walls of Kent Island High School's cafeteria Wednesday, laying out narrowed-down options for a new Bay Bridge.The self-paced open house welcomed the community to gather information and submit feedback as the Maryland Transportation Authority conducts Tier 2 of the Chesapeake Bay Crossing Study. The study, launched in 2017, seeks to examine the state's options when it comes to the aging bridge.
Melissa Williams, Maryland Transportation Authority director of the division of planning and program development, said the team that developed the various plans for the new bridge went through in-depth analysis on the traffic data gathered throughout the year. It has developed seven proposed alternatives to the current Bay Bridge, with one alternative being a no-build option.
"We are proposing to remove both existing Bay Bridge spans due to the substantial cost of future maintenance and repair the impact to the traveling public associated with those repairs," Williams said.
Bridge spans, full tunnels, bridge tunnels and double decker bridge options were evaluated during the study. Bridge spans were recommended as construction would have fewer environmental impacts and a lower cost compared to other options. Additionally, the bridge spans would allow for greater flexibility in maintaining traffic during maintenance and emergency response situations.
The proposed alternatives include either a new eight-lane or 10-lane bridge consisting of two spans constructed north or south of the existing bridge.
The proposed alternatives consider bus service improvements, part-time shoulder use, interchange consolidation, park and ride facilities, congestion pricing, and pedestrian and bicycle shared use.
The Kent Island open house marks the third total, and second in-person, open house held by the Chesapeake Bay Crossing Tier 2 Study. On the Dec. 11, 129 attended the meeting. An in-person open house was also hosted at Broadneck High School in Annapolis Dec. 9, with 192 in attendance. In-person open houses followed a virtual open house on Dec. 4, in which 435 individuals logged on.
According to Williams, the open houses provided a transparent view of the project to the community.
"It's great to show lines on paper, " she said.
Patty Baker, of Kent Island, remembers the construction of the westbound span of the Bay Bridge. "It was impressive to watch," she said.
Baker attended several of the study's open houses last year and was interested to see how progress and updates have developed. "I couldn't have dreamed what would happen," she said, noting now the once rural area has become more and more part of a freeway and for so long summer beach traffic has detected weekend activities for locals. With the potential for roadway widening, Baker voiced concerns about areas so close to Route 50 including the Stevensville Cemetery, where her own family plots are. She said she appreciated the open house's layout and staff clarification to questions, particularly as to why the new bridges cannot be placed in different corridors.
"They are doing the best they can with what they are working with," she said.
Attending the project's last open house a year ago, Martin Gleason, of Grasonville, was interested in continual aspects of the project and found it to be very informative in regards to the "when, where, and how."
An area resident of 47 years, Brian H. of Kent Island, considered the potential new bridge "long overdue" and found the study thoroughly researched. He was enthusiastic about how the potential lane widening change would improve traffic flow.
Tom Helfenbein, of Kent Island, found the open house informative and offered suggestions of widening certain merging areas and moving chokepoints down to Route 404. "All consideration seems to stop at the (Queenstown) Outlets," he said.
Despite opportunities for public comment, Jennifer Laird, of Chester, claimed she didn't feel like the opinion of locals was being considered and did not approve of any aspect of the project, stating, "It's going to change everything," including bringing in more people from the western shore. Laird claimed the infrastructure was unequipped to handle the traffic and strongly preferred the new bridge be placed elsewhere.
Cheryl Gover, of Queenstown, voiced concerns of bottlenecking, traffic congestion impacts, and was worried how the proposed bridge shared use path would affect jumpers. Gover also recommended finding ways to create alternative routes off the bridge for locals.
Working in Glen Burnie, Jay Diepenbrock, of Centreville, takes a round trip over the Bay Bridge at least twice a week and knows personally how bad traffic can be. Noting it gets worse before it gets better, Diepenbrock was a little disappointed by the the projected timeline, with scheduled construction completion no sooner than about 2035.
"It will probably happen when I'm too old to be driving," he said. Nonetheless, Diepenbrock was optimistic it would be a much needed improvement for future generations.
Heather Lowe, project manager for the Bay Crossing Tier 2 Study, said a multi-use path for bicycles and pedestrians would be separated from travel lanes by a physical barrier across the more than four-mile bridge.
December open houses serve as formal scoping meetings to hear comments on the issues that will be evaluated in an environmental impact statement, according to Andrew Bing, virtual open house facilitator. Included in the areas of environmental considerations are impacts to natural resources, impacts to parks and recreation areas and impacts on historic properties and archaeological sites.
The Environmental Impact Study will focus on socioeconomic resources and land use, and minority and low income population. After time to consider and evaluate public feedback, a draft impact study is anticipated to be published in November 2025, followed by additional public hearings.
A final environmental impact study and record of decisions are anticipated for fall 2026, along with identified selected alternatives.
The Transportation Authority is anticipating finishing the current phase of the Chesapeake Bay Crossing Study in 2026. Five years of design and permitting would follow with construction anticipated for 2032, Bing said.
Anyone unable to attend the open houses still has time to submit comments through the Chesapeake Bay Crossing Study website. Comments received by Jan. 13 will be part of the study's summarization, Williams said, and comments will continue to be received after this date. "We want to hear what you have to say," she said.
Following the data collection, the study is expected to return with additional open houses next year.
Viewing of the virtual open house is available online. More information, as well as feedback submissions and public comments with personal information redacted are available for viewing at baycrossingstudy.com.
Reporter Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado contributed to this story.

title: St. Michaels raises penalties for 6 town code violations
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado

 ST. MICHAELS — Significant increases in fines for various violations of town codes were approved by the St. Michaels commissions on Wednesday evening.The increases were made on six different town codes and included including raises in fines for short-term rental, transient vendors and leash animal control violations. The fines for some infractions increased by more than 10 times.
Violation fines for short-term rentals operating without permission from the town doubled from $250 to $500.
Condemnation, otherwise known as "housing standards," increased from a steady $100 to $250 for a first violation, $300 for a second violation and $500 for a third violation.
Addressing non-compliance currently has a violation fine of $25. It has been increased to $150. This means that any owner of a building or premises that is not posted with the official street number within 30 days after said owner receives notice of the official street number shall be punishable by a fine of $150. Each day that the owner fails to display the official street number will constitute a separate offense.
Fines for violations relating to transient vendors, or vendors who sell produce or seafood at a roadside or a temporary location, were increased from $25 to $250.
Public urination fines were increased from $25 to $250, and public defecation fines went from $50 to $500.
Finally, leash animal control violation fines doubled from $50 to $100.
Commissioner David Wojciechowski asked if code enforcement officers would issue a warning first prior to issuing fines on the violations. Officer Jeffrey Oswald said on most of the violations there will be warnings prior to the penalties. This would not be the case for public urination and defecation.
After Commissioner Alfred Mercier opened a quiet public hearing on the increases, the commission unanimously approved the fine raises.

Legislators hear Cambridge's priorities before General Assembly session begins

 CAMBRIDGE — Before the regularly scheduled Cambridge City Council meeting on Dec. 9, the council and city staff shared their priorities with state legislators, who are preparing to go back to Annapolis for the 447th session of the Maryland General Assembly.During the legislative delegation work session, Cambridge City Manager Glenn Steckman acknowledged getting state funding this year will be difficult and asked that the Lower Shore delegation notify the city if they come across anything during session that could benefit Cambridge.
Steckman said the city doesn't have a list of laws or law changes that it wants enacted by the General Assembly.
"We're not here to try to make laws and recommend the law changes, but to show you what the issues that the elected leadership here is dealing with and the appointed staff is dealing with," he said. "We're looking for your help and guidance on the legislative level."
The six priorities — which Steckman detailed during the meeting and said are in no particular order — are to:
Preserve and renovate Cambridge's historic City Hall on Gay Street.Continue to move the Cambridge Harbor project forward.Improve housing and revitalize the Pine Street neighborhood.Make enhancements and improvements to city youth services.Update and improve the city's water and sewer infrastructure.Provide local workforce development programs and opportunities.
Steckman said when it comes to workforce development, it can be difficult for residents without transportation who are seeking employment or training opportunities in other counties.
"Obviously, if we want to grow the industrial part of the economy or (the) commercial (part), we need more job training to prepare, not only our existing workforce, but our workforce coming up through the school system," he said.
After Steckman discussed the city's priorities, Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico), Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) all chimed in.
Hutchinson said he sees improving youth services as a very important priority, referencing a local teen who had been detained by the Department of Juvenile Services for stealing a car.
"This is a really serious issue," Hutchinson said. "If we have children who are saying, 'I'm bored and it's fine,' then we really need to work on that and correct that."
Sample-Hughes said that some of the bills on rentals and housing that didn't get passed during last year's session could come back to the General Assembly this year. She said it would be useful for the city to keep in touch as the legislators hear these bills brought back.
"I think your on the ground insight is very beneficial to what we have to do when it comes to the policy work and not only just the financial side of things," she said.
Adams told the council this year will be a "budget year." The state faces a predicted $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026.
"We know that this is going to be a tough year," Adams said. "So legislative requests that revolve around funding capital projects are going to be tough. There is always bond money, and we as a delegation will surely do our part ... in submitting those requests."
Mautz asked that the council stay in touch with the Lower Shore delegation throughout the upcoming legislative session. He said that when the governor's budget comes out, the city should make sure there aren't cuts that will negatively affect the city.
"If there's an actual cut that's going to affect something in the City of Cambridge, somebody needs to call (us)," he said.

author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com

Developers host 3rd community meeting for Easton Crossing project

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 591

 EASTON — Developers and residents gathered Wednesday evening for a third community meeting concerning a planned mixed-use development on Brookletts Avenue.Chesapeake Community Development, a subsidiary of The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, hosted the meeting to update neighbors on its draft site plans and facilitate community feedback.
The Easton Crossing infill project is expected to add around 120 units where a former Perdue AgriBusiness operation used to sit. Additionally, there are significant plans for commercial use and open areas.
Renderings show six buildings planned for the 6.5-acre site. Ross Benincasa, senior vice president of community development at Chesapeake Community Development, said the first building, which will have 15 residential units, is projected to open in December 2027.
Benincasa emphasized the mixed-income aspect of the project on Wednesday. Some units will be at market rate, and others down to where people "will be paying $500 to $600 a month for a new apartment."
"Unlike most developers, we don't build affordable units and market-rate units," Benincasa said. "We build the same unit across the site, and we just have specific ratio goals that we hit for that site. If I'm living in an affordable unit and Joe is in a market-rate unit, and I go over to … Joe's apartment one night, I will have no idea who pays what."
Based on previous feedback, developers and architects are looking into using bricks that are darker in color to match surrounding buildings. They also touched on other topics that were raised at previous community meetings this year, such as lighting, open space and plantings.
"You're going to be seeing a mix of pedestrian (lights) and some larger lights in the areas of the parking lot," Benincasa said. "But those larger lights, from a sizing perspective, are going to feel more like downtown Easton."
There will be a focus on maintaining open space at the property, as well as around 70% native plantings. Benincasa added that once finished, there will be "around four to 10 shrubs or trees per 50 feet."
All parking spots will be screened, some by shrubs and trees and others by buildings. While Benincasa said South Street will be a "secondary" exit and entrance for residents, developers "fully anticipate" most drivers to use Brookletts Avenue.
"But we don't want them on Brookletts. That's the point," resident Harriett Page said.
Benincasa said a traffic study was completed by Lenart Traffic Consulting last week, which did not signify worries about the traffic increase around the site. An increase of around 20 cars during peak hour on Brookletts Avenue is projected.
Resident Joe Minarick said "with Brookletts being the main thoroughclear and the main import" for the site, those projections "(seemed) a little funny."
"Brookletts might be the front of the project, but it is not the only way that people are going to go in and out," Benincasa said. Those heading east toward Caroline County may use Kemp Lane to access Dover Road, he said.
As for the commercial aspect of the site, Benincasa said developers aren't expecting national businesses. In fact, Chesapeake Community Development is looking for local businesses "emotionally invested in their success."
Developers may also encourage businesses to hire people with disabilities, a segment of the population that The Arc strives to serve.
"We have had discussions about if a business wants to hire people with disabilities, then there would be, sort of, credits for that," said Jonathon Rondeau, president and CEO of The Arc. "Or for hiring local as well."
"That will be coming in 2026, 2027," he continued, "as we think about what those incentives are as we begin to market the commercial spaces."
