 MILLINGTON — "I am proud of what we achieved and am looking forward to this project coming to life and bearing fruit," Millington Mayor Kevin Hemstock told an audience of stakeholders and community leaders on Dec. 3, about the new senior housing center being built. The new facility will be located at 172 Sassafras Street — the site of the former Millington Elementary School.He along with Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) Secretary Jake Day, Chair of Home Partnership Inc. Phil Wohlfort and Kent County Commissioners Ron Fithian, John Price and Albert Nickerson, tossed out the first shovelfuls of dirt.
"As we break ground today, it's not just the beginning of a building project, I think this is going to be important for a lot of people in Millington," Hemstock said.
Earlier, inside the building of the school, in a spacious room with walls that still had paintings of emblematic characters from childhood, Clifford the Big Red Dog, The Wizard of Oz, Winnie the Pooh and Bambi, Hemstock pointed out the irony that the senior center will be built there.
"This is a magical moment," Hemstock said, adding that 100 years ago the location was a farm. Then in 1974 the school was built. He said it is interesting to think the first students at the school may benefit in the near-future from what is being built.
2005 was the first mention of a senior housing center in the Town.
Since then, the concept has grown significantly, he stated, plans altering from building a senior center across the street to this location.
Jamie Williams, director of Kent County Economic and Tourism Development traced the history of the property after the school closed in 2017.
The property officially transitioned to the County in May of 2019, she said, then the approximate 24 acres and 36,000 sq ft. building and property were purchased by the Town of Millington in 2022 for $1.
Williams, who told the audience the project speaks to the power of community, collaboration and vision, highlighted the partnerships involved.
The Upper Shore Regional Council provided $50,000 for a preliminary architectural feasibility report.
The Rural Maryland council approved $100,000 for design and engineering cost of the roof and fire suppression system.
The Town of Millington invested $1.4 million for repairs, maintenance, utility cost, staff time, permit fees and submitted a $500,000 community legacy grant application to the DHCD for the construction of the roof and fire suppression system.
Home Partnership Inc. committed over $630,000 towards reconstructing 2200 square ft. for senior-focused spaces.
With all that effort, Williams acknowledged, challenges still remain, estimating the overall cost is projected to be $1.5 million.
She recognized that also includes creating walking trails, a community garden, and creating other enriching open spaces. That takes partnerships, to "build a brighter future for Kent County," she expressed.
After introductions, Secretary Day spoke, expressing the need for this center in an aging population.
"Housing is critical, particularly when we have failed to build housing from 2018 until now," Day said.
Housing costs are high and not likely to decline, he added.
With supply chain interest and expensive labor costs, as all the developers, builders and government officials could attest to, it can be challenging, Day noted.
Day emphasized that with local government all-in, and the developers and community all-in, he knows that Governor Wes Moore would want the DHCD to be all-in, as well.
"We're not at the finish line yet but we are 100% committed," Day reiterated.

title: Caroline County meeting sheds light on possible police accountability 'overreach'
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County meeting sheds light on possible police accountability 'overreach'

 December 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 756
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Law enforcement officials from multiple counties gathered at the Caroline County Commissioners meeting Tuesday, bringing concerns about an incident involving a Caroline County sheriff's deputy and its implications for police accountability committee practices throughout the state.The officials represented the state's Police Accountability Board, a state agency that oversees administrative charging committees, county organizations intended to provide oversight for police practices.
The charging committees were formed as a result of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021. According to maryland.gov, the committees' job is to "... (review) the findings of each law enforcement agency's investigation of police misconduct complaints forwarded by the agency to the Committee. From information related to the investigation, the Committee makes determinations and recommendations."
"We have a lot of law enforcement representation in the room," Commission President Travis Breeding stated at the beginning of the discussion. "I think this will be a great opportunity to discuss the role of the ACC (Administrative Charging Committee) and the PAB (Police Accountability Board)."
The discussion stemmed from an incident that called into question the county committee's investigation practices.
A Caroline County sheriff's deputy, who was not named, was investigated by the committee about a harassment complaint. Charge committee members invited the deputy to meet with the committee regarding the complaint, a move considered by some sheriff's departments to be "not proper protocol" or an "overreach."
"I understand that," said John Bartlett, a member of the Caroline County Administrative Charging Committee who was involved in the event in question. "I've been called in for incidents happening when I was on the job. That's why I walked to his cruiser, identified myself, asked him if he had talked to a lawyer or if he wanted a lawyer, and he was comfortable with coming in (to meet with the committee) without a lawyer."
A date for the incident was not specified. Charging committee members told The Star Democrat they could not further elaborate on the matter.
Sheriff Donald Barker of the Caroline County Sheriff's Office was very confused as to why his officer was called into the meeting, saying Tuesday that to his knowledge the harassment charge had already been exonerated at the time of the incident.
"But the problem I have is my deputy also told me that John told him that he was not," Baker said. "They'd already exonerated him of harassment. So he's already exonerated the entire complaint. What are you going to ask?"
Police Accountability Board members in attendance voiced that it was unusual for a county charging committee member to approach an officer in this manner.
"I think that the only concern that I've had is it's the first time I've seen an ACC ask an individual to come in and testify," James DeWess, Sheriff of Carrol County, said. "I think if somebody's got to meet a deputy out in the parking lot and ask them if they need an attorney, then they shouldn't be inviting them in. I think that's an extension of an overreach of what they should be doing, and that's really the only thing that concerns me."
The Police Accountability Board and the charging committee members agreed Tuesday that the state legislation establishing the oversight committees needs some work in order to clarify protocols for incidents like this going forward.
Caroline County Attorney Stewart Barroll drafted an agreement that will be sent out to the Police Accountability Board and the charge committee at a later date.
Reading from the draft, Barroll said. "Subpoenas may be issued by the ACC or by the chairman acting on behalf of the ACC. The ACC may not request or compel a police officer to appear before the ACC unless it has first requested the information it seeks from the LEA (law enforcement agency), and if still not satisfied, served written questions upon the officer, together with a notice signed by the chair or presiding officer stating that the ACC is in need of the officer's answers to make its determination of whether an officer is to be administratively charged, a copy of the notice and the questions shall be delivered by the chair or the presiding officer or ACC staff to the head of a law enforcement agency that employs the police officer, who shall deliver same to the officer and notify the ACC of the date of service within 15 days after service, the officer shall provide to the ACC and written the answers and a signed statement that the answers are true to the best of the officers, knowledge, information and belief."
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office could not be reached for comment.

title: Drive-through Chester Dunkin’ concept plan moves forward
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Drive-through Chester Dunkin’ concept plan moves forward

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News

 CHESTER — A new, online order focused, cashless Kent Island Dunkin' Donuts franchise took the next tentative steps forward with Queen Anne's County Planning Commission's approval of a concept plan Dec. 12.Maritime Coffee LLC is proposing to administratively combine three deeded parcels to construct a 1,415 square foot Dunkin' Donuts fast food restaurant at 100 Olde Point Village, Chester, in the Town Center zoning district, according to Steve Johnson, senior planner.
Located on Kent Island at the corner of Route 50 and Cox Neck Road, the business will serve drive-through and walk-up patrons with no dine-in service or seating.
With the lack of indoor seating, the applicant also requested a reduction in 16 parking spaces from its required 33.
Noting the fast paced style of the establishment and no inside seating available, "If there's 36 cars on site, there's something wrong," Todd LaLumiere, Maritime Coffee LLC owner said.
Conservative estimates on the low end found drive-through capacities at approximately 120 vehicles an hour and, with roughly 11 parking spaces, online order capacity can handle an additional 132 patrons an hour, he said.
Altogether, the location could handle a combined total of approximately 252 potential patrons per hour, Davis said.
Mark Keeley, project manager at Traffic Concepts Inc. performed the traffic and queuing studies and noted queuing space was "more than adequate," to handle the volume.
With dual order boards, the proposed Chester drive-through has room for 30 queuing vehicles, which was more than other locations, he said.
Studying five Dunkin' locations in Anne Arundel County in 2019 during peak business times of 7 to 9 a.m. and 4 to 6 p.m, the highest queue from the order board was 13 vehicles, with an average being nine vehicles, Keeley said.
"We do 70% of our business by 11 in the morning," LaLumiere said. .
Anticipating "cannibalizing sales" to some extent from the existing location, LaLumiere said the proposed eastbound store will serve primarily as a backup for the existing westbound location.
Much of Dunkin's business, particularly after Covid has been through the drive-through, he noted.
The proposed location anticipates utilizing Dunkin's new drive-through model of separate payment and pick up windows for added efficiency during busy periods, according to LaLumiere.
Six employees are proposed to staff the location during peak hours with drive-through and online orders, and with no cash register inside, he said.
LaLumiere also did not foresee a lot of walkup foot traffic for the proposed location.
During the public comment portion of the Planning Commission meeting, Kent Island resident of 45 years, William Howe spoke out against the proposed Dunkin', stating his daughter owned the Fields of Heather Bakery in Chester's Rainbow Plaza — a business that already provides breakfast items and baked goods to the community.
Howe claimed visitors coming over from the western shore for the weekends would be the only ones benefiting from the new Dunkin'.
Traffic on Cox Neck and Postal Road are "horrendous," particularly on Sunday mornings, Howe said, and that the turning lane off Route 50 wasn't long enough to handle the influx, predicting traffic backups.
The Concept Plan approval was granted by the Commission, who cited the plans were consistent with the 2022 Comprehensive Plan.
Due to its model without dine-in seating, the location was found to generate less parking needs than county parking standards require and the requested reduction in parking was also granted.
The project includes a redevelopment of two existing office spaces and the property will be served by a private well and public sewer — 2.2 acres along Cox Neck Road will be dedicated to Queen Anne's County.
The Department of Public Works is in conceptual agreement with the proposals for stormwater treatment and the applicant will continue to work with them through the next phase of the project.

 The Town of Greensboro conducted its Town Council meeting on Thursday via Zoom discussing many issues on the agenda, as well as some raise by members of the audience.A Greensboro resident, who did not identify herself during the meeting, suggested a YouTube channel be created for residents who can't attend the Town Council meetings, which at this time are only offered online via Zoom call. Streaming the meetings on YouTube would allow residents to watch them after the meeting has happened.
"I kind of put out an idea about having a YouTube channel that we could upload these meetings to," the resident stated, "so that the public isn't confined to coming out in person or watching a live Zoom, something that they could go back and watch after the fact as they're available to was pretty well received. They like the idea that they could go back and view after the fact, so that's just something to consider for the council."
Suggested citizen patrolAnother suggestion offered by the same town resident was a citizen security patrol to work with local law enforcement on keeping the community safe.
This suggestion came in response to the town's lack of law enforcement. Earlier this year, the town weighed whether to close its police department, which was down to only one officer.
"Another thing that I put out that was also pretty well received with a few concerns, was a community citizen security patrol," the resident said. "Putting together some volunteers that could work with the local law enforcement, with some training and background checks to be qualified to be a volunteer, to ride around, identified with maybe a magnet saying that there are community watch, maybe some signs throughout the town saying there's community watch in the area, just to kind of reduce since we're having a police staffing issue too."
New historical society presidentThe president of the Greensboro Historical Society, Vanice Myers, is stepping down as president and moving on to another position in Caroline County as Vice President of the Caroline County Branch of the NAACP.
"Effective Dec. 31, I will no longer be the president of Greensboro Historical Society. The new president of the historical society will be Chad Dean," Meyers said.
When Meyers took the position in 2023, she was the youngest and the first Black president of the historical society.

title: Remarkable events, development top 2024 Mid-Shore headlines
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Remarkable events, development top 2024 Mid-Shore headlines

 January 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Holiday 
 
 1941
 Words 

 Read News Document

 2024 brought countless stories, ranging from changes in local politics to historic celebrations.As we reflect on 2024, the Star Democrat would like to thank all our readers for their stories, their support and for being actively involved in the community.
GROUND BROKEN FOR NEW HOSPITALOfficials and stakeholders joined together at the Talbot County Community Center in October to celebrate the groundbreaking of a long-awaited regional medical center.
The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's project is estimated to cost around $550 million.
Shore Regional Health first applied for a certificate of need to relocate its Easton hospital on Sept. 7, 2012. Industry changes, fiscal concerns and shifting project plans delayed the timeline.
In January, the Maryland Health Care Commission finally approved the certificate of need application.
The hospital will be built on around 230 acres just north of the Easton Airport and across from the Talbot County Community Center. It is replacing the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in downtown Easton.
Site preparation construction is currently underway, with the bulk of construction beginning in the spring of 2025. The medical center is expected to be completed in the summer of 2028.
The new hospital will serve as the primary inpatient hospital for Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
STAR DEMOCRAT TURNS 225The Star Democrat celebrated its 225th anniversary in August. In celebration of the landmark anniversary of continuous news coverage of Maryland, the newspaper held a party at the Avalon Theatre in Easton on Oct. 3 to celebrate the milestone.
The Star Democrat traces its history to the Republican Star, founded in August 1799 by Smith as the Jeffersonian rival to The Maryland Herald, Easton's Federalist newspaper. John Adams was president at the time. The paper has been published during every president's term since, making it one of the oldest newspapers in the country.
In 1799, The Star stood for the principles of individual liberty, local autonomy and limited central government. As it continues in its mission to inform the public about important local issues and happenings, these doctrines still apply.
For the anniversary, leaders from senators to local officials gathered in October to celebrate the years of work the paper has done for the community and will continue to do.
LAKESIDE WASTEWATER PLANT COMPLETEDIn June, the Lakeside wastewater treatment plant was completed in Trappe. This controversial project, an essential step in moving forward with the Lakeside at Trappe housing development, faced lawsuits, petitions and an array of public outcry over environmental concerns over several years.
First proposed over 20 years ago, the planned 2,501-unit housing development spans more than 850 acres off of U.S. Route 50. The development is slated to include a mix of single-family homes, townhouses and apartments, and commercial and retail spaces.
Trappe's existing plant had the capacity to take on wastewater from the development's first 120 homes. That flow will eventually be diverted to the new wastewater treatment plant serving the development, a plan approved by county legislation and a Maryland Department of Environment wastewater discharge permit.
During a June Trappe Town Council meeting, two Lakeside transfer agreements were presented. These agreements were the first steps in eventually passing ownership of the new wastewater treatment plant to the Town of Trappe.
ELECTIONS SHAKE UP LOCAL GOVERNMENTMajor changes were set during the 2024 election cycle. Three new members were elected to the Talbot County Board of Education in November.
Cynthia Marrah Jurrius, Karla Wieland-Cherry and Ann O'Connor won seats for their districts. Wieland-Cherry and O'Connor defeated incumbents to win their spots on the board.
St. Michaels and Cambridge councils also had significant turnover. During the Commissioners of St. Michaels election held in May, the town had three of the five commissioner positions up for vote.
Jay Hudson, David Wojciechowski and Alexis Roiter were elected to fill three seats up for grabs during a townwide election. They defeated four other candidates for the office, including two incumbents — David Breimhurst and Joyce Harrod.
In Cambridge, a close election stirred controversies as Cambridge Commission President Lajan Cephas was elected the city's mayor.
From past criminal charges to residency requirements to campaigning practices, the race gave voters a lot to talk about. Former Mayor Andrew Bradshaw's bid for the office came up short. Bradshaw resigned from the position after he was charged with 50 counts of distributing revenge porn on Reddit 2½ years ago.
RIDGELY POLICE DEPARTMENT DISBANDEDThe Town of Ridgely was hit with big news in March, when the town lost the service of the Ridgely Police Department due to a state investigation into the town's police chief, Jeff Eckrich. Ridgely's commissioners suspended Eckrich and the entire department on March 12.
The town entered a short-term agreement with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to provide police coverage in place of the suspended officers. When the Ridgely officers were officially laid off at the start of the fiscal year on July 1, the town entered into a new agreement with the sheriff's office for fiscal year 2025.
The town of Ridgely has since sold seven vehicles and three firearms once belonging to the Ridgely Police Department, according to records obtained by the Star Democrat. In August, the state announced that the investigation into Eckrich had been closed, citing that "sufficient evidence" of allegations made against him was not found.
C-SD TRACK WINS TITLECambridge-South Dorchester High's track and field teams held big wins in 2024.
The girls track team picked up a fifth title when Kassidy Young won the shot put with a heave of 33-1, and also got big points from Al'Janae Jackson, who was runner-up in the 100 meters (13.06) and 200 (27.27) and the pole vault (7-9).
Led by Jayden Smith, Tori Willis Jr., and Tekai Drummond, Cambridge-SD won the 1A boys title with 155½ points, easily outdistancing second-place Perryville (94½).
CAMBRIDGE SUES CWDIIn July, Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc., Yacht Maintenance Company and the Cambridge City Council reached agreement in a lawsuit filed by the city in May.
The City Council filed a lawsuit against CWDI, the group spearheading the Cambridge Harbor project, and Yacht Maintenance, a boat service company. The lawsuit alleged CWDI was in violation of a transfer agreement it entered into with the city in June 2021.
The transfer agreement gave CWDI roughly 22 acres of land — including about 2.6 acres of land subject to a lease agreement between the city and Yacht Maintenance — for $5.
The city's lawsuit sought $75,000 in damages and requested temporary, preliminary and permanent injunctions stopping defendants from transferring any portion of the property in violation of the covenants of the 2021 transfer agreement.
When the lawsuit was settled after months of mediation, all parties voiced a desire to move the Cambridge Harbor project forward.
In August, Matt Leonard, CWDI's former executive director, left the position, leaving Frank Narr to serve in the role in the interim.
In December, CWDI and the Dorchester Chamber of Commerce held a groundbreaking ceremony for the Cambridge Harbor promenade.
PRIDE BANNERS, FESTIVAL STIR DISCUSSIONIn January, Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus and Ward 3 Council Member David Montgomery voted against issuing the permit to hold the annual Pride Festival event. The festival permit was approved in a 3-2 vote, eliciting strong reactions from many town residents in the following months.
At a May 20 meeting, Gunsallus said that the Pride flag is "antithetical to America" and questioned whether the town should use funds to support such flags and banners, voicing his opposition to Easton funding and displaying celebratory banners for Pride in June. Montgomery supported Gunsallus' statements about the flags and doubled down during following meetings.
Montgomery said the country is being "torn apart by identity politics." He went on to call out the transgender community's involvement in the LGBTQ+ movement specifically, which was met with boos and some attendees leaving the chamber.
Gunsallus' and Montgomery's comments were met with support and opposition from many town residents and other elected officials.
In November, Gunsallus initiated the motion to approve the festival permit for 2025, which this time was passed with no back-and-forth council discussion. Montgomery was not present for the vote, though he told the Star Democrat that if he was present he would have once again voted against approving the permit.
FEDERALSBUG SETTLES HISTORIC LAWSUITA historic lawsuit against the Town of Federalsburg ended in a $260,000 settlement that includes an apology to the town's Black residents and other requirements memorializing the case.
The April 1 settlement includes a sweeping array of measures aimed at providing reconciliation after Federalsburg's previous at-large election system was determined to have prevented Black residents from electing their chosen representatives.
The town's Black population has grown steadily over the years, with Black residents now accounting for about 43% of the roughly 2,800-resident population.
But until last September, the town had never had Black representatives on the Town Council in its 200-year history. Two Black women were elected to the Town Council during Federalsburg's 2023 election — Darlene Pitt Hammond and Brandy James.
The settlement came just over a year after the plaintiffs filed suit in federal court in Baltimore under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Through months of charter amendments, legislation and federal court rulings, the town's previous at-large election system was changed to a two-district system to ensure more representation of Federalsburg's Black residents.
GROUND BROKEN FOR TRAINING FACILITYIn December, first responders, along with local and state officials, broke ground on a state-of-the-art emergency services training facility in Easton.
The A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus is being constructed on Mistletoe Drive. The 7,200-square-foot facility is intended to allow for cross-training between emergency responders and reduce long commutes for first responders in training.
The campus will have a public safety building and an educational building with classrooms, as well as a 1,500-square-foot concrete pad for car fire and extrication training. Hostage rescues, ladder climbs and traffic safety situations are other ways in which the facilities will be used.
TOWN MANAGERS Easton, Cambridge and Oxford all lost town managers last year.
For Easton, the vacancy is the result of a "mutual agreement to part ways" between the town and former Town Manager Donald "Don" Richardson in August. Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey has been serving as town manager in the interim.
The Town of Easton has secured the services of the professional recruitment agency Sumter Local Government Consulting.
For Oxford, former Town Manager Cheryl Lewis retired in June. The town of Oxford was in the midst of controversy due to a previous hire of Michael Calvert, the town's would-be town manager.
Calvert — who was previously a city administrator for Liberty, South Carolina — had been slated to get sworn in as Oxford's next town manager. But just three days after announcing the hire, the Commissioners of Oxford announced the town and Calvert had "mutually agreed to part ways."
Shortly after the news of Calvert's hire, some community members expressed concerns. Oxford resident Scott Rensberger said it was "shocking" the town didn't vet Calvert more because it took him a short time to find out "there were a lot of problems" in the town he was leaving.
In December, Oxford announced the hire of Holly Wahl, who announced her resignation as Chesapeake Beach's town administrator on Dec. 4 amid some turmoil in the western shore town, largely dealing with increasing water and sewer bills.
Tom Carroll, Cambridge's city manager of two years, submitted his resignation in March. In a letter addressed to the mayor and commissioners, Carroll said his last day as city manager would be no later than May 17.
"This was a hard decision for me to reach, but I do know it is the right decision to make," he wrote in an email to the Star Democrat. The reason for this decision, he said, was his concerns with Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.'s Cambridge Harbor project, a project to develop the space along the Cambridge waterfront.
Glenn Steckman was appointed as Cambridge's city manager in July. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Governor will not push beer and wine sales, he says
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Governor will not push beer and wine sales, he says

 January 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 400
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Wes Moore (D) made a strong push for beer and wine sales in grocery stores in Maryland last month. But he changed his stance before the Maryland General Assembly convened for the start of this year's legislative session."This is not going to be one of my administration's priorities," Moore said to The Daily Record's Eye on Annapolis summit just a few hours before legislators gathered for the opening day of the 2025 General Assembly.
Talbot County is the only county in Maryland where beer and wine can currently be purchased at a grocery store. Maryland is one of five states where the sale of beer and wine is not permitted in grocery stores and similar establishments. Other states include Alaska, Delaware, Minnesota and Rhode Island.
Last month, Moore told news outlets around the state that he would push legislators to pass a bill permitting beer and wine sales in grocery stores during this year's General Assembly.
Even when Moore pushed, legislators from the Eastern Shore believed a potential bill on the matter would be overshadowed by state money matters.
"We have a $2.7 billion deficit this year, and I would think that the governor would have more important things to be worried about than beer and wine sales," Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said.
Both Adams and Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said this issue has come up every year they have been in office.
"I'm on the committee jurisdiction for alcohol," Adams said. "Our committee has heard this bill in years past, and we've not supported it because it would be devastating to small business owners that many of which are in my district and here on the Eastern Shore and have been very vocal about their concerns about this kind of legislation."
What has stopped this bill in the past, the legislators said, is the effect competition beer and wine sales in grocery stores will create for small business owners.
"Even in Talbot County, where they sell beer and wine and even liquor in grocery stores. If you speak to those vendors that are liquor stores, they will tell you that while they've been able to survive, that those grocery stores are an economic competitor to them," Mautz said. "So the idea that, well, this works in Talbot County, or works throughout the state, I think is a big assumption as far as not putting these stores out of business."

title: Wind causes snow drifts on Mid-Shore, make clearing roads more difficult
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Wind causes snow drifts on Mid-Shore, make clearing roads more difficult

 January 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Thursday afternoon, Grand Rental Station of Easton employee Zach Kilmon sat atop a green tractor and cleared snow off the facility's driveway.It was not the first time Kilmon had been out to clear snow in front of the building that day. With strong winds blowing through the Mid-Shore, snow has been drifting into the roads, making conditions difficult on drivers and on public works departments.
With the next bout of snow expected Friday night, public works departments on the Mid-Shore are trying to address those snow drifts.
Dorchester County Manager Jerry Jones said they have plowed every road in the county.
"Every road in the county has been touched multiple times," he said. "But with this prevailing, strong, 20-plus mile-per-hour northwest wind, you can go through and them a half hour later, there's drifts again."
According to the National Weather Service, wind gusts Friday night were anticipated to reach as high as 29 miles per hour in Cambridge and 30 miles per hour in Easton.
Talbot County Manager Clay Stamp said snow drifts are having a significant effect on the county's back roads.
"We're working hard with our road crews to address that," he said. "And we've activated our farm community to join our county resources to try to address the re-drifting of these roads. And it's just an uphill battle until the wind decreases."
Stamp said the rural community has been very helpful with clearing roads using tractors, which has freed up county resources.
"As a rural community, we're very proud of our farm community for stepping up when the community is in need with that heavy equipment," he said.
Jones said that in Dorchester County, a lot of contractors have offered assistance in clearing roads.
"And we have certainly welcomed their offers and gotten them into the queue to try to help us manage these roadways," he said.
Kilmon said Grand Rental Station of Easton has rented out tractors to "a good few" people interested in clearing snow. He said he witnessed a few cars get stuck in ditches Thursday in front of his workplace on Centreville Road.
As they try to address snow drifts, both Talbot and Dorchester counties are preparing for the predicted snowfall Friday evening. According to the National Weather Service Thursday, about an inch of accumulation is possible in Easton and two inches of accumulation is possible in Cambridge.
Stamp said Talbot County's crews are prepared for the additional snow. He said the county wants to stress to the community that it's better for drivers to stay off the roads if they're able to and allow road crews to clear snow. He said drivers should also avoid the snow drifts if possible.
"I think our roads crew (members) are often unsung heroes," Stamp said. "They work well into the night, day in and day out, to try to get these roads open. We appreciate the public's patience."
Jones said Dorchester County's road crews are working as much as they can and the county is monitoring potential precipitation on Friday.
"We've got a lot of road here," Jones said. "I think it's 570-some miles that we're responsible for. So we're certainly doing the best we can to get that all done. And we're certainly working with State Highway (Administration) in trying to leverage that relationship as well where we can. I think right now, we just need mother nature to ease up on us and give us a break so we can get on top of it and get it cleared up."

 CAMBRIDGE — During a Dorchester County Council meeting Tuesday, the county manager and council recognized public safety and public works employees for their efforts in the snowstorm that brought as much as 10.5 inches of snow to the county.Dorchester County Manager Jerry Jones said county public safety and public works employees worked hard throughout the snowstorm.
"A lot of great work has been done, and I just wanted to recognize them for the efforts they put forth," he said. "Because it's no easy lift. While many of our county residents are home asleep, warm in their beds, these (employees) are out there in the middle of the night during these treacherous conditions and getting the job done."
County Council Member Ricky Travers said the Public Works Department employees had to go out and "spend long hours" plowing snow.
"It takes a lot out of you to deal with it," he said.
Council President Lenny Pfeffer thanked Jones for leading the county through the "first big storm" since Jones took on the role of county manager in May. Pfeffer also reminded everyone to check in on the elderly and neighbors through this weather.
"Make sure everybody's safe during this time when it's hard to get out," he said.
WAGS, WINGS AND WHEELS AND FUN RUNAlso during the meeting, the council approved two pet-centric events involving Baywater Animal Rescue.
One event, the second annual Run Fur their Lives 5K Fun Run, will be held on April 19. The event is being put on by Baywater Animal Rescue.
The other event, the 2025 Wags, Wings and Wheels Show, has been scheduled for Aug. 9 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Cambridge-Dorchester Regional Airport. The event will be put onby the airport, Baywater Animal Rescue, Chesapeake Classic Car Club and Carol's Kitchen. Proceeds from the event will go to Baywater Animal Rescue and Dorchester County Dog Control.
Although the airport has hosted Wings and Wheels events — where classic cars and airplanes are on display — in the past, this year's event will make pets the "primary focus," Airport Director Steve Nuwer said during the council meeting.
Nuwer said the event will be combined with Young Eagles Day, as well. "So there'll be a lot of activity," he said.
After Nuwer spoke, Baywater Animal Rescue Board President Tom Divilio said the Eastern Shore's leading no-kill animal shelter depends on donations and events like these.
"So we really appreciate getting to do this event," he said. "I think it'll be a great event."
AUDIT SERVICESThe County Council approved a recommendation from the county's Finance Department to have Zelenkofske Axelrod LLC provide audit services to the county.
Along with the accounting firm having county auditing experience and being closer in location to Dorchester County, Finance Director Karen Tolley said Zelenkofske Axelrod LLC is more aligned with the scope of work needed in the county.

title: Cambridge mayor, council sworn in for four-year terms

 CAMBRIDGE — As she spoke of goals to unite the city and stimulate economic development, Mayor Lajan Cephas made the Cambridge City Council meeting and swearing in ceremony a little more interactive for residents than the average City Council meeting.As part of her speech at the end of the meeting — which took place at the Elks Lodge on Pine Street on Monday — Cephas asked the audience to vote on a resolution to return Cambridge to the "innovative, industrial hub" of the Eastern Shore that it once was.
After voices of residents saying "aye" filled the room in response to the figurative resolution, Cephas responded, "the motion carries," signaling the city's next era of leadership.
"Where we are in this process is it's going to take all of us to create this 'one Cambridge,' united, abandoning differences," Cephas said. "And with this vision backed by faith, we will stimulate a living, economic workforce development, which will increase our tax base, providing the highest level of city services for residents and businesses while providing the most legacy outcomes for our youth, our elderly and also families."
Cephas and Cambridge commissioners Brett Summers, Shay Lewis-Sisco, Frank Stout, Sputty Cephas and Brian Roche were all sworn in that evening by Dorchester County Circuit Court Clerk Amy Craig. Claps and cheers from residents resounded through the Elks Lodge as each elected official was sworn into their four-year term.
Once sworn in, the new council unanimously elected Sputty Cephas, the Ward 4 commissioner, as commission president. This decision makes Cambridge's highest elected leadership — mayor and commission president — a pair of siblings.
After thanking his fellow commissioners for their vote of confidence, Sputty Cephas spoke about the importance of continuing to move forward as a city. He said that it will take "a collective effort" from all residents, including the youth and elderly, and called on those in the audience to look at their neighbors and say, "We need you."
"The only way this works, is if each and every one of you play your part," he said.
This was not the first rodeo for three of the five commissioners on stage that night. Sputty Cephas, Roche and Stout have all taken the oath of office before.
Roche, who represents Ward 5, and Cephas were re-elected to their positions in the city's October election. Stout, who represents Ward 3, served as the Ward 3 commissioner from 2008 through 2012.
Toward the end of the meeting, each commissioner spoke. Many of them thanked residents and reflected on their campaigns.
"I look forward to working on a lot of issues that I identified during the campaign," said Summers, who represents Ward 1. "And I look forward to working with my fellow commissioners and mayor on these issues."
Lewis-Sisco, who represents Ward 2, told residents that, in her new role, she will welcome their ideas, suggestions and expertise.
"Our city is not perfect," she said. "But what I do believe firmly is that when we come together and we unite as one, we can actually see our city progress."

title: Dorchester Burial Sites Preservation Board gets another chance
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester Burial Sites Preservation Board gets another chance

 January 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 717
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A board designed to help preserve grave sites in Dorchester County has one year to prove it is able to accomplish its mission or it will face dissolution.After holding a public hearing about repealing a chapter of the county code regarding burial sites preservation, the Dorchester County Council agreed Jan. 21 to keep the chapter — which includes the Burial Sites Preservation Board established within it — for a test period.
"A one-year test from today to see what you can accomplish and see if it is a worthy board to have within this county," Council Member Ricky Travers said before making the motion.
Throughout the public hearing and following discussion, council members brought up concerns of past problems with the board's participation and its ability to work cohesively. Council President Lenny Pfeffer said that in the one-year test period, the board would need to prove it can fill its seats and provide a quorum at its meetings.
Travers said board members would need to work together, not against each other as has been the case in the past.
"As passionate as people might be about grave sites, ... we cannot have this controversy," Travers said. "So whomever comes on that board needs to be willing and ready to work side-by-side."
County Planning and Zoning Director Susan Webb said the Maryland Historical Trust is the state's enforcing entity regarding burial sites preservation.
"And we were basically duplicating the effort," she said. "While this may be a good board for a nonprofit, being under the county's umbrella, I don't think it's working out."
Dorothy Samonisky, the chair of the Burial Sites Preservation Board, said the Maryland Historical Trust only gives guidance and does not "act as an arm of the law" like the county can.
"So right now, this burial site preservation is the only thing that gives you as county members anything to stand on if there is an incident with a grave site."
Pfeffer clarified that the board is an advisory group to the council.
Samonisky said people have been buried in Dorchester County since 1669, and many of those burial sites are on private property. She said the policy in county code gives the county the authority to "act upon destruction of those cemeteries."
Ashley Samonisky, who also spoke during public comment, said the board can guide council actions and help with outreach and education. She said there needs to be something in the code that addresses what happens if a person "maliciously destroy(s) a property or (tries) to hide the fact that it was there," in order to build a beach house, for example.
"There needs to be fines," she said. "There needs to be penalties up to and including the cost of restoring it to the pre-demolition stage. These are just a few ideas that this body can help with."
Dorothy Samonisky acknowledged that there were "internal conflicts" between several board members at one point. She said she also was out due to two major surgeries in 2024.
"We had met up through '23 and had things on the agenda and topics to discuss," she said.
Council Vice President Mike Detmer, who ultimately voted in favor of the board having a one-year test period, said he thinks the board has value, but would function better if not affiliated with the county.
"It being a law and having to be constituted a certain way and done a certain way is holding an effort to preserve burial sites back," he said, later adding, "I think it could be more flexible and more dynamic as a stand-alone."
Detmer said as long as he is on the council, if someone comes to the council with "a salient point" about something in the county, it will get attention. That doesn't require a board, he said.
Before the council unanimously agreed to give the board a test period, Travers said the board had previously gone through an "extremely adversary" time that got to the point where some board members felt unsafe coming to the meetings. He said the county practically had to act as a referee.
"And that's not what we need on our boards," he said.
Pfeffer warned the this can't happen again.
"The last board that was assembled ... had brought things to this chamber," he said. "Had brought thoughts of slander. Had brought disagreements. I will not allow that to happen during these meetings."

title: St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board holds first meeting
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board holds first meeting

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News

 ST. MICHAELS — After months of controversy surrounding its creation, the St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board held its first meeting at the Boy Scout Cabin in St. Michaels Thursday morning.During this meeting, members of the board, the St. Michaels Business Association and residents of the town came together to discuss the future and current condition of the tourism industry.
The board discussed potential budgets, marketing and branding strategies including combining various websites, and getting a better understanding of the tourists who are visiting and the tourists the board would like to bring to St. Michaels.
Timothy Law, the representative of retail businesses on the board, said as a business owner he is really excited for the work the board will produce.
"I love St. Michaels, and today was a huge stride forward to really understanding tourism and promoting our spectacular destination. I think it's a great group of people and we've got a great diversity of thought and diversity of background. It was just a very positive first step."
The idea of a tourism board was brought forth during a commissioners candidate forum hosted by the St. Michaels Business Association last April, when representatives of the Business Associations stated a need for marketing assistance due to a decrease in revenues within the last year.
The purpose of the board, according to a town memo, would be to assist the town in its efforts to encourage businesses to locate or remain in the town and to make recommendations to the commissioners. The board would also "work closely with the Talbot County Tourism Board on a unified, regional marketing approach."
The board has seven members serving four-year terms, all appointed by the commissioners. Membership includes residents not associated with a business and representatives from the lodging, eating/drinking, retail or service, marinas, museums and nonprofit sectors.
The members of the board were elected by the Commissioners of St. Michaels and include:
Brian Ball, managing director for the Wildset Hotel, to represent lodging.
Chris Agharabi, chief executive officer of Ava's Hospitality Group, to represent restaurants.
Katie Blaha, advancement manager of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, to represent nonprofits/museums.
Michael Morgan, owner and president of St. Michaels Marina LLC, to represent marinas.
Timothy Law, owner of American Holiday Shop, to represent retail.
Craig Bertolett, chief operating officer of COLUMBIA Technologies, and Michael McMillan, associate clinical professor of accounting at the University of Maryland, as two representatives for the residents of St. Michaels.
Included in the board is St. Michaels Commissioner Katrina Whittington as acting representative for the commission.
On Thursday, the board discussed the importance of a unified marketing message and the potential benefits of public Wi-Fi for data collection. Board members emphasized the need for a clear target audience and suggested a short-term plan to focus on digital marketing.
Ball said it's important for people to understand how tourism effects all aspects of the town's economy.
"St. Michaels is very much a tourism-based economy and it really affects everything we do from local government to all the businesses and all the restaurants and hotels," Ball said. "I think that this (board) is a very valuable economic tool to use to help the town grow."
Plans were made for the next meeting to include presentations on budget allocation and marketing strategies. The next meeting will be held on Jan. 30.

title: Cronan sworn in as Talbot County Circuit Court judge
author: Konner Metz
content:
Cronan sworn in as Talbot County Circuit Court judge

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 508
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With hundreds in attendance at the Talbot County Courthouse, Philip Cronan was sworn in as the new judge of the Talbot County Circuit Court Friday afternoon.Cronan, appointed by Gov. Wes Moore last month, assumed the seat from acting Administrative Judge Broughton Earnest. Earnest had been serving since March 2024, when previous Judge Stephen Kehoe was appointed to the Appellate Court of Maryland.
"You can put your stamp on the system of justice here," Earnest said during Friday's ceremony to Cronan. "You're the face of justice, at least in the Circuit Court. There are things you can do not only to perpetuate this system, but to enhance it."
In an interview Friday, Cronan said he's excited to begin as the Circuit Court's administrative judge.
"This is a very humbling experience, and it's just an incredible honor to have the opportunity to serve Talbot County in this capacity," Cronan said. "I look forward to it."
Cronan received his law degree from the University of Baltimore School of Law. He served as an assistant state's attorney in Caroline County before beginning his own private practice in Easton.
The new Circuit Court judge is a founding principal of the Easton-based Hollis, Cronan & Fronk law firm. Over the years, his practice has taken a broad path, including domestic litigation, civil litigation, criminal defense and family law.
He said the application and appointment process for the Circuit Court seat was extremely detailed and thorough. Once a judicial nominating commission selected Cronan and two other finalists for the role, they each met with the governor.
It was right before Christmas when Cronan received a call from Moore congratulating him for his appointment.
"I was super excited," Cronan recalled. "I was in court, I was in District Court in Dorchester County when he called. He's such a charismatic, energetic figure, even on the phone. He just makes you feel good."
Cronan says in a one-judge county like Talbot, a judge is "integral" in fairly administering justice.
"I hope to operate in a way that really makes people feel that they are heard, and that they have an opportunity to be heard," Cronan said. "And that they find the process to be fair, even when it doesn't go their way — that they're not steamrolled by the court, so to speak.
"We need to make sure that our citizens find the court a place where they can find justice. If they don't feel heard, if they feel slighted in any way, then we're going to fail. We need to really focus on that."
Cronan previously served as a law clerk for former Talbot County Circuit Court Judge William Horne. He noted Horne held high respect for the institution of the court, something Cronan says was "very powerful."
The longtime Easton attorney aims to channel what he's learned from judges across the state into his work in the Talbot County Circuit Court.
"I've had the benefit of watching so many other judges and how they handle it," Cronan said. "The incredible importance to have a good temperament, to have respect for everybody there, to treat people with dignity."

title: Cambridge City Council hears plans for Harriet Tubman mural area
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge City Council hears plans for Harriet Tubman mural area

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 677
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge mayor and commissioners spent a significant portion of their three-hour meeting Monday learning about Alpha Genesis Community Development Corporation's plans to revitalize the area surrounding the Harriet Tubman mural behind 424 Race St.Adrian Holmes, president and program director of Alpha Genesis, said the second phase project will help extend the stay of tourists in Cambridge.
"Right now, most people who go back there stay no longer than five or ten minutes because there's nowhere to sit, it's hot, it's just not really appealing," she said. "So this is what we want to do to help the people who come to the mural extend their stay. And when they extend their stay, they'll spend more money ... and they'll just have a better experience."
The plan, which extends into Cannery Way off Race Street, is to add two retail spaces adjacent the mural. One of the spaces will be a souvenir shop, Holmes said. The building itself will also include Alpha Genesis' headquarters, three other retail spaces that face Race Street and an exhibition deck.
In front of the mural will be the Harriet Tubman Pavilion, which will shield viewers from inclement weather. Near the pavilion, there will be a community garden.
"We affectionately call this project the North Star Village, a tribute in honor of Harriet Tubman," Holmes said.
Alpha Genesis has been working with the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, the Maryland Historical Trust, the Rural Maryland Council, state legislators and the City of Cambridge to make enhancements to the space. Alpha Genesis is still raising funds for the second phase of the project, which will cost around $1.5 million. The project has received funding from the Maryland General Assembly and the city.
"And then we have a couple grant opportunities that can cover the rest of it," Holmes said.
According to council meeting documents, the proximity of Alpha Genesis' property to city property has made the project a "joint venture" between the two. One document from Alpha Genesis states the city will improve Cannery Way and the adjacent parking lot, and Alpha Genesis will focus on 428 through 432 Race St.
Alpha Genesis is asking the city for the installation of public restrooms, the repositioning of the brick wall on Cannery Way and the addition of a replica of the Ben Ross Cabin on the Cannery Way property.
Holmes said restrooms would benefit tourists who come from far distances to see the mural. Alpha Genesis' proposal is to construct a "North Star Station" that includes two all-gender bathrooms, a 135-square-foot public meeting room and a small lobby space with digital kiosks that have information about the city.
RESTROOM DISCUSSIONCommissioners asked a variety of questions about Alpha Genesis' plans. Multiple questions focused on the restroom proposal.
Commissioner Brian Roche shared his concern with the North Star Station blocking the view of the water from Cannery Way. Holmes said a possible change to the proposal could be to remove the meeting room from the station to make it smaller.
Commission President Sputty Cephas asked who would be responsible for maintaining the public restrooms. Alpha Genesis Executive Director Jermaine Anderson said he thinks it would be a good idea to form a youth or recidivism program where those in the program would be tasked with maintaining areas around the mural.
"Now's the time," he said. "Let's get real creative. Let's continue planning, continue talking, developing relationships. ... I think we can find the solutions we need."
During public comment, Chuck McFadden said he supports revitalizing the area, but the city should be careful about how much it commits. McFadden also cautioned that bringing youth in to clean the public restrooms might not be an easy feat.
After council discussion, the City Council unanimously voted to have city staff work closely with Alpha Genesis on its proposal and make sure it gets through the Historic Preservation Commission and the Planning and Zoning Commission. The vote, which Cephas motioned, also called for a presentation on the fiscal impact of the proposal and made sure Roche and any other interested commissioners can work with city staff on the matter.

title: Centreville Planning Commission tables cannabis expansion
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Centreville Planning Commission tables cannabis expansion

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 660

 CENTREVILLE — Centreville cannabis dispensary Green Thumb Industries request for major site plan approval for a two-acre expansion was tabled Jan. 15 by the Centreville Planning Commission to address additional comments.The original facility final site plan was approved in 2021 with two-acres of outdoor growth, and Green Thumb is now requesting amended final minor site plan to expand with an additional two acres and include a new irrigation shed and incorporate drying trailers to enclose order, according to attorney Kevin Shearon, DMS Associates on behalf of the applicant.
The expansion is a permitted use and meets town requirements, he said.
Public comment was split on the expansion.
Several emails from citizens presented to the planning commission voiced support, citing Green Thumb as a job creator and revenue source for the town, as well as cannabis fitting into the expanding definition of agriculture.
In-person public comment largely played a different tune however, mainly residents of Symphony Village speaking against the odor.
Over the summer odors were described as minimal or not as noticeable, but during September to December of the harvest and drying time, residents claimed the order as "pungent" and "almost daily."
In operation in Centreville for a year and a half, Green Thumb has undergone major odor mitigations following previous community feedback, spending over $100,000 assessing, identifying and installing technology, according to Rebecca Brown, of Green Thumb's government affairs department.
Green Thumb has invested over $40 million in the building, she said.
The location had been vacant for eight years before Green Thumb moved in, Brown said. The location was chosen for the Green Thumb's ability to grow as expansion is a key component of the business model and needed to stay competitive, she said.
Green Thumb is considered one of the largest private employers in town and in the county, employing over 200 at the Comet Drive location, Brown said.
Byers Scientific performs the testing samples both indoor and outdoor for Green Thumb twice a year previously in June, Brown said.
While odor hasn't completely gone away, Green Thumb was doing everything it could to diminish odors, "and we're not going to stop doing that," according to Brown.
Smells have been identified as coming from harvesting and processing, not just budding outside, Green Thumb officials said, and mitigation has been applied where odors have been noted to be the most prevalent including the extraction lab, and the indoor kitchen hood, where edible products are created.
Green Thumb previously utilized a cost-prohibited hemp dryer, while moving forward, seeks to use fully enclosed drying containers with charcoal odor mitigation built in, according to officials.
Scrubbing the air, the 40-foot long, eight-foot wide containers perform roughly 42 air changes per hour and filters are swapped out every two weeks, officials said.
The same odor mitigation technology already employed will be utilized on a broader scale, she said.
Brown claimed with the expansion, twice that outdoor growing area would not double the odor, "It's sort of like when you bake two apple pies versus you bake four apple pies, you're not going to smell any additional pies, you're already smelling it."
Acknowledging she was not in the marijuana industry, planning commission member Wendy Emerson disagreed with the pie analogy, stating herself as a baker, and that "four pies will in fact provide more scent."
Emerson sought information regarding the industry's standards that she claimed should have been shared with the planning commission prior, including what was the odor level previously, where is it today, and what is the intended increase.
Noting existing technology to detect other odors such as carbon monoxide monitors, Emerson sought exploring technology to monitor cannabis odors and Brown said Green Thumb could look into technology as part of the expansion's approval.
The planning commission also noted the plan's public works agreement and tree canopy requirements need addressing.
Tabling a vote, the planning commission determined there was not enough information and sought additional comments to be addressed including testing data from other Green Thumb sites during the fall months and submission of the most recent Jan. 20 test results.

title: Tunis Mills bridge replacement project moves forward
author: Konner Metz
content:
Tunis Mills bridge replacement project moves forward

 January 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 629
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TUNIS MILLS — A beloved bridge in the Tunis Mills community is moving toward reconstruction after months of resident input into the bridge's redesign.In recent years, the 345-foot-long Leeds Creeks Bridge and its wood planks have deteriorated. County engineers consider the bridge structurally deficient, necessitating a replacement.
Tuesday, the Talbot County Council agreed to move forward with the bridge replacement project. County Engineer Ray Clarke recommended the county work toward finalizing rights-of-way acquisitions and necessary permits so construction can be pursued later this year.
As proposed, the replacement would include a wooden deck and a timber wearing surface. The structures below the bridge supporting it, known as piles, would consist of concrete and steel materials.
Clarke told council members that in order to use federal funding for the project, the bridge replacement project cannot use timber piles per the State Highway Administration. He added that trying to build an all-timber replacement will cause significant delays and costs.
"The big disadvantage we have is that if we don't get the federal aid, we're probably going to need to request the council for additional funding for the project, local funding," Clarke said. " … This could be a $3 or $4 million ask."
The project costs around $6.5 million, with $1.5 million coming from the county. The rest is federally funded.
Advocates of a 100% wooden replacement have been in dialogue with the county, including at an August public meeting. Susan McDermott and John Tabori, two of those advocates, have lived in Tunis Mills next to the bridge for four years.
McDermott says the original proposal to rebuild the bridge many years ago "was just unacceptable to the community." The county's recent proposal matches more of what she and some other neighbors had hoped for.
"We're very pleased that the council has shown as much flexibility toward community views as it has," McDermott said.
Residents like McDermott previously expressed concerns that an asphalt wearing surface would encourage speeding across the bridge. The county's plans now include a timber wearing surface. Clarke said that change will amount to around a $250,000 increase.
The other main change based on community feedback is a reduction in the height of the safety railing from 42 to 36 inches.
McDermott, who leads a small group of neighbors called the Tunis Mills All-Timber Bridge Alliance, hopes to find answers to whether an exception can be made for the requirement that piles not be timber.
She adds that the bridge is an integral part of the community.
"I think the town feels that the wooden bridge of Tunis Mills — one of the last wooden-deck bridges in the county — is very much part of the community," McDermott said. "It's not just a bridge that occasional traffic goes across. We've got a lot of walkers in this neighborhood, a lot of kids and people just use that bridge as a foot path."
After a video of the bridge was shown during the meeting, Talbot County Council Member Lynn Mielke said it seems the replacement "needs to be done sooner rather than later."
Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher thanked Clarke and his team for their efforts to advance the replacement project.
"I appreciate the homework that you've done to investigate the alternatives as requested and appreciate that we really can't sacrifice the federal aid," Lesher said. "The economics of this project dictate that we absolutely need to go with the recommended steel concrete pilings and concrete cap."
Lesher motioned to approve the project as presented, and the rest of the council unanimously agreed. Lesher added that he hopes the federal funding for the project comes through, referencing President Donald Trump's temporary pause on federal grants and loans announced earlier this week and rescinded Wednesday.
"And we'll just hope that any suspension of federal grant aid for transportation projects is very short-lived," Lesher said Tuesday.

title: Reassessments show property values up 22% in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
Reassessments show property values up 22% in Talbot County

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 423
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot County property values rose at a rate slightly above the statewide average, according to data from the Maryland Department of Reassessments and Taxation.The state's 2025 reassessments show the value of Group 1 residential and commercial properties in Talbot County increased by 22.1% from 2022, the last time they were assessed. Statewide, Group 1 property values increased 20.1% on average.
Each year, one of three groups is reassessed, determining its property value change from three years ago. Last year, Group 3 properties were reassessed, with their values increasing by 18.4% from the previous assessment.
However, the 20.1% mark statewide is down from 2024's reassessment average in Maryland, which was 23.4%.
In 2022, Group 1 property values rose by a higher rate of 6.2% in Talbot County.
"It's just where we are," said Jim Bent, an Easton-based realtor for Benson & Mangold Real Estate. "I think we're going to have some kind of a reset in values at some point in the next few years. I don't think it's going to be what we saw in 2007. But different neighborhoods can only go a certain amount."
He added that "it's awful hard once you get the price up to get it back down." Home values are sharply increasing due to construction costs, among other factors, Bent said.
"For someone to come in and purchase a piece of land that has no development on it and start the process with engineers, attorneys, architects, everything else, they've got a significant amount of money invested before they start digging in the ground," Bent said.
Property taxes will not necessarily increase at the same rate as the value reassessments do, since each year only one of three groups is reassessed.
Talbot County Finance Director Martha Sparks added that the assessment's impact on property owners is "more complicated" due to Talbot County's revenue cap, which limits how much the county can collect from property tax revenue.
Property owners can receive credit through the Homestead Tax Credit program if their property is considered their principal residence. Those who received property assessment notices in the mail this month will see their tax credit status.
Lesley Jackson, Talbot County supervisor at the Maryland Department of Reassessments and Taxation, says those who have "approved" written in the box under the "principal residence" line on the notice are set to receive their tax credit.
Jackson says property owners with a box that reads "denied" should contact the department. Those who received notices reading "Principal Residence: NO" have not applied, and if it is their primary residence, they can apply online for the tax credit.

 DENTON — The Caroline County Historical Society wants to rebuild a working relationship with the County Commissioners so they can get some help funding for different projects to help bring tourist to the town."We have in and around Preston a five-mile radius the most significant components of the Underground Railroad in the United States," lifetime member of the historical society Mick McCrea said.

It aims to address the growing need for modern and efficient detention facilities in the region, where counties are struggling to finance renovations or replacements of their aging detention facilities.
The commissioners said they still have not received exact numbers for how much everything will cost and how much the county will save by joining the agreement with the other counties.
Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter suggested that the county should do an independent evaluation of the operating cost.

The county also want numbers crunched on transportation, employment and other things.

title: Attorney general releases immigration guidances; local officials react
author: Konner Metz
content:
Attorney general releases immigration guidances; local officials react

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the days since President Donald Trump signed executive orders bringing sweeping changes to immigration policy, Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown has released immigration enforcement guidance for local law enforcement agencies and healthcare providers.Last week, Brown joined 10 other attorney generals across the United States in addressing the president's federal immigration directives.
In a joint statement, they wrote that state and local law enforcement agencies "cannot be commandeered" to assist federal immigration agents.
"As state attorneys general, we have a responsibility to enforce state laws — and we will continue to investigate and prosecute crimes, regardless of immigration status," the statement read. "We will not be distracted by the President's mass deportation agenda."
LAW ENFORCEMENT
In Brown's guidance toward law enforcement, the attorney general stated, "the federal government cannot compel state and local law enforcement to enforce immigration laws."
"This guidance ensures that law enforcement agencies understand the scope and limitations of their authority and makes clear that the rule of law does not change depending on the federal government's priorities," Brown wrote.
The guidance outlines that police officers cannot do the following: extend detentions to investigate immigration status, give names and addresses to federal authorities without a warrant, or ask about immigration status if it's not relevant to an investigation.
Dorchester County Sheriff James Phillips said his department won't overstep boundaries, but they will assist federal authorities if requested.
"If they ask for police assistance, we're going to help them," Phillips said.
"It's his opinion, it's how he's interpreting the law, and I understand that," said Phillips of Brown's guidance, later adding that "I'm not going to turn my back on another police officer doing his job."
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker said as he's aware, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, is "going after hardened criminals that are in Caroline County."
Baker said the sheriff's office will assist federal immigration agents in ways that federal and Maryland laws permit. He said that U.S. Homeland Security Investigations has had a presence in recent weeks.
"I think that HSI has peaked as far as going after people who are here illegally and are committing crimes," Baker said of what he's heard from his deputies.
HEALTHCARE FACILITIESIn his guidance to healthcare providers, Brown wrote that "no Marylander, regardless of immigration status, should have to choose between their health and safety."
If an immigration agent enters a healthcare facility, Brown's guidance instructs staff to request the agent's credentials and contact legal counsel.
The attorney general said healthcare staff shouldn't give out patient information unless shown a warrant, subpoena or summons. Brown added that staff shouldn't "attempt to bar the officer from public spaces" or "take other action to thwart the investigation."
Trena Williamson, regional director of communications and marketing for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, said the medical system "has a consistent approach" for interactions with all law enforcement officers.
"We remain committed to complying with federal and state laws while ensuring all Marylanders have access to essential health care services," Williamson wrote. "Recent executive orders from the president have not resulted in any changes to our approach."

title: Design for new Francis Scott Key Bridge unveiled
author: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com
content:
Design for new Francis Scott Key Bridge unveiled

 February 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 582
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tuesday morning, Gov. Wes Moore joined local, state and national leaders at Tradepoint Atlantic to unveil the design for the new Francis Scott Key Bridge: a 285-foot cable-stayed bridge, which will stand in the same place as the former structure.The new cable-stayed structure will be the first of its kind in the state, with two lanes of traffic in each direction, 10-foot shoulders and enough height to accommodate passing vessels. According to Moore, the rebuilding will employ "many Marylanders" and use the "best materials" available.
"We get cars from Michigan out to market. We bring sugars and spices to Louisiana. We haul farm equipment from the East Coast deep into the farmland. Commerce and trade are the bedrock of our state," Moore said.
During the conference, Moore noted the hard work of Marylanders during recovery efforts following the bridge's collapse last year and the ongoing rebuilding process.
According to the governor, initial reports estimated that it would take 11 months to clear the site of the collapse and reopen the Port of Baltimore. The recovery process took only 11 weeks.
Alongside Moore, Rep. Sarah Elfreth (D-Md.) remarked that the process would not have been possible without bipartisan cooperation.
"We are able to get here by being able to work together," the governor said. "Without that level of bipartisan support, we wouldn't be here."
Moore has high hopes that the rebuilding will strengthen the Port of Baltimore, turning the city into "a maritime hub for the East Coast and a maritime hub for the nation."
Other local leaders not in attendance weighed in on the pivotal point in the bridge's reconstruction.
Rep. Johnny Olszewski (D-Md.), who grew up in Dundalk and represented the area as Baltimore County Executive until last month, believes the bridge's reconstruction is a symbol of the area's resilience.
"The Key Bridge was symbolic of our community's grit and fortitude, and its collapse was deeply painful and personal for so many of us. We grieved the men who lost their lives in this unimaginable tragedy and suffered the pain of uncertain livelihoods in the weeks that followed," Olszewski said. "Today, we celebrate an important milestone as we do what Baltimore always does in the toughest of times: rebuild bigger, better, stronger."
Despite the solidified design, there are a number of elements still to be determined — namely the bridge's title.
Since the bridge's collapse, the Caucus of African American Leaders, a coalition of Black activists across the United States, have called for the renaming of the span due to Francis Scott Key's history as an owner of enslaved people. Alternatively, the organization suggested the bridge be renamed after Rep. Parren J. Mitchell, the first Black Marylander elected to the House of Representatives in 1970.
During the current legislative session, the Maryland Senate is set to hear Senate Bill 119, which "will honor the history and legacy of Maryland" by retaining Key's name.
Additionally, there are ongoing discussions about a memorial for the six men whose lives were lost during the collapse. Although Moore was asked about a potential memorial during the conference, he did not provide a clear answer.
"Once the bridge is complete, the memory of those lost on March 26 will not be forgotten," Moore said.
Following the ongoing surveying around the site, the next step in the rebuilding process will be the demolition of the remaining pillars on either side of the former bridge. The demolition is anticipated to occur in May.
Construction on the new structure will begin "immediately after," according to Moore, and is slated to be completed by 2028.
