title: Easton leaders at odds over affordable housing ordinance's next step
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton leaders at odds over affordable housing ordinance's next step

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 602
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Town leaders held a tense discussion Monday regarding inclusionary zoning, debating how quickly the town should move forward with an ordinance meant to address affordable housing shortages.At Monday's meeting, the Town Council was asked to schedule a workshop to review the draft of an inclusionary zoning ordinance that's been in the works for two years.
In November, the Planning Commission approved the ordinance by a 4-1 vote. It would require residential developers to allocate 15% of their units as affordable.
Initially, Town Council President Frank Gunsallus made a motion for the town to seek out a firm and delay the workshop. The motion was immediately seconded by Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery, but a lengthy discussion followed before the motion was eventually rescinded.
"It's clear from studies in other jurisdictions that the impacts have varied but that they have included a serious slow down in building because this is essentially a tax on builders," Montgomery said of inclusionary zoning. "They've included higher housing costs to the extent that it's been possible to pass those on."
Gunsallus proposed the town find an independent firm to conduct a study "over the next nine to 12 months." The firm would provide "an objective analysis" of the positive and negative effects an inclusionary zoning ordinance may have, he said.
Montgomery said in his experience, the town could be "looking at $50,000 at a minimum" for such a study.
Mayor Megan Cook disagreed with the proposal to hire an outside firm for a long-term study. She emphasized that town planners, staff, and the Planning Commission have already spent a significant amount of time drafting the ordinance and considering its potential effects.
Town planners worked with an advisory firm, David Paul Rosen & Associates, to help revise the legislation last summer.
"What information are you looking to gain that has not already been looked at?" Cook asked Gunsallus. "And by the way, we don't have $50,000 in this year's budget."
"I beg to differ," Gunsallus responded. "I read the budget thoroughly, I would actually very much beg to differ on that."
Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry said she'd like to "see the scope of work" before the town commits funds toward a study. Curry asked who would select the firm. Gunsallus said the council would be in charge.
"Why? Why would the council be choosing?" Cook asked.
"Because we're the ones tasked with needing to make a decision on this," Gunsallus said. "The town has already spent a significant amount of money into drafting it. Because the responsibility ends right here, that's why."
Gunsallus later added that based on studies he's read, there are "serious doubts" about whether inclusionary zoning will lead to the number of affordable units the town is seeking.
"But there's equal research out there that shows that it will," Cook said.
Councilmembers Don Abbatiello and the Rev. Elmer Davis said they'd like to have the workshop before making a decision on a study. Council agreed to a March 3 workshop for the Attainable Housing Task Force to provide a report related to the ordinance.
Gunsallus maintained that he appreciates the hard work of town staff. He said it's the council's "responsibility to carefully evaluate what has worked elsewhere before determining the best course of action for Easton."
"There is a serious housing issue with the Town of Easton," Cook said toward the end of the discussion. "We can't even employ a police officer, hire a new police officer, and have them be able to live in the town that they have been sworn to serve. That is a real issue."
"We are talking this to death," Cook added. "And that is inaction by constant conversation."
This story has been updated.

author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com

From crushes to banning cell phones — Maryland lawmakers propose new legislation covering range of issues

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland state senators and delegates have introduced a variety of bills in the 2024 legislative session, addressing issues ranging from state symbols and education mandates to law enforcement policy and budget concerns.State Symbols and Utility RegulationsState Sen. Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) has introduced Senate Bill 562, which would designate the original Maryland Orange Crush as the state cocktail. The bill is co-sponsored by Sens. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Wicomico, Worcester).
Hershey also sponsored Senate Bill 561, which, along with House Bill 227 sponsored by Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), would allow electric cooperatives to use unclaimed funds only to assist cooperative members or donate to nonprofit organizations, rather than treating them as abandoned property.
Additionally, Hershey introduced Senate Bill 355, seeking to delay the implementation of the Family and Medical Leave Insurance Program by two years.
Energy and Education LegislationDel. Jeff Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) is behind two bills on solar energy regulation: House Bill 739 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 478) and House Bill 742. One bill would prohibit the use of eminent domain for solar siting, while the other would return control over solar development to county governments.
Ghrist also introduced House Bill 736, which seeks to remove the mandate requiring local school systems to offer pre-kindergarten for three-year-olds. Another provision in the bill would increase state funding to help Kent County construct a new middle school.
On law enforcement, Ghrist is supporting a bill — potentially House Bill 122 — that would require the removal of unfounded complaints from police personnel files.
Nursing, Historic Preservation, and Cemetery ProtectionsDel. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) has proposed House Bill 602 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 407), directing the State Board of Nursing to negotiate reciprocity agreements with neighboring states for advanced practice nursing licensure. Another measure, House Bill 616 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 421), would extend the statute of limitations for crimes related to cemetery destruction and prohibit damaging cemetery landscaping. The bill is co-sponsored by Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico).
Hutchinson is also behind House Bill 760, which would establish a local appeals process for Maryland Historic Trust decisions.
Budget Deficit Shifts to CountiesGov. Wes Moore's proposed budget shifts some of the state's structural deficit onto county governments. Ghrist criticized the move, stating that counties did not contribute to the deficit but are now being forced to compensate for state overspending.
"For my district, $720,000 will be shifted to Caroline County on top of an additional $1.8 million more that the county will have to add to education under Kirwan mandates," Ghrist stated. He cited similar financial burdens for other Eastern Shore counties, including Cecil, Kent, and Queen Anne's.
"This will stifle economic growth because people will be sending more of their hard-earned money to the government rather than spending it in their local economies," Ghrist added.
Law Enforcement and Traffic StopsA controversial proposal, Senate Bill 292, has drawn strong opposition from law enforcement officials, including Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker. The bill would reclassify certain primary traffic offenses as secondary offenses, preventing law enforcement from stopping drivers solely for those violations.
"These minor traffic violations could actually lead to catching suspects that have committed serious felonies, recovering firearms, and stopping drug-related crimes," Baker said. A hearing on the bill is scheduled before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
Other Bills of Local InterestHouse Bill 28, sponsored by Del. Josh Bouchat (R-Carroll, Frederick), proposes a constitutional amendment requiring all Maryland counties to adopt a charter government structure.
House Bill 278, also from Bouchat, would provide an income tax subtraction modification for enhanced agricultural management equipment to support sustainable farming practices.
House Bill 192, introduced by Del. Nino Mangione (R-Baltimore County), aims to curb student cell phone use in schools under the proposed "No Distracted Learning Act."
As these bills move through the legislature, local officials and residents will have the opportunity to voice their support or concerns during committee hearings and public forums.

 EASTON — The Town of Greensboro's special meeting stream on Monday was cut short.The Zoom meeting was a victim of a "disturbing experience," which led the town to continue the meeting without the live stream.
"We were just having a normal meeting, and next thing we know, there's an interruption with vulgar racial language and pornographic video," Town Manager Tammy Kelledes said. "It was stopped within a minute or less than that."
After the meeting, the town put out a statement via Facebook stating all future Zoom meetings for the town would be suspended.

The town later clarified that Zoom meetings would be suspended while the incident is investigated by the FBI, not indefinitely.

Greensboro will still be uploading the meeting minutes for residents to check and see what was discussed, the town said.
"They can always get a copy of the of the meeting minutes. There's certainly, there are plenty of people that attend that put the content out on social media," Kelledes said.
The town of Greensboro's plan is to have another form of video up after the investigation has been conducted and they receive recommendations on what software is good to use to conduct meetings without interruption.
"We're just trying to get through the investigation and see what the FBI tells us and what they recommend," Kelledes said.

title: Mid-Shore crews clean roads quickly after heavy snowfall
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore crews clean roads quickly after heavy snowfall

 February 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 427

 EASTON — The National Weather Service recorded nine inches of snow in Easton on Wednesday, which was more than expected six to eight inches forecasted earlier this week.The weather service recorded 8.5 inches of snow in Denton and eight inches of snow in Cambridge.
As a result of heavy snow, conditions on roads throughout the Mid-Shore were expected to be bad. After having battled another large snowfall just a month prior, road crews and first responders were prepared.
Caroline, Talbot and Dorchester counties responded to the snow fast and were able to clear roads in a timely manner, allowing many government offices to open Wednesday.
"Our Public Works team was ready for the winter weather that hit Tuesday afternoon," Kathleen Freeman, Caroline County administrator, said. "Crews came in at 4 p.m., and with the rising temperatures, they quickly cleared the roads and made sure all county buildings were accessible."
"By 10 a.m. Wednesday, everything was set for a delayed start," she said. "I want to thank our road crews and all essential staff for their hard work in making this event go as smoothly as possible. Their quick response kept everything running with minimal disruption for our community."
Caroline County opened their offices at 10 a.m. Wednesday morning, as did Talbot County and the towns of Easton and Denton.
Talbot County could not be reached for comment, but the county decided to open up their offices at 10 a.m. Wednesday morning.
Dorchester County's offices were open during regular business hours Wednesday, though non-essential employees were given the option to work from home if they could, according to a Facebook post from the county government.
"We had a great night. Snow slacked up earlier than expected. It was great experience," Dorchester County Manager Jerry Jones said. "Folks stayed off the road. It was good Mother Nature is helping us. The window was bigger (than with the last snow) to get everything. Emergency responders were great as well."
Schools decided to keep campuses closed Wednesday because of the snowfall, but several districts had students attend class virtually.
Talbot County Public Schools conducted its first virtual learning day since 2020, and district officials were pleased with the results, according to TCPS Directer of Communications Debbie Gardner.
"The feedback from school principals has been positive," Gardner said Wednesday afternoon. "Student attendance has been better than we anticipated, and our teachers have done a fantastic job."
Dorchester County Public Schools conducted a virtual learning day as well, but could not be reached for comment.
Caroline County Public Schools did not have students attend class virtually, but the district plans to open on time Thursday.

title: At Daysprings Townhomes, poor housing conditions persist
author: Konner Metz
content:
At Daysprings Townhomes, poor housing conditions persist

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 1351
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Phillip Gibson often walks around the complex where he lives, checking in on his neighbors at the Dayspring Townhomes. He's recognizable and trusted by neighbors, many of whom call him "Pappy."Last October, the retired maintenance worker walked around the complex and into some of his neighbors' units, pointing out what looked like mold above the shower of a second-floor bathroom.
He repeated one word that encapsulates how he and many others view the living conditions at the low-income complex: "Unacceptable."
"I've only been living out here for eight months," Gibson said in October. "This is what I'm seeing. This is crazy. This is crazy, and I've been a maintenance man for 40 years."
Gibson isn't alone, as other residents of the Caroline County-owned complex have voiced similar concerns.
During recent months, dialogue surrounding the 46-unit operation has picked up among housing and social activists, disgruntled tenants and Caroline County officials. Property management has sought to collect unpaid rents while many tenants point to poor housing conditions and unresponsive maintenance requests.
Owned by the county, the property is run by East Coast Property Management, a Delaware-based company. In November, the Dayspring Townhomes filed 23 complaints against residents for failure to pay rent.
Shore Legal Access and Maryland Legal Aid took on cases for residents that accepted their legal services. Some cases were dismissed, while others were ruled in favor of the landlord. A number of tenants agreed to rent payment agreements.
County officials say only around half of the units are currently occupied and collecting rent. Some of the vacated units have extensive damage stemming from evicted tenants, Caroline County Administrator Katheleen Freeman said at a Feb. 4 county meeting.
While the county explores the possibility of selling the property to a qualified nonprofit, some residents remain confused and frustrated with lacking maintenance and communication.
Gibson said he wants the units fixed up, and that at times, property management has been putting "a Band-Aid on a little sore" when it comes to addressing issues.
"I can't let these people live like this," he said.
LIVING CONDITIONS
The Dayspring Townhomes complex is located just outside Ridgely on School Street. The initial property was built in 1994 by Interfaith Housing Development, a former local nonprofit that worked with the county, according to Caroline County Commissioners Vice President Larry Porter.
That nonprofit ceased operations a handful of years ago, leaving the low-income housing complex in the hands of its owners, Caroline County, and the contracted property management company, East Coast.
In October, Caroline County paid for First State Inspection Agency, based in Milford, Delaware, to perform unit-by-unit inspections.
Of the complex's 46 units, inspection records showed common damages in a number of units: cracked window surfaces, doors off their frames and damaged outlets or light switch covers. Some apartments had damaged or worn stairs.
None of the units had smoke detectors in the bedrooms, which Caroline County and property management remedied in the days after inspection.
Manizh Brown, a former tenant, lived at Dayspring for more than a year with her two children. In her townhome, an electrical outlet was faulty, closet doors were broken and the ceiling leaked where the second-floor bathtub sits.
"Everybody else got similar … problems. Especially this," Brown said while standing in her then-apartment, pointing to the leaks. "This is really getting me."
Brown said many of the issues with her townhome existed when she moved in. Aside from her floor, which she said was upgraded, Brown said there weren't sufficient improvements.
"The health situation right here, the water and everything else. F. F-minus," Brown said. "Ain't no way I should move in, and there's mold already on my window sill."
Caroline County officials have labeled the Dayspring Townhomes as high priority, facilitating the inspections last fall and consistently checking in with property management and the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development.
"We want those units to be in good shape," said Porter, the Caroline commissioner. During recent meetings, the county has focused on facilitating renovation of heavily damaged units.
Some residents hold concerns about physical safety, as well. A non-fatal shooting outside of the complex last August intensified those worries. The county purchased security cameras, which were placed at the front of the complex.
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker has remained in contact with Bridge Maryland Inc., a Baltimore County nonprofit that's held meetings for residents to air concerns and is assisting tenants with the court process.
Some tenants and nearby homeowners participate in neighborhood association meetings, during which they discuss their concerns about violence, drug use and large parties in or outside of the Dayspring Townhomes.
In October, resident Trina Ewell said the shooting was still affecting her peace of mind, and her son's as well.
"You're just at your own risk," Ewell said. "And I do know that my son has increased with panic attacks because of the shooting."
PROPERTY MANAGEMENT
East Coast Property Management, which manages the Dayspring complex, has more than 50 rental properties across Delaware, Maryland and Virginia, according to its website.
Despite repeated attempts to reach the property manager or a company representative, East Coast Property Management did not respond to The Star Democrat's requests for an interview or comment.
Residents have raised concerns about a lack of communication with property management, the property manager and maintenance workers.
"We have not heard from anybody, letters, emails," Ewell said last fall.
Brown said in order to place maintenance requests, she called the "maintenance man" or the property manager, as there was no standard maintenance order procedure.
"You ain't got to do no type of papers, no work (order), just tell them," Brown said. Often, she considered doing some of the maintenance fixes herself.
Rachel Wolpert, a chief attorney at Maryland Legal Aid who has worked with landlord and tenant issues since 2008, says it's an "incredibly relationship-based business."
Wolpert acknowledged it's a difficult task to be a property manager at any apartment or multifamily complex. She notes, though, that clear communication and follow-through from property management are critical.
"I see successes when the on-site manager is accessible and responsive to tenants," Wolpert said. "And then you see real troubles where tenants feel like the on-site manager is not accessible, not responsive."
Recently, tenants were notified monthly rent rates would increase. Porter said since there are no rent subsidies, but also an income threshold tenants must be below, a tight window exists of those who qualify but can still meet rent payments.
Bridge Maryland Board of Directors President the Rev. Angelique Mason said in an interview that rent payments and fear of eviction both play a role in how outspoken residents feel they can be.
"We do know that some of them are not being vocal because they might be behind in their rent," Mason said. "They had this idea that they might be evicted if they speak up. And that's really why Bridge is being the voice for the people, because some of them do have fear of eviction."
WHAT'S NEXT?
While Caroline County owns the property, the option for that to change is up in the air.
"Our position at this point that we're going to express is the possibility of selling that property to a qualified nonprofit organization," Porter said at a November county meeting. "The question we need to have answered is the mortgage amount."
Porter calls it a "tough situation" because of that mortgage conundrum. The state has involvement with the property, he said, binding the county to have at least a portion of ownership and the apartments to be low-income in order for the mortgage to remain deferred.
As the county has been in consistent dialogue with Maryland Housing and Community Development, many tenants faced court proceedings at the end of 2024.
Bridge Maryland organizer Hannah Freeman, who has facilitated community meetings, assisted many tenants during the court process. She said while some owed thousands in rent, others owed less than property management alleged.
Freeman says she remains focused on helping those who need it most.
"There's people just out homes," Freeman said. " … These are people with kids, with legitimate complaints about management."
Ewell acknowledged that amid her concerns regarding safety and the complex's living conditions, there isn't always another option.
"You got to live somewhere," Ewell said. "Right now, during this time with everything, you have to. You have to live somewhere."

title: Six months into the job, Cambridge city manager says he'r ready to tackle city's challenges
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Six months into the job, Cambridge city manager says he'r ready to tackle city's challenges

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge City Manager Glenn Steckman likes a challenge."I've dealt with cities on the verge of bankruptcy and cities going into bankruptcy," he said.
Although Cambridge is not on the verge of bankruptcy, the city does face challenges when it comes to housing, communication and certain delayed projects, Steckman said, mentioning the Cambridge Harbor project and the old city hall renovation project.
"That's sat vacant now for almost 18 years," he said about the old city hall, "and the cost of the project has doubled in those 18 years."
Nearly six months into the job, Steckman is working with his team to tackle these issues, which he knows can't be solved in a day.
"It's a process," he said. "No community gets into facing their challenge in a year, and it takes years to address a community challenge."
Ten years from now, Steckman would like to see better housing for residents, general improvements made that the city can afford to maintain and the Cambridge Harbor project at or near completion.
When it comes to housing, Steckman said improvements are already being made, but it's going to take time.
"But I also think there are a lot of people that I have interacted with that are committed to that," he said. "And I would like to see stronger collaboration with the area organizations so we're all rowing in the same direction."
Collaboration is important to Steckman, although he acknowledges it's not always easy.
"I think the challenge in any community is sometimes there are personalities and people who may have felt excluded, people that might have been hurt," he said. "How do we speak with them and look at their conditions and address them. But in any community, there are some very strong personalities, and Cambridge is no different."
Steckman said it's not realistic to ask for everyone to "sing by the same song sheet."
"But how do we work better together?" he asked.
Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas said Steckman has made an effort to work with the many different communities within Cambridge, from the Black community to the Hispanic community to the senior community to different neighborhoods.
"When you seek different perspectives, it always gives the best outcome," Cephas said. "Even myself as a Black woman. If I just go about my day every day from the perspective of a Black woman, I'm going to miss some things. So that's why it's always important to have a diverse staff, a diverse group of people that you can rely on to get information from."
Starting this Saturday, Feb. 15, Steckman will be at City Hall from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. one or two Saturdays per month to speak with any residents who aren't able to see him during the normal week day. Steckman has also made it easier for residents to come to City Hall by making it so they don't need to be buzzed in at the door. The city has also put in a railing and an automatic door opener for accessibility at City Hall.
"Because I try to maintain an open door policy," he said about the changes. "But I want to talk with people. ... I'm not a huge fan of just emails back and forth."
Born and raised in Baltimore, with experience serving on the Ocean City Council and a career spent managing cities as far away as Alaska, Steckman is no stranger to Maryland nor city management. In his free time, along with spending time with his wife and their two dogs, Steckman enjoys reading.
He said it's important to read about what's going on not only in his community, but in surrounding communities.
"We are not some little isolated community," he said. "And sometimes people in other communities have very good ideas that maybe we can export here or modify what they're doing."

title: Maryland considers shake-up in how judges are picked
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Maryland considers shake-up in how judges are picked

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland lawmakers are weighing two bills this year that would shake up how the state chooses circuit court judges.The proposals are at odds with one another. One bill aims to adjust the existing contested election process for circuit court judges by opening primaries to all Maryland voters. The other would eliminate contested circuit court elections altogether — a shift that would require a constitutional amendment.
The proposals represent two sides of a decades-long debate in the Maryland General Assembly about the value of contested circuit court elections.
Some members of Maryland's judiciary argue doing away with judicial elections entirely would shield judges from the ethical and practical challenges involved in competitive political campaigns.
"The job of a judge is, or at least should be, inherently apolitical," said Maryland Supreme Court Chief Justice Matthew J. Fader.
Others stand by Maryland's approach to filling circuit court benches, arguing that contested elections are a valuable opportunity for voters to shape their judiciary.
Circuit court judges are currently the only Maryland court to run in contested elections. All other state courts fill their benches with judges appointed by the governor, giving voters a say in whether those judges hold their seats in retention elections every 10 years. But the judges run unopposed and, at least according to some of the state's leading legal experts, no Maryland judge has been ousted in a retention election in living memory.
While the governor appoints judges to fill vacancies on circuit courts, the state constitution requires those judges stand for reelection every 15 years — elections in which they, unlike any other Maryland judge, can face a challenger.
The conversation about the system's merits has restarted among Maryland lawmakers, with Fader and other prominent Maryland legal figures backing a bill that would change circuit courts' process for filling benches to match the rest of Maryland courts.
The proposal arose from a work group formed by the Maryland Judicial Conference three years ago to review the issue. The work group released its final report — which argued that Maryland should move away from contested circuit court elections — last year.
"We believe that this is the best solution to maintain public trust and confidence in the court and in its ability to have judges who are fully qualified to take office in all cases," Fader told members of the House Judiciary Committee in a preliminary hearing on the bill.
Proponents of the bill assert that contested elections for circuit court positions open the bench to candidates who are unqualified for the role.
"Our system allows individuals with little to no judicial experience to challenge sitting judges," said Prince George's County Circuit Court Judge Cheri Simpkins. That means some judges who were initially appointed to their seat "must run against opponents who only meet the minimum qualifications of being a licensed person residing in the county for five years and paying a nominal filing fee," she added.
Maryland State Bar Association President Raphael Santini pointed to former Prince George's County Circuit Court Judge April Ademiluyi, who won her seat in a contested election in 2020 and whose "egregious" violations of judicial ethics prompted the Maryland Supreme Court to remove her from the bench in 2024.
Appointed judges, Santini told Capital News Service, have passed through a rigorous vetting process run by a judicial nominating commission and more than a dozen committees within the state's bar association. That vetting is done by fellow attorneys from a variety of legal fields who are well-equipped to review a candidate's legal and personal record, he added.
Elizabeth Hewlett, an attorney in Prince George's County and supporter of the proposal, said that voter participation in circuit court races is vastly lower than participation in better-publicized races, in large part because judges' schedules and ethics code leave them poorly positioned to campaign.
Campaigning in competitive elections, said Kelly Hughes Iverson, co-chair of the Maryland State Bar Association's laws committee, can place judges in ethically compromising positions.
"When the courts are fundraising, the appearance of sitting judges accepting campaign donations from contributors, which includes attorneys and litigants who have cases before them, undermines the public trust in an independent judiciary, and may discourage candidates from applying for the bench at all," Iverson said.
Attorneys are more engaged in judicial elections than the general public, Santini said, and more likely to contribute to a judge's campaign.
Backers also argue that judges, who routinely receive threats from those impacted by their decisions, put their safety at risk when campaigning for reelection.
But not all members of the judiciary are on board with the proposed changes.
"All it does is remove any opportunity for anyone to challenge the person that is named by the governor," said Carroll County Circuit Court Judge Maria Oesterreicher, who won her seat in a 2018 contested election and served on the judicial workgroup that put forward the bill.
Critics like Oesterreicher argue while circuit court elections are imperfect, they are also a rare opportunity for voters to play a larger role in shaping Maryland's judiciary.
If lawmakers are concerned about the qualifications of judicial candidates, she argued, they could require candidates to go through the same vetting process as applicants for appointed seats.
"That's an easy solution, but we've jumped right to the extreme," Oesterreicher said. "I think taking the rights out of the voters' hands is not the right way to fix the problem of judges campaigning if that's the problem that people want to fix."
Skeptics asserted that the appointment process is far from perfect, in large part because it relies on a relatively small group of attorneys to review and recommend candidates. Those attorneys, critics argue, may choose favorites based on politics or personal relationships rather than qualifications.
"It is clubby," said Claudia Barber, who ran unsuccessfully for an Anne Arundel Circuit Court seat last year. "It is also political … which is why, oftentimes, the best is not always chosen."
"I ran against someone who was the third member of the same law firm to be on the bench that only has four seats," Oesterreicher said of her 2018 campaign. The appointment process can favor well-connected attorneys over those with equal or greater qualifications, she argued.
Del. Robin Grammer Jr., a Republican representing Baltimore County, offered harsher criticisms. He argued that the proposal to end contested circuit court elections would primarily benefit the judges, not the public.
"Elections are hard," he told CNS. "You don't get to exempt yourself out of the system and have, frankly, what ends up being a lifetime appointment just because you think it's hard … When is the last time a judge has lost a retention election, like, ever?"
Grammer also contended that judges could avoid ethical concerns about campaign contributions from attorneys by finding alternative fundraising options.
Lawmakers skeptical of eliminating contested circuit court elections have another option this year: expanding voters' input in circuit court primaries.
Del. Chao Wu, a Democrat representing Howard and Montgomery County, is the sponsor of a bill that would replace Maryland's closed partisan primaries for circuit court elections with open, nonpartisan primaries. Closed primaries leave unaffiliated voters — who make up nearly a quarter of the state's electorate — without a voice in key local races, Wu said.
"I think a lot of unaffiliated voters feel they're really disenfranchised," Wu told CNS. "They're not able to vote in (primaries for) one of the most important positions in the state."
Wu's bill received no pushback from members of the House Judiciary Committee, but lawmakers have yet to act on either bill.
If the proposal to end contested circuit court elections passes this session, the question will appear on Maryland voters' ballots in November 2026.

title: Planning Commission approves majority of 123-unit Easton Crossing development
author: Konner Metz
content:
Planning Commission approves majority of 123-unit Easton Crossing development

 February 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 641
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A mixed-use project on Brookletts Avenue at the site of the former Perdue AgriBusiness operation received a stamp of approval, though not a full one.The Easton Planning Commission voted Thursday to approve 67 of the 123 units planned for Easton Crossing, a joint commercial and residential development. But Building 409, the project's largest structure, and the 56 units that come along with it are still under consideration.
Commission members and residents alike expressed concerns about the five-story building that includes around 10,000 square feet of retail space. Developers from The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, the project's developer, agreed to work on alternative options for the unapproved building and return to the commission at a future date.
Largely, the commission applauded developers for their advanced outreach to the community, as well as what they called an attractive project aimed at addressing Easton's lack of affordable housing.
"I love the project," commission chair Philip Toussaint said. "I think the positive aspects of it far outweigh any negative aspects. We have to take that into account when we're making a decision."
Toussaint joined vice chair Michael Ports, William Ryall and Victoria McAndrews in approving the project with the exception of Building 409. Thomas Klein was the sole vote against, citing his concerns that the plan's 217 off-street parking spots won't suffice once the units are occupied and commercial tenants move in.
The proposal noted 49 on-street parking spaces along Brookletts Avenue are mostly unused right now and would provide additional parking once renters and businesses move into Easton Crossing.
Klein said only 217 dedicated spaces for a 229-bedroom development did not seem sufficient, particularly if the backup plan is parking on Brookletts.
"If people from the development start to go and park in those areas, the tenants that live there now are not going to have any place to park," Klein said.
Ross Benincasa, senior vice president of Chesapeake Community Development, presented the site plan at Thursday's meeting. It calls for 30% of the rental units to be affordably priced, with others at workforce and market-rate levels.
Demolition of the Perdue grain bins and storage buildings currently on the lot began this month. Apartments are expected to be available beginning in 2027.
Speaking to the commission Thursday, Benincasa said the nonprofit developers felt a "necessary duty" to make a dent in Easton's affordable housing crisis with the infill project.
"We really felt kind of a need to make sure that if this was going to be developed, that we thought of it more inclusively," Benincasa said, "and more geared around making sure there was housing provided for all income levels, including people with disabilities."
BLENDING INWhile many complimented the project's cohesion with the intersecting Rails to Trails, worries centered around the fact that the structures don't integrate into the neighboring historic community.
Talbot County Council Member Lynn Mielke, speaking for herself and not the council, said the project is "incompatible" and its architecture ignores the nearby residential buildings.
Toussaint pushed Benincasa on if it was appropriate for the project to face away from The Hill, one of the first free African American neighborhoods in the country. The commission chair said that's been a significant source of public input.
"It appears to me that you've turned your back on the existing community, The Hill district," Toussaint said. "And you focus on Rails to Trails, and did a wonderful job of that."
Benincasa said The Arc doesn't own a lot of land in The Hill community to be able to integrate with it and that he disagrees with sentiments that the project doesn't fit into the surrounding fabric.
"We are not necessarily in that community here, and I would go as far to say as I think that doing duplexes here or mimicking that in some way would kind of really negatively offset what we could do in terms of usable units," Benincasa said. "It's never been a serious consideration."

title: Oxford residents share thoughts on who should be allowed to vote in town elections
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Oxford residents share thoughts on who should be allowed to vote in town elections

 February 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 731
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — At a Commissioners of Oxford public hearing Tuesday evening, it all boiled down to the question of who should have the right to vote in town elections.The public hearing was held for a resolution that would amend the town's charter to clarify a person must register with the Talbot County Board of Elections to qualify as a voter in the town. This means a resident would not be able to vote in Oxford town elections if they aren't registered with the county board.
The commissioners opted not to vote on the resolution during the meeting.
"Listening to this conversation, it seems like we're putting the cart before the horse," Resident Warren Davis said during the public hearing. "What we really want to do is figure out who we want to vote in our elections."
Oxford Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan said registering with the Talbot County Board of Elections means an Oxford resident is declaring their home in Oxford as their domicile, or primary residence. She said that when a person registers in Talbot County, they are removed from any voting registry they may have been on elsewhere.
Currently, the town charter states a person should register in the town office. The charter says it is the duty of Oxford's Election Board to keep registration lists up to date.
When it comes to eligibility, the charter states a person is able to vote if they are a U.S. citizen, are at least 18 and have resided in the town for at least 30 days prior to any town election.
At the outset of the public hearing, Ryan said the commissioners could choose to take a different path than the resolution presented.
Commissioner Katrina Greer brought up her concern that the list of registered voters in Talbot County is not always updated.
"As residents in a very small town, I know who lives here, I know who died this year," she said. "And so it's much easier for our own board of elections to clean up those voter logs."
Residents who spoke at the public hearing brought up scenarios and shared thoughts on who should and shouldn't be able to vote in town elections.
After confirming Oxford commissioners serve all proprietors and renters in town, Dan Kordell said anyone who owns or rents property in town should have a say in who is serving them.
"It's about representation," he said.
Jim Wilcox asked the commissioners to focus on who should vote based on "who has skin in the game." He said property owners and people with leases for more than 30 days should be able to vote in town elections.
"I would say somebody who has maybe a six-month lease," he said. "Something that shows a substantial term commitment to Oxford rather than just landing here for 30 days."
Warren Davis brought up that there are multiple residents in town with more than one residence. He included himself in the category, saying he usually goes to Maine in the summer.
"Should I be allowed to vote in Oxford because I'm not here for 30 days before the election?" he asked.
Multiple residents spoke to the issue of whether residents away at college should be able to vote in town elections. David Donovan said he doesn't think these students should be able to vote in town elections.
"They don't have any skin in the game," he said. "They don't have any intention to move back here. ... So I don't think those people should be allowed to vote here."
Chris Maynard said that could be considered disenfranchisement.
"We should keep in mind that 18-year-olds, we're referring to them as children, but they're really adults," she said, later adding, "It's not that the parents drive them over to the voting place and tell them what to do."
Donovan said he has an alternative to the town's proposed resolution. He proposed the town instead amend the voting eligibility section in the charter to say that voters should be physically present in their Oxford residence 30 days prior to the election unless they are absent due to vacation or circumstances beyond their control.
He said residents absent from town for those 30 days due to "voluntary enrollment in any education program" should not be considered eligible to vote.
Donovan said the town should add an application for absentee voting that requires absentee voters to affirm they are eligible to vote.
After the public hearing, the commissioners agreed to schedule a work session to discuss the issue further.

title: Residents challenge solar project over zoning, health risks
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Residents challenge solar project over zoning, health risks

 February 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Public Service Commission heard residents' concerns Tuesday over a proposed community solar project on 41 acres of a 199-acre property at 10066 Peacock Corner Road in Millington, owned by David Chance.The project, designated TPE MD KE51, is being developed by Turning Point Energy (TPE), a renewable energy firm that has spearheaded several solar initiatives in Maryland, including a second proposal in Kennedyville. According to company information, Turning Point focuses on sustainable, ground-mounted solar projects designed to expand clean energy access in the region.
More than a dozen residents gathered at Galena Elementary School at 7 p.m. for the PSC hearing, moderated by Chief Public Utility Law Judge Chuck McLean. In addition to Turning Point representatives, legal counsel, and project managers, officials from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, Kent County Attorney Tom Yeager and Planning, Housing and Zoning deputy Carla Gerber were in attendance.
After brief introductions by Turning Point's team, Yeager and Gerber outlined the county's position. Yeager noted that local zoning restricts solar projects in this agriculture district to five acres and contended that Turning Point should have applied for a special exception. Project manager Frances Yuhas said the company was aware of the five‐acre limit for utility-scale solar in the district and chose not to seek an exception, adding that final approval lies with the Public Service Commission under state preemption.
Resident Darryl Calloway expressed his concern, saying, "I would love someone to address the health concerns I have such as microwaves. Anyone who lives near these arrays, what happens to them?"
Certified solar thermal engineer Dick Durham raised additional issues about panel efficiency and recycling challenges, noting that the panels contain materials such as lead and cadmium telluride. He also warned that pending legislation, Senate Bill 0931, could reshape land-use controls in ways reminiscent of eminent domain.
When asked about the origin of the panels, Yuhas said production could occur in the United States but noted that international manufacturing — including in Mexico or China —remains a possibility. Maryland Department of Natural Resources official Ginny Rogers addressed environmental risk concerns, stating, "From what we see there is no risk at all involved," and outlined plans to plant native, pollinator-friendly ground cover to boost biodiversity.
Kennedyville resident Judi Gifford questioned the economic benefits of the array, asking, "Are there any savings for residents at all?" Yuhas replied that subscribers to the power would be guaranteed a 5 to 10 percent discount over a 25-year subscription. Gerber added that the county would likely reclassify the property as commercial rather than agricultural, potentially increasing tax revenue.
At the hearing, Turning Point announced they committed to a $52,000 donation to Kent County's agricultural preservation program — a request based on state law calculations of agricultural value. Representatives from the company stayed afterward to discuss next steps pending a PSC decision on their certificate of public convenience and necessity.
When asked how they felt the county received their project proposal, TPE representative, Attorney Margaret Witherup of Witherup Allen Law admitted, "It's hard to tell. Each site is different."
No other comment were received from Turning Point legal counsel, Attorney Witherup, or from representatives at Kimley-Horn and Associates, Inc. Kent County officials said they will continue to monitor developments in the project. More details can be found under Case No. 9742 at the Maryland PSC website.

author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels discuss ordinance for leaf blowers

 February 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 ST. MICHAELS — On Wednesday, St. Michaels officials held their third discussion of Noise Ordnance 567, which deals with gasoline-powered leaf blowers.Residents have voiced their concerns about gas leaf blowers being very loud and being used at especially early or late hours, concerns the new ordinance aims to address.
"So I think the main challenge from a policy standpoint is the impacts on local commercial lawn care companies by requiring electric leaf blowers," Town Administrator Rob Straebel said. "But for non commercial users such as residents and property owners, this could be a fairly easy transition."
The conversation surrounding limiting leaf blowers was first brought up on Oct. 25, 2023 but stopped after commercial landscape operators said they couldn't do their job properly with electric leaf blowers. The conversation was brought back up on Jan. 22, this time aimed at just gas-powered leaf blowers, which are usually noisier.
The commissioners would take into the consideration that residents would need to purchase electric leaf blowers, they said, by ensuring it does not go into effect for another year or two. Noise levels for electric or battery leaf blowers will have to be limited to 65 decibels.
Contractors and St. Michaels public works officials argued that gas leaf blowers makes their jobs easier. Electric or battery powered leaf blowers must be charged, which takes time. They also argued that gas-powered leaf blowers are more powerful and help them accomplish their jobs faster.
Commissioner Alex Roiter argued that the contractors and workers are wasting time by just blowing a couple of leafs with the gas blower.
Public Works Operational Manager Brian Thompson pushed back and explained that "most contractors are not going to waste time. They want to get in and get out because it's money flow."
Thompson said he is not against electric leaf blowers but that there are certain times when gas-powered equipment is needed.
After back-and-forth, the officials decided the ordinance needed some work because it did not properly explain what equipment can be used and by whom.
The commissioners decided to table the conversation for another meeting.

title: Southern Dorchester residents share thoughts on town incorporation
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Southern Dorchester residents share thoughts on town incorporation

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 646
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WINGATE — Lifelong Dorchester County resident Dick Dawson thought the Lakes and Straits Volunteer Fire Company hall in Wingate on March 3 was busier than he's seen in 45 years, apart from luncheons and dinners."That tells you something," he said at the outset of a meeting at the fire hall to discuss efforts to incorporate a new town in the southern part of the county.
Dawson, his 17-year-old grandson Drew Dawson and Elijah's General Store owner David Beverley are working to incorporate Blackwater, a new town, in an effort to protect southern Dorchester County communities from disappearing due to sea level rise and state critical area regulations.
The communities included in the plan for Blackwater are Andrews, Robbins, Wesley, Lakesville, Crapo, Wingate, Toddville, Bishops Head and Crocheron. Each community would still exist within the new town. The planners believe incorporation would give the area a better chance of receiving funding from government agencies.
March 3, the planners shared their vision and heard from residents of the communities that Blackwater would encompass. Residents raised concerns about taxes, money management, residency requirements and the incorporation process. With multiple residents in the room opposed to the idea, tension ebbed and flowed throughout the meeting.
During a tense portion, with some residents visibly upset and yelling, Chuckie Hayward said he was tired of the "bickering." He said although he's against the idea to incorporate, he came to listen.
"I'm here because I want to hear everything out first before I really make a decision," he said.
Many residents shared concerns with having to pay taxes to the town. The Dawsons and Beverley have said the town would not impose new taxes.
Drew Dawson said 60% of residents would have to vote in favor of being taxed in order for the town to impose taxes. He said he doesn't see that happening.
County resident Matt Ritter said taxes often arise when communities experience growth.
"Once you allow building and allow all this excess to happen, growth comes down here and this becomes just like Cambridge," he said. "And then you've got all these city folk down here trying to change things up. And they always raise their hand to raise the taxes."
Former Cambridge Mayor Andrew Bradshaw, who shared his understanding of municipalities at the meeting, said the town would be able to secure federal and state funding that is only open to municipalities.
"If you all can get the kind of representation this would provide, it gives a force behind the effort that just doesn't exist right now," Bradshaw said.
In order for Blackwater to get incorporated, the planners need to gather signatures on a petition, then go to the county to submit the drafted town charter for review. If the county accepts the charter, the decision will go to the registered voters within the area that Blackwater would encompass.
Resident Scott Hughes spoke about the importance of forming the town the right way and having a "bulletproof" charter. He said he expects the push to create Blackwater will be a success.
"But let's make it happen so that nobody can take advantage of it," he said.
Lindsay Wheatley said she sees three options for the communities: Sell all the land to sika deer hunters who want to strip away houses and put up deer stands, stay and not do anything as roads and the area's heritage crumble, or fight.
"This might be our only opportunity ever," she said. "We're dwindling. Look around, right? I chose to come back here because I love it, and all of you love it too. I'm going to fight. I'm going to sign it. I'm going to do everything that I can do with integrity and honesty to protect this area for as long as I can."
Drew Dawson said he and the other planners will discuss the ideas raised during the meeting and decide how to amend the draft charter.
"I think there are some pretty good ideas," he said.

title: Proposed tax breaks could mean service cuts in lower-income counties
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Proposed tax breaks could mean service cuts in lower-income counties

 March 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 963
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore plans to change how Marylanders take deductions on their state income taxes, but officials in some of the state's poorest counties say that plan could force them to cut services."You mentioned that the federal government is creating chaos for our state government in an effort to balance their budget," Del. Jefferson Ghrist, a Republican representing Caroline, Cecil, Kent and Queen Anne's Counties, told Gov. Moore in a recent budget hearing. "It appears that your budget does sort of the same thing to our county governments."
Moore's administration, however, contends that the reforms will provide tax relief to a majority of Marylanders — including residents of lower-income counties — even if those county governments face a revenue loss.
"This proposal leaves more cash in the pockets of the majority of Maryland's households," said Budget and Management Secretary Helene Grady.
Lawmakers in Annapolis are weighing a two-pronged approach to tax reform intended to shift the scales in favor of low- and middle-income households.
Moore's proposal to double the state's standard deduction would provide a tax break to Marylanders who opt not to itemize their income tax deductions — many of them low- and middle-income. To account for the resulting revenue loss, the governor's office proposes ending the practice of itemized deductions, which would mean a larger income tax bill for many high-income Marylanders.
But county governments also collect income taxes, and a tax break for lower-income Marylanders would deal a blow to some counties' budgets.
Representatives from Allegany County appeared in Annapolis last week to ask lawmakers to soften that blow.
"Governor Moore discussed the idea that no Marylanders should be left behind," Allegany County Attorney T. Lee Beeman told lawmakers on Friday. "Ultimately, his proposal this year will do exactly that in Allegany County. It will leave Allegany County behind."
If the General Assembly moves forward with doubling the standard deduction, Allegany County would stand to lose $3.2 million in revenue next year, according to Maryland's Board of Revenue Estimates.
While the vast majority of county residents would receive a tax cut, "we'll be looking at probably cutting potentially each and every service we have," said Allegany County Administrator Jason Bennett. "We're pretty slim as it is."
Last year, the county laid off emergency services staff and scaled back employee health insurance in response to a $13 million deficit. Additional cuts could mean scaling back snow clearance operations in the winter, public transit service and support for the county's library service, he told Capital News Service.
If Allegany County raised local income taxes to the maximum rate allowed under Maryland law, he added, the county could only make up for half of the projected losses created by doubling the standard deduction.
Allegany County is not alone. Del. Malcolm Ruff, a Democrat representing Baltimore City, noted that doubling the standard deduction could undercut services in his district.
"Baltimore City would lose approximately $40 million over the next five years based on those changes," Ruff said.
The Board of Revenue Estimates projects that half of Maryland's counties and county equivalents would lose income tax revenue if the state moves forward with the proposed changes to deductions. Those include all but one of the 10 poorest Maryland counties as of the Census Bureau's 2023 American Community Survey.
"Contrast that with our friends in the beltway corridor," said Beeman. "Montgomery County stands to gain $300 million in income tax revenue over the next five years. It's a shocking contrast."
Meanwhile, some members of the Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland have expressed concerns that eliminating itemized deductions would have a disproportionate impact on majority-Black districts in the Washington suburbs.
Residents of Charles and Prince George's Counties itemize their deductions at higher rates than residents of any other Maryland counties. That presents a political challenge for someone like Sen. Michael Jackson, a Democrat representing parts of Calvert, Charles and Prince George's Counties. Residents in those districts are more likely than other Marylanders to see their tax bills increase under Moore's plan.
Jackson told CNS that he and other caucus members representing those counties are in talks with the governor to address their concerns.
But Moore's current proposals drew praise from some outside observers.
"Itemized deductions are regressive," said Miles Trinidad, a state policy analyst with the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, a nonpartisan think tank. "These policies offer the largest benefits to higher income taxpayers and little if any benefits to low- and middle-income families."
Grady, meanwhile, notes that the governor's tax reforms would offer a tax cut to a majority of Marylanders, and that aid to local governments accounts for a third of general fund expenses in the proposed 2026 budget — aid that would support both public school systems and county governments.
The governor's office also underscores that Maryland's standard deduction is only a third of Virginia's, meaning that some poor and working-class residents who would pay no income tax in Virginia make enough to pay income tax in Maryland.
While Moore's proposal would still leave Maryland's standard deduction lower than those in Virginia and Washington, his office argues the change is in the interest of fairness.
However, given the dire state of Maryland's budget and the prospect of dwindling federal support, Grady also noted that the state may not be in a position to simultaneously offer tax cuts to most Marylanders and shield counties from the statewide budget crunch.
"Given the general fund challenge, it would be very difficult to insulate counties entirely from impacts," she said.
Senate President Bill Ferguson, a Democrat representing Baltimore City, echoed Grady's sentiment.
"I appreciate [the governor's] approach of bringing forth a proposal that attempted to balance state needs, local needs and our business climate," he said. "But we're dealing with an unprecedented situation, and so just as the state is having to tighten the belt. I think local jurisdictions are going to be in a similar place this upcoming year."

title: Town Council holds off on confirming County Council vice president to utilities commission
author: Konner Metz
content:
Town Council holds off on confirming County Council vice president to utilities commission

 March 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 597
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — While board and commission appointments typically pass by the Easton Town Council with little to no discussion, such was not the case at Monday's meeting.Some councilmembers raised concerns over Mayor Megan Cook's appointment of Pete Lesher to the Easton Utilities Commission, ultimately deciding to hold off on confirming that appointment. Lesher is the vice president of the Talbot County Council.
Town Council President Frank Gunsallus asked Cook if her appointment went through staff review. Cook said it went through a review process with Easton Utilities and she met with John Horner, the nonprofit's president and CEO.
Gunsallus asked if Lesher would step down from his county seat. "I do not believe so," Cook responded.
"He swore an oath to the county, and sometimes we have competing interests," Gunsallus later said. "And he can't have two masters. I think there will be a conflict when land needs to be resumed for solar, as is currently in the legislature. So I think that that is something that we should be considering."
Lesher was appointed to fill the role of current commission member Buck Duncan, whose term expires this May.
Town Attorney Sharon VanEmburgh said at Monday's meeting it wasn't fully clear whether there were legal issues with Lesher being on the County Council and potentially the Easton Utilities Commission.
VanEmburgh said the state's constitution doesn't allow someone to hold two "trust and profit" offices. The question in need of answering is whether the commission post would be considered such.
"I think we would probably get to the conclusion that it is not a second office of trust and profit," VanEmburgh said. "But I just don't know."
Gunsallus suggested the appointment go through both the town and county's ethics commissions. Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry said if VanEmburgh returns with an opinion that supports the appointment as legal, she sees "no need for an ethics review on a local basis."
Ward 4 Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis said it's "vital and important" for the town to ensure it's "on the right side of the law." Councilmembers agreed to address Lesher's appointment at the town's next meeting once legal advice is obtained.
"As always, we respect the Mayor and support the members of the Town Council and their decisions," Horner wrote in a statement Wednesday. "The appointment and confirmation of an Easton Utilities' Commissioner is an essential step in ensuring the efficient and effective management of our operations."
OTHER APPOINTMENTS
During the discussion, Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery said he feels appointments are already a "rubber stamp" by the time they hit the council's desk.
"I would really like to have an opportunity to have some discussion with the mayor … in an executive session," Montgomery said, "just to hear your thoughts about different candidates rather than always having one candidate put in front of us."
Cook said during appointment processes, there's a "lot of thought" that goes into candidates and resumes.
"It's not something that we take lightly," Cook said.
Montgomery said he hopes the opportunity for such conversations will be afforded to the council during interviews for the town manager role. Cook said the council will have chances to meet candidates, adding that there will be full-day interviews.
It's been seven months since the town parted with its most recent full-time manager, Don Richardson, on Aug. 5, 2024. Police Chief Alan Lowrey has served in an interim capacity since.
Last December, Easton announced it opened a search for a new town manager. The town secured the services of the professional recruitment agency Sumter Local Government Consulting.
Wednesday, Cook told The Star Democrat that the town has narrowed its search down to a group of semifinalists.

title: Hundreds protest Rep. Harris, Trump outside Tidewater Inn in Easton
author: Konner Metz
content:
Hundreds protest Rep. Harris, Trump outside Tidewater Inn in Easton

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hundreds lined Dover and Harrison streets Thursday evening, protesting Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) and the Trump administration outside a fundraiser hosted by Harris at the Tidewater Inn.By 5 p.m., a large crowd gathered outside the Talbot County Democratic Party headquarters and began walking down sidewalks and past the Tidewater.
They repeated chants of "Andy Harris has got to go" and "fire Andy Harris." Some called for the congressman, who represents the Eastern Shore of Maryland, to host a town hall.
Phil Jackson, chair of the Talbot Democratic Central Committee, said Harris is "absolutely failing to represent Talbot County."
"Andy Harris has historically done very little for the Eastern Shore," Jackson said. "... I think this is indicative of a very strong desire for new leadership."
By 6:30 p.m., Harris' event inside the inn continued and most of the crowd had dispersed. The large crowd did not appear to encounter Harris at any point Thursday evening.
Following his event, Harris told The Star Democrat that the Eastern Shore elected him and President Donald Trump, and that he's "delivering on President Trump's agenda."
Among the president's agenda items raised by protesters Thursday was the Department of Government Efficiency, Elon Musk and mass firings of federal workers. Many of the more than 300 protesters held signs opposing DOGE.
"I think folks have had enough with the current administration and the overreach and behavior we're seeing right now," Jackson said.
Harris, meanwhile, said the cuts are necessary due to a federal deficit nearing $2 trillion.
"If they want to help us with some way to make the government more efficient — other than actually letting go of people whose jobs are probably not contributing to government efficiency — I'm all ears," Harris said of those who oppose the firings. "But they're not offering solutions."
"I feel bad for anyone who's losing a job, but I'm hoping with the economic growth we have, we're going to provide plenty of private sector jobs for those leaving the federal government," he added.
Harris, who chairs the House Freedom Caucus, met with Trump at the White House Wednesday. He said people at his fundraiser Thursday were excited to hear about what's going on in Washington, D.C.
"I told them some of what it's like to be sitting next to the leader of the free world," Harris said.
Outside the Tidewater, the tenor from protesters was much different. The crowd of hundreds loudly cheered as cars drove by and honked in support of the protest.
Jackson was pleased with the large turnout and says the protest was a "tipping point."
"It's really reached an egregious point," Jackson said. "And I think people are really upset about it."

title: Emergency cannabis bill discussed at Caroline commissioners meeting
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Emergency cannabis bill discussed at Caroline commissioners meeting

 March 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 522
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners held the first reading of an emergency cannabis legislative bill and the introduction of permit zoning on property legislative bill at Tuesday's meeting.The emergency cannabis bill is proposed to allow Caroline County to get on track with regulations and requirements of from the state.
The adjustments are being made as a result of House Bill 805, a 2024 bill that established zoning requirements for cannabis businesses that are more restrictive than some that existed prior to the legalization of recreational cannabis in the state.
The state regulation mandates that cannabis dispensaries cannot be located within 500 feet of schools, child care center, programs, recreation centers, libraries, public parks or churches.
At last week's meeting, Commissioners Vice President Larry Porter suggested a zoning map be created to show the zoning locations for the proposed emergency cannabis bill.
While Caroline County Director of Planning and Codes Crystal Dadds is still working on the zoning map, Porter made a suggestion on increasing the distance for dispensaries from schools.
"My concern is the dispensaries, I don't think 500 feet is enough," Porter said. "Im particularly concerned about the schools."
The 500 feet distance of schools, child care center, programs, recreation centers, libraries, public parks or churches is mandated by the state.
While dispensaries will only be allowed to be located in C1 and C2 commercial zoning districts, some schools in Caroline County are close to commercial zoning districts.
"I don't think we will ever run into a situation where a dispensary is that close to a school," County Commissioners President Travis Breeding said, "but to Commissioner Porter's point, 500 feet is not enough."
The county could be at legal liability if they decide to mandate that the buffer between cannabis businesses and schools will be bigger.
"So what will happen if you enact an ordinance with a greater distance and someone applies within the 500 feet and they are denied, it would be an appeal by the judge to rule in favor of the applicant," County Attorney Stewart Barroll said. "Or somebody can file suit against the county stating their ordinance is invalid."
The officials will discuss all avenues of the proposed bills and make some revisions before making a final decision.
The county commissioners also discussed a new section to denials of a zoning legislative bill. The new section will allow the Department of Planning and Codes to deny applications if an applicant is not within code or zoning compliance of the county on that same property.
"If you had a violation on your property, let's say you put a pool in without a permit and it's unresolved," Batts said, "now you come in and you want to seek a permit for something else, we would not grant that permit until you updated or gotten your proper permits for the other structure."
If a resident comes into fix a violation, the county will permit to allow the resolution of the violation.
Also covered in the proposed bill if an applicant has multiple properties they can apply for permits on one property and not be denied because of a violation on another property.
Both proposed bills will move on for the first and second reading.

title: Harris speaks to Dorchester Chamber after rally calling for town hall
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Harris speaks to Dorchester Chamber after rally calling for town hall

 March 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 748
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Hours after a rally was held questioning Rep. Andy Harris' (R-Md. 1st) loyalty to his constituents, Harris told Dorchester Chamber of Commerce members inside the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Golf Resort, Spa and Marina that his office is here to help them."We can make your business run easier," he said during his keynote speech for the chamber's 79th annual business meeting and dinner. "We can work through the bureaucracy. Please get in touch with my office. We're more than happy to help you."
Earlier that evening, protesters lined the sidewalks of U.S. Route 50 outside the Hyatt, calling on Harris to hold a town hall and questioning whether Harris' allegiance is to his constituents or to Elon Musk and the Trump administration. The rally was organized by Cambridge Indivisible, a chapter of a national organization that aims to elect progressive leaders.
Speaking to members of the media after the chamber dinner, Harris said he didn't believe many of the people at the rally were his constituents.
"They're brought in by buses," he said. "I don't know where those buses come from. And we know that the national Indivisibles are involved. So we believe that a lot of those people aren't even constituents."
Harris said he heard from a Washington, D.C., organization's leader "who knows what's going on" that people at the rally were getting paid to be there. He said he would not name who told him that.
"This is astroturf," he said. "This is not grassroots."
Cambridge Indivisible Founder and Chair Michelle Fowle said many of those at the rally were her neighbors who live in Cambridge.
"He's just a liar," she said about Harris.
Harris said he will be holding a virtual town hall on March 25 so he can communicate with constituents from all over his district.
"If these protesters want to call in, if they want to get on my town hall, I will answer that question on my town hall," he said. "But I'm not going to hold a town hall for 100 people when I could hold a town hall and reach out to 5,000 people who don't have to leave their homes, get bused in by some entity paying for that bus."
Harris said he is "laser focused" on working for his constituents and advancing the Trump administration's agenda.
"Who also won the district with high numbers," he said about President Donald Trump (R) getting elected in November.
In Dorchester County, Trump won 55.99% of the vote, according to the Maryland State Board of Elections.
During the rally before the chamber dinner, protesters brought up concerns with recent mass firings of federal workers. Suzanne Sullivan said she has concerns about what the firings will do for the local economy. Sullivan, who lives in Dorchester County, is the wife of environmental scientist Jake Shaner, who was recently fired from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Harris told media after the dinner that most companies layoff employees every three to five years. He said that with federal tax cuts, the federal government will grow the economy so there are "plenty of jobs for every American."
"Look, do I feel for everybody who's laid off?" he asked. "Absolutely. Private industry, public government. It's a personal family setback. That's exactly why we have unemployment insurance and we have the social net until these individuals find another job."
HARRIS' KEYNOTE SPEECH
During his keynote speech, Harris touched on a number of issues relevant to Dorchester County and the Eastern Shore. He spoke about the importance of the agriculture industry, low-cost energy and the H-2B visa program.
Harris also brought up the need for blue catfish processing centers to help reduce the population of the invasive species in the Chesapeake Bay. He said federal funding will be available to entrepreneurs who want to build processing plants so the catfish can be considered a commercially viable seafood product.
Harris said two things the county should focus on are addressing drug and alcohol addiction and making sure every child is reading on grade level.
"And we can certainly provide help from the federal government," he said. "But I'll tell you, some of the best solutions are at the local level."
Harris, who lives in Cambridge, said it is a pleasure to represent the people of the Eastern Shore. He said he lives a "blessed life" where he can be at Mar-a-Lago one night and eating at Cindy's Kitchen in Cambridge the next morning.
"It's like the best of both worlds," he said. "And to be honest with you, I like Cindy's better. But don't tell the president that."
