 EASTON — U.S. Sen. Angela Alsobrooks (D) met with multiple municipal leaders from across the Eastern Shore to discuss issues they face.In addition to meeting with multiple municipalities, Alsobrooks visited Eastern Shore agricultural leaders and participated in a tour of Chesapeake College. She met with higher education leaders during her stop at the college.
Alsobrooks heard concerns of municipal officials including the freezing and cutting of Federal Emergency Management Agency funds and how U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement on the Eastern Shore can affect the agricultural economy and area families.
"It's so important today to be here and to have conversations," Alsobrooks said. "We spent the day here very intentionally to hear from farmers, to hear from business owners, to hear from municipal leaders, who are primarily sharing the impact of some of the federal cuts that we've seen and that we've seen in some of the freezing of funds."
Multiple municipalities voiced their concerns about the freezing and cuts of federal funding. One big project on the Eastern Shore is the Ocean City beach replenishment project.
According to Ocean City officials, the beach replenishment project was first started in 1989 and is a partnership between the federal government, the state of Maryland, Worcester County and Ocean City.
The project was built to protect the shoreline along the Ocean City coastline. It consists of building a dune system, a seawall and pumping sand on the beach to provide protection from storms.
The project has estimated to save $1 billion in property damage since its completion in 1991. Every year in the winter, Ocean City conducts the project, but the federal funding for this winter project has not been received.
Another concern brought to Alsobrooks was the funding freeze for the Shore Resiliency program by FEMA.
According to Cambridge officials, the plan for the project includes three main elements: a living shoreline, earth and rock embankments and stormwater management to alleviate flooding.
Almost 30% of the design for the Cambridge program is done, but the funds for that project has been frozen.
Another concern brought to Alsobrooks was helping kids who experience immigrant enforcement with their parents and how immigrant enforcement will effect the economy on the Eastern Shore.
Salisbury officials mentioned two men on work visas with families who were picked up by ICE and that have already been shipped to New Orleans. The officials are concerned about how the agricultural economy can be affected.
Another story mentioned was about two daughters a 5- and 7-year-old whose parents were picked up by ICE. The children lived at home for two days without mentioning anything to school officials.
Alsobrooks listened to all concerns and what what she plans to do and how important their concerns are to the state.
"I'm going to be working to make sure that I really do what I can to to get those funds unfrozen and to continue to stay in communication with leaders and community of members to help our state be successful," she said.
Officials voiced appreciation for Alsobrooks listening and her promise to continue to communicate with leaders on the Eastern Shore.
"It's really important that the senator hears from small communities here in the Eastern Shore," said Easton Mayor Megan Cook. "It feels like she's really taking our concerns seriously into heart, and she's going to find the answers to our questions."

 The Caroline County Commissioners, Deputy Administrator Daniel Fox and grant coordinator Stacy Seward, who helps with the budget annually, tackled the first workshop for fiscal year 2026 budget at the county commissioners meeting on Tuesday.While the budget is a work in progress, Caroline County Commissioner President Travis Breeding cautioned that the work done at Tuesday's meeting is fluid and could be changed as discussions continue.
"I should point out that a lot of this is fluid and still up in the air," Breeding said, adding that the pending state budget could change things. "We still don't have a clear picture of what kind of fiscal situation were going to be in when they strike the budget."
The county is expected to bring in $77 million in revenue, while the proposed fiscal year expenditures are currently $79 million, leaving a $2 million shortfall.
For capital funding the county has $7.3 million allocated for capital funding. The requested amount for capital funding in FY26 is $10.4 million, leaving a shortfall of $3.1 million.
Both budgets need to be in balance when they are presented at a public hearing in May.
The commissioners discussed both the operating and capital budgets to account for the shortfalls in both budgets.
CAPITAL BUDGET
A number of items were discussed in the capital budget.
The Department of Corrections control panel for $120,00 is already being worked on but the requested new van is still in question. While the van is damaged the county took into account the mileage on the van is only 22,330.
"I think we should get the van looked at and evaluated," County Commissioner Frank Bartz said.
The Department of Emergency Services could receive funding for the 14 cardiac monitor replacement, but the commissioners discussed waiting one more year for purchasing a number of requested trucks.
Facilities requested a long list of items which the county commissioners discussed to fund the first seven and will discuss the rest as the budget workshop sessions continue.
The county commissioners discussed potentially cutting capital funds for these organizations.
All Circuit Court request for $272,000.DES $180,000 for EMS lieutenant and EMS division chief.Facilities proposal to receive $498,000 of requested $1,477,000.All Public Works requests except a six-wheel dump truck and a Husqvarna Zero Turn mower for $1,203,500.All Rec and Parks requests except a Skag 72-inch Zero Turn mower for $136,000All 4-H Park requests for $90,000.All Human Society requests for $85,000.
OPERATING BUDGET
While the operating budget has a $2 million deficit, the county must find cuts in many different areas. Companies in the expenditure category gave the commissioners the most discussion at the county commissioners' first workshop.
"I appreciate everything these volunteers organizations do," County Commissioners President Travis Breeding said. "There is a lot of other volunteers organizations and nonprofits in the county that we don't give money to, our job is public safety. My position is the same as its been the last two years, I don't think we should fund any of them."
While Breeding thinks they could potentially save funding here, Commissioners Porter and Bartz said that some nonprofits should be allocated some funds.
"I looked at some of the budgets to see whether the $5,000 will impact their budgets or not, some I thought I felt we could contribute to, some I struck off," Bartz said.
The commissioners also discussed the fire companies that requested a 10% increase in allocation, and a property tax credit. Breeding landed on a 5% increase, Porter at 10% and Bartz at 7.5%.
"Enter our different numbers I don't think we will come to a consensus today, we have one more public hearing," Breeding said.
The commissioners will discuss more requests. Here are the numbers for the potential expenditure category:
Expenditure Category: Breeding allocated $6,300 for non-profit organizations.Porter allocated $5,000 to Positive striders.Bartz allocated money to all nonprofit organizations.Porter gave $50,000 for a property tax credit, Bartz and Breeding $0.All commissioners have different numbers for allocations.

title: Cambridge amends paving contract to address ADA requirements
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge amends paving contract to address ADA requirements

 CAMBRIDGE — During a Cambridge City Council meeting March 18, the council voted unanimously to amend a paving contract to include updating intersections so they are compliant with the Americans with Disabilities Act.In September, the City Council awarded David A. Bramble Inc. with a $447,150 contract to resurface three miles of roads at various locations in the city. City Manager Glenn Steckman said the contract was approved before city staff was made aware that if the city paves through intersections that are not up to standard with Americans with Disabilities Act, it has to update those intersections.
"So to pave through the intersection, you have to improve the intersection," Steckman said.
During the council meeting, Steckman told commissioners the city could either spend approximately $125,000 more to address the intersections as the city paves the three miles or reduce the scope of the project and pave less road in order to address the intersections with the money already budgeted in the contract.
Steckman said the city is estimating intersection updates would cost about $6,000 per intersection. He recommended the council vote to spend additional money to complete the three miles of paving. He said the city had originally budgeted $600,000 for the project.
Before the council took a vote, commissioners asked questions about prioritizing certain streets and areas for paving.
According to City Council documents, the city used a 2018 pavement condition study for the project to determine which streets are in most need of being repaved. Commissioner Brian Roche said it would be a waste of money to ignore the study.
"You have to be careful because we could end up having roads that fall further into disrepair just because someone thinks that their road is in worse shape when in fact an engineering analysis has determined where (is in worse shape)," he said.
After discussion, the council voted to increase the cost of the contract to include updates to the intersections without reducing the scope of the project.

title: Ridgely commissioners, residents weigh in on potential of reinstating police department
author: Konner Metz
content:
Ridgely commissioners, residents weigh in on potential of reinstating police department

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 769
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Over a year after suspending the now-defunct Ridgely Police Department, town commissioners say reestablishing the force will cost the town nearly double its projected payment to the county sheriff for police coverage.At a workshop Wednesday, Commissioner Brad Sears told residents that restoring the department would cost an estimated $852,000. Ridgely currently receives dedicated coverage from the Caroline County Sheriff's Office based on a memorandum of understanding. Renewing that MOU for fiscal year 2026 would cost $493,000, per estimates.
A number of residents questioned the Town Council's openness to consider reinstating the department. Concerns raised stem back to the town's controversial decision to suspend and subsequently lay off the department last year amid a criminal investigation into the police chief that came up empty.
Residents were only permitted to testify in front of the commissioners Wednesday if they had signed up around a day in advance.
Heather Amador said the workshop felt like the town was "checking a box."
"I feel solid that your minds are made up," Amador told commissioners. "Some of you openly expressed that at the last town meeting. It feels pretty certain that my words and efforts will be for nothing."
"We're not going to make any decisions tonight," Sears said. "We're not really going to take questions, because we want to focus on what you, the public, have to say. And we want to take some time to properly consider what you have to say."
The commissioners suspended former Police Chief Jeff Eckrich and the entire department March 12, 2024, amid a state criminal investigation into Eckrich due to "suspected" perjury and misconduct in office.
On July 25, 2024, an investigation report by the Office of the State Prosecutor found no "sufficient evidence of criminal activity warranting further investigation or prosecution."
But by that time, the Ridgely officers had already been laid off with the start of the new fiscal year July 1. The town began selling and transferring its police vehicles and equipment in the weeks before the state prosecutor's report was released.
Since then, Ridgely has maintained a contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to have assigned officers covering the town. Last week, the Sheriff's Office announced a third officer was assigned to the Ridgely patrol group.
At Wednesday's meeting, Sears explained why Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker and Chief Deputy Rodney Helmer weren't in attendance.
"They wanted to attend, but they were advised by their attorney not to attend because there is potential litigation outstanding," Sears said. Lt. George Paugh attended in their place.
While two residents submitted written testimony in support of maintaining Caroline County Sheriff's Office coverage, residents who spoke at the meeting largely asked for two other options: reinstating the town's force or ending the Sheriff's Office contract and operating like towns such as Goldsboro and Preston, which receive general county and state police patrol.
"Since the sheriff has taken over, we've had no community policing like before," said Christine Eckrich, wife of the former Ridgely chief. "And a lot of the hours have not been covered. So now my question is, what are we paying for? Why are we double paying for the Sheriff's Office to come to Ridgely."
Resident Anna Mansfield questioned if the budget estimates for a reestablished town force and the county coverage are comparable.
"Was the Ridgely Police Department afforded the ability to reduce their hours to meet the amount of hours expected for the desired budget?" Mansfield asked commissioners.
Sears, who assumed his seat in July 2024 after the department's suspension earlier that year, prepared the cost estimates by reviewing past police budgets, meeting with a consultant and comparing projections to other local departments.
He said it's key to have "rationale and cost effective reasons" when considering creating a police department.
Resident Jennifer Nesselroad stood up to express her displeasure.
"We had a police department, and we don't need to start a new one because you illegally took ours away," she said, leaving the room.
President John Buckle said in an opening statement that "the commissioners will listen carefully to what everyone has to say." Commissioner John Hurley provided no comment at the workshop.
As the meeting closed, Sears emphasized that reinstating the police department would require infrastructure and safety improvements to the department's office within the town hall building.
"But the police department existed how many years without those features," resident Robin Martin said.
"Things have changed a lot over the last five to 10 years," Sears responded. "The racial incidents, the general degradation of respect for authority, COVID and so on has changed our cultural landscape. Violence is on the upswing."
"It's very difficult to be a police officer," he later added. "It's very difficult to attract and retain police officers."

title: Harris hears constituent concerns during telephone town hall
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Harris hears constituent concerns during telephone town hall

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 597
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After rallies in the last month called on Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) to hold an in-person town hall, Harris opened a channel of communication with constituents Tuesday evening to answer questions and hear concerns.The telephone town hall was attended by more than 10,000 people, Harris said. He said the reason he likes doing telephone town halls rather than in-person town halls is because more people are able to attend without having to leave their homes.
"Far many more (people) than we could ever do in any other venue," Harris said.
During the hour-long telephone town hall, Harris heard from around 15 people. Those who called in only gave their first names, with some sharing where they live.
Many concerns and questions raised during the town hall dealt with recent federal layoffs, the fate of programs like Social Security and Medicaid, recent actions taken by the Trump administration and Harris' voting history. Some of the people who spoke shared their criticisms of Harris.
One caller, identified as James, shared concerns about the recent announcements of funding cuts to the National Institutes of Health. He said "fundamental" NIH discoveries fuel the pharmaceutical industry and without the funds to make those discoveries, the pharmaceutical industry will "collapse."
"Trump has sent his idiots from the Department of Governmental Elimination into our fundamental medical research," James said, referencing the Department of Government Efficiency. "And this will destroy the fundamental formation of discovering drugs in this country. So, Congressman Harris, wake up."
After sharing he thinks Elon Musk — who heads the Department of Government Efficiency — shouldn't be called an idiot, Harris said the Trump administration wants to reduce overhead costs, which he believes would allow the federal government to spend more money on research.
Harris, a former physician who was an NIH-funded researcher, said institutions who receive a research grant can get as much as 80% in additional funding for overhead. He said there should be a cap on that overhead funding.
"To me, that's taking advantage of the federal government," he said. "And if we can cap the overhead, it allows us to actually spend more money on actual research projects, not on administrative costs."
Another caller, identified as Allison from Wicomico County, asked what Harris is doing to protect his constituents' data that may have been accessed by the Department of Government Efficiency.
Allison brought up the recent rally Cambridge Indivisible held in Cambridge to demand he hold a town hall. She said Harris "blatantly lied" that the protesters at the rally were bused in and not his constituents.
As she continued to talk about how she knew many of the people at the rally, Harris tried to speak. As Allison continued speaking, Harris said he was sorry, but he would have to mute her.
"Look, if you're going to filibuster, I have to cut you off," he said before muting her.
Harris then said there was a bus, funded by Indivisible, going to Cambridge, adding "there's no question in anyone's mind" about that.
Cambridge Indivisible Co-Founder and Co-Chair Michelle Fowle has said many of those at the rally were her neighbors who live in Cambridge.
In response to Allison's question about personal data, Harris said there are multiple government organizations, like the IRS, that have access to citizens' personal data. He said the Department of Government Efficiency has accessed people's birth dates to identify "fraud, waste and abuse."
"I would hope that everybody wants waste, fraud and abuse uncovered," he said.
Harris instructed those that he wasn't able to hear from during the event to stay on the line after so their question could be recorded and his office could get back to them.

title: Easton Town Council president candidates speak out against sign vandalism
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Town Council president candidates speak out against sign vandalism

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 460
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Candidates for Town Council president are speaking out against recent sign vandalism ahead of Easton's May 6 election.In a letter to police Thursday, current President Frank Gunsallus said he was notified that a swastika was placed on one of his campaign signs at the corner of South Aurora Street and South Lane. He said that came after "significant vandalism" of a number of his other signs.
"This act of hate has escalated the situation into a deeply troubling reality that demands our collective attention," Gunsallus wrote.
Don Abbatiello, the current Ward 2 representative running against Gunsallus for the presidential seat, said theft and vandalism do not belong in the town's elections.
In an interview Friday, Abbatiello said he informed Gunsallus of the defaced sign after discovering it while campaigning in town Wednesday.
"We obviously disagree on some issues, we're running against each other, but there's no reason to deface people's property," Abbatiello said. "There's no reason to bring hatred into this at all. We are still a community. We're still neighbors. We should act like it."
Gunsallus contacted the Easton Police Department after seeing the South Aurora Street sign. He also says campaign signs have been stolen from his home.
Abbatiello says a few of his signs have gone missing as well, though he's unsure if they were stolen or blew away due to wind.
Interim Town Manager Alan Lowrey, Easton's police chief, said an investigation into the defaced sign on South Aurora Street is underway. Lowrey told The Star Democrat that as for missing signs, some were taken down by town code enforcers due to violating town code.
Political sign violations include too many signs on one property or signs placed in a public right-of-way, Lowrey said. To avoid confusion moving forward, Lowrey has asked code enforcement to notify him of any signs not within the code so he can contact the candidate.
Lowrey says he's reached out to both Abbatiello and Gunsallus regarding signs that need to be moved or removed due to town code. Both candidates have complied, Lowrey noted.
Gunsallus and Abbatiello each denounced sign vandalism and acts of hatred.
"These types of things shouldn't happen during a campaign," Gunsallus wrote in a statement to The Star Democrat. "However, I'm hopeful this can be a turning point for our town to come together, reject hate, and foster love in its place."
"We're a community, we all live here together," Abbatiello said. "We need to get along with one another. And bringing in things like that, totally uncalled for."
Easton Police Department Sgt. Patrick Sally says stealing or defacing political signs are criminal offenses. He emphasized that many homeowners and businesses have security technology, such as Ring cameras, that can help identify those stealing or defacing signs.
"You're going to pay the price if you're caught," Sally said.

title: Easton Farmers Market retains downtown spot for 2025
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Farmers Market retains downtown spot for 2025

 540

 EASTON — The Easton Farmers Market is set to remain at its normal downtown spot this season, though the location drew concerns at a recent town meeting.The market's public assembly permit was approved by the Easton Town Council March 18, allowing the market — operated by the Avalon Foundation — to run Saturdays from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. on North Harrison Street behind Goodwill in the town's parking Lot 5.
But some business owners expressed worry about the farmers market limiting downtown parking on Saturday mornings.
Steve Mangasarian, owner of Breakfast in Easton, said at the March 18 Town Council meeting that there have been parking and trash disposal issues stemming from the farmers market.
In an interview, Mangasarian said while he's not against the market and acknowledged it has "many good actors," he believes the Avalon is not doing enough to police market vendors.
"We feel as if we have a right as taxpayers to be entitled to some parking spaces, to be entitled to the secure use of our dumpsters, and accessibility to our parking lot," Mangasarian said. "And nobody at the farmers market seems to worry about these merchants who are being negatively impacted by the market."
Marie Nuthall, the Avalon's outdoor event coordinator , argued the downtown location is crucial for community connection. The market has been in the same spot for more than 30 years, Nuthall said.
"Over that time, families get to know where to find us, generations, their kids, so forth," she said. "Longevity and consistency is very, very important to us."
"The town has a vested interest in the farmers market being there, because we are part of a tourism draw," she added.
Nuthall said vendors sign memorandums of understanding at the beginning of each season outlining proper garbage disposal standards and parking regulations.
"We do everything that we can to be really good neighbors to all the neighboring businesses," Nuthall said.
The public assembly permit first went through the Easton Police Department before it hit the Town Council desk. While the Easton Police Department recommended approval for the North Harrison Street location, it also suggested an alternative spot at the District Court parking lot on Dover Street.
That lot is larger and would prevent downtown parking from being unavailable on Saturday mornings, according to EPD recommendations.
Easton Sgt. Patrick Sally said while the Harrison Street setup is "as safe as it ever has been," the department explored another option because an unofficial parking lot on Washington Street at the site of the former Safeway is soon to be under construction.
In an interview, Sally said the district court lot may be more of a "long-term" consideration. "It is a safety concern because there (are) a lot of people that do walk there," Sally said of the current downtown location.
Crossing guards are typically stationed at the current location during peak hours to assist pedestrian traffic on Harrison Street and Brewers Lane.
Nuthall said it's a relief to have the market remain in Lot 5 this year. She said "if a move is inevitable" in the future, she hopes the market and vendors "have buy-in" during that decision-making process.
"It should be something that is done thoughtfully and collaboratively," Nuthall said.
The Easton Farmers Market kicks off its 2025 season Saturday, April 12, and runs through December.

title: Talbot Planning Commission sends DAF legislation to County Council
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Planning Commission sends DAF legislation to County Council

 April 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 380
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council will soon be considering new restrictions on the storage of food processing residuals.Wednesday, the Talbot County Planning Commission unanimously voted to send a piece of legislation up to the council, deeming it consistent with the county's comprehensive plan.
The legislation aims to help Talbot County fall in line with neighboring counties on restricting the residuals, which are animal waste from food processing that are often applied to farmland as fertilizer.
Under state law, the residuals cannot be applied to land between Dec. 15 and March 1, requiring them to be stored during the winter months.
Last year, Caroline County restricted storage of food processing residuals, often referred to as dissolved air flotation, or DAF, residuals. It came amid significant resident complaints of the noxious odors and bugs that stemmed from farming operations keeping the product in open storage tanks.
Talbot's legislation would ban open-top storage of DAF or food processing residuals. Closed-top storage would be permitted provided it follows the following conditions, among others:
The storage applicant receives site plan approval from the county.The applicant has an approved nutrient management plan from the state.The applicant has at least a 500-foot setback from residential properties, or at least a 200-foot setback if all affected property owners consent.The applicant applies the materials on the same property where they are being stored.The applicant stores and applies the materials in a permitted zoning district.
The legislation would not ban storage of food processing residuals in a temporary storage unit — such as a "mobile, closed container" — near where they are being applied. Such temporary storage would be capped at 90 days.
Before the commission approved the legislation, the body set forth a few minor conditions to be amended.
"The one thing that we do want to make sure is that we exempt food processing residuals that are used for livestock feed," commission member Chip Councell said.
Bryce Yelton, assistant planning officer, said that would be an easy amendment to make, simply by adjusting the definition for food processing residuals in the legislation.
Councell added that the county discussed the DAF legislation with the Talbot County Farm Bureau last August. The farm bureau was supportive, he said.
While the commission is recommending approval to the County Council, the bill will still require a council vote to be enacted.

title: Talbot County Police Accountability Board reports decrease in misconduct complaints
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County Police Accountability Board reports decrease in misconduct complaints

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 416
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County's Police Accountability Board investigated just six resident complaints of police misconduct in 2024, down from 15 complaints in 2023.Mitch Ettinger, chairman of the board, reported these statistics to the Talbot County Council Tuesday. He said the decrease in complaints is "a testament to the fantastic law enforcement agencies" in the county.
Complaints have ticked up since January. In the first quarter of 2025, the charging committee has received seven complaints of police misconduct, Ettinger noted. An explanation for the uptick was not provided at the meeting.
Of the six complaints last year, four were dismissed and two resulted in administrative charges against an officer.
According to the board's 2024 report, the decrease is due, in part, to a resident moving out of the county who submitted many complaints in 2023.
With fewer complaints to investigate, PAB members became interested in how they might otherwise serve the county, Ettinger said.
Tuesday, Ettinger noted all police misconduct complaints in the last two years have been made directly to law enforcement agencies and subsequently referred to the charging committee. Ettinger said residents may not be aware that complaints can be made directly to the accountability board as well.
He asked council members for feedback on whether the board is meeting expectations and on potentially expanding the role of the PAB.
"Our mandate is narrow by statute," Ettinger said, "but we have seen in other jurisdictions, PABs go well beyond that mandate at the direction of their council, including to review policies of law enforcement agencies."
"The PAB feels that its role is not all that substantive," he added.
Police accountability boards were mandated statewide by Maryland's Police Accountability Act of 2021. PABs, made up of everyday residents, are responsible for meeting with law enforcement agencies, fielding complaints of police misconduct, reviewing use of force reports and submitting annual reports to county officials.
All counties have an administrative charging committee that sits under the PAB. Those committees determine if an officer will be administratively charged and, if so, what discipline they receive.
County Council Vice President Pete Lesher said he hopes for the county to "look at other models and see what might be working in other jurisdictions."
Council member Keasha Haythe said it is important for the county to consider both looking at other jurisdictions and increasing resident awareness of the PAB complaint process.
Meanwhile, council member Dave Stepp said he is comfortable with the board's responsibilities remaining the same.
"I see no reason to expand the scope or functionality other than what's required by law," Stepp said.

1. Why are you running for Easton Town Council president?
I'm running for council president because elections should be about options, not just be a coronation. It's important to offer voters a choice.
I want to bring a collaborative, consensus-building leadership style to the council and to be a leader who listens. Good leadership is about teamwork — no matter how strong your ideas are, they won't move forward without support from your fellow council members. I believe I can lead with respect and cooperation to help guide thoughtful decisions that reflect the needs of our residents.
2. What issues will you prioritize if elected?
My priorities are smart development, public safety and fiscal responsibility. Easton is growing fast, and we need to manage that growth and avoid unnecessary development.
I support limiting annexation until we ensure infrastructure can support our current development. For large redevelopment projects, the Town Council needs to be included in the decision making.
I'll prioritize support for our police and fire departments — funding, staffing and equipment must be maintained to support first-class service. Health care access is another major concern. I want to work with medical partners to attract more doctors.
I will ensure we continue balanced budgets, prioritizing services residents rely on without wasting taxpayers' money.
3. While the town has grown, affordable housing remains a challenge for residents. How should the town build more housing, in particular affordable housing?
There's no one-size-fits-all solution to affordable housing, but we must be proactive. I'd work closely with partners like the Affordable Housing Board and Habitat for Humanity to explore opportunities for creating starter homes. Zoning tools, incentives for developers and creative use of town-owned properties could also play a role. We need to support a mix of housing types to serve working families, young professionals and seniors. It's important to balance affordability with quality in the community.
4. The town has seen increased development in its downtown core as well as on Route 50. How should the town prepare for the impacts of such growth?
To prepare for Easton's growth, we need a strong, forward-thinking plan that addresses traffic, infrastructure and public services. New development should not outpace our ability to support it. Council members must be actively involved in major project decisions, particularly those with large impacts. Developers should be responsible for mitigating traffic and parking issues their projects may cause. Infrastructure improvements should be timed with development, not after. Transparency, community input and smart land-use policies are key to guiding growth in a way that keeps Easton a livable, vibrant town and preserves our way of life.
5. What are your plans for public safety in Easton? What can be improved?
Strong public safety services are essential to maintaining Easton as a safe and welcoming place for families, businesses and visitors.
I support increasing the presence of police on the rail trails, in parks and at community events to ensure safety and visibility. I support expanding our public camera system to deter crime and aid investigations. Our police need competitive benefits, including improved pensions, to attract and retain top talent.
Our volunteer fire department needs to be supported with the best equipment. I'm incredibly proud of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department's regional training campus that will better prepare our emergency responders and reduce training costs.
6. What have you accomplished during your time on the council thus far? How will you seek to continue those efforts?
During my time on the council, I've supported initiatives that improve quality of life and promote responsible government. I've worked to expand walkability, including sidewalk and crosswalk improvements. I've brought new playgrounds and improved old ones in my ward. We've passed balanced budgets every year without raising the property tax rate. I helped implement the take-home car program for Easton Police, an important recruitment and retention tool. I've focused on community-based policies that are practical and sustainable.

title: Easton Planning Commission approves Zaxbys on Route 50
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Planning Commission approves Zaxbys on Route 50

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 493
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Easton Planning Commission approved a plan to build a Zaxbys restaurant on Route 50 Thursday.Developers for the restaurant largely quelled concerns expressed last month when commission members tabled architectural approval. Those concerns centered on the bright red and blue colors in design renderings.
Thursday, franchise co-owner and Delmarva Real Estate Management Group attorney Curtis Snyder presented colored renderings of an updated design, which includes additional brick around the 2,000-square-foot building. The new renderings were less "cartoonish" in color and more accurately reflect what the building will look like, Snyder said.
Most commission members felt the updated design was an improvement.
"There are some existing businesses that have blues that are much brighter than this," commission member Laurie Forster said. "… I don't think it's unacceptable, and I do think it could be a great addition to the restaurant scene."
The Georgia-based franchise has hundreds of restaurants nationwide and is known for its chicken fingers, wings and signature sauces.
Commission member Tom Klein said the Easton Zaxbys will bring jobs to town and serve as an upgrade to the "eyesore" that is the empty Wendy's building.
"If this went down in flames, I don't know how long it would be before something else came along," Klein said. "So it could be sitting for quite some time like a lot of other empty lots on 50."
Snyder said the Zaxbys building will be smaller than the former Wendy's, allowing for two drive-thru lanes that can accommodate 26 cars at once. "We're confident in getting people in and out," Snyder said in response to a question of whether lines may spill onto the highway.
PUSHBACK
During Thursday's meeting, member Victoria McAndrews criticized the design, saying it's "very garish" compared to other Zaxbys restaurants in the country.
"I'm just not looking at this as an improvement over what was not satisfactory to begin with," McAndrews said.
Snyder said corporate isn't willing to budge on the blue and red colors, part of the company's branding efforts.
McAndrews said the commission is not doing its job by accepting designs pushed down from the corporate level.
"That's in direct conflict with what the (comprehensive) plan says for Easton that we're supposed to strive for, which is not making it look like Anywhere, USA," she said.
"I'm still getting blowback from corporate over this design," Snyder responded. "They do not want this brick on their building. … This is an extreme deviation in their mind."
Following Forster and Klein's comments, commission Chair Philip Toussaint and member William Ryall indicated their satisfaction with the updated Zaxbys application. Ryall made the motion for approval, and McAndrews joined the rest of the commission in voting yes despite her concerns.
"I think it's an improvement," Ryall said. "It's not perfect, but nothing ever is."
The Easton Zaxbys is one of three locations developers are pursuing as part of the restaurant's Maryland debut, with the others in Cambridge and Berlin.
The Easton location is projected to open in late 2025 or early 2026, Snyder told The Star Democrat last month.

title: Easton election: Gunsallus, Abbatiello weigh in on housing, growth and more
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton election: Gunsallus, Abbatiello weigh in on housing, growth and more

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 749
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Town Council president candidates Frank Gunsallus and Don Abbatiello both recognize the need to monitor and manage Easton's growth, but they each indicated different strategies on how to do so in editorial board interviews with The Star Democrat this week.Gunsallus, the incumbent, is being challenged by Abbatiello, the current Ward 2 councilmember. Voters head to the polls May 6 to decide the council's next leader, as well as representatives for the second and fourth wards.
During the interviews, both candidates were asked how to tackle Easton's affordable housing issue.
Gunsallus noted one of his priorities is to vote down an inclusionary zoning ordinance town leaders have expressed mixed opinions on. Instead, he said methods like removing impact fees or marking down land should be considered.
"It's a lot simpler than it's being made out to be," Gunsallus said. "Those are very straightforward, simple ways that can be done very soon to make that happen."
Abbatiello said the main issue with the lack of affordable homes is the rising price of land. He said incentivizing developers to build "middle housing" options is a solution.
"How do you get that price of land out of the equation? You have townhouses," Abbatiello said. "And townhouses become your starter home for people."
The current Ward 2 representative added that his vote against the Gannon Range project on Matthewstown Road in 2022 stemmed from the high prices of those homes.
"It was bringing us $450,000, $500,000 homes, which is not something that we needed," he said.
Gunsallus pointed out he's asked for the Town Council to have more say in approving housing projects. At a February workshop, Gunsallus and others led a discussion of how the council has only approved 37% of the town's 1,000 housing units in the pipeline at the time.
ENVISIONING THE FUTURE
The town is in the early process of revising its comprehensive plan for the first time in 15 years. The Planning Commission is currently reviewing drafts of the new plan, which lays out a vision for how the town should prioritize its growth.
Abbatiello said that in 2010, Easton was aiming to draw developers into town, but now the focus has changed.
"Tap the brakes, we need to slow down," he said of the current thought process.
The town's current comprehensive plan calls for 1% year-to-year growth. Gunsallus says he's "of the school of thought that that 1% is the ceiling, and we should not be exceeding that."
"When I graduated high school here in 2006, the town was literally half the size population-wise that it is now," he said. "So if we continue that same rate of growth, in 20 years, we'll have almost 40,000 people here."
REPRESENTING RESIDENTS
Candidates were asked questions concerning constituent representation. Gunsallus said he's given underrepresented groups a voice since being elected, such as when he voted to remove a 10-cent paper bag fee, a measure that narrowly fell short.
"That stemmed directly from a conversation with a room full of people about, 'I count my pennies when I go shopping so I can buy bags because my food stamps don't cover the cost of bags,'" Gunsallus said.
Abbatiello said if elected, he would push for each ward to have quarterly meetings. He said follow-up is critical, such as when he helped Ward 2 residents who raised concerns about safely walking to Walmart and Giant.
"I was annoying in saying, 'There needs to be a sidewalk on Elliott Road,'" Abbatiello said.
LEADERSHIP
With an election cycle that's become increasingly heated, both candidates offered thoughts on the responsibility of the council president and the disagreements that come with serving on the council.
"You can be the most amazing council president in the world, but if you can't get there with the rest of the council members, then you're going to lose every single vote that comes up," Abbatiello said.
"Sometimes you are not even part of the issue, but you still have to mediate or at least navigate the conversation," Gunsallus said. " ... Let's find common ground and go from there."
Gunsallus said it's been an honor to serve in the role since 2023.
"I'm happy with what has occurred under my administration, and I am looking forward to continuing the good work for another four years," Gunsallus said.
Abbatiello acknowledged serving on the council isn't an easy job, but he said it's an enjoyable one.
"You wonder if you're making the right decision," Abbatiello said. "But at the same time, I am still glad that over the last six years I've had the opportunity to make those decisions. And I wouldn't trade it for anything."

title: Easton Town Council candidates make their cases at town hall
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Town Council candidates make their cases at town hall

 April 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News

 EASTON — With the election less than a week away, voters had the chance Tuesday to ask Town Council candidates a number of questions about issues facing Easton, including fiscal responsibility and housing.During a town hall hosted by The Talbot Spy and the Avalon Foundation Tuesday night, all seven candidates for three spots on the council made their pitches to voters.
For the council president seat, incumbent Frank Gunsallus and current Ward 2 representative Don Abbatiello will square off.
With Abbatiello opting to run for president, a new resident will assume the Ward 2 seat. In that race, Lynnette Keefe and Robert Rankin will face off.
The Ward 4 race will present voters with three options: incumbent the Rev. Elmer Davis, who has served in the seat since 2020; Moonyene Jackson-Amis, previously Ward 4's representative from 2001 to 2008; and newcomer Cameron Keefe.
Gunsallus and Abbatiello, along with other candidates, spoke about the town's budgetary outlook. The town's proposed budget for fiscal year 2026 is $28 million and includes a real property tax rate of 52 cents per $100 of assessed value. That mark hasn't changed since 2008.
One resident asked whether the candidates would consider a property tax rate cut given increasing property values, which have caused residents' tax bills go up.
Gunsallus said he would consider it and that it has been discussed by the council. He said the town could work on increasing the number of business to bring in more commercial tax revenue.
He added that since joining the council in 2023, he's pushed for detailed reviews of the town's budget.
"Through my direction, this council has done something that it hasn't done in at least 30 years," Gunsallus said, "and that is go line by line, every single line, in the $28 million budget to be just that: responsible stewards of the town's money."
Abbatiello said during this year's budget discussions, he was against a property tax rate hike. He said a tax break is dependent upon the town's fiscal need.
"If we can afford to reduce taxes, great. I'm all in favor of that," Abbatiello said. "I don't think we should just automatically say we're cutting taxes. We need to also look at other revenue sources."
Abbatiello said he's focused on keeping the Easton Volunteer Fire Department a volunteer organization — since a shift to paid would be "one of the biggest tax increases this town will ever see."
Ward 4's Cameron Keefe advocated for the town to continue funding its police department at a high level. He said he's "absolutely immovable" on fiscal transparency.
"I would like to — and I might be shooting myself in the foot — strike fear into the hearts of our representatives and let them know, the money we're spending is not ours," Keefe said. "We have to have the people of Easton's best interests in mind."
HOUSING
During both the moderated and open question portions of the town hall, the need for more affordably priced homes was mentioned. Candidates offered different ideas to tackle the dilemma.
Jackson-Amis said the town should "hold the developers responsible" by requiring a percentage of units be affordable. She vouched for smart growth, and said the Town Council should have more say in approving housing projects.
"We need to be very strategic in what it is we desire, and then how that can be implemented," Jackson-Amis said. "But the council is accountable for that. We're responsible. It's not the Planning Commission."
Davis has lobbied for that same increase in council involvement. Tuesday, he told residents the town should buy land and partner with a housing developer or nonprofit.
"So, therefore, the people who work at Wawas can get a house that's around $200,000 because the town has purchased property," Davis said. "I think we need to make that kind of investment for affordable housing in the Town of Easton, and we will meet the needs of the individuals in the community."
Ward 2 candidate Lynn Keefe emphasized the town should be thinking "outside of the box" when it comes to addressing housing and infrastructure problems.
"I really feel like we need to work on our green space here," she said. "We need to look at different parts of housing, not just affordable housing through the government, but also sustainable neighborhoods."
Rankin, Lynn Keefe's opponent, said development is the most common issue he hears from residents. Rankin said it's important to attract health care professionals and young people to Easton while also keeping an eye on growth.
"It's really important that we properly manage these developments that are coming on to make sure that those potential concerns are mitigated," Rankin said.

title: Gunsallus campaign flyer is misleading, outright false
author: MEGAN COOK
content:
Gunsallus campaign flyer is misleading, outright false

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MEGAN COOK | Section: Columns 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As someone who has worked hard to serve this community with honesty and transparency, I've always believed that facts should guide our public conversations, especially during an election. That's why I feel compelled to address several misleading and outright false claims circulating in recent campaign materials.When falsehoods are left unchallenged, it risks becoming accepted as fact. Our community deserves better. These tactics are part of an effort not to inform or unite us but to stir fear and falsely influence voters. That's not who we are in the Town of Easton, and it's not how we should conduct ourselves.
One candidate, Frank Gunsallus, has claimed he is the only council member in 30 years to have gone "line by line" through the town budget. That statement isn't just misleading, it's false and is a disservice to the many council members, past and present, who have worked diligently every year to ensure taxpayer dollars are spent wisely. Every budget season involves careful review, discussion and difficult decisions. Suggesting otherwise dismisses the thoughtful and responsible work of others who have taken that duty seriously, including myself when I served on the council from 2009-2023.
The inclusionary zoning bill is still a work in progress, and no final version has been drafted. Since 2022, there have been numerous meetings and workshops with both the Town Council and Planning Commission. A dedicated task force, made up of volunteers who spent countless hours reviewing Easton's housing needs, was appointed to offer thoughtful recommendations. That group is still finalizing its report.
To claim the bill mandates high-density housing in every neighborhood is simply false and undermines the work of dozens of people trying in good faith to address a real challenge. The goal is simple: to make it possible for teachers, nurses, police officers and others who serve our town to actually live here. If an officer has sworn to protect and serve our town, they ought to be able to call it home.
The same flyer accuses the mayor and staff of quietly ushering in development with little or no public input. That's not only untrue, it's an insult to the hardworking staff, Planning Commission and community members involved in every step of our public planning process. Nothing is being "snuck in." Transparency and community input are cornerstones of how we operate. Claims to the contrary are simply false.
It's also been claimed that I "recruited" three pro-mayor, pro-development candidates to run for Town Council. That's false. Two of the implied candidates are already serving on the council. One of them is running against Mr. Gunsallus not because of ideology, but out of concern over how meetings are managed, the lack of respect shown and civility and communication breakdowns among council members.
Mischaracterizing the motives of individuals who Mr. Gunsallus opposes is unfair and misleading. Voters should look for leadership that is respectful, collaborative and able to work with others, especially when navigating difficult issues. That's the kind of leadership Easton deserves.
It's also been suggested that because I wasn't born in Easton, I somehow care less or am less committed to this community. That's not only wrong, it's also deeply disrespectful. My husband and I moved to Easton 22 years ago for his job as a pediatrician and to be closer to his family. My work as mayor, as a former council member and my involvement in projects like Project Idlewild, CarePacks, coaching sports and serving on local boards and clubs, has always been about giving back to the place my husband and I chose to raise our family.
And I'm far from alone. Many of the people who make meaningful contributions to Easton each day weren't born here. What matters is not where someone started, but the heart and effort they bring to serving this town.
Easton is a town worth fighting for, not with fear or falsehoods, but with integrity, respect and a commitment to the truth. Elections should be about ideas, accountability, and the future we want to build together, not personal attacks or misleading claims. I will continue to stand up for the facts, for our hardworking staff and volunteers and for a community where we listen to each other even when we disagree. I encourage every voter to look past the lies, ask thoughtful questions and choose leaders who value collaboration, honesty and real public service.

title: Voter turnout is solid and steady for Easton election

content:

 395

 EASTON — The polls had been open for less than three hours at 9:45 a.m. Tuesday, but 500 residents had already cast their ballots in Easton's election.The Easton Town Council has three of its five seats up for grabs, and all races are contested, including the council president race between incumbent Frank Gunsallus and current Ward 2 representative Don Abbatiello.
In Ward 2, Lynn Keefe and Robert Rankin are vying for the Abbatiello's current seat. In Ward 4, incumbent the Rev. Elmer Davis, former council member Moonyene Jackson-Amis and newcomer Cameron Keefe are facing off.
All seven candidates were at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department Tuesday morning to speak to voters.
Abbatiello, Davis and Rankin stood next to one another under a tent in the lawn outside the fire hall. Gunsallus was set up with his own tent next to them.
Jackson-Amis spent some time inside the fire hall lobby Tuesday morning, chatting to residents. Lynn and Cameron Keefe, mother and son, stood next to cars in the parking lot to greet voters as they entered and exited.
Lynn Keefe said the campaign has been a great experience and that she's thankful for all who came out to vote. She said no matter who wins, it's important to be respectful.
"It's been a whirlwind," she said of the recent weeks campaigning.
Resident Carolyn Coon voted Tuesday morning. She said the importance of this election brought her to the polls. Coon said Easton "needs civility back in place."
"I think the council's been disjointed," Coon said. She added that misinformation during the campaign cycle — coming from "one side," she said — has hurt and divided the town.
"I think it's been really sleazy," Coon said.
Jason Bell stood at the corner of Leonard Rieck Drive and North Aurora Street, where vehicles turned into the parking lot. He held a large American flag and a Gunsallus sign.

"I'm supporting America," Bell said of his support for Gunsallus.
Inside the fire hall, election supervisor Ed Forte and election judge Alison Sanford swiftly assisted voters who were unsure of which wards they live in.
At one point Tuesday morning, around 20 people stood in line, though the wait wasn't long. Sanford said there was steady voter turnout.

title: Cambridge Indivisible aims to teach members about civics, cofounder says
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge Indivisible aims to teach members about civics, cofounder says

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 645
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — For Cambridge Indivisible cofounder and Cochair Michelle Fowle, it's about understanding the power you have."I think the really important thing is for people to understand the power that they actually hold," she said. "So that's kind of my focus. And I'm doing that here."
When Fowle moved to Cambridge from California with her husband, Andy, in September, the two hit the ground running to form Cambridge Indivisible, which is a chapter of a national organization that aims to elect progressive leaders.
Fowle said the overarching goal of the group is to give people a place to build community and learn about civics. She said everyone is welcome.
"We have Republicans who are showing up now at our protests, asking how they can help," she said. "And I embrace them."
Mentioning health care and housing, Fowle said there are issues that people on both sides of the aisle can unite on. She said that for her, the organization isn't about identity politics.
"We don't have to agree," she said. "In fact, we shouldn't agree. And it's healthy to have that conversation. I'm not trying to make you be me."
There was a time when Fowle knew very little about politics.
"They say that there's two days that are critical in your life," she said. "It's the day you're born and the day you find out why. And in November 2016, I found out why."
Fowle said the 2016 general election results thrust her into a world of activism after not paying close attention to politics for many years. While living in California, Fowle learned from other organizers, helped put on rallies and marches, and built relationships with elected officials.
"For somebody who didn't know anything, I can teach it now," she said.
MAKING WAVES
In recent months, Cambridge Indivisible has garnered attention over events it has hosted around town. During one event in March, the chapter hosted Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md.) for a town hall.
The chapter also has hosted multiple rallies to criticize elected federal leadership. That criticism has been largely directed toward Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) for not holding in-person town halls for his constituents. Harris hosted multiple virtual town halls in the past two months.
Fowle said the Cambridge chapter of Indivisible has more than 1,000 members from across the Eastern Shore. She said there is no formal registration process to be a member.
Cambridge Indivisible Treasurer Ilia Johnson said she joined the chapter this year to get more representation for the Hispanic community in the area and to support her neighbors. She said she likes that Cambridge Indivisible is a group "for everybody."
"All we want to do is what's best for everybody," she said.
During a Cambridge Indivisible rally held along U.S. Route 50 in Cambridge on April 19, Gloria McVeigh said she joined the chapter after Harris was elected in November. She said it's a nice group that holds the same values as herself.
Although there have been disapproving shouts from people driving their cars past Cambridge Indivisible rallies these past few months, Fowle said the chapter hasn't faced much opposition other than from Harris.
In the past, Harris has shared his criticisms of and concerns with the Indivisible organization as a whole.
Following a Cambridge Indivisible rally held March 13 that called on Harris to hold an in-person town hall and questioned his allegiance to his constituents, Harris alleged those at the rally were "brought in by buses" and not his constituents. He said he heard from a Washington, D.C., organization's leader "who knows what's going on" that people at the rally were getting paid to be there.
"This is AstroTurf," Harris said about the organization in March. "This is not grassroots."
Fowle said the chapter does get internet trolls on its public page, and she deletes their comments and blocks them.
"It's like listen, when this hits you — and it will — I'll be there for you if you want," she said about the internet trolls.

title: Seafood odor dispute in Easton's 4th ward still simmering
author: Konner Metz
content:
Seafood odor dispute in Easton's 4th ward still simmering

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As summer nears, disagreement between a local seafood processor and neighboring residents over odor mitigation efforts is resurfacing.Residents in Ward 4 have long complained of odor emanating from Chesapeake Brand Seafood on Maryland Avenue during crab season.
It led to action by the Easton Town Council last December. The town passed an ordinance requiring seafood processing operations to install odor control technology "in such a manner that no odor" could be detected.
Per the ordinance, an odor control system must be installed by July 1. But Chesapeake Brand Seafood is now requesting an amendment to the ordinance, citing that industry experts say the "no odor" language is an unachievable goal.
Peter Maloney, who lives around 500 feet from the business, has been a vocal neighborhood leader for affected residents. He says the odor makes it hard for his kids to enjoy time outside.
"It's not something we signed up for," said Maloney, who moved to Easton around five years before the business opened in 2019.
He added that Chesapeake Brand Seafood isn't acting as a good neighbor with its attempt to amend the already-approved ordinance.
"They're kicking the can down the road," Maloney said.
At Monday's Town Council meeting, the amendment was introduced and referred to the Planning Commission for review at its May 15 meeting. Town Council will still have the final say.
If passed, the amendment will remove the requirement that odor control systems act "in such a manner that no odor from any product or by-product can be detected outside the building on the same property or on adjacent properties or public rights-of-way."
Replacing the deleted language is, in part, the requirement that engineers or industry experts confirm the installed odor control equipment uses "best control technologies and methods designed to mitigate odor before it leaves a building."
Owner Mitch Hughes says his business requested the amendment due to the "no odor" language. He's looking for clarity over whether that mandate would be based on odor detection or resident complaints.
"Zero odor means I'm done completely," Hughes said. "It's just not possible."
Hughes is ready to install the odor control technology, but he's holding off since he doesn't want to begin footing the $800 monthly cost if it won't end up meeting the ordinance.
"They all said we can install a system and get your odor down," he said. "But there's no way you can reach zero odor."
Maloney and other residents spoke in opposition to the proposed amendment Monday.
"I feel like I've earned my right to retire, and I don't want to have to do it inside my household," Carla Howell said.
"We are organized, and we are all very angry about this as you can hear," Emily Stone said. "And we will not be quiet until something is done."
Ward 4 Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis, who pushed for the ordinance to be passed last year, said he's against any amendment.
"I think the ordinance as it stands is an excellent ordinance," Davis said. "And the crab industry hasn't been a good neighbor."
Ward 1's Maureen Curry said Monday that Chesapeake Brand Seafood gave the council a "flat-out no" on the prospect of moving to a new location, likely one not in a residential area. Hughes, whose business was legally permitted by the town to locate on that property, says he's only against moving if he has to foot the full bill.
Hughes said the business has taken steps as requested by town code enforcement to reduce odor. Remaining complaints, he said, are due to the steaming process.
"It's kind of hard to fix the smell of steamed crabs," Hughes said. "That's just part of the process. That is our process."
But Maloney and other residents said Monday the proposed amendment feels like a stall tactic from Chesapeake Brand Seafood as the July 1 deadline nears.
Maloney said in an interview that the neighbors aren't looking to hurt a business. They are, however, fighting for what he calls a "well-worded" and effective ordinance to stand as originally approved.
"To loosen this at the expense of all property owners who have dealt with this for five years is unfair," Maloney said.

title: Andy Harris, local Republicans take aim at Moore, talk '26 election cycle
author: Konner Metz
content:
Andy Harris, local Republicans take aim at Moore, talk '26 election cycle

 May 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: News 
 
 874
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — During the Caroline County GOP's annual Lincoln Reagan Dinner last week, U.S. Rep. Andy Harris and state Sen. Steve Hershey took aim at Gov. Wes Moore amid speculations he will make a 2028 presidential bid.Speaking to a room full of locally elected Republicans and Republican voters in Denton on Thursday evening, Harris (R-Md., 1st) acknowledged Moore's (D) frequent visits to the Eastern Shore.
"He's smooth. The guy's smooth," Harris said, pausing briefly. "The guy's as liberal as the day is long," he added. "The guy's a socialist."
Rumors of a potential Moore presidential run, though denied by the governor himself, have emerged amid his weeklong trip to Japan and South Korea last month and his slot as the guest speaker for a high-profile South Carolina Democratic fundraiser later in May.
Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) tackled the Moore speculations head-on, stating that the governor wouldn't make an appearance on ABC's "The View" just to remain governor. In Moore's May 1 spot on the daytime talk show, the governor repeatedly stated he is "not running" in 2028.
Following his appearance on "The View," Moore told CNN that he's focused on Maryland when asked whether he's ruling out a 2028 presidential campaign.
"I think anybody who is positioning themselves in 2025 for 2028 is not taking 2025 seriously," he said.
But Hershey was adamant that Moore will run for the presidential seat.
"It's going to end here in Maryland," Hershey said Thursday. "That thing is going to go away, because we have done such a great job of holding him accountable for what has gone wrong in Maryland."
Moore is up for reelection to his gubernatorial seat in 2026. He will face at least one Democratic primary challenger in the form of retired businessman Ed Hale.
Hershey was less confident about the Republican Party's chances to defeat Moore in the 2026 gubernatorial race, but maintained his hardline stance.
"They are going to spend more money on Wes Moore than any governor race probably in the country," Hershey said. "Because people do think he's going to be the next president. And he cannot possibly lose a governor race in Maryland. But we're going to fight that. We're going to put a great candidate out."
Hershey proclaimed the 2025 General Assembly as the "worst session" he's experienced and said it is "at the hands" of Moore. He said that House and Senate Republicans will hold the governor accountable as next year's gubernatorial election nears.
LOCAL ELECTIONS
While Hershey emphasized that Republicans will focus on flipping a handful of seats in Maryland's General Assembly in 2026, other Republican leaders spoke to the importance of campaigning at an even more local level.
Nicole Harris, Andy Harris' wife and chairwoman of the Maryland Republican Party, said she and Executive Director Adam Wood have kept the party's efforts in town and county elections quiet.
"We didn't want the Democrats to catch on," she said. "The Democrats have caught on over the last few weeks.
"So now we need all hands on deck. But we have flipped more seats in municipal elections than the Democrats have so far this year."
Nicole Harris said the state party is celebrating a sweep in last week's election in La Plata, a town in Charles County that is welcoming an entirely new council.
Julie Quick, chair of the Caroline County Republican Central Committee, noted Preston's election of a new town commissioner as a recent Republican loss. In a race where only 36 residents voted, newcomer Scott Messick defeated incumbent Nelson Anderson in the non-partisan race.
"Had we gotten out the vote, we could've taken that election," Quick said.
Republican-endorsed candidates in the race for Easton Town Council went 0-for-3 in last week's election, a campaign cycle which sparked questions of whether political party influence is appropriate in nonpartisan local races.
Quick acknowledged that some local candidates may not want endorsement from a political party. But she said the committee still needs to "recruit good candidates" and create a foundation to support the party's state delegates and senators.
"They're the bench, and we need a bench," Quick said of municipal candidates.
HARRIS TALKS 2026
Thursday, Rep. Harris briefly made mention of Jake Day, the Department of Housing and Community Development secretary who's rumored to be considering a challenge of Harris for the 1st district seat that stretches the length of the Eastern Shore.
Day confirmed to Maryland Matters earlier this month that he's raising money for an "exploratory effort."
"Tax them till you leave office Jake Day," Harris told the crowd Thursday, likely referencing Day's time as mayor in Salisbury.
When asked of Day's potential congressional bid in an interview with The Star Democrat after the event, Harris said, "This is America. Anybody can explore."
"He's just not going to have any luck because he has a record."
Harris added that he's focused on carrying out President Donald Trump's agenda — not his run for reelection next year.
The congressman did note that as chair of the far-right House Freedom Caucus, he offers a unique level of access that can benefit the residents he represents.

title: Planning Commission recommends against seafood odor amendment
author: Konner Metz
content:
Planning Commission recommends against seafood odor amendment

 May 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 613
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Planning Commission Thursday provided an unfavorable recommendation on a recently proposed amendment to a seafood odor ordinance.The ordinance, which came after a multi-year push from Ward 4 residents, aims to address complaints of odor emanating from Chesapeake Brand Seafood, a facility located on Maryland Avenue near many homes. The legislation was passed in December, but a final resolution hasn't been reached.
The business recently requested an amendment to the already-approved ordinance, citing that industry experts consider legislation's requirements unachievable.
It requires the business to install odor control technology so "that no odor ... can be detected outside the building on the same property or on adjacent properties or public rights-of-way." The deadline to install is July 1.
Owner Mitch Hughes, attorney Zach Smith and the vendor of an odor control system explained Thursday that the ordinance isn't feasible as written.
Their amendment proposes a new standard — that engineers or industry experts confirm odor control equipment uses "best control technologies and methods designed to mitigate odor before it leaves a building."
Commission members agreed the proposed change was too vague. But they also acknowledged that the original ordinance doesn't create a clear path to compliance.
"I feel like we're trying to put a round peg in a square hole here," member Tom Klein said.
Chairperson Philip Toussaint said the business, which was legally permitted to operate by the town beginning in 2019, should've never been OK'd at that site.
"That's tough to hear when we, again, followed the town zoning codes," Smith said. "It's tough to hear that position from the Planning Commission."
Smith said the amendment is not an attempt by Hughes to avoid addressing the odor complaints. Hughes noted he's fully willing to install the odor control system, but he doesn't want to foot the cost if his efforts won't meet the ordinance.
Smith said if the "no odor" requirement isn't changed, it leaves only two options: Chesapeake Brand goes out of business or involves the town in "some sort of protracted legal battle."
Commission members, along with some residents, criticized the business for proposing the amendment so soon before the July 1 deadline.
"If we had another month or two, it could've been doable," said William Ryall, the commission's chair pro tem.
The commission voted 4-0 to advise the Town Council to reject the amendment. But in that same motion, the commission directed the council to incorporate an "enforceable standard" into the already-approved legislation. Despite much discussion Thursday, it's not yet clear exactly what that standard might be.
The Town Council will still review the proposed amendment, likely considering the commission's advice to find a middle ground on a standard that can be met and enforced.
PUBLIC INPUT
Public comment was mixed Thursday, with many of the residents affected by the odor in attendance to oppose Chesapeake Brand's amendment. Some suggested alternative ways to reach a compromise.
Shawn Nuthall said the amended wording has "no teeth, no data, no standards."
"We've been going through this for years and years and years," he said. "It's way, way too long. They should've done something before now."
Others, including some fellow business owners and seafood processors, spoke in support of Hughes and Chesapeake Brand Seafood.
"Mitch got a permit," Donna Bramble said. "He did not hide what kind of business he was having. He told you what it was going to be. It's a signed, legal document, and now the town is trying to take that away."
Joe Spurry, owner of Chesapeake Landing Seafood in St. Michaels, said Hughes has good intent and that the town should be wary of not driving the business away.
"He started a business that nobody starts," Spurry said. "Processing seafood is a dying business. I'm one of the last in Talbot County. He's the newest."

title: Abbatiello, Rankin, Davis sworn in as Easton's new council sets off
author: Konner Metz
content:
Abbatiello, Rankin, Davis sworn in as Easton's new council sets off

 May 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Family, friends and residents packed the council chambers Monday to watch three Easton Town Council members take the oath of office, including new president Don Abbatiello.Abbatiello, newly-elected Ward 2 representative Robert Rankin and returning Ward 4 representative the Rev. Elmer Davis were sworn in by Mayor Megan Cook, marking the start of council's first meeting with its new makeup.
Abbatiello defeated outgoing president Frank Gunsallus in a heated election on May 6. But all was cordial Monday night as Abbatiello shifted from his Ward 2 chair to the center seat on the dais.
The new council president thanked his wife and two kids, mother and sister, and town residents for their support during the campaign.
"We're facing a lot of challenges as a community," Abbatiello said. "Growth, housing, access to medical care, traffic — these are just some of the things that we heard during the campaign that people are really concerned about. We do have some challenges ahead of us. And I'm looking forward to working toward solutions to those challenges."
Abbatiello added of Gunsallus, "Even though we disagreed and were at odds during the election, I want to thank Mr. Gunsallus for his service to the community over the last two years."
Gunsallus, whose term as president began in 2023, provided remarks before shaking hands with the rest of the council at the start of Monday's meeting.
"We haven't always agreed, but we've always shared the same goal: to do what's best for Easton," Gunsallus said. "And for that, I am proud."
"To the new council, I wish you nothing but success as you take on the important work ahead," he added. "May you lead with wisdom, listen with compassion and help Easton grow in a way that honors its past and embraces its future. I have every confidence that this town is in good hands."
Easton residents came out in droves to vote on election day, with over 3,200 ballots cast, a town record for a municipal election. All three races were contested, but Abbatiello and Rankin secured decisive victories (69% of votes each) in two-person races while Davis won comfortably (54%) in a three-person race.
After the swearing-in ceremony, Cook said she believes voters "sent a clear message."
"They want to see respect and civility restored," Cook said. "They want their local leaders focused and working together collaboratively to address the needs of our community."
Following the meeting, council members shared excitement for the work ahead of them.
"I applaud all three of you for how you ran your campaigns, and I am delightful at the outcome," said Ward 1 representative Maureen Curry, who endorsed Abbatiello. "And I am so looking forward to working with all of you."
Ward 3's David Montgomery, who made a somewhat surprising endorsement of Abbatiello during the campaign, said voters demonstrated a want for "integrity, openness (and) clarity."
"I am looking forward very much to the next two years of working on this council and working together cooperatively, in a friendly manner, with respect for each other, even when we don't necessarily agree on everything," Montgomery said.

title: Greensboro Historical Society building decision to be made June 5
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro Historical Society building decision to be made June 5

 May 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 471
 Words
