 GREENSBORO — At the Greensboro Town Council Meeting Thursday, the council decided that on June 5, they will make a decision on whether or not the historical society would keep its space.Town officials began discussing potentially moving the Greensboro Historical Society out of the Weaver Building in March. The move would free up space for other organizations and town agencies, but it would leave the historical society without a permanent home.
Though no decision was made Thursday, Councilman Joe Noon made it clear he feels the council and the town should make a decision very soon because the town needs the building.
"Mayor, council, this was already discussed," Noon said. "We said that we were going to ask them to leave at one meeting, then we come back, then we say, 'we don't know if we want them to leave or not.' We need our building back.
"Let's stop playing with the historic society, please. You already know that we all need the building back. Let's just come up with the date."
The council members elected to hold a public hearing at the June 5 meeting, then make a decision on the historical society after the public hearing.
Councilwoman Christina Robinson and Councilman Pete Brelia said they had met with Greensboro Historical Society President Charles Dean and discussed multiple relocation options for the historical society.
While Dean couldn't make it in person to Thursday's meeting, he told the Star Democrat that the he had a "pleasant exchange" with the council members.
"We had a pleasant exchange of ideas when we did meet," Dean said. "It was not adversarial at all, nor did I think it would be, so I just look forward to the June 5 hearing and hope that the public would turn out to support the Greensboro Historical Society."
Robinson and Brelia made points on different locations, but no location has been solidified and no final decision was made. The council members say they plan to continue to work towards a solution that would be best for both parties.
"We all value the historical society," Robinson said. "We are trying to keep it within the town limits. No final decision has been made, but we're all aware that something needs to be done, and we are working to try and work out a solution that works out for everybody."
Dean assures residents that the Greensboro Historical Society will not be dissolved and will work to find a location if moved.
"If they vote to remove us from the Weaver building, they're not dissolving the historical society," Dean said. "The Greensboro Historical Society will continue to exist. We will find a place for the collection even if the museum has to go dormant for some time, things will be in storage and eventually we'll find a better place and we will to continue to celebrate Greensboro's history at that point."

title: Dorchester County Council approves 2026 budget
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester County Council approves 2026 budget

 May 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 434
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DORCHESTER — After receiving community feedback over removing the tax differentials for Cambridge and Hurlock, the Dorchester County Council worked with each other, County Manager Jerry Jones and county staff to modify the proposed county budget.The differentials, which lower tax rates in the municipalities to account for duplicated services, remain intact in the fiscal year 2026 budget passed by the County Council Tuesday.
Rather than removing the differentials, the county made adjustments to its budget including deferring all nonprofit funding to a later time.
The county's real property tax rate will increase by 3 cents across the board, bringing the overall tax rate to $1.03 per $100 of assessed value. Cambridge residents will pay 95.67 cents per $100 of assessed value, and Hurlock residents will pay 94.79 cents per $100 of assessed value.
"We came up with a product. Is it the best product in the world? Heck no. But it will suit the needs of the people in the county," said council member William Nichols in reference to the budget.
As Nichols voted in favor of the budget bill, he made a point to explain to the community that this was the worst budget he has seen in the 30 years he's sat on the council. Nichols said that there have been no hidden agendas and that he appreciates all the feedback.
Council President Lenny Pfeffer is concerned the council will end up in the same position next year, with the state of Maryland expecting to reach a $6 billion deficit in the next two years if there are no significant changes.
Council member Rob Kramer agreed with Nichols, saying this was the worst budget he's seen in the 20 years in his seat, but "we made lemons out of lemonade."
Contention between the state capital and rural Maryland was brought up often. Kramer said he doesn't think Annapolis has any hope in rural Maryland, but at the same time, he doesn't have any hope in Annapolis.
Maryland Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) attended the meeting Tuesday, assuring residents they have a voice in Annapolis. Hutchinson echoed the sentiments of the council members, saying there's a major disconnect between what happens in the capital and what happens in the community.
"I just ask you, please, when you hear us talking about this stuff next year, please, I ask you to write letters, please make phone calls, please be as active as possible in your community to relay to Annapolis that Dorchester County cannot continue to take the economic hits it has been," Pfeffer said before opening up the floor for comments.
The budget bill will take effect on July 1.

title: Legacy Bricks honor military veterans, memorialize the fallen
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Legacy Bricks honor military veterans, memorialize the fallen

 May 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 961
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Memorial Day remembers U.S. servicemen and servicewomen who lost their lives defending this country's freedom and, as is the tradition, they will be honored during ceremonies at American Legions, VFWs, churches and so forth.At the North East Community Park, however, fallen servicemen and servicewomen are memorialized every day of the year — not just on Memorial Day. A spotlight also shines there on U.S. military veterans in general. That's because there is a flag-court-style monument comprised of bricks bearing the engraved names of those who made the supreme sacrifice, as well as of those who are veterans.
Dedicated last July 3 during the town's Salute to Cecil County Veterans ceremony and fireworks show, the monument at the base of a tall pole holding the U.S. flag and the MIA-POW banner is known as the Legacy Bricks Veterans Memorial.
"North East town leaders understand the importance of memorializing those who paid the ultimate price and of honoring those who served. Many of those bricks out there are in memory of those who lost their lives defending the United States. Other bricks honor those who served in the military. Every person who ever served in the military took an oath — I will risk my life defending this country," emphasized Gene Daley, who is commander of the North East Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW) Post 6027.
Daley, who served in the U.S. Army from 1986 through 1995, when he received his honorable discharge at the rank of staff sergeant, noted that North East VFW contributed one of the engraved bricks that make up the memorial.
"We have a brick out there for POWs-MIAs. They never returned from war and it's likely that most, if not all, are dead," said Daley, who is a 1985 North East High School graduate.
Of the more than 500 bricks cobbled together to create that special 320-square-foot area in the park, about 200 bricks already have been inscribed with names and other information about those servicemen and servicewomen who died while defending this country or about the military veterans. Each brick was bought for $75 by relatives of veterans and of those who lost their lives in service. They were purchased between November 2023 and January 2024 — the first ordering period.
About 40 engraved bricks were added recently, reflecting purchases made by families between November 2024 and January 2025, marking the second wave. Every year, during a two-month period that starts on Veterans Day in November and ends on New Year's Day in January, relatives of servicemen and servicewoman who paid the ultimate price or of military veterans can purchase legacy bricks to honor their loved ones.
There are approximately 250 blank bricks right now, and they serve as placeholders for future Legacy Brick purchases. Once ordered, the company engraves the requested message on a brick and ships it to North East. Then a blank, placeholder brick is removed from the monument and the inscribed brick is put in its place.
"This installation provides a lasting tribute to the men and women who have contributed to our nation's freedom. It covers every single major military conflict, dating back to World War I. Anytime we, as a town, can honor a legacy, it's a powerful thing," said North East Assistant Town Administrator Grant Handley.
North East Mayor Kelly Benson commented, "These Legacy Bricks honor those in our community who have made the most selfless sacrifice of servicing our country. It is a privilege to have this memorial in our community park."
Some of the inscribed bricks honor or memorialize servicemen and servicewoman who are or were Cecil County natives. Common information engraved on the bricks include name, branch of military, rank and duration of service and, when applicable, the conflict in which he or she served or in which he or she perished while serving.
"There also are personal messages on the Legacy Bricks, like, 'We miss you'," Handley said. "Some include cool nicknames, like 'Hell on Wheels', and the nicknames typically have something to do with the units that they served with."
The idea for a central monument in the park came about after Gold Star families had submitted plaques honoring their loved ones and asked the town to display them. Steve Riley, who works for Entech Engineering and is the town's contracted engineer, designed the Legacy Bricks Veterans Memorial.
"He did it for free, which was awesome. It was his way of contributing," Handley said.
The construction of the Legacy Bricks Veterans Memorial was included in a series of North East Community Park upgrades that totaled $343,828 and was covered by a combination of grants and other sources, such as the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA). The overall project included two sand volleyball courts, a horseshoe pit, renovation of public bathrooms, new playground equipment, exercise stations along the walking trail, new handicap-accessible sidewalks and ramps to easily access park pavilions.
Daley is thankful that he served in the Army, explaining, "It gave me the confidence to do things that I didn't think I could ever do. It gave discipline. The military gives you a way to conduct yourself in your life."
One of the bricks in that town park memorial bears the name of Daley's late father, Felix Daley, who served in the U.S. Navy for about 20 years, starting during World War II. That brick, reflecting Felix Daley's service to his country, is a point of pride for his son and for his other surviving relatives.
As for Memorial Day, Daley commented, "It is important that we remember those who gave their lives for our country. The surviving parents, husbands, wives, brothers, sisters and children will always feel that loss. Memorial Day is akin to the day when someone important to you dies. We must always remember them."
For more information on how to order a Legacy Brick, call 410-287-5801, ext 7106.

title: Police accountability legislation worked on by Caroline County Commissioners
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Police accountability legislation worked on by Caroline County Commissioners

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 470
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Tuesday, the Caroline County Commissioners conducted the second reading and public hearing for a legislative bill making changes to legislation defining the county's Police Accountability Board, Administrative Charging Committee and trial boards.The changes come after law enforcement agencies voiced confusion about how far the powers of these boards and committees extend.
"I will tell you in practice that (law enforcement agencies) have to work with the ACC. This has to be a partnership. This should not be a combative relationship," Executive Director of Police Training and Standards Commission Wayne Silver said.
The committees and boards were formed as a result of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, which aimed to create a system for evaluating and investigation complaints against law enforcement agencies.
The county implemented the accountability board, charging committee and trial boards when required by the state. But the exact duties and appearances of these boards are still being fine-tuned through the county's legislative processes.
Silver talked with the county commissioners about the trends seen in other counties and about how these counties implemented the boards and committees.
One of the questions presented by the commissioners asked about the subpoena power of the charging committee. Silver gave insight on how subpoena power should be implemented.
"To my knowledge, Caroline County is the only county to ever subpoena an officer," Silver said. "The ACC does not have subpoena authority... Our position on this, ladies and gentlemen, is that it is the law enforcement agency that would issue the subpoena if it was necessary."
In December, law enforcement officials from multiple counties gathered at a Caroline County Commissioners meeting, bringing concerns about an incident involving a Caroline County sheriff's deputy and its implications for police accountability practices throughout the state.
The deputy, who was not named, was investigated by the administrative charging committee about a harassment complaint. Committee members invited the deputy to meet with the committee regarding the complaint, a move considered by some sheriff's departments to be "not proper protocol" or an "overreach."
After a 40-minute conversation with Silver on Tuesday, the commissioners opened the public comment period for the legislative bill.
While no one spoke during the public comment period, the county received multiple letters from the Police Accountability Board and Administrative Charging Committee and a letter from Denton Chief of Police George Bacorn on behalf of other chiefs in Caroline County.
After discussion, some of the important changes made within the legislative bill establishing the roles and powers of the boards include:
Clarifying definitions and language and correcting grammar errors.Adjusting requirements of board members, including removing the three-year residency requirement and allowing members to attend meetings virtually. The commissioners will also appoint an alternate member of the Police Accountability Board.Removing subpoena language from the legislation. title: Talbot, Queen Anne's counties included on Trump's list of 'sanctuary jurisdictions'
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot, Queen Anne's counties included on Trump's list of 'sanctuary jurisdictions'

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 636
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot and Queen Anne's counties have been listed as "sanctuary jurisdictions" by the Trump administration, a label disputed by officials from both counties.President Donald Trump issued an executive order last month instructing DHS Secretary Kristi Noem to track the jurisdictions the administration considers to be defying the president's immigration crackdown efforts.
On Thursday, the Department of Homeland Security published a list of more than 500 jurisdictions across the country, stating that those jurisdictions are "defying federal immigration law."
Queen Anne's and Talbot officials challenged the claim Friday. In a statement, Queen Anne's County called the sanctuary designation "wholly inaccurate."
"Queen Anne's County has never adopted or endorsed sanctuary policies, nor have we enacted any ordinances or resolutions that would shield individuals in violation of federal immigration law," the statement read.
Talbot County said it received no communication from the federal government that it wasn't complying with federal immigration laws in advance of the list being published.
"We have, and will continue to, follow all applicable federal laws and have not taken any deliberate actions to obstruct their enforcement," a statement from a Talbot County spokesperson read.
"We welcome further information and guidance from the federal government so we can address any pertinent issues," the statement added.
The DHS website states that jurisdictions were designated "sanctuary" based on the following factors: "compliance with federal law enforcement, information restrictions, and legal protections for illegal aliens."
Noem said in a DHS press release about the list of jurisdictions that the department is "exposing these sanctuary politicians who harbor criminal illegal aliens and defy federal law."
"These sanctuary city politicians are endangering Americans and our law enforcement in order to protect violent criminal illegal aliens," Noem said.
As part of Trump's effort to label "sanctuary jurisdictions," federal agencies are directed to identify federal grants and contracts for potential "suspension or termination, as appropriate," per the president's executive order.
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said in an interview Friday he's concerned for the status of a federal grant that goes to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office. This year, the agency received $40,000 to increase patrol efforts in Trappe, a town without its own police department.
The grant — which is administered annually — has led to a number of arrests and reduced crime, Gamble said.
"We hope that we can reapply and renew that grant," he said.
Talbot County's inclusion on the list was a "total shock" to Gamble, who says his office has always complied with immigration agents. "They haven't asked us to do anything," he said. "We haven't said no to anything."
Gamble said he's spoken with the former and current Maryland ICE directors, both of whom indicated they are unsure of why Talbot County is listed.
Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann expressed similar sentiments. He said Friday he's not aware of any actions by his office or the county government that could lead to the sanctuary designation.
"This is continued misinformation that's been perpetuated now," Hofmann said. "I've heard this for a couple years, so it's of no surprise."
Under Trump, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, has ramped up agreements with local law enforcement agencies, referred to as 287(g) agreements, to carry out immigration crackdown efforts. ICE has signed nearly 700 of these agreements nationwide and seven in Maryland.
Neither Talbot County nor Queen Anne's County are currently engaged in 287(g) agreements. Hofmann and Gamble said since the sheriff's offices aren't in charge of the counties' jails, they can't enter into jail enforcement agreements with ICE like other Maryland counties have.
Hofmann noted the Queen Anne's sheriff's office was eligible for ICE's Secure Communities program, a separate and now defunct effort where local agencies submitted fingerprints of those arrested to the federal government. Fingerprints were cross-checked with immigration databases.
Hofmann added that since it ended, his office "hasn't changed on how we deal with criminals," emphasizing a "zero tolerance" approach.
The Associated Press contributed to this report.

title: Human remains found on farm during Cherrywood Solar construction
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Human remains found on farm during Cherrywood Solar construction

 June 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 316
 Words

 GREENSBORO — On May 20, while Cherrywood Solar workers were at Ronald Spearing Farm, human remains were found."They found that while they were conducting grading activities at the Spearing Farm on Bridgetown Road, and they immediately stopped work, secured the area and went to their plan," said Crystal Dadds, Caroline County director of planning and codes.
"Cherrywood has a plan when anytime they come across what's called an 'unanticipated discovery,' they made all the proper notifications contacting Public Service Commission, the Maryland Historical Trust, the sheriff's office, the state's attorney, the planning and code, the health officer, roped off the area, covered the area with tarps to protect it because we did have bad weather."
Cherrywood then brought in Search, an organization that has an archeological team to do a preliminary assessment of the area where they presumed remains were found.
The Search team then made a determination that there were human remains at the site. Five burial plots were discovered.
Cherrywood Solar brought the team back to do an ground-penetrating radar to see if there were any more potential burial sights. Once the final report from that test comes back, the Burial Sites Preservation Board in Caroline County will review that data and make a recommendation of what area needs to be protected.
Cherrywood Solar, produced by NextEra Energy Resources LLC, is a 145-megawatt project in Caroline County.
NextEra Energy Resources sent a press release to the Star Democrat Wednesday stating, "We are cooperating with Caroline County and other pertinent agencies on the investigation. Once we receive clearance from the relevant authorities, we will resume construction activities."
All parties involved believe that there was no foul play involved. They are believed to be human remains of family members from previous property owners.
"Given the fact that the house on this farm is a late 1800s house, most likely it was a family burial plot that could date back that far," Dadds said.

title: Talbot County to revisit removing DEI statement with airport's federal funding at risk
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County to revisit removing DEI statement with airport's federal funding at risk

 June 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 635
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council will revisit the prospect of removing its diversity, equity and inclusion statement amid concerns for Easton Airport's federal funding.Though voted down in March, a resolution to remove the diversity statement found in the county's employee handbook is on the agenda for Tuesday's council meeting. Its reappearance is fueled by a directive from U.S. Department of Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy that could put millions of dollars for an ongoing Easton Airport project at risk, council members say.
The diversity statement — created after the passage of a 2020 resolution — defines diversity, equity and inclusion, explains its purpose and details the county's approach to ensuring diversity. It also outlines how employees can report discrimination.
In an April 24 letter, Duffy outlined the department's interpretation of federal law, including regarding DEI.
"Whether or not described in neutral terms, any policy, program, or activity that is premised on a prohibited classification, including discriminatory policies or practices designed to achieve socalled 'diversity, equity, and inclusion,' or 'DEI,' goals, presumptively violates Federal law," Duffy wrote.
Duffy wrote that noncompliance with federal law or "failure to cooperate" with federal agencies "could lead to a loss of Federal funding from DOT."
Easton Airport's ongoing modernization project — which will relocate and expand the airport's main runway — is 90% funded by the Federal Aviation Administration, an organization within DOT. The airport is owned and operated by Talbot County.
The resolution to remove Talbot County's DEI statement was initially proposed by council member Dave Stepp in February. It elicited strong resident opposition, stirred two heated council meetings and split the five-member council.
The council rejected the statement's removal in March by a 3-2 vote: President Chuck Callahan joined Stepp, while Vice President Pete Lesher and council members Keasha Haythe and Lynn Mielke opposed.
But now, Stepp and Lesher are sponsoring the resolution's reappearance after working together to tweak it given the recent DOT directive. Lesher said he supports it "without enthusiasm."
"The two of us came together, knowing that we are coming at this from different points of view," Lesher said in an interview Monday.
They both say passing the resolution will protect essential federal funds for the Easton Airport's modernization project. Stepp said $46.8 million is at risk.
"I think that folks didn't think this was real prior," Stepp said of the funding risks. "And they certainly will now."
Lesher said he's confident the county isn't violating what the Trump administration and DOT are targeting. But merely having the DEI statement, he said, could lead to blowback from what he called a "capriciously" acting administration.
"Does this feel like extortion? Yes," Lesher said. "We have to choose our battles. And I believe that what we are giving up here is important for appearances, but it is not substantive. We are not changing any policies in Talbot County by issuing this new administrative resolution."
The two sponsors of Tuesday's resolution offered slightly different interpretations of what it will do if passed.
Lesher said it would supersede the 2020 resolution and either lead to the removal or revision of the DEI statement so that it doesn't "presumptively violate" Duffy's directive.
Council can't "un-direct" staff to create the statement, Lesher said. Instead, he said, the resolution serves as "fresh direction."
Stepp, meanwhile, indicated the measure would completely repeal the 2020 resolution and remove the DEI statement, which is how the resolution was initially presented when it failed.
"It was fiscal responsibility then, and it's fiscal responsibility now," Stepp said.
The updated resolution will be read aloud Tuesday and potentially voted on. Lesher and Stepp both say they expect it to pass.
"We cannot afford to put the airport funding at risk," Lesher said. "It just would leave us in the middle of a project. It would really leave us in a lurch."
The Talbot County Council meets at 5 p.m. Tuesday in the Talbot County Courthouse Bradley Meeting Room.

title: Talbot council, planning commission weigh in on controversial short-term rental restrictions
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot council, planning commission weigh in on controversial short-term rental restrictions

 June 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 567
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Planning Commission members are largely skeptical of proposals to increase regulations on short-term rentals in the county.During a joint workshop with the County Council on Tuesday, the commission reviewed legislation sponsored by council members Lynn Mielke and Pete Lesher. Planning Commission members said they struggled to understand why stricter rules for short-term rentals were necessary.
Commission Member Chip Councell said some of the proposed items are more of a "hindrance" than an improvement to the county's existing rules.
"I would almost support an easing of some of the restrictions more so than getting more stringent," Councell said. "I'm struggling to see this as a balance."
Mielke has previously said the legislation was drafted amid a "proliferation" of short-term rentals in Talbot County, noting her concerns for St. Michaels village communities such as Bentley Hay and Rio Vista.
Mielke said Tuesday that in village zones, some communities don't have covenants or restrictions on the temporary rentals. County attorney Patrick Thomas, who helped draft the legislation, noted it can be "tricky" to change covenants since many require 75 to 80% of homeowners to agree.
"They can be overwhelmed by short-term rentals, so the idea was to sort of make a distinction," Mielke said.
Mielke added that an increasing number of short-term rentals are "being scooped up by investors," which she says is hurting the county's affordable housing stock. Planning Commission members disagreed.
"I don't see where this is a proliferation," Councell said, citing that the number of licensed short-term rentals hasn't significantly increased or reached 200 in the last few years.
"They're taking them from subpar to show pieces for people to come down and enjoy," said commission chair James Corson. " … I don't think the majority of these are even in that range of affordable housing."
Some of the new restrictions if the legislation is passed would include: mandatory landlines; more detailed stay logs for license renewals; a seven-night minimum stay for lease holders in residential and village districts; and a split of licenses into two classes based on if the property is the applicant's primary residence.
As drafted, properties that aren't the applicant's primary residence would face new license limits: one license per 500 or 1,000 feet, depending on the zoning district.
The proposals have drawn support from a number of residents around the county but sharp criticism from short-term rental property agents and owners who view them as government overreach.
Property owners already must go through a review board to obtain or renew a license to operate a short-term rental. Most license requests are granted.
Corson raised qualms with how the proposed seven-night minimum stay could deter tourists from attending weekend events such as the Waterfowl Festival. Lesher acknowledged it's "largely a weekend business" and said he's comfortable keeping the current three-day minimum in place.
County Council member Dave Stepp weighed in against proposals for more detailed logs and required landlines.
"To have that legislation in there, it just doesn't make any sense," he said of the landlines.
No official changes were made to the draft regulations Tuesday. The commission will hold a public hearing and discuss the legislation at its July 2 meeting. A recommendation will then be made to the council, likely with significant revisions to the original proposals.
Planning Commission vice chair Michael Strannahan said the issue comes down to preserving the balance between economic benefits and maintaining the county's complexion.
"It's the old growth versus character thing we face all the time," Strannahan said.

title: Easton council maintains seafood odor ordinance, rejects amendment
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton council maintains seafood odor ordinance, rejects amendment

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 678
 Words

 EASTON — The Easton Town Council on Monday rejected a proposal to relax language in a seafood odor ordinance that has been a topic of contention between residents and a local business for much of the last year.In a 4-1 decision, with council member Maureen Curry the lone yes, the council voted down an amendment proposed to change the wording of the odor law that takes effect July 1.
The town's ordinance, passed back in December, is meant to address resident complaints of odor from Chesapeake Brand Seafood on Maryland Avenue, a crab processing facility near many homes. Per the ordinance, the business must install odor control technology and do so "in such a manner that no odor ... can be detected."
While attorney Zach Smith said Monday that an odor control system was recently installed, he appealed to the council to accept the amendment. Smith and Chesapeake Brand Seafood owner Mitch Hughes have said the "no odor" standard is unachievable, citing industry experts. They've expressed concern that once the ordinance goes into effect, further complaints could leave them out of compliance and force them to close the business.
Ward 2 representative Robert Rankin visited the business last week and said on one hand, he's "optimistic and hopeful" the new odor system will address the residents' complaints.
"On the other hand, it just being installed over the weekend, it doesn't give a lot of time to measure success," Rankin said.
Ward 4 representative the Rev. Elmer Davis said it's a "wait-and-see" approach. "We may have to look at our (original ordinance) and make sure that it has teeth," he said.
Ward 3's David Montgomery said he wished there was a more obvious correct decision. He said the focus will turn to town code enforcement on how future complaints or violations are dealt with.
During more than 40 minutes of public comment on the topic, multiple residents said the smell hasn't gone away since the system was installed. A Chesapeake Brand employee noted the system may take some time to be fully dialed in.
Those who spoke included family and friends of Hughes or local watermen. Some criticized the town for issuing the restrictions targeted toward Chesapeake Brand, a business that was legally permitted by the town and opened in 2019.
"There's been a negative portrayal of my cousin in the paper and on social media when in fact it should be the town that is to blame for all of this drama," said Kim Gibbons-Neff, Hughes' cousin.
"The town should have nipped this in the bud after the initial complaints and told the residents that the business is in compliance and they are doing nothing wrong," she added.
Local business owner Donna Bramble said the town could be losing trust with small businesses.
"As a business owner, how can small businesses trust the Town of Easton if you issue a permit, they put the expense in of starting their business, and then because there's a complaint, you force them to move?" Bramble asked. "And that's really what's happening. You're going to force Mitch to close up and move."
Peter Maloney, one of the residents who's led calls for reduced odor from the business, said residents don't have anything against Hughes or small businesses.
"They got a legal permit to be there. And that is a question you all need to ask, as to why that legal permit was given," Maloney said toward the council. "But that doesn't mean that they should be there."
Smith, the attorney, warned the council that its "authority here is not limitless."
"While the town can certainly adopt new standards to some extent, you can't adopt standards that are going to preclude him from continuing to operate his business," Smith said.
Following the public hearing and vote, council President Don Abbatiello said people on both sides made valid points and that it wasn't an easy decision to reject the business' amendment.
"But at the end, at least for myself, it's responsibility to represent the residents," Abbatiello said. "And my hope is that going forward, this mitigation process will work, and the facility will be able to stay there and be successful."

"It's quite gratifying," Donovan said after hearing the results. He said it was hard to tell if the news was good when he initially received the phone call from Oxford's Board of Elections Supervisors Tuesday night. "They're very matter of fact. They have a form they read to you, so you don't really know what the punch line is until the end."
Donovan will serve a three-year term as an Oxford commissioner.
The town's elections took a new shape this year, with the Board of Elections overseeing the process after residents voiced concerns over transparency.
The board instituted two new rules that chair Debbie Krolicki said went smoothly during Tuesday's voting process. Krolicki said residents now have to bring proof of domicile and identification, measures taken in order to prevent "temporary residents" who do not live in the town year-round from voting.
"About 95% of our voters have brought their IDs," Krolicki said. "They're very happy about our new process, but it's a new process."
According to Costigan, the past three elections have become increasingly "ugly" and contentious. "People should treat each other with a little bit of respect and a little bit of courtesy, you know?" he said Tuesday afternoon.
Donovan and Costigan both referenced separate "smear campaigns" that have spread throughout the town during campaigning.
"I was surprised that they waited until the last minute when they knew there was no opportunity for me to address it, which I thought was underhanded," Donovan said in reference to emails sent to town residents Sunday questioning Donovan's motivations.
Though tension was building between candidates, the atmosphere on Election Day was relatively light. The Board of Elections livestreamed the vote count inside the Oxford Community Services Building.
Resident Carol Griggs said she came out to vote in this election because of pressing issues at hand, particularly town finances and the Strand Beach project.
"You know, we need a little change here," she said. "We need things to move forward."
Griggs said this election has drawn more community attention than previous elections due to all the "hot button issues" at hand like town finances and the Strand project.
Costigan said he was disappointed with the results of the election and in some ways disappointed with the people of Oxford. "I've served in this town for 15 years, and they decided to bring on somebody new. I understand that, that's their choice," Costigan said.
Donovan will be sworn in as the new town commissioner on July 3. "Honest to God, I think this is a win for everybody in Oxford," he said. "There's still a small number of people that may be upset by this, but I also believe that those people are just as important to the outcome as anybody else in town, and I will represent them as if they voted for me. I hope that I can earn their trust."

title: 'Proven leader': Easton will soon welcome Kitzrow as new town manager
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Proven leader': Easton will soon welcome Kitzrow as new town manager

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After nearly a year without a permanent town manager, Easton will welcome Andy Kitzrow next month.Kitzrow, the current Salisbury city administrator, was tapped by Mayor Megan Cook to assume the post from Police Chief Alan Lowrey, the interim town manager since August. Kitzrow begins July 7.
During an interview in Salisbury last week, Kitzrow said he instantly noticed opportunity in Easton.
"The more I looked at Easton, the more I started to fall in love with where they're going," Kitzrow said.
The new town manager is Cook's most major appointment in her two years as mayor. Kitzrow will oversee town operations, lead department heads and town staff, and be a point of contact with the mayor and Town Council members.
After whittling down a list of around 12 semifinalists, the town conducted full-day interviews with four finalists. It was an intensive but worthwhile process, Cook said.
She felt Kitzrow rose above the others, as he was up to speed on what's happening in Easton and meshed well with her and with town employees.
"(Staff) really thought of the candidates, he could get up and running the fastest because he had the background of Maryland politics," Cook said.
Kitzrow, 42, served as Wicomico County recreation superintendent before becoming Salisbury's deputy city administrator in 2017 and city administrator in 2023.
In Salisbury, Kitzrow worked under three different mayors, including Jake Day, now the Department of Housing and Community Development secretary. Day noted Kitzrow's oversight of city permit and procurement operations as especially impactful.
"It's not easy work, but he's a proven leader," Day said of Kitzrow. "Somebody who can do it."
Cook says while the Day connection didn't factor into her decision, it will benefit Easton as the town tackles its own housing challenges and initiatives.
"Having that relationship, I think, is great. It's key," Kitzrow said. "A lot of this is about relationships, whether they are elected officials or state officials."
A BETTER FIT
Working under three different mayors, Kitzrow says he's experienced three very different visions.
In early 2023, Day left Salisbury with then-city administrator Julia Glanz to head up the state's housing and community development efforts. Jack Heath served as mayor until current Mayor Randy Taylor won an election later that year.
During Day's tenure, Salisbury undertook a number of efforts to redevelop its downtown through programs providing tax incentives to developers, such as "Here is Home" and HORIZON — the latter aimed at bringing multifamily residential and hotel units, an initiative which Kitzrow championed.
"(He was) the mastermind behind the HORIZON legislation that we passed locally," Glanz said.
Taylor and developers have clashed in recent months over the stalling of downtown projects, some of which were approved by former mayors and councils. In April, DelmarvaNow.com reported that developers of a downtown project filed a $40 million lawsuit against Salisbury and Taylor.
While Kitzrow believes the change in vision is OK and can be solved through compromise, he acknowledges it factored into his choice to accept the Easton post. Neither Taylor nor Heath could be reached for an interview.
"Professionally and personally, the town that Megan wants to run and her goals align more with what I value and what I want to be part of," Kitzrow said.
GOALS IN EASTON
Salisbury's population is nearly double Easton's, but Kitzrow sees similar challenges and opportunities in the two areas.
He said he wants to "move projects forward in a smart way." In Salisbury, he's dealt with a housing pipeline of around 5,000 units and led a focus on building "from the inside out." Easton's pipeline has recently hovered around 1,000 units.
Kitzrow is hoping to bring a focus to Easton's Rails to Trails network, given his parks and recreation background, as well as get "under the hood" in the human resources department.
Cook said she's excited to bring on a consistent leader during what she says has been a year full of change in town. "I'm looking forward to a steady ship ... and some calm seas ahead," Cook said.
Working for the mayor, Kitzrow emphasized that strong relationships with the Town Council will be crucial in completing the work that will make Easton a better place.
"We are working together, not against each other, and I think that's important," Kitzrow said.
Kitzrow will remain living in Salisbury with his wife and kids. He owns Escape Salisbury, a downtown escape room business.
But he's looking to learn as much about Easton as possible. He said he's especially excited to meet business owners, nonprofit leaders and community members in his first 60 days on the job.

title: Queen Anne's County eyes solar soil development fees
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's County eyes solar soil development fees

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 779
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In response to the Renewable Energy Certainty Act, Queen Anne's County Commissioners considered an emergency ordinance to give a semblance of control back to the county and try to reap soil development fees. It is a tactic no other jurisdiction has yet tried.On May 20, the General Assembly put forward and Gov. Wes Moore approved Senate Bill 931/Renewable Energy Certainty Act that address specific state siting requirements of solar energy generating systems, community solar energy generating systems, establishes siting and standards, and energy storage devices.
Taking effect July 1, this Senate bill establishes a (new, higher) 5% limit to the total acreage of the combined number of solar energy generating stations that may be approved for construction in the priority preservation areas.
It also gives the Public Service Commission the power to approve solar and energy storage projects that meet specific conditions, even if local jurisdictions object; aims to expedite the permitting process for solar projects; addresses the use of agricultural land for solar development, including provisions for priority preservation areas; and also includes some minor provisions for local (county) input on project design and implementation.
While complying with the new rules in Senate Bill 931, Queen Anne's County is now pushing the envelope to try and recoup money from the state permitting solar to be placed on county Class 1 soils, Commissioner Jack Wilson said.
According to Wilson, Queen Anne's County is seeking to impose an impact fee on soils used for development of solar through a per-acre financial contribution to be made to the county when solar energy generating stations and storage devices are developed on Class 1 soils.
The fee will be based on the rates used in the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation (MALPF) process, which is recognized by the state, according to Wilson.
"It's like if you were going to collect this and pay this for this land, we should be reimbursed at the same level," Wilson said.
With concerns for the Maryland Ag Land Preservation Fund not being supported by the state over the next few years, the proposed impact fee or Compensatory Preservation Contribution on solar generating systems and storage sites is a way to recoup money for further land preservation, Wilson said.
The contribution or soil impact fee will be based upon 50% of the fair market value appraisal as determined by the annual amount, according to Amy Moredock county planning and zoning director, and directed to the county Farmland Preservation Fund.
Senate Bill 931 differs from similar recent cannabis legislation because it doesn't let counties create additional use standards, Moredock said. This means the county must remove all existing utility-scale solar standards and definitions and apply new standards instead.
The Senate bill addresses community solar, which the county's ordinance did not have specific provisions for and also requires the county address energy storage siting, Moredock said.
Solar is permitted in Queen Anne's countryside, agricultural, and industrial zoning districts, according to Moredock.
The county code has kept solar out of mixed use zoning districts, and high and medium density residential zoning districts, she said.
In accordance with the law, Queen Anne's County was also able to prohibit solar in Tier One and Tier Two growth areas and surrounding growth areas often zoned agriculture. This would prohibit siting within areas that are slated for development and municipal growth, she said.
Donna Landis-Smith and Joe Pippin of Queen Anne's County Soil Conservation helped solidify a compensatory preservation contribution, a payment into the dedicated farmland preservation fund to assist with obtaining easements, Moredock said.
The law is written that the 5% applies to the definite article Priority Preservation Area and does not have a caveat as to when that calculation begins, Moredock said.
Easements already preserved are not included in the total Priority Preservation Area numbers, she said.
As listed in the 2022 Comprehensive Plan, the county has approximately 109,000 acres available for the 5% designated for solar, according to Moredock.
Of the 238,000 acres in the county, approximately 88% of it is zoned agricultural and ag use, according to Landis-Smith. At the time of the previous comprehensive plan, there were 83,684 acres preserved and since the adoption of the 2022 Comprehensive Plan, the county has preserved an additional almost 8,000 acres, Landis-Smith said.
The county currently has 1,100 acres in solar.
The commissioners have noted there is a good chance the impact fee proposal would get challenged, Wilson said.
Moredock credited the expertise of Queen Anne's County Geographical Information Systems Coordinators Sam Stanton and Tyler Pease for their understanding of land use to be able to present clear statistics.
The introduction of the ordinance will move forward to the planning commission for more discussion and a public hearing scheduled in two weeks.
The Queen Anne's County Commissioners will next meet July 8 at 5:30 p.m.

A new YMCA in Caroline County? Talks are starting on the topic

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners are moving to discuss building a new YMCA in Caroline County."I just make a comment, the YMCA, there's been a lot of discussion about the YMCA building a facility in Caroline County, and I think we need to start having a serious discussion with them about why they haven't," commission Vice President Larry Porter said. "I mean, they've built them all around us, and I think it's time to have have that discussion with Robbie Gill."
County Administrator Kathleen Freeman responded saying that she had talked to Gill, the CEO of the YMCA of the Chesapeake, the day before the meeting.
Freeman said that she and Gill discussed restarting conversations about bringing a new YMCA to Caroline County and they will continue to have discussions to make sure that it happens.
On Friday, Gill told the Star Democrat that the YMCA of Chesapeake has always had "a desire to build a full facility YMCA in Caroline County," conversations sizzled out after COVID-19 hit in 2020.
"Since then we've been blessed and fortunate enough to have opened new facilities in St. Michaels, Centerville and Chestertown," Gill said. "Even with all those wonderful things that have happened and tens of thousands of people that have benefited from it, Caroline County has still been a priority for us. We just haven't quite been able to put the pieces to the puzzle together, and so I'm excited that Kathleen and the commissioners have an interest in beginning those conversations again."
The current YMCA facility is an 11,000-square-foot storefront facility that is in Denton just off of state Route 404 in a shopping center. While the facility provides service to Caroline County residents a new facility would potentially look something like the new facilities built around the Mid-Shore.
"if you look at the YMCA that just opened at Centerville, it's a 70,000-square-foot facility serving a little over 7,000 people," Gill said. "...They're really built specifically to meet specific community needs."
The new facilities around the Mid-Shore have congregate meals daily for older residents in the community. To service the elderly, the YMCA partners with multiple groups around the community.
The new facilities include a six-lane pool with a shallow depth entry, allowing chances for swim classes for kids and adults. Another feature included is a double gymnasium with an indoor walking track, giving residents options for physical activity on cold and hot days.
Two other features includes multiple program open spaces and after-school care programs that will be beneficial for Caroline County Public Schools.
While their is no timeline on a new YMCA, Gill is happy that conversations have started again.

title: What they do doesn't always match what they say
author: DAVID REEL
content:
What they do doesn't always match what they say

 July 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 784
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following Richard Nixon's election as president in 1968, John Mitchell, Nixon's campaign manager, was asked by the media what to expect when Nixon assumed office.Mitchell said prophetically long before Watergate, "Watch what we do, not what we say."
Those words apply to many candidates for public office today.
The are at least two recent examples in Maryland.
Prior to leaving office after two terms, Republican Gov. Larry Hogan proclaimed he had no interest in running for an open U.S. Senate seat in Maryland formerly held by Ben Cardin.
Hogan went as far as saying his experience as a business executive and eight years serving as governor, left him reluctant to serve in a deeply divided legislative body marked by lengthy and often bitterly partisan dialogue and decision making.
Then in February 2024 Hogan entered the Senate race where he easily won the Republican nomination in a primary election but lost in the general election with 42.8% of votes cast.
In 2022, Wes Moore was elected as Hogan's Democratic successor with 64.5% of votes cast.
Almost immediately following his election Moore was widely viewed by political pundits in Maryland, Washington, D.C., and nationally as a potential presidential candidate in 2028.
To date, Moore has said early and often regularly he is not pursuing that goal.
Despite saying that, it has been most interesting watching media reports of what Moore has done in the political arena during his first term as governor.
Moore ...
Spoke at the 2024 Democratic National Convention.Campaigned for Kamala Harris in Pennsylvania, North Carolina and Michigan.Campaigned for Democratic candidates in Virginia.Appeared on The View where Joyce Behar told him he looked "very presidential."Interviewed with CNN following his college commencement speech in southeastern Pennsylvania.Attended an Aspen Colorado fundraiser hosted by Damian O'Doherty, a Maryland political operative and co-founder of Baltimore based KO Public Affairs.Shared his thoughts on "bold, purposeful leadership" on a podcast with the NBA's Golden State Warriors head coach Steve Kerr and CBS Evening News co-anchor John Dickerson.Delivered a keynote speech at the South Carolina Democratic Blue Palmetto Dinner.Attended a fish fry hosted by Congressman Jim Clyburn who is widely credited for a Joe Biden 2020 primary campaign resurgence when that campaign was stalled.Met with former political advisers to Barack Obama and Joe Biden to discuss a presidential path to the White House through South Carolina.Spoke to hundreds of political insiders in South Carolina about his personal biography and on his record as Maryland governor.Spoke at an NAACP "Fight for Freedom" dinner in Detroit, Michigan.Spoke at the Virginia Democratic Party's Blue Commonwealth Gala.Will attend The Sun Valley Conference in Idaho sponsored by private investment firm Allen & Company, which is branded by Fortune magazine as an annual "billionaire summer camp," that brings together business executives, social media titans, traditional news figures and elected officials who aspire to become president.
Ultimately, all this travel and schmoozing by Moore may be for naught.
Next year, Moore must win a Democratic primary election and a general election in Maryland.
Conventional wisdom that he will win both is far from a given.
In polling done earlier this year, Moore's job performance approval fell to 55% from 61% from polling done in the prior month.
These poll results occurred before Moore signed into law a wide range of tax increases, new taxes, fee increases and new fees that were approved in the 2025 general assembly session.
As I write this, Moore has an opponent in the 2026 Democratic primary and three potential opponents seeking a gubernatorial nomination in the 2026 Republican primary. He will have a Green Party candidate in the 2026 general election.
In the Democratic and Republican primaries there may be more candidates deciding to run.
One wild card in the Republican primary is former Governor Hogan.
Despite his failed U.S. Senate run, a survey done after Hogan's two terms as governor, showed he had a 77% job approval rating that included an 81% approval rating with Democratic voters.
Hogan has not yet announced his decision on seeking a third term which the state constitution allows since it would not be a third successive term.
Assuming Moore is the successful Democratic candidate for governor, there is also the hard political reality that not meeting expected vote totals in elections that any candidate is expected to win can be an insurmountable roadblock on a journey to the White House.
Preeminent Maryland political analyst Len Foxwell has observed: "What we have seen in the past where prospective gubernatorial candidates and prospective presidential candidates have been derailed because of weaker than expected showings back home."
Regardless of who is elected Maryland governor in 2026, voters in that election cycle and every election cycle in Maryland would be best served if there was no longer a regular mismatch between what some candidates of every party affiliation do and what they say.

title: Fate of Talbot's short-term rental proposals still up in the air
author: Konner Metz
content:
Fate of Talbot's short-term rental proposals still up in the air

 July 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 728
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The future of short-term rental legislation in Talbot County remains uncertain as the county's planning commission and elected officials have yet to find a middle ground.In an ongoing debate since May, Talbot County Council members Lynn Mielke and Pete Lesher are aiming to further regulate short-term rental properties in the county. But agents, owners and now county planners have indicated opposition to the proposals.
At its July 2 meeting, the Talbot County Planning Commission reviewed draft legislation line-by-line. Commission members delivered mixed thoughts on some of the rules, but for the most part, they provided negative reviews on changes they described as "onerous" and unnecessary.
And on a couple specifics, they discussed relaxing requirements instead of increasing them.
In an interview Tuesday, Mielke said it's clear the commission is "100% on the side of short-term rentals."
"Anybody who is affected negatively by short-term rentals doesn't have a voice," she said. "And those who are profiting from short-term rentals control."
The Planning Commission left written comment open on July 2, and it's unclear exactly when that body's amended version of the legislation will be officially sent to the council.
The commission's recommendation is likely to gut a number of the proposed regulations; however, the commission is only a recommending body in the matter, leaving the County Council with final say.
PROPOSED RULES
Proponents of the legislation, such as Mielke and some county residents, argue a proliferation of short-term rentals is hurting local communities, especially village zones. Opponents say the number of rentals hasn't significantly increased in the last few years and that changes aren't needed given a lack of formal complaints from neighbors.
As currently set up, property owners obtain short-term rental licenses from a review board. Once an initial license is approved, they must obtain renewal from the board one year later, then every two years.
Some of the new proposed restrictions include mandatory landlines, more detailed stay logs for license renewals, a seven-night minimum stay for lease holders in residential and village districts, and a split of licenses into two classes based on if the property is the applicant's primary residence.
As drafted, properties that aren't the applicant's primary residence would face new license limits: one license per 500 or 1,000 feet, depending on the zoning district.
Commission member Paul Spies said the class split is a "hard sell."
"I think the law as it is is fine," he said. "Two licenses, to me, doesn't make sense."
"It seems onerous on staff," Commission Chair James Corson said.
For renewal applicants, the proposed legislation lays out new logging requirements. Property owners would need to submit specific stay logs, including when the property was occupied by the owner or family members.
"I think that's a little bit too much of an overreach," Chip Councell said.
Mielke said the concerns around how much work will be put on staff and what would be asked of rental owners aren't totally valid. She said wording for the draft regulations was derived from Prince George's County.
"It had a basis," Mielke said, adding that for tax purposes, rental owners should already be documenting information that the new proposals would ask for.
The commission at times voiced that Talbot County's current short-term rental rules could be relaxed. Commission members said the council should make rental licenses transferable. Currently, new applications must be submitted if ownership of a property is transferred.
"The use hasn't changed. Zoning follows a land, it does not follow the owner," Councell said. "So it would seem to me that there would be a way that makes sense.
"I would say that a short-term rental license should be transferable" with conditions, he added.
Lesher and Mielke disagree.
"That's something that I don't support," Lesher said in an interview. "I think that who is running one of these matters, and that should not be automatic in the transfer and renewal."
Lesher said the council does pay attention to the commission's recommendation, and that with positive reviews of some smaller aspects of the proposals, there will be an update to the code no matter where some of the more major pieces land.
"I do think that something should pass here," Lesher said.
It's still unclear whether Mielke and Lesher's proposals will garner majority support from the council. Dave Stepp and Keasha Haythe both said they are waiting for the commission's official recommendation and further discussion.
Council President Chuck Callahan says he hopes to take the recommendations into account while coming "to a compromise" with all council members.

title: Oxford's Strand Beach frustrations grow as fencing is erected
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Oxford's Strand Beach frustrations grow as fencing is erected

 July 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 455
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — The Strand Beach project has sparked controversy within Oxford since its inception in 2018. Now, a new town manager, a recently elected commissioner and highly invested residents are taking it upon themselves to assess where the project stands.At Tuesday evening's meeting, Oxford commissioner Dave Donovan used his time during the commissioner comment period to say, "I'd hate for a meeting to go by and not talk about the Strand."
Residents sat up a bit straighter and were excited to hear this.
Recently, protective fencing was erected all over the Strand Beach.
"I mean, my god, what an eyesore," Donovan said.
In order for the town to be in compliance with the Maryland Department of Environment, 85% of the Strand must be covered by marsh and vegetation — as seen from an aerial view — for five years.
The protective fencing, which signifies where the marsh and vegetation will go, covers a large portion of the former beach area.
"I think that's a huge change for people to accept because those used to be beach areas," Commission President Katrina Greer said.
Donovan asked if it would be expensive to take the fencing down, and Greer said it would. "It's $25,000, believe it or not," she said.
The fencing will potentially be up for seasons, but commissioners said they hope that will not be the case. Greer said the fencing helps the plants take hold and without it, they could be installing thousands of plants each year.
"It's the project that keeps giving," Greer said, sarcastically.
The town has been urging the Strand Project's contractor, Underwood and Associates, to complete the living shoreline for several months. On Tuesday, commissioners discussed changing contractors from Underwood and Associates, which the town still has the power to do at this stage of the project.
During the open comments period, resident Jan Greenhawk suggested that the town sue Underwood and Associates.
"I'm going to be short and sweet. I know you're going to closed session and you're going to talk about legal issues," Greenhawk said. "I'm going to give you an opinion, and I think a lot of people in town might agree with this: We need to seek legal action against this contractor. I think he pulled a fast one on the town of Oxford."
Underwood and Associates was unable to comment on the situation before The Star Democrat's deadline.
Currently, there is no ADA accessibility at the Strand Beach and the little walking room there is on the street is consumed by an 80-inch standing puddle.
"(The standing water) has been an outstanding problem for this project for years, and years and years," Donovan said.
There will be an update on the Strand's stormwater issues at the next meeting, which will take place Aug. 12 at 6 p.m. at 101 Market Street.

author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
From crushes to banning cell phones — Maryland lawmakers propose new legislation covering range of issues

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 636

 ANNAPOLIS – Maryland state senators and delegates have introduced a variety of bills in the 2024 legislative session, addressing issues ranging from state symbols and education mandates to law enforcement policy and budget concerns.State Symbols and Utility Regulations
State Sen. Steve Hershey (R-36) has introduced Senate Bill 562, which would designate the original Maryland Orange Crush as the state cocktail. The bill is co-sponsored by Sens. Johnny Mautz (R-37) and Mary Beth Carozza (R-38).
Hershey also sponsored Senate Bill 561, which, along with House Bill 227 sponsored by Del. Chris Adams (R-37B), would allow electric cooperatives to use unclaimed funds only to assist cooperative members or donate to nonprofit organizations, rather than treating them as abandoned property.
Additionally, Hershey introduced Senate Bill 355, seeking to delay the implementation of the Family and Medical Leave Insurance Program by two years.
Energy and Education Legislation
Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-36) is behind two bills on solar energy regulation: House Bill 739 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 478) and House Bill 742. One bill would prohibit the use of eminent domain for solar siting, while the other would return control over solar development to county governments.
Ghrist also introduced House Bill 736, which seeks to remove the mandate requiring local school systems to offer pre-kindergarten for three-year-olds. Another provision in the bill would increase state funding to help Kent County construct a new middle school.
On law enforcement, Ghrist is supporting a bill — potentially House Bill 122 — that would require the removal of unfounded complaints from police personnel files.
Nursing, Historic Preservation, and Cemetery Protections
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-37B) has proposed House Bill 602 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 407), directing the State Board of Nursing to negotiate reciprocity agreements with neighboring states for advanced practice nursing licensure. Another measure, House Bill 616 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 421), would extend the statute of limitations for crimes related to cemetery destruction and prohibit damaging cemetery landscaping. The bill is co-sponsored by Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-37A).
Hutchinson is also behind House Bill 760, which would establish a local appeals process for Maryland Historic Trust decisions.
Budget Deficit Shifts to Counties
Gov. Wes Moore's proposed budget shifts some of the state's structural deficit onto county governments. Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-36) criticized the move, stating that counties did not contribute to the deficit but are now being forced to compensate for state overspending.
"For my district, $720,000 will be shifted to Caroline County on top of an additional $1.8 million more that the county will have to add to education under Kirwan mandates," Ghrist stated. He cited similar financial burdens for other Eastern Shore counties, including Cecil, Kent, and Queen Anne's.
"This will stifle economic growth because people will be sending more of their hard-earned money to the government rather than spending it in their local economies," Ghrist added.
Law Enforcement and Traffic Stop Restrictions
A controversial proposal, Senate Bill 292, has drawn strong opposition from law enforcement officials, including Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker. The bill would reclassify certain primary traffic offenses as secondary offenses, preventing law enforcement from stopping drivers solely for those violations.
"These minor traffic violations could actually lead to catching suspects that have committed serious felonies, recovering firearms, and stopping drug-related crimes," Baker said. A hearing on the bill is scheduled before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
Other Bills of Local Interest
House Bill 28, sponsored by Del. Josh Bouchat (R-5), proposes a constitutional amendment requiring all Maryland counties to adopt a charter government structure.
House Bill 278, also from Bouchat, would provide an income tax subtraction modification for enhanced agricultural management equipment to support sustainable farming practices.
House Bill 192, introduced by Del. Nino Mangione (R-42A), aims to curb student cell phone use in schools under the proposed "No Distracted Learning Act."
As these bills move through the legislature, local officials and residents will have the opportunity to voice their support or concerns during committee hearings and public forums.

title: 'Only going to get worse': Talbot officials discuss rise in senior homelessness
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Only going to get worse': Talbot officials discuss rise in senior homelessness

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: News 
 
 648
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County officials and senior care leaders met Tuesday to discuss creating a task force to address senior homelessness, a rapidly accelerating problem, experts say.The request for the task force comes from Talbot County Council member Lynn Mielke. Based on council feedback, a resolution to create the task force seems poised for approval at the council's Aug. 12 meeting.
Members of the county's Commission on Aging and other health and housing experts spoke on mounting challenges faced by area seniors, from housing costs and food insecurity to mental health struggles.
Rachel Smith, chair of the aging commission, said a task force would help align local nonprofits, county boards and the health department. There's currently a "disconnect," she said.
"There isn't anybody who is behind all of these organizations pushing to keep everybody connected," Smith said. "And that's what we found is one of the biggest problems. We have all these organizations out here that are doing so much great work, but then we've got to figure out a way to connect so we can help all these people."
Mielke said there's no single solution to help the homeless senior population.
"Each agency would bring solutions or suggestions, but not one agency can deal with all of the issues," Mielke said.
As drafted, the senior citizens task force would consist of representatives from the following entities: Commission on Aging, Delmarva Community Services, Talbot Interfaith Shelter, Neighborhood Service Center, Talbot County Health Department, Easton Town Council and County Council. Members from Mid-Shore Behavioral Health and law enforcement agencies may also be added based on Tuesday's discussions.
The task force would make recommendations to the County Council on housing, transportation and meal services for homeless seniors.
Homelessness is growing
Julie Lowe, executive director of Talbot Interfaith Shelter, cited jumps in calls from seniors as evidence that homelessness is on the rise.
In 2023, the shelter received 15 calls from men 55 and older and 14 calls from women 55 and older. One year later, those marks increased to 30 and 23, respectively.
This year, the Easton-based shelter has already received 19 calls from men and 13 calls from women in that age range.
Talbot Interfaith has limited capacity, Lowe said. It runs a multi-year program to transition people into paying for partial rent before moving out on their own. But even when shelter residents move out, Lowe said finding a financially viable apartment in the area isn't an easy task, especially for seniors who can't work.
"Most of the people who we work with will never get to that point with the market-rate housing and where it is now," Lowe said.
Lee Newcomb, a Talbot County social worker for 26 years and the aging commission's secretary, said she's never seen senior need at such a high level.
Newcomb said the Days Inn in Easton is home to many unhoused individuals. Smith said seniors especially suffer in the winter months since Talbot County doesn't have a low-barrier homeless shelter.
Smith noted an incident at the Days Inn last December as a wake-up call. According to police, an unhoused man who was living in the woods behind the hotel was found dead on Dec. 14, 2024.
"I feel like we missed something there," Smith said. "We shouldn't have our senior residents — some of them have worked in our community — die."
Cambridge-based Delmarva Community Services has served many homeless people from Talbot County down in Dorchester, according to president and CEO Andy Hollis.
Hollis said a low-barrier, overnight shelter is a gap in Talbot County, and something that a task force could work on. Many others at the meeting on Tuesday emphasized the need for a physical location to consolidate services for the senior homeless population.
'We don't have this issue in Talbot,' we thought for so long," Hollis said. "And we truly do. It's something that is long overdue in terms of being addressed."
"The challenge is not leveling out and it's only going to get worse," he added.

title: Talbot's cannabis regulations draw mixed reviews from residents, operators
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot's cannabis regulations draw mixed reviews from residents, operators

 August 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: News 
 
 678

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA — Debate over how strict Talbot County should be on cannabis operations has peaked in recent weeks, especially among Cordova residents.Last month, the county began to consider draft cannabis legislation focused on growing and processing operations. As originally written, such businesses would be barred from locating within 500 feet of residential properties.
Two Talbot County residents who were awarded state licenses for cannabis operations spoke out against strict "no odor" requirements and the 500-foot mark in the draft rules. They asked the council to consider dropping the residential setback to 200 feet as they look to acquire property to locate their cannabis businesses, potentially in Cordova.
Many residents disagree.
"We knew we were going to have agricultural smells," Cordova resident Donna Albright said in an interview. "We were not expecting the continuous odor of marijuana."
Albright and others have lobbied the Talbot County Council to reject the 200-foot setback and keep the "no odor" requirement as initially drafted. Albright said at a county meeting last month that around 150 residents signed onto a petition against any amendments relaxing the setback.
Some have objected to cannabis operations as a whole.
"I have grandchildren that come over, and I would like them to not have to look at this," Cordova resident Perry Davidson said at a July 22 meeting. "So I would ask you not to let something like this happen in Talbot County. It's just not a great idea."
Recreational cannabis use was legalized in 2023 in Maryland. Talbot County's legislation comes as neighboring jurisdictions have enacted regulations on growing and processing operations. The County Council is eligible to vote on the cannabis legislation at its Aug. 12 meeting.
Discussion on cannabis among Cordova residents largely began online and at county meetings after a cultivation license holder, Lori Yates, said at a July 8 meeting that she was potentially working on acquiring the Triple Creek Winery property.
The winery, now closed, is located on Three Bridge Branch Road in Cordova. An owner of the property did not respond to a request for comment.
Yates said in an email Thursday that her entity, Hanson Street Partners LLC, prefers to locate somewhere in Talbot County and plans to acquire property by the end of the year.
She wrote that a 500-foot setback is "quite burdensome," citing the fact that other jurisdictions use 200-foot marks for cannabis operations.
Yates says her motivation to open a cannabis site comes from her experience as a cancer survivor. She pointed out cannabis' use by cancer patients.
"Recreational use has gained increasing cultural acceptance and has shown itself to be less dangerous than alcohol consumption," Yates wrote.
For the residents opposed, the location of Chapel District Elementary School in comparison to the winery raised qualms. Albright also shared worries about groundwater contamination due to high water use.
Albright said she's not against cannabis use, but that "our biggest thing is about processing in our front yard." Speaking to the County Council last month, Albright asked that the county keep the "no odor" language.
"We are deathly opposed to the continuous odor," she said.
Zac Hopkins, co-founder of Lady Grace LLC, the county's other license holder for processing, said he's reviewed more than 10 potential sites in Talbot County.
"Unfortunately, if the current draft cannabis legislation is enacted as written, every one of these properties would be deemed noncompliant; effectively preventing the production of this Maryland state-certified agricultural product within our county," Hopkins wrote in an email.
While over 100 people signed onto the petition against reducing the setback, some Cordova residents have expressed their support for vetted cannabis operations.
"I know that these facilities are run clean," longtime Cordova resident Sylvia Carroll said in an interview. "They don't destroy the environment."
Carroll acknowledged that "the further away from a residence, the better." But she added that she sees much of the opposition coming from misunderstandings about the prospective operations.
"I've lived through the chicken factory and I've lived through the manure spreading and chicken houses being emptied," Carroll said. "I think people just aren't really informed as to what it is. I think they think they're just going to be selling drugs out the back door."

title: Sheriff's Office will absorb Federalsburg Police Department, Town Council says
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Sheriff's Office will absorb Federalsburg Police Department, Town Council says

 August 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 405
