 FEDERALSBURG — While an agreement has not yet been signed, Federalsburg officials said the Caroline County Sheriff's Office will absorb the Federalsburg Police Department, taking over policing duties for the town.The Town Council had yet to work out the exact details of a memorandum of understanding with the Sheriff's Office at the town's meeting Monday evening. The council did not vote on the matter, but they indicated they planned to sign an agreement for one year of policing services.
According to council member Brandy James, all Federalsburg Police Department staff will move to the Caroline County Sheriff's Office when the agreement is signed. The Sheriff's Office will use the current Federalsburg Police Department as a substation.
The decision comes as the town tries to tackle $5 million in debt.
James said the police department takes up half of the town's budget. At Federalsburg Public Forum on July 21, council member Ian Furgerson said if the town were to sign an MOU with the Sheriff's Office, it would save the town between $300,000 and $500,000 per year.
Multiple items in the MOU are still being discussed, but the current draft includes five deputies to be assigned to the town. Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan made it clear to the public the MOU is still a work-in-progress, and the number of officers has not been confirmed.
"I also want to add that while there's been discussions about the number of officers to include in an MOU, there will be an MOU once it's kind of ironed out and reviewed and everything on a Federalsburg agenda, and there will be a public hearing on it," Ryan said.
"The decision has not been made as of now. I think that's the direction that they're going, but there still will be an actual agreement on an agenda for a public comment and a vote."
James said this is the best decision for the town and the officers.
"It actually giving these officers what they so much needed, which is increase in salary," James said. "They get access to le-ops, they get more than what we as a town can provide to them. Police and is very competitive, and Federalsburg is one of the lowest paid agencies. So we felt as we wanted to give this MOU situation a try for a year, and throughout that year we want to have quarterly meetings with the public."
The MOU will have a public hearing at a future Federalsburg Town Council meeting.

title: Easton Town Council speaks out on increased ICE activity
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Easton Town Council speaks out on increased ICE activity

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 727
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Councilmember David Montgomery led the prayer at Monday's Easton Town Council Meeting, during which he asked for God to watch over Pastor Daniel Fuentes Espinal.This was the first of many mentions of Espinal, who has been detained by U.S. Customs and Immigration Enforcement since July 21.
"We pray especially for Daniel Fuentes Espinal. Watch over him during his trials, and return him to his family, if that is your will," Montgomery said.
Espinal came to Easton in 2001 on a six-month visa. He has been pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015.
Espinal was detained by two ICE agents in Easton and taken to ICE's Salisbury Field Office on July 21, according to his daughter.
He was quickly transferred to the Baltimore ICE detention center, where he remained for three nights. That Thursday, Espinal was transferred to an ICE detention center in Louisiana, where he will stay until his hearing, which has not been scheduled yet.
The comments at Monday's meeting came amid increased ICE presence in the town.
"ICE was here today and made some arrests. I mean, it seems like they're here more often than ever," Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis said.
Michele Dappert, president of the Talbot County Democratic Forum, said the forum learned of what she believes could be dozens of immigration arrests early this week through both word-of-mouth and corroborating photos and videos. An exact number could not be provided.
The Rev. John Nash from Sts. Peter and Paul said one member of the church's Spanish-speaking congregation was "abducted" Tuesday.
"She was abducted some time this morning, and she's not permitted to call anyone, so nobody knows where she is," Nash said. "They're going after these poor innocent folks who are just trying to make a living."
Easton Police Capt. Greg Wright confirmed that the department was aware of ICE activity in the town on Monday, though the department was not involved in any arrests and could not provide specific details.
Easton resident Emily Stone, who spoke to the council Monday, wanted to know if the police department has a formal agreement with ICE and if the Town Council had taken any actions to get Espinal home.
"I, in particular, want to learn more about how the arrest of Rev. Espinal is being handled by the Town Council and if you have made any requests to our state representative, Andy Harris, to learn more about his well-being or his location," Stone said.
Wright responded, saying the police department has no interaction with ICE nor does it have a formal agreement. They usually are not notified about ICE operations or apprehensions in Easton because ICE is a federal program.
While the town has taken no formal actions on behalf of Espinal, every council member used a portion of their comment period Monday to speak about the effects of the recent ICE arrests on the community.
Councilmember Maureen Curry said she is "distraught" over the detention of Espinal as the daughter of an immigrant herself.
"We are a nation of immigrants, and in my opinion, and it is just my opinion, this administration has turned their backs on the hardworking, honest people like my father that came to this country to make a better life for themselves and their families," Curry said. "Pastor Espinal has been a pillar of our community for nearly 24 years, and his family and his congregation are devastated by his detention."
Council President Don Abbatiello ended the meeting by encouraging concerned residents to reach out to Congressman Andy Harris (R-Md.) and Sens. Angela Alsobrooks (D-Md.) and Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.).
"There is ultimately something wrong with a system where Pastor Espinal and other residents are picked up for what amounts to misdemeanors in civil violations and placed in holding cells far from their loved ones," Abbatiello said. "The way the law is written and enforced right now, this is what happens."
In a statement to The Star Democrat Tuesday evening, Harris said he is "aware of the case and believe(s) it's important to fully understand the details before drawing conclusions."
"We are trying to determine what leeway the Secretary of Homeland Security has in granting exceptions to deportation orders," Harris said. "That said, the Trump administration has been clear: individuals who are in the country illegally should self-deport and follow the proper, legal process to return."
Reporter Konner Mets contributed to this article.
This report has been updated to include comment from Rep. Andy Harris.

title: Move-in date for Doverbrook Apartments uncertain due to snag with HUD
author: Konner Metz
content:
Move-in date for Doverbrook Apartments uncertain due to snag with HUD

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 614
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Doverbrook Apartments, rebuilt and seemingly ready to welcome in residents, have spent all summer empty due to a snag between the Housing Commission of Talbot and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.Run by the housing commission, the 64-unit, voucher-based complex celebrated a renovation this spring, adding 14 apartments to accommodate more low-income tenants. It opened its doors to town, county and state officials for tours upon completion.
But move-in for residents has been delayed since May.
Easton Town Council members expressed concerns earlier this month about the delay, pointing out how it has and will continue to create confusion for residents.
"You're gonna have a lot of people who ride by those buildings, and say, 'What in the world is going on?'" said Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis, whose ward includes Doverbrook, at an Aug. 4 town meeting.
Don Bibb, the Housing Commission's executive director, fielded questions from the council on the matter.
Bibb said the mounting holdups stem from HUD's requirement that the complex's housing choice voucher plan undergo a 45-day public comment period and be advertised in a newspaper. The plan, available for public review in Easton's town office, outlines the complex's occupancy guidelines and priority and waitlist rules, among other things.
Bibb said the commission made slight changes to the plan, such as clarifying which residents are given priority. HUD determined the changes necessitated a reset of the 45-day comment period.
"We dispute that point," Bibb said at the Aug. 4 meeting. He said a waiver request has been submitted to the federal agency.
HUD did not respond to a request for comment Tuesday.
The apartments were closed in December 2023 for renovation. Returning residents, who have been temporarily housed by the commission in St. Michaels, will have priority. In April, 145 people applied to be put on the Doverbrook waitlist, Bibb said last week.
Davis said in an interview Tuesday that the situation is a "sad state of affairs."
The council member has spoken to residents who have sent in applications, and he said their excitement to move into the new apartments has dwindled with the significant delay.
Residents must meet income standards and qualify for the housing vouchers to have their applications approved for the voucher-based complex. Davis is concerned the holdup could put some at a disadvantage.
"What if a person was good in May and may not be good in August or September?" Davis said. "They won't be able to get an apartment, and I don't think that's fair."
Bibb said in an interview last month that rumors spurred by the delay, such as site contractors not getting paid, are false.
Amid swirling speculation, Bibb said the commission would like to get the ball rolling, but he maintained that the commission would continue to honor HUD's needs.
"We're losing revenue. That's not a good thing," Bibb said on July 25. "But it is what it is. Compliance with federal government is a critical point for any type of project like this."
At the time, Bibb said the hope was for most of the units to be occupied by the end of August. But at last week's Town Council meeting, it seemed that target would be moving back.
Bibb told the council that if the waiver request isn't approved, the updated housing choice voucher plan for Doverbrook Apartments was set to go live Aug. 7. That would make Sept. 21 or 22 the worst-case scenario dates for move-in to begin, he said.
Davis said he hopes such delays can be prevented in the future. He acknowledged that the renovated apartments themselves are impressive.
"I think (last week's) discussion brought a lot of enlightenment," Davis said on Tuesday. " ... There were still a lot of questions that were left on the table."

title: Talbot County's cannabis bill fails, goes 'back to the drawing board'
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County's cannabis bill fails, goes 'back to the drawing board'

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A zoning bill for cannabis facilities in Talbot County failed to pass Tuesday after months of consideration, sending the County Council back to square one.Since recreational cannabis was legalized in Maryland in 2023, local jurisdictions have been tasked with creating zoning regulations for different types of cannabis operations. Talbot County planners have worked nearly a year on drafting a cannabis processing and growing bill, outlining rules on setbacks from homes, odor mitigation and more.
On Tuesday, council members voted down two proposed amendments to the cannabis bill and, eventually, the bill itself. Opposition from council President Chuck Callahan and member Lynn Mielke, along with abstentions from Keasha Haythe (and, in one instance, Dave Stepp), combined to defeat the legislation. Vice President Pete Lesher and Stepp supported the amendments, while Lesher was the sole yes vote on the unamended bill.
Lesher told The Star Democrat that he didn't expect the bill to fail. He believes without it, the county in a tricky spot.
"I think we find ourselves in an interesting position figuring out what the course forward is on regulating cannabis," Lesher said during the meeting. "The state has told us that we must do so, and we now don't have a plan."
As drafted, the legislation would have required processors and growers to locate at least 500 feet away from residential lots, mitigate cannabis odors so nothing is "detectible from adjacent properties" and obtain site plan approval from the county.
Multiple state cannabis license holders had advocated for a reduced setback and lessened odor mitigation requirements, citing that they may not be able to successfully open in Talbot County without those changes. But those edits didn't appear in legislation on the table Tuesday.
Stepp offered an amendment to harden the 500-foot setback so it couldn't be reduced by way of an agreement between affected neighbors, though that failed with only Lesher's support.
Lesher offered an amendment to make permits for processors available only through special exception, as well as increase minimum lot size for growers and processors from 20 to 40 acres. Those changes were recommended by the county's Planning Commission, but only Stepp joined the vice president in supporting them.
Council members who voted no on the legislation cited varying reasons.
Haythe said in an interview after the meeting that she needs more information and has concerns about the effects of odor on children.
"We're gonna have to go back to the drawing board and come up with something," Haythe said. On Wednesday, Haythe said she's working with council and County Attorney Patrick Thomas on drafting a new bill.
In an interview, Stepp said there were "too many moving parts" with the legislation for it to pass. The residential setback should be closer to 1,000 feet, he said.
"I feel like it wasn't the best product that we could've put forward yet," Stepp said. While he still has "a hard time believing" recreational cannabis passed statewide, he acknowledged the county is in a position where it must create some sort of local zoning law.
Many residents have weighed in on the legislation. The matter gained traction in Cordova after a license holder said she was in talks to buy the now-closed Triple Creek Winery. Property owners haven't confirmed or denied if that's still a consideration.
Some residents raised worries that a cannabis business could locate too close to Chapel District Elementary School. Haythe echoed that sentiment.
"Children are a huge concern as it relates to the odor that's smelled, the air that's breathed in the areas where the growing and processing will be done," she said. "We just don't want that to affect the children at that school."
Callahan wrote to The Star Democrat that his concern is land value. "The community doesn't want this," he wrote on Wednesday.
WHAT'S NEXT
It's unclear exactly how soon legislation may return to the council's desk. Any significant changes may necessitate a return to the Planning Commission and potentially a council-commission work session. The council already met with commission members in September to draft the now-failed bill.
In the meantime, the county will operate without clear zoning on cannabis processing and growing facilities. At Tuesday's meeting, Lesher asked how staff will deal with potential permit applications from cannabis license holders looking to locate in Talbot County.
Bryce Yelton said he believes the county "might have to hold it" based on the fact that zoning legislation is under consideration. He deferred to Thomas, the county attorney, for a firmer answer.
Thomas said state law requires cannabis operations to comply with local zoning. Prospective cannabis operators may not be able to make progress in this current limbo period, he said.
"If the county were to take the position that cannabis does not fall under existing agricultural use, then it wouldn't be permitted as such under the zoning code," Thomas said. "So without this (bill), they wouldn't be able to go forward under that position."

title: Easton task force narrows list of recommended housing solutions
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton task force narrows list of recommended housing solutions

 August 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 650
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An 18-member group tasked with identifying solutions to address the Easton's affordable housing stock is honing in on which specific recommendations to send to Town Council.Last Thursday, 11 members of the Attainable Housing Task Force met to review a draft version of the task force's final report prepared by Miguel Salinas, the town's planning and zoning director.
They agreed on five main recommendations, which will be spelled out in an edited version of the draft and eventually presented to the Town Council at a joint workshop. Those recommendations include:
Zoning reform suggestions including removing limits for "missing middle" units such as townhomes, increasing maximum densities for some residential districts and adjusting dimensional standards and lot size requirements.A public-private partnership with a housing organization to build an affordable housing project on public land. Potential sites to include the old Talbot County Health Department and vacant county land near Magnolia Drive.Community education to help residents better understand the affordable housing issue.Make some fee exemptions for developers. A main recommendation is to create a Payment in Lieu of Taxes, or PILOT, program, which could provide a property tax break to developers building affordable units.Inclusionary zoning.
Many at the meeting said the task force's job is to lay out potential solutions to improve Easton's affordable housing conundrum. There is no "silver bullet" fix, said task force co-chair Michael Ports, also a member of the Planning Commission.
"These are all just little pieces to the puzzle," said Susie Hayward, director of government affairs for Mid-Shore Board of Realtors. "Not one area is gonna solve the problem. These are all just pieces to make it better."
DEBATE
Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery — who serves on the task force alongside Ward 2's Robert Rankin — raised most of the concerns on the recommendations.
Montgomery said the community outreach recommendation went out of bounds for town government duties. He asked for a "more neutral tone." The draft report indicated that the Town Council should consider a housing webpage and a "media initative to 'put a face' to the housing crisis."
"The part that I could never, ever support on this is a media campaign to provide a human face" to the issue of affordable housing, Montgomery said. " … I just don't think that's the role of government."
Others responded that it's needed to educate people on what exactly affordable housing is.
"It's important to define it for people to understand it because nobody does," task force member and realtor Jim Bent said.
Hayward added that people need to understand that affordable housing matters for "the survival of our businesses."
"They're surviving now without them," Montgomery responded. Hayward disagreed, citing a Talbot County Chamber of Commerce survey of business owners where they expressed concerns that "employees are tentative when they're living in other counties," she said.
At one point, Montgomery said the task force didn't have the proper time "to discuss the pros and cons" of the recommendations. It met 10 times in 2024, though draft recommendations weren't specifically discussed until the final five meetings.
Rankin suggested that when editing the report, Salinas include drawbacks to the recommendations. Ports said the pros and cons aspect was already written especially well by Salinas in the section recommending inclusionary zoning, which Ports believed "strengthened" the argument for inclusionary zoning.
Inclusionary zoning was a hot topic during the town's last election. A draft town ordinance requiring residential developers to allocate 15% of their units as affordable stalled out this winter.
Montgomery, a vocal opponent of the measure, said at the task force meeting that the body's recommendation should be less focused on the old draft ordinance and take a more general stance on inclusionary zoning.
Even if passed, Montgomery said, inclusionary zoning wouldn't immediately bring affordable housing units to Easton.
"That's right, that's why we should've passed it three years ago," Hayward responded. "That's why we gotta pass it today, for all the developments that are coming up in the next five years, 10 years."

 ST. MICHAELS — Dog park discussion continue in St. Michaels.At the Wednesday Commissioners of St. Michaels meeting, the commissioners announced that there will be special sessions in the future to discuss all things dog park and to pick a location that makes sense for all residents of the town.
While determining the master plan for San Domingo Creek Park construction, discussion arose about a dog park being included in the master plan. The commissioners decided not to include a dog park in the plan.

Residents voiced their opinions about where the dog park should or shouldn't be located.
The commissioners want to take into account multiple factors when decided the location of the dog park, including cost of building and maintenance, liability concerns, who is allowed to use the park and the less amount of people affected by the noise and traffic.
Town Manager Don Richardson, who started in the position earlier this year, has experience with creating a dog park in Easton.
"So I think we are actually a lot better off having somebody who has that experience and is able to ask the questions that we don't really know to ask quite yet," Hudson said.

title: Easton's food truck rules come under scrutiny
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton's food truck rules come under scrutiny

 August 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 677

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Residents and food truck owners are speaking out against Easton's rules on food trucks as the town has begun enforcing restrictions more closely.Trisha Wright and Daniel Reyes, owners of the Korean BBQ food truck T & D Fusions, say they had been setting up next to places like the Shore Medical Center and Kohl's before the crackdown this month.
Wright organized an online petition this week for the town to reconsider its limits on food trucks. As of Friday, it received over 3,000 signatures and widespread attention on social media.
"I just feel like we're being shafted because we're mobile," Wright said.
An ordinance on food trucks has been in effect since 2011. It states that mobile food businesses must operate in conjunction with an approved temporary use, such as a permitted festival or parade. Other town rules include:
Food trucks can operate on property owned by the food truck establishment itself, said Town Council President Don Abbatiello in an interview.Food trucks serving crews at active construction sites are exempt, per the 2011 ordinance.Food trucks can acquire a "transient business" license, per the
town charter
. Fees for the first two days are $500 each, and $150 for each day after up to a maximum 30 days.
Discourse online has especially centered on food trucks that had been setting up during lunch hours outside the hospital.
Food truck operators say they've heard from hospital employees who are upset the trucks are no longer there. Employees relied on them as an easy, accessible lunch option, said Mary Jo Flatten, owner of the lemonade bus Bravanson's Main Squeeze.
"They take care of us, so we should turn around and take care of them," Flatten said.
Shore Regional Health spokesperson Trena Williamson said in a statement the hospital complies with town zoning rules.
"We appreciate the interest from food truck vendors; the Town of Easton determines where they may operate and what zoning and permitting requirements they must follow," Williamson wrote.
The food truck debate is expected to come up at Monday's Town Council meeting. President Don Abbatiello said the council is considering both short- and long-term solutions.
"What we're gonna try to do is try to come up with something at the very least that would allow for food trucks to go back to the hospital area," Abbatiello said.
Further out, he believes there's a "desire on the council to have a real conversation" on the ordinance. Any major proposals will include ample time for public input, he said.
"We got to be fair to the restaurants and businesses that actually employ the folks that live here in town and pay taxes to help support town initiatives," Abbatiello said.
Abbatiello said he's unsure of exactly how consistently the town has enforced the 2011 ordinance. This summer, a restaurant raised the concern of food trucks operating in town limits, Abbatiello said. Town leaders declined to name the restaurant.
The recent enforcement has followed the "ordinance as it is written," Abbatiello said.
Wright said other areas have been more welcoming, such as Caroline County and Cambridge. But local food trucks are still pushing for change in Easton's regulations, she said.
"It does take effect on all of us, so we have to become one," Wright said. "We have to become stronger together."
As council members prepare to discuss the matter on Monday and food truck supporters organize to come out to the meeting, one local business is stepping in to fill the void.
KustomScapes & Pools owners Karen Glass and Jon Glass Sr. are scheduling a lineup of food trucks outside their business next week. The pool business sits off of Easton Parkway at the end of Route 662. Despite being surrounded by town land on all sides, the property itself is county land and not bound by Easton's food truck ordinance.
Karen Glass said they wanted to pull together as a community after hearing about the food truck controversy. They have trucks slated for almost every day next week and a coffee truck every other Friday, she said.
"This is what our community was built on," Jon Glass said. "The community supporting each other and small businesses supporting small businesses."

title: Ed Hale announces run for governor
author: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com
content:

 STEVENSVILLE — Clayton Mitchell, a Stevensville resident formerly of Kent County, is serving as an adviser to the gubernatorial campaign of Dundalk native and storied businessman Ed Hale Sr.Hale, previously a registered Democrat, declared his intention to run as a Republican in the upcoming election. Taking the podium at Canton Waterfront Park, he said his campaign would focus on public safety and education. His formal announcement came just three months after he informally declared his candidacy as a Democratic opponent to incumbent Gov. Wes Moore.
Hale, who formally announced his candidacy for the 2026 Maryland governor's race last week, has a complex resume.
According to a 2015 article in the Wall Street Journal, Hale disclosed that he worked covertly for the Central Intelligence Agency for nearly a decade during the 1990s and early 2000s. He said he allowed the CIA to create a fictitious company under his corporate umbrella to be used as cover for field operatives, and claimed he spoke with a CIA handler between 30 and 50 times a year. Hale reported traveling to Saudi Arabia, Poland, Denmark and Norway, among other places, providing the agency with economic reports upon his return. He also said he was involved in a canceled operation in Georgia in 1998 concerning the purchase of ships for intelligence purposes and played a role in the CIA's early search for Osama bin Laden by facilitating covert agent deployments across Central Asia. Hale said his role with the CIA ended after the Sept. 11 attacks.
In addition to his intelligence work, Hale founded First Mariner Bancorp before stepping down from an operational role in 2011. He also owns property in Easton.
Hale's roots run deep in southeastern Baltimore City and Baltimore County. He was born and raised in Dundalk and, according to previous Eagle coverage, chipped in money to help restore the wrought iron gates at Dundalk's Battle Monument Park in 2014 after a resident stole the previous structure to sell for scrap.
The businessman is also responsible for the development of Canton Tower, the 17-story waterfront structure that kicked off a wave of retail and housing growth in the area during the 2000s and 2010s.
While he has had a hand in Baltimore's development, Hale's pursuits extend beyond the city. He currently owns the Baltimore Blast soccer team.
His Republican candidacy, however, is already proving contentious.
In a press release published shortly after Hale's announcement, Maryland Senate Minority Leader Steve Hershey voiced concerns about the businessman's sudden platform switch.
"Just because he may no longer feel comfortable associating with the progressive wing of the Democratic Party doesn't mean he now embraces the Republican Party's long-standing principles of limited government, fiscal responsibility, individual liberty, and strong public safety," Hershey said.
"We've built a Republican movement in Maryland that stands for more than just opposition to the far left — it stands for authentic leadership and a clear governing philosophy," he continued. "Our voters expect more than opportunism — they expect commitment."
Others, like county council candidate Tim Fazenbaker, have aligned themselves with Hale. In a recent interview, Fazenbaker said that he and Hale, both natives of the greater Dundalk area, are planning a joint tour of Dundalk in the coming months.
Mitchell is an attorney and former chairman of the Board of Appeals at Maryland Department of Labor.
Editor Hannah Combs contributed to this article.

 BETTERTON — For the past two Saturday afternoons, residents living near Betterton held informal meetings discussing Halo Betterton Solar LLC.Halo Betterton LLC had submitted an application in April for a 5-megawatt solar project on a 30-acre site at Howell Point Road and Still Pond-Betterton Road which, if built, will be directly across from some of these neighbors.
As brought up in previous council meetings, the town is opposed to the project because the company's plans do not fit with Betterton's comprehensive plan. It takes away any potential to have commercial development in that area.
The informal meetings were conducted by Paul Falcon and Kathryn Klvana at 13959 Still Pond Road and then at the Betterton Volunteer Firehouse, and drew out other neighbors who would be affected by building the installation.
The second meeting that took place at the firehouse was well-attended and included Mayor Donald Sutton, council member Gerry Werner, longtime residents and people passionate about this cause coming from other Maryland regions affected by these facilities.
Sutton said it is good to see so many people come out and express their concerns.
Residents raised multiple objections to the proposed solar installation during the meetings.
Douglas Cregar said his group has researched the project extensively and opposes the installation.
"We've done our research and are against this solar installation here," Cregar said. "Studies show that everyone within a mile will lose 5% in property value. Also, among 35 active solar proposals in Maryland, there is no location like the Betterton area they plan to build on, that is surrounded by residential housing on three sides."
Art Pleasanton raised concerns about emergency services, noting the proposed site would interfere with helicopter medical evacuations.
"If (solar) is built where they want to build it they'd have to do it over a helicopter landing zone," Pleasanton said. "The next nearest one is at Worton at the school. For anyone who thinks this is not an issue, last year a little girl was saved from drowning because we had a way to get her out fast."
Kathryn Klvana expressed frustration with recent state legislation that could override local zoning decisions.
"I'm shocked that with this new law Governor Wes Moore just signed, the state can override local zoning and put this huge solar farm across from our homes," Klvana said. "We moved to this beautiful place to retire. We're zoned community residential. What about our rights?"
Tracy Cameransi, who lives in a small area just outside of town, said she frequently receives calls from solar companies but will not sell to them. She is opening her home for residents to attend the upcoming virtual hearing together.
"We have a small area just outside of town and we get calls all the time from these solar companies," Cameransi said. "We will never sell to them, but what we are doing is opening up our home on Sept. 9 for the Zoom hearing and everyone is invited to attend at 13499 Still Pond Road."

 RIDGELY — On Monday, Ridgely commissioners and residents discussed potentially allowing chickens within town limits.Listed in Chapter 64-4 of the town's code, the breeding, feeding, pasturing and penning of chickens and multiple other animals is currently prohibited within the town. But after some discussion from town residents, rules regarding chickens could change.
According to town staff, the conversation has been ongoing through the past couple of months, but it gained traction after residents began preparing petitions and presentations on chickens.
Mason Sparks, a resident of the town, gave a presentation to the town on chickens at the commissioners' August meeting. At Monday's meeting, Sparks said that he knocked on 471 doors and received 178 responses from residents, 87.6% of whom were in favor of allowing chickens.

Meyer addressed some concerns he said he has heard about chickens.
"As far as noise, hens are no louder than barking dogs or children playing. As far smells, a small backyard coop that's kept clean would have minimal smell. It's no more disturbing than any other farm smells that town is currently surrounded by. I think the benefits outweigh any small disturbance that would cause to any neighbors around the town."
After hearing from residents, the commissioners voiced their opinions.
"It seems like the residents are definitely in favor," Commissioners Chad Leister said. "I know that I personally reached out to all our neighboring town councils and spoke to them, mainly just to see, some I guess bad feedback they would have for the chickens, and, as you know, there wasn't really a whole lot of it. So, I think I'm willing to be okay with it."
The commissioners made a motion to work on the legal wording of the town code to draft an ordinance to allow chickens within the town. The ordinance is expected to be presented at the next meeting.

title: Easton leans away from annexing new land in comprehensive plan update

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News

 EASTON — As planners draft Easton's new comprehensive plan, the town's direction on annexing new land is becoming clear: slow down.At a workshop Monday, the Easton Planning Commission chose to retain language in the comprehensive plan update that discourages new annexations in the next 10 years.
As recently as last year, Easton annexed around 17 acres of county land east of U.S. Route 50 between the Royal Farms and Unitarian Universalist Fellowship. It's expected to become an affordable housing project, though the developer will still need town approval on an application.
Town Council members have indicated concerns about annexing additional land into town, especially as Easton deals with the question of whether it's maxing out on residential growth.
The comprehensive plan, last updated in 2010, is undergoing revisions before potential council approval later this year or early next year. It outlines how the town aims to grow in the next decade, touching on areas such as annexation, population growth and traffic.
On Monday and at a workshop last month, commission and council members noted that there may be exceptions to the no-annexation rule.
"I would have a hard time with being absolute about annexation, saying that that's not happening," Ward 2 Councilmember Robert Rankin said on Aug. 25. "Because there may be exceptions."
The main exception to completely halting annexation seems to be Easton Point, the development project that seeks to revitalize Port Street and the area around the Tred Avon River. The effort hasn't significantly progressed in recent years, council members say.
Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry said at last month's meeting that Easton Point's redevelopment is "an enigma." She advocated that annexation of the county land in that area be excluded from any no-annexation directive in the new comprehensive plan.
"The Easton Point development project's been on the board for almost 20 years," Curry said. "We have to find a way to move that forward if we can."
Town leaders largely agreed that a project like Easton Point rises to the level of an "extraordinary" annexation that should be permitted under the comprehensive plan's guidance.
Still, the plan should emphasize that annexation generally is "not a priority for the town," said Planning Commission member Victoria McAndrews on Monday.
GROWTH RATE
Hesitation to approve future annexation requests stems, in part, from the town's growth. From 2000 to 2010, the town's population increased 36%, according to census data. In the next decade, growth slowed to 7%, bringing Easton's population from 15,945 to 17,101.
When commission and council members met for a joint workshop in August, the council maintained that the comprehensive plan should include a target growth rate for population. The 2010 version has a 1% annual growth rate, which for the most part hasn't been exceeded. Bumping it up to 1.75% was discussed.
Michael Ports, the commission's vice chair, said Monday that 1.75% "makes the most sense." But other commission members leaned toward a 1.14% annual growth rate, which is based off of historical trends.
Commission Chairperson Phil Toussaint agreed with the 1.14% rate, emphasizing that it needs to be at a mark so the Town Council feels comfortable approving the plan as a whole.
TRAFFIC
When housing projects come to the commission or Town Council for approval, they include traffic impact studies. Developers typically hire a traffic engineering firm to conduct the study of the development's potential impact on traffic backups.
Planning Commission members said moving forward, the comprehensive plan needs to demand more thorough traffic reviews. Klein said studies often choose a few intersections next to the project and ignore the town's main arteries, where traffic is already an issue.
Easton Planning and Zoning Director Miguel Salinas said the best way to expand the scope of a traffic impact study for a development is if town engineers or the State Highway Administration request a larger scope during meetings with the project's traffic engineer.
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said he wants to continue requiring developers' traffic studies to include a percent change in traffic based on if the development were to be built.
Toussaint said he wants the studies to include more consideration on the impact to pedestrians, not just vehicles. He added that studies should be framed around the town's ongoing Complete Streets study, which is assessing Easton's roads on a large scale.
"What we've received in the past as a traffic impact study is going to be worthless for us going forward," Toussaint said. "It's propaganda at this point, prepared by the applicant's engineers."

title: Dorchester council talks juvenile crime, other priorities with state legislators
author: Konner Metz
content:
Dorchester council talks juvenile crime, other priorities with state legislators

 September 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Dorchester 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Council members provided a number of requests to local legislators on Tuesday in advance of the 2026 General Assembly, including an ask to tighten up on juvenile crime.During an annual meeting outlining the county's goals for statewide legislation this winter, Eastern Shore delegates and senators weighed in on the logistics of potential bills the county would like to see offered.
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) acknowledged the request for more stringent laws on juvenile crime. She noted that she and others are looking to see what comes out of the state's juvenile reform commission, which was created last year.
"I hear you loud and clear and know that there's something needs to be done," Sample-Hughes said. "But I think we're in the trenches of trying to figure out what is in this task force."
Youth crime in Cambridge has raised concerns in recent weeks, especially from Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips. On the second day of school at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, two students were arrested after assaulting the school safety monitor.
Sample-Hughes noted that last winter, a failed piece of legislation would have increased the age minimum from 14 to 16 for a juvenile to be tried as an adult. County Council Vice President Mike Detmer said it should go the other way, if anything.
That legislation even being proposed last year is a sign that "the well's gonna be poisoned" for any commission or task force recommendations, Detmer said.
"This is not hypothetical. This is reality that unfolds weekly in our town," Detmer said. "And it's a hazard to people around and it's a hazard to them."
Council Member Ricky Travers said state youth justice laws are "setting up a whole group of juveniles for failure."
Meanwhile, Council President Lenny Pfeffer said the county's warden has raised concern about separation requirements between juvenile and adult inmates.
"Our facility, being limited on staff, and size and logistics, sometimes finds it difficult to house a juvenile," Pfeffer said. "We have to sometimes bring in additional personnel above the normal shift size."
Pfeffer said it's a "one size fits all" conundrum, where the rural and small Dorchester County can't as easily comply with state regulations.
For his part, Detmer said he's "increasingly concerned about the legislature's encroachment on local control," noting he doesn't think the Eastern Shore legislators are responsible.
"We need to have something where there can be more nuance with blanket laws," Detmer said.
WORKERS' COMP
Pfeffer said the county is bound by state law to pay out equal workers' compensations to all fire service volunteers, whether they perform on-duty or administrative roles. He asked if there's a way for state law to be adjusted so those working in purely administrative roles, and with less risk of workplace injury, could be classified differently.
Del. Christopher T. Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) addressed the council's request. He warned that a workers' comp bill won't be easy. He added that it's important the county doesn't get caught reducing workers' comp for someone who may switch between field service and office work.
"Don't get mixed up in these scenarios where you have an audit and/or you have a person that does clerical work on Monday through Wednesday, but then ends up on a fire call Thursday or Friday and then gets hurt," Adams said.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) asked council members to take a look at workers' compensation laws that other counties are bound by to see if there's something that could work.
Other potential legislation discussed by the County Council and state legislators on Tuesday included:
Outlawing the use of shoulders to pass vehicles in left-turn lanes. Dorchester County Sheriff's Office Sgt. Robbie Larimer said there's been accident concerns.Reducing or removing the requirements for the county to advertise leases in newspapers. Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he's tried to see through a bill on the matter multiple times, though it's never passed.

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge officials have created a document outlining the responsibilities of residents to help clarify what property owners must take care of versus what falls to the city, a merchant or a utility company.Officials decided to create this document because of increasing code enforcement issues within the past year that caused city staff to spend more of their time handing out citations and going to look at properties.
At a meeting in June, City Manager Glenn Steckman said Cambridge was stepping up its code enforcement as trash cans are increasingly left on the sidewalk, grass is going uncut and cars are parked in the wrong direction.
"There seems to be a lack of lawnmowers in our community because the grass and grass height has been an ongoing issue in the town, and we're having to send violation notices out," Steckman said.
Per the document released this month, property owners are responsible for the following:
Maintaining the weatherhead, the cap where the service line meets the building.Maintaining wiring from the weatherhead to the meter, and from the meter into the building.Maintaining and marking privately owned underground lines such as pet fences, sprinklers and outbuildings.Maintaining all piping from the outlet side of the gas meter through the building.Performing annual checks of gas line connections.Maintaining clean access points for plumbers.Maintaining the sewer service line from property line to building.Maintaining all plumbing within the building.Preventing unauthorized stormwater connections like sump pumps and downspouts.Maintaining sidewalks, driveways, aprons, sod, and ensuring they are safe for public use.Removing snow from sidewalks within 36 hours after snowfall.Trimming trees and shrubs so they don't obstruct sidewalks. Must have seven-foot clearance on sidewalks or 12-foot clearance on streets.Immediately removing animal excrement from sidewalks, streets, parks or other public places unless physically unable.Maintaining the water service line from the curb stop to the building.Maintaining plumbing inside meter pits and within the building.Installing and maintaining a Pressure Reducing Valve (PRV) if required.Keeping the water pit visible and maintaining plumbing inside it.Keeping weeds, grass, and vegetation under 6 inches.Keeping property free of litter, refuse, and unsightly growth.
The city is responsible for the following:
Maintaining, repairing, operating public sewer mains under streets and public areas.Repairing and maintaining curbs, gutters, streets.Maintaining water mains.Maintaining service line up to curb stop.If a water meter is in an outdoor pit the city owns and maintains the meter and the pit.
The utility companies are responsible for the following:
Maintaining meters and transformers on property that are part of the utility system.Servicing lines from pole to weatherhead.Maintaining all equipment and piping up to and including the gas meter.

 ST.MICHAELS — On Sept. 10, George Walish Jr. launched his campaign as a Democratic candidate for Maryland's 1st Congressional District.Walish, 75, is a St. Michaels resident and a former senior executive at BMW of North America. He briefly served as an elected commissioner for the Town of St. Michaels in 2008 and 2009.
Walish said he is running because he believes he could do a better job representing the Eastern Shore and responding to residents' needs than Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st). Harris has represented the district in Congress since 2010.

title: Chair of honor: Delaware Rotary honors POWs, MIA soldiers.
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Chair of honor: Delaware Rotary honors POWs, MIA soldiers.

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new display outside of city hall ensures that prisoners of war and service members still missing in action will never be forgotten in Newark, Delaware.The Newark Morning Rotary Club unveiled a POW/MIA Chair of Honor during a brief ceremony Thursday evening, on the eve of National POW/MIA Recognition Day.
"The Chair of Honor will surely stand as a testament to our commitment to remembering and respecting the courage and dedication of the brave individuals who we honor today," club president Jamie Zingaro said. "It also reminds us of the horrors of war and the tremendous impact war has on our families. As Rotarians, we recognize the importance of service above self, and this memorial will continue to remind us of the service and sacrifices so many have made to keep us free."
Hundreds of POW/MIA Chairs of Honor can be found in public spaces around the country, ranging from professional sports stadiums to city halls, and even the U.S. Capitol Building. The perpetually empty chair is meant to help people remember that even though the soldiers are not here, there's always a place for them.
Newark already has a Chair of Honor that is used at the annual Memorial Day ceremony and displayed inside city hall. However, the new one is suitable for outdoor display.
The chair was installed in an area of the city hall parking lot that also includes flagpoles and a plaque honoring city employees who served in the military. It is surrounded by stanchions topped with symbols representing each of the branches of the military, and a bronze plaque explains the purpose of the chair and includes the words "You are not forgotten."
With the blessing of city council, the Rotary Club funded the project and committed to maintaining the display in the future.
Rosely Robinson, who has helped install dozens of Chairs of Honor throughout Delaware and surrounding states, noted that since World War II, there are still 81,000 service members unaccounted for.
"Outside of their families and friends, they have nearly been forgotten," Robinson said. "This chair serves as a constant reminder of those still missing and that we have a place for them when they come home."
Of those missing, 121 are from Delaware.
"It doesn't sound like a big number, but 121 families, brothers, sisters, moms and dads are still waiting, and they should never be forgotten," Robinson said.
Ralph Galati, an Air Force captain whose plane was shot down over North Vietnam, was a prisoner of war for 14 months.
"It was not heroic. It was not brave," Galati said. "But it was performing one's duty, hopefully with dignity and to be able to return with honor."
He said he and his fellow prisoners showed their resolve through resistance by having church services, singing the national anthem and reciting the Pledge of Allegiance.
"All of them were forbidden to be discussed and performed during captivity," he said. "Yet they were the very things that mattered the most to us, so we proudly recited them, regardless of the punishment or consequences. And today, none of these are taken lightly by me. It could be a flag flying gently overhead, or a song before a baseball game or a great rendition of the national anthem, the impact is still the same."

 WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday warned Maryland officials not to award contracts based on sex and race in the reconstruction of Baltimore's Francis Scott Key Bridge."Any reliance on race- or sex-conscious factors in contracting decisions could introduce significant legal vulnerabilities and inefficiencies in the management of the project," Secretary of Transportation Sean Duffy said in a letter to Maryland Gov. Wes Moore on Friday.
The secretary criticized the project's work plan, arguing that Moore has "prioritized race and gender-based requirements ahead of project completion."
Democrats in the Maryland congressional delegation responded in a joint statement, noting the bridge project was approved by Congress.
"As we have with other major infrastructure disasters with nationwide implications, Congress came together on a bipartisan basis to provide the full resources necessary for reconstruction to ensure it can be rebuilt as quickly and efficiently as possible," the lawmakers said.
"The federal government's commitment to fund the rebuild is enacted into law, and the construction contract was awarded through a legal, competitive, transparent process," they added.
Moore did not address Duffy's comments about sex and race.
"We will continue to work with the Trump Administration to find ways to reduce costs and rebuild faster," Moore said in a statement. "The safety of the bridge and the sound stewardship of taxpayer dollars remain our top priority as we work to fully restore economic vitality — not only to the Port of Baltimore and the State of Maryland, but for the people across the country."
Along with concerns over hiring practices, Duffy questioned the reconstruction project's budget.
"DEI contracting practices and ballooning project costs are already threatening to delay this critical project," Duffy said. "We will leverage our oversight authorities to ensure this vital bridge is rebuilt the right way."
President Donald Trump last month said on social media he might have to "rethink" federal support for the Key Bridge. He called Baltimore "crime ridden" and "out of control" and has threatened to send federal troops into the city, as he has in Los Angeles, Washington and Memphis.
Trump's warning about the bridge funds followed Moore's invitation to Trump to visit Baltimore or "keep our name out of your mouth."
The bridge collapsed in March 2024 after it was struck by a ship. The demolition of the bridge began in July. Following reconstruction, the bridge is slated to open in the fall of 2028.

 EASTON — Beginning Monday, Easton council members will host ward-specific town halls in hopes of increasing transparency and engaging with constituents.Maureen Curry (Ward 1), Robert Rankin (Ward 2), David Montgomery (Ward 3) and the Rev. Elmer Davis (Ward 4) will each host town halls open to their constituents at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department in the coming weeks.
The town halls were mentioned during Easton's recent election, including by Don Abbatiello, now council president and then Ward 2 representative.
Abbatiello said he aims to attend all four town halls.
"We wanted to make sure that we left no stone unturned when it came to sharing information," Abbatiello said.
Rankin will kick off the meetings with Ward 2 residents on Monday. Montgomery will host Ward 3's discussion on Oct. 9. Davis will lead Ward 4's on Oct. 23, and Curry will wrap it up with Ward 1's meeting on Oct. 27. All four meetings will be held at the Easton fire hall from 7 to 8 p.m.
Abbatiello said the idea to host semi-regular ward town halls birthed from discussions on the campaign trail, with some residents feeling like they didn't have enough access to town information or couldn't attend town meetings, which are typically twice a month at 5:30 p.m.
The council president said the town's done a good job in improving its communication to residents since he joined the council in 2019, especially on its website and social media platforms. The new town halls are a continuation of that effort, he said.
Council members will provide brief presentations to residents at the meetings, updating them on recent projects in town and their respective wards. Then, the sessions will open up for feedback and questions from the public.
"We want residents to be informed and know what's going on," Rankin said. " ... The more we can hear from folks … that really helps us a lot."
Housing, growth and traffic are expected to be major points of discussion, council leaders said.
"The central topic, for me at least, will be growth," Montgomery said. "And I think that's a topic that concerns everybody of Ward 3 because of how residents have to tend to traffic."
Rankin said he expects his discussion to touch on recent development projects and the town's comprehensive plan, which is in the process of being updated for the first time since 2010 and will lay out a vision for the town's growth over the next decade.
Davis said that in addition to growth and development, he expects to field questions on the Easton Police Department and resident concerns about safety.
The Ward 4 representative highlighted the town halls as another avenue to be open with the public.
"Everybody can be included and get some questions answered," Davis said. "Our main goal is to show transparency to the community."

title: County weighs ICE Program: Officials seek details on 287(g) jail enforcement model before considering public comment and vote
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
County weighs ICE Program: Officials seek details on 287(g) jail enforcement model before considering public comment and vote

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 654
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County officials say they are seeking more information from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement about the county's eligibility for a 287(g) Jail Enforcement Model program.At an informal community forum Sept. 29 hosted by Eastern Shore Indivisible at the Kent Island branch of the Queen Anne's County Public Library, County Commissioner President Chris Corchiarino and Sheriff Gary Hofmann updated residents on the status of discussions with ICE.
Corchiarino said the county has not yet been told whether it qualifies for the Jail Enforcement Model, one of three agreements available under ICE's 287(g) program. He emphasized that no plans are in place.
"We're waiting to hear from federal officials," Corchiarino said. "We don't have clear details or expectations yet of what a memorandum of understanding would look like."
Program background
Under the Jail Enforcement Model, correctional officers can be deputized with limited federal authority to serve civil detainers within a county detention facility. Other models under 287(g) include the Warrant Service Officer and Task Force programs, though Corchiarino said Queen Anne's is not pursuing those.
On July 30, the county's Republican Central Committee hosted an informational meeting in Stevensville with James Brooks, community relations officer for ICE's Washington and Baltimore field offices. Following that session, Corchiarino said, residents asked county leaders to seek more information about the county's eligibility.
He noted that requirements for correctional facilities vary by jurisdiction in Maryland. In Queen Anne's County, the detention center falls under the authority of the county commissioners rather than law enforcement.
"If we find out we're not eligible, then it's a moot point," Corchiarino said. "If we are eligible, then we'll need to look at requirements and a cost analysis. Any decision would go through public comment and ultimately a commission vote."
There is no set timeline, he said, adding that even if ICE responds soon, the matter would take time before reaching an agenda.
Community questions and concerns
During the forum, some residents voiced concerns about immigration enforcement and civil rights. One man who identified himself as part of the Hispanic community said he had been detained twice "on the west side of the bridge" and carried laminated copies of his birth certificate out of fear.
"What's going to be done to ensure I keep my American rights … without being afraid of the lights in the rearview mirror?" he asked, drawing applause.
Hofmann said the sheriff's office does not have authority to serve civil detainers and in his 30 years could recall only one case involving an ICE civil detainer in the county. He stressed that the role of ICE is separate from the role of county commissioners or the sheriff's office.
"Regardless of origin, whether American or immigrant, there are bad people with warrants for crimes, and we are obligated to enforce the criminal law," Hofmann said.
He added that ICE falls under the umbrella of Homeland Security Investigations and that since 2010 the county sheriff's office has had a designated desk for Homeland Security agents, used in rare but valuable partnerships on cases involving fraud, child pornography and human trafficking.
"What I don't want to do is create fear amongst our community," Hofmann said. "We want people to get the services they need here in Queen Anne's County. We are genuinely here to take care of everyone fairly and equally."
Calls for transparency
Some residents said they want more public collaboration when federal topics arise.
"This affects everyone. It's not just Republicans or Democrats. We should be working together to protect our community," one Grasonville woman said.
A Centreville woman added that she wanted reassurance county law enforcement would remain lawful and not adopt questionable tactics she had heard about elsewhere.
Corchiarino said he considers public input an important factor in any decision.
"A room full of people, that's persuasive for me," he said.
Silvia Gonzalez Roman, co-founder of Eastern Shore Indivisible, said the group invited an ICE representative to the forum but did not receive a response.
"Building community with open dialogue is what it is all about," she said.

title: Workshops held during Oxford Commission Meeting
author: LILY TIERNEY ltierney@chespub.com

 Commissioners of Oxford held several work sessions during the town's Sept. 29 meeting. These included:Town electionsCommissioners discussed the possibility of creating a supplemental municipal voter list in addition to the county's list.
They plan to discuss the matter further at a workshop on Oct. 8 and are actively seeking the public's feedback.
Ethics ordinance recommendations from the Ethics CommissionCommissioners considered revising the ethics ordinance after the Ethics Commission said the current version is confusing from years of edits.
Additional proposals included adding an alternate member, staggering terms for continuity, and clarifying the distinction between the Ethics and Town commissions.
Members of the Ethics Commission suggested narrowing financial disclosure rules, which currently require candidates to report all global property and business interests, to instead focus on conflicts of interest within Maryland.
The Ethics Commission also discussed separate disclosure standards for elected officials, appointed members and staff, and agreed to add a campaign finance section requiring filings at candidacy, election and post-election.
The updates are slated for completion by February ahead of the next election cycle.
Economic development prioritiesThe Oxford Business Association pressed town leaders for clear economic development priorities to guide its work, particularly on tourism and use of accommodation tax revenues, now at historic lows.
Commissioners asked for detailed budgets and proof of return on investment before committing tax dollars, moving away from funding with "no strings attached."
The association's representative said they must consult members before releasing past financials. They agreed performance metrics, like website analytics, which are currently hindered by technical issues, will be needed once town priorities are defined.
Short-term rental permitting processCommissioners considered adopting a software called Granicus to crack down on unlicensed short-term rentals, estimating 35 to 44 units operate in town but only five hold permits.
The program, already in use by Talbot County, would cost Oxford $2,000 a year.
The software would also help enforce a proposed rule requiring license numbers in rental ads, which officials say are easier to track than actual bookings.
Breezeline franchise agreementCommissioners are reviewing their franchise agreement with Breezeline, weighing whether to stay with the old terms or adopt a new template that covers only cable.
The draft also drops the 2% public, educational and government funding, meaning the town would need to add a franchise fee of up to 5% to recoup costs.
Commissioners said they'll hold a public hearing, likely after the holidays, to gather resident feedback on service quality before entering negotiations.
Utility payment processingCommissioners are exploring new approaches to utilities and services, including an online portal for utility bill payments that would allow credit card use but carry a 1.5% to 3.5% transaction fee which will likely be passed on to residents rather than absorbed by the town.
An Automated Clearing House payment option through Shore United Bank is also being considered, with specific cost proposals to be discussed at a future meeting.
Electric fees paid by the townThe Electric Vehicle Institute has offered to replace the current chargers with faster, pay-as-you-go chargers that would eliminate the current expense of $600.
Commissioners will also separately review electricity costs tied to the watermen's boat slips, citing the town's commitment to its working waterfront.

title: Some thoughts on a US president from Maryland
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Some thoughts on a US president from Maryland

 October 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 736
 Words 

 Read News Document

 To date, no individual born or living in Maryland has been elected to serve as president of the United States.Ever since Gov. Wes Moore was elected in 2022, he has been viewed by many as a rising star in the Democratic Party.
Many of his admirers have even suggested he has potential to be the Democratic Party's 2028 candidate for president.
That is not surprising. Wes Moore is a charismatic, progressive and relatively young elected official at a time when both major political parties are struggling mightily with internal divides between longtime and elderly party leaders and emerging younger leaders.
Despite that political chatter, Moore has repeatedly said he will not run for president in 2028.
Instead, he has said he is eager and ready to run for reelection as governor for a second four-year term.
That said, if Wes Moore does have future national ambitions, they may ultimately be delayed or derailed by another charismatic Maryland Democratic elected official — U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen.
Van Hollen has had a long career in politics starting with elections to serve as a Democratic member in the Maryland House of Delegates and in the Maryland Senate.
He was elected to serve in the U.S. House of Representatives as the Democratic representative from Maryland's 8th Congressional District.
In 2016, he was elected to the United States Senate, re-elected to a second term in 2022, and is now the senior U.S. senator from Maryland.
Van Hollen has not said anything about if or when he may run for president, but his actions speak louder than silence on this matter.
Van Hollen has regularly and aggressively challenged a wide range of decisions and actions of the second Trump administration, including but not limited to federal government spending cuts, immigration deportments and closing or relocating federal agencies.
Van Hollen has opposed Trump administration efforts to detain and deport El Salvador native Kilmar Abrego Garcia, maintaining Garcia has been denied due process on these efforts.
In September, he was the keynote speaker at a Democratic Steak Fry in Polk County, Iowa.
Iowa is a longtime early testing ground on the popularity and viability of presidential candidates from both major parties.
Van Hollen has been a guest on Yahoo News, CBS News, CNN, NBC News and The Hill.
Between now and the next two election cycles, a lot can happen in the Maryland and national political arenas.
In Maryland, Wes Moore is widely expected to win a second term next year, but in today's volatile and unpredictable political environment, that is not a given.
Next year, Maryland's Republican voters may nominate a candidate that unites, energizes and mobilizes their base voters. Those voters combined with enough Democratic and unaffiliated voters, could result in Wes Moore losing next November. That is unlikely, but not impossible.
In 2014, Democratic candidate and former Lt. Gov. Anthony Brown was almost universally expected to be elected governor, but he lost in a historic upset to Larry Hogan.
Key elements of a winning political campaign always include messaging, money and meeting expectations.
In his upcoming reelection effort, Wes Moore will have no problem with messaging and raising campaign contributions.
He may find meeting or exceeding expectations to be a challenge.
His rising star status could be greatly diminished if, in a deep blue state, his reelection vote margin is significantly lower than his landslide win for the governorship the first time when he received 64.5 % of votes cast.
One unanswered question for Wes Moore and or Chris Van Hollen is if either would agree to be nominated as the Democratic vice-presidential nominee in 2028.
Historically, pursuing a nomination for the vice presidency is not something candidates publicly announce or overtly pursue. Instead, presidential nominees for both major parties announce their choice for a vice presidential running mate and their choice is ratified at their party's national convention.
That was the case when Richard Nixon chose Maryland's former governor Spiro Agnew as his running mate in 1968. Agnew served in that role until 1973 when he resigned in disgrace.
Serving as a vice president as a pathway to nomination and election as president has had mixed success. Only six have done so since 1948 — Harry Truman, Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, George H.W. Bush and Joseph Biden.
Ultimately, only time will tell if either Wes Moore or Chris Van Hollen will be the first Marylander in history to be nominated or serve as president of the United States or be the second Marylander in history to be nominated or serve as a U.S. vice president.

title: Ridgely responds to allegations made by ex-officers in lawsuit

 RIDGELY — The Town of Ridgely claims it acted lawfully when it disbanded its police force in 2024, according to a federal court filing made last week.Responding to a lawsuit filed by former Ridgely police officers in U.S. District Court in August, attorneys representing town commissioners and employees submitted a motion to dismiss claims made against the town by eight plaintiffs — former Police Chief Jeff Eckrich, six other officers and one civilian employee.
In the motion, submitted Friday, attorneys for the town argued Ridgely acted within its charter when eliminating the police department, a decision made for "legislative and budgetary" reasons, the motion states.
Plaintiffs alleged the town violated due process when it suspended and later laid off all members of the Ridgely Police Department last year amid a state investigation into Eckrich for suspected misconduct in office. The plaintiffs also allege the town committed civil conspiracy and defamation.
Officers were laid off effective July 1, 2024. Later that month, the Office of the State Prosecutor released a report finding "no sufficient evidence" of misconduct by Eckrich. Ridgely commissioners chose not to reinstate the department despite pleas from residents to do so.
After the state opened its investigation into Eckrich in March 2024, Ridgely entered into a temporary contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to provide police coverage in town, a contract that was then renewed and adjusted after the town opted to lay off the officers in April 2024.
The former officers alleged the town and Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker "orchestrated a coup" to disband the department. Attorneys for the town disputed that in their response Friday.
The town's "actions were lawful, discretionary, and justified by legitimate policy considerations," the defendants' argument, written by attorneys Kevin Karpinski and Bently Green Jr., reads.
Ridgely commissioners were made aware of the state's investigation "weeks after" it began, attorneys wrote.
"Once the OSP investigation concluded, the Town made a reasoned decision that reinstating the RPD was not feasible," the response reads.
Defendants represented by Karpinski and Green are: current Ridgely Commissioner John Hurley, former Commissioners John Buckle and Anthony Casey, three town employees, the Town of Ridgely and James Joles — a former Ridgely officer whose complaints about Eckrich fueled the state prosecutor's investigation.
Three other defendants — Baker, Chief Deputy Rodney Helmer and the State of Maryland — didn't file response motions by the Friday deadline, according to online federal court records.
Baker told The Star Democrat on Monday that he and Helmer are being represented by the Office of the Attorney General, declining to comment further. The attorney general's office, closed Monday, didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.
The initial lawsuit from August claimed Joles — an officer who resigned from the force in January 2024 — met with Baker, devising "a plan that would eliminate the RPD and allow Sheriff's Office to assume responsibility for law enforcement" in Ridgely.
No specific details or evidence substantiating the alleged meeting between Baker and Joles were provided in the plaintiffs' complaint, which was submitted by attorney Ray Shepard.
Joles, in an interview last month, denied claims made in the lawsuit, adding that he only met the sheriff once and exchanged "maybe a four-word conversation."
Judge Brendan A. Hurson, of the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, will review the town's motion for dismissal.

title: Aaron’s Place presents potential new location to Caroline County Commissioners
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Aaron’s Place presents potential new location to Caroline County Commissioners

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 433
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Cheryl Beulah, executive director of Aaron's Place, discussed the food pantry's potential new location with the Caroline County Commissioners on Tuesday.The proposed location on Meeting House Road will allow Aaron's Place to work in partnership with His Hope Ministries and the Chesapeake Culinary Center to provide a year-round homeless shelter and multiple different classes, additions and food storage locations, Beulah said.
Plans for the location have been in the works for the past two years while volunteers from Aaron's Place and His Hope Ministries have resolved issues with the Environmental Protection Agency resulting from a covenant on the property.
The EPA covenant came after the property was contaminated with volatile organic compounds in the 1980s, Beulah said at the meeting Tuesday. Extensive testing has been conducted over the years, with the contamination shrinking due to a large pumping and air system installed by the previous owner, Russel Metals.
The EPA covenant is restrictive, primarily concerning water usage, but the EPA has indicated that as long as the project does not break the wellhead and uses water according to county instructions, it can proceed. The EPA also said that if three negative VOC tests are obtained after the project is on the property, it would consider removing the covenant.
Beulah told the commissioners how great the location will be for the community after all renovations were completed.
"To take that big piece of building, that building and that property, clean it all up, fix it all up and have it as a resource center to serve the people in the community. All the agencies that can come together will come together under one roof, joining forces together, joining resources together, and providing us a significant services in our community," she said.
The commissioners asked Beulah and the group questions about what services will be included at the new location. The group responded with a full analysis of the building.
"So, it's three main components, three main partners. Aaron's Place, His Hope Ministry and the Food Aggregation, those are the three main ones," Beulah said.
The group said the project requires significant funding. They are forming a capital campaign committee and exploring various funding opportunities around the state, Beulah said, and wanted to make sure they had the commissioners' support for the project before proceeding.
While the commissioners did not suggest a certain amount of money to support the project, the commissioners all said they will support the project and provide any help they can offer.
"I think it's a very worthwhile project," Commissioners Vice President Larry Porter said. "I think if nothing else, it'll make that entrance to this town beautiful."
