title: Raskin speaks to Dems in Easton; weighs in on shutdown, '26 midterms
author: Konner Metz
content:
Raskin speaks to Dems in Easton; weighs in on shutdown, '26 midterms

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 701
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md.) visited Talbot County Democrats in Easton on Sunday, taking aim at President Donald Trump and the Republican Party.In a nearly 40-minute keynote speech during the Talbot County Democratic Forum's annual Kennedy-King Unity Dinner, Raskin went on energetic runs to engage the crowd, alternating between current issues such as immigration enforcement and Trump's ongoing battles with federal courts since taking office.
Local officials, including Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher, attended.
Raskin, who represents residents in Montgomery and Prince George's counties, hosted a town hall in Cambridge in March. He said he enjoys trips to the Eastern Shore, especially since he went to summer camp in Worton as a child.
"I come because I know you're the only Marylanders who don't have a Democratic member of Congress," Raskin told a packed crowd inside of Temple B'nai Israel on Sunday.
Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) is the representative for Eastern Shore residents.
Raskin also used the speech to tout some of his optimistic and broad opinions, such as granting Washington, D.C., and Puerto Rico statehood and abolishing the electoral college — a system he called "an accident waiting to happen every four years."
Raskin criticized Trump for imposing tariffs in a manner that the congressman said exceeds presidential power. He said Trump's actions are being rejected in district and appeals courts around the nation.
"The rule of law is holding, Donald Trump is losing until we get to just one court," Raskin said. "There's one court that has been packed and stacked and sliced and diced and gerrymandered to his advantage and to his liking, which is the Supreme Court."
After delivering the speech and accommodating a long line of local Democrats hoping to chat or take photos, Raskin weighed in on the ongoing government shutdown in an interview.
He said an agreement needs to be reached where people are not losing health care tax credits — the central issue driving the Senate's deadlock on an appropriations bill.
"I hope that our Republican colleagues will recognize that and come back to Washington and make a deal," Raskin said. "But right now it's just Democrats in Congress waiting for the Republicans to come back home to D.C."
Maryland Republicans in Congress have placed blame on Democrats, criticizing them for not OK'ing a continuing resolution to fund the government through Nov. 21. Harris said earlier this month that Sens. Chris Van Hollen and Angela Alsobrooks, both Democrats, are part of the problem.
"Because so many Marylanders are federal employees, I think that the two senators should realize that will harm a lot of Marylanders," Harris said.
TALK OF 2026
Sunday evening inside Temple B'nai Israel, early discussions on 2026 election strategy were held. Justin Butler, director of party affairs for the Maryland Democratic Party and a member of the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee, said the party needs to "get back to voters" and listen.
"Here in Maryland, we can't be out of touch," Butler said.
Raskin said the biggest challenge facing Democrats is the national redistricting fight. Republicans have led pushes to redraw maps in states such as Texas and Florida, while Democrats have countered in California and New York.
"They have proven themselves to be focused like a laser beam on gerrymandering us into oblivion," Raskin said. "We have to fight back at the state level wherever we can, and then we have to mobilize a huge popular movement to oppose that assault on democracy."
In Maryland, a state senator filed a bill to redraw the eight congressional districts— a proposal that would edit Harris' 1st District to remove Harford and Cecil counties and add part of Anne Arundel. Harris has said the proposal will lose in court, and "perhaps the courts will redraw a nonpartisan map" to flip seats for Republicans.
Locally, Butler told the crowd Sunday that a priority for Democrats going into 2026 should be winning more seats on the Talbot County Council. Currently, Lesher and Keasha Haythe are two Democrats to three Republicans on the body.
"We have a chance, next year, to fix that," Butler said. "To make sure that we have a majority on the County Council that's gonna be able to implement tolerance, compassion, unity and truly work for all citizens of Talbot County."

title: St. Vincent de Paul expands operations during a time of increasing need
author: Konner Metz
content:
St. Vincent de Paul expands operations during a time of increasing need

 October 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 572
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The completion of an expanded St. Vincent de Paul food pantry couldn't have come at a better time for Talbot County residents in need.John Plaskon, president of the Easton chapter of St. Vincent de Paul, said at a ribbon-cutting ceremony on Wednesday morning that Tuesdays and Saturdays — the pantry's distribution days — are becoming busier.
"There's more cars coming through lately than ever before," Plaskon said.
Volunteers for the nonprofit organization on Canvasback Drive will be better able to accommodate increased need thanks to a 2,560-square-foot expansion. Town, county and state officials joined St. Vincent de Paul to cut the ribbon Wednesday on a larger pantry, thrift store and advisory offices.
"We are a community of tremendous opportunity, and we're very thankful for what we have," Easton Mayor Megan Cook said. "But we're also a community of tremendous need. And the mission of St. Vincent de Paul really does help with that."
Plaskon said after the event that the expansion project, led by Willow Construction, cost nearly $1.4 million. Between funds from the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development and Talbot County Council, and gifts from local donors, that mark was fully funded.
County Council President Chuck Callahan said acts of philanthropy in the county impress him, including St. Vincent de Paul's work. Callahan chairs the board of the Neighborhood Service Center, a nonprofit on the other side of town.
"It's a big effort on all of us, and that's really what this community is all about," Callahan said.
The relocated food pantry allows volunteers more space to operate on busy pickup days. A refrigerator and freezer were added to the end of the food pantry, along with other new equipment.
St. Vincent de Paul broke ground on the expansion in August 2024. It was a three-phase endeavor that Plaskon said "flowed pretty smoothly" over the last year and change.
The nonprofit's new thrift store has raked in more money, which goes toward the food pantry and advisory offices. Plaskon said weekly returns have risen 35% to around $9,000 a week.
Plaskon recently took over as president of the organization, which is made up of over 300 volunteers and has no paid employees. On Wednesday, he presented a proclamation honoring former president Alex Handy, who served in the role for 16 years.
Handy had similar praise for his successor.
"I am so grateful for having John step forward in that meeting and ever since, taking over this project," Handy said. "He has done a miracle amount of work here, and I can't thank him enough for steering us and steering this project to a wonderful culmination today."
Just before the ribbon was cut, the Rev. James Nash, pastor of Sts. Peter & Paul Church in Easton, told St. Vincent de Paul volunteers just how important they are to the community.
"A lot of the people on the day of food pickup, they will come here an hour and a half early or two hours early, just to sit," Nash said. "So you not only provide food. ... You give people the chance to just shut down for an hour or an hour or 20 minutes. ... And you offer them a place to come that's safe, where they feel heard, where they feel cared about."
Nash said he's seen other St. Vincent de Paul chapters during his career. The Easton one stands out.
"Nothing like this, nothing like this," Nash said of other chapters. "You all have a lot to be proud of."

Talbot OKs bill to begin accepting cannabis funds

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council last week approved a bill allowing it to accept money from a statewide cannabis reinvestment fund, which currently has around $730,000 allocated for the county.Maryland's Cannabis Reform Act in 2023 created a Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund, designed to allocate 35% of the collected taxes from cannabis sales back into communities most affected by the disproportionate enforcement of previous cannabis laws.
County Attorney Patrick Thomas said at the council's meeting on Oct. 14 that the county can't use the money until it passed the bill, which effectively establishes Talbot's own reinvestment fund and a commission to administer the funds. Talbot Family Network, the board responsible for the county's youth and family services, will serve as the commission.
After the public hearing yielded no comments, the council moved the bill to third reading and approved it 4-0. Council member Lynn Mielke abstained.
The county must use the money for community-based initiatives, as defined by state law, such as after-school, behavioral health, housing or homeless prevention programs.

title: Easton police seek permits for future protests
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton police seek permits for future protests

 October 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — While police said Saturday's No Kings protest in Easton remained civil, they're asking the town to consider requiring public assembly permits for similar future protests.Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey raised the concern at a Town Council meeting Monday. He said Saturday's protest — during which hundreds lined sidewalks on Dover Road — was a challenge for police.
"As with any big event, my concern with police coverage is the unexpected, the person who does not appreciate that (protest)," Lowrey said. "We've seen it all across our country. It's a little frustrating when these events are not going through the public assembly event process, to allow us to plan."
Easton's No Kings rally was just one of thousands nationwide, where people gathered in opposition of the Trump administration. Lowrey said one counter-protester remained civil, though police did get a call from a business concerned about people crowding parking lots.
Talbot County Democratic Central Committee Chair Phil Jackson said in an interview that the committee and the Talbot County Democratic Forum were in "regular contact" with the mayor and police in advance of Saturday's rally to ensure safety.
Also on Saturday in Easton, police and emergency officials held a mass casualty simulation, designed to train first responders in an active shooter scenario. The training ran from 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. at the Temple B'nai Israel and surrounding areas.
Lowrey said the Easton Police Department had a "great deal of resources committed" to that simulation. Combined with the large protest, the agency's patrol division was "essentially wiped out."
"We were able to respond to a call here or there, but if something happened, at that point, it comes at the expense of all the other citizens in the town because we have no officers available to respond to other emergencies," he said.
Saturday's No Kings protest didn't obtain a public assembly permit, nor did the first No Kings gathering in June. Lowrey said the town should look at rewording its public assembly permit rules to explicitly require such protests obtain a permit beforehand.
The police chief said the permits allow the department to adequately staff both the event and day-of calls or emergencies.
According to town code, permits must be obtained for "any open air public meeting, rally, conference, assembly or similar gathering upon any public property." The word "protest" is not included in the code.
Permit applications cost $100, though some events require additional costs depending on the equipment and police officers needed. Permits are first reviewed by police and then either approved or denied by the Town Council. Rarely does the council reject a permit request after a positive police recommendation, though some requests in the past have garnered debate and slim majorities, such as the Delmarva Pride Festival.
Jackson noted that the No Kings Day protests are nationally coordinated and then organized at a local level in the days and weeks leading up. Local organizers, he said, are open to following any new or adjusted permit requirements brought by the town.
"We are very interested in ensuring that these events comply with local policy," Jackson said. "Should the Town of Easton move forward with changes to their public gathering permits, we will look to comply with those and follow the process."
Lowrey added that Easton police typically provide as much coverage as possible for public assemblies at no cost by using on-duty officers. Feedback from Saturday, he said, was that officers were helpful. But he hopes the department can better prepare for future protests.
"But when you have 800 to 1,200 people lining streets and stuff, things can go wrong very quickly," he said. "And that's always my biggest fear. It takes a car driving through 30 people, and we have a mass casualty, actually, incident, and not an exercise."
